Africa News


September 1, 1996


Liberia;
UN To Maintain Small Observer Team in Liberia


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

United Nations - The Security Council has voted unanimously extend for three months the mandate of the small UN Observer Mission in Liberia. Resolution 1071 was adopted August 30.

The Security Council,

Recalling all its previous resolutions concerning the situation in Liberia, in particular resolution 1059 (1996) of 31 May 1996,

Having considered the report of the Secretary-General dated 22 August 1996 (S/1996/684) on the United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL),

Noting the letter of 21 August 1996 to the President of the Security Council containing the Final Communique of the Heads of state and government of the Economic Community of West Africa (ECOWAS) Committee of Nine of Liberia, held at Abuja on 17 August 1996 (S/1996/679),

Welcoming the increasing restoration of Monrovia as a safe haven,

Emphasizing once again that the people of Liberia and their leaders bear the ultimate responsibility for achieving peace and national reconciliation,

Recognizing the positive role of ECOWAS in its efforts to restore peace, security and stability in Liberia,

Expressing its appreciation to those African States contributing troops to the ECOWAS Monitoring Group (ECOMOG),

Commending also those member states that have supported the peace process, UNOMIL, and ECOMOG, including through contributions to the United Nations trust fund for Liberia,

Stressing also that the continued presence of UNOMIL in Liberia is predicated on the presence of ECOMOG and its commitment to ensure the safety of UNOMIL and emphasizing the need for enhanced coordination between UNOMIL and ECOMOG,

1. Welcomes the report of the Secretary-General dated 22 August 1996;

2. Decides to extend the mandate of UNOMIL until 30 November 1996;

3. Welcomes the agreement of ECOWAS in Abuja on 17 August 1996, which extended the 1995 Abuja agreement until 15 June 1997, established a timetable for implementation of the agreement, adopted a mechanism to verify compliance by the faction leaders with the agreement, and proposed possible measures against the factions in the event of noncompliance;

4. Calls upon the Liberian factions to implement fully and expeditiously all the agreements and commitments they have entered into;

5. Requests the Secretary-General to report to the Security Council by 15 October 1996 with proposals for assistance which UNOMIL or other United Nations agencies could provide in support of the Liberian peace process, including support for the election process, disarmament, demobilization, and verification of compliance by the factions;

6. Further decides to maintain UNOMIL deployments at an appropriate level as recommended in the report of the secretary-general and requests that the secretary-general take into account the need to ensure the security of UNOMIL personnel and advise the council of any planned further deployments;

7. Stresses that the continued support of the international community for the peace process in Liberia, including the participation of UNOMIL, is contingent on the Liberian factions' demonstrating their commitment to resolve their differences peacefully and to achieve national reconciliation in accordance with the agreement reached in Abuja on 17 August 1996;

8. Condemns all attacks against and intimidation of personnel of ECOMOG, UNOMIL, and the international organizations and agencies delivering humanitarian assistance as well as the looting of their equipment, supplies, and personal property, calls upon the leaders of the factions to ensure the immediate return of looted property, and requests the secretary-general to include in the report referred to in paragraph 5 above information on how much of the stolen property has been returned;

9. Condemns the practice of some factions of recruiting, training, and deploying children for combat, and requests the secretary-general to include in the report referred to in paragraph 5 above details on this inhumane and abhorrent practice;

10. Demands once more that the factions and their leaders strictly respect the status of the personnel of ECOMOG, UNOMIL and international organizations and agencies, including humanitarian assistance workers, and further demands that these factions facilitate the freedom of movement of UNOMIL and the delivery of humanitarian assistance and that they strictly abide by the relevant principles and rules of international humanitarian law;

11. Stresses the importance of respect for human rights in Liberia and also the human rights aspect of UNOMIL's mandate;

12. Stresses the obligation of all States to comply strictly with the embargo on all deliveries of weapons and military equipment to Liberia imposed by resolution 788 (1992) of 19 November 1992, to take all actions necessary to ensure strict implementation of the embargo, and to bring all instances of violations of the embargo before the Committee established pursuant to resolution 985 (1995) of 13 April 1995;

13. Urges all States to provide financial, logistical and other assistance in support of ECOMOG to assist it to carry out its mandate;

14. Urges all States to contribute to the United Nations trust fund for Liberia;

15. Stresses the importance of close contacts and enhanced coordination between UNOMIL and ECOMOG in their operational activities at all levels and calls on ECOMOG, in accordance with the agreement regarding the respective roles and responsibilities of UNOMIL and ECOMOG in the implementation of the Cotonou agreement (S/26272) and with the UNOMIL concept of operations, to provide security for UNOMIL;

16. Requests the Secretary-General to continue to keep the Security Council closely informed of the situation in Liberia;

17. Decides to remain seized of the matter.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

2 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 1, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia Says Has Enough Food In Stock


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission yesterday ordered the halting of raising aid underway in some localities to victims of overflowing Awash River as the government has the capacity to deal with the flood crisis.

Commissioner Simon Mechal said, in a statement he gave to newsmen, the government has so far provided 8,445 quintals of food and 1,000 blankets as well as house utensils to flood victims encamped at Boka, Didmtu, Choka, Alemtena and Gefersa in Wonji and Koka as well as Methara, Amibara, Dubit, Tefki, Dulecha and Buremudaitu.

He said the Commission's central warehouses in Nazareth, combolacha and Dire Dawa are stocked with 702,614 quintals of wheat, biscuit and enriched FAFA flour. 

Compared to the small amount of emergency relief distributed so far, the food reserve is enough even for other purpose, he added.

Ato Simon said the food was reserved to give prompt response to emergency situations anticipated particularly for this year.

"Even if deemed necessary, we can borrow food from the national food security reserve administration, but the situation on hand do not push us to go that far," he said.

the government has made no appeal for aid to the Awash River flood crisis, although the cost of the damage done to both human and property could be no means be considered low, Ato Simon said.

He added eventhough philanthropists and aid agencies have volunteered to render assistance, the government did not accept the offer as the situation had not gone out of its control.

Unless the government appeals for aid attempts being made in Methara, Wonji and Nazareth to raise assistance to flood victims is illegal, the commissioner said.

Ato Simon said more than 131,000 sacks were also sent to Wonji, Nazareth and Awassa for the reinforcement of flood protection and bunkers.

He said a committee comprising different offices in the Middle and Lower Awash Basin was set to carry out disaster prevention activities.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


3 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 1, 1996


Ethiopia;
Government Acts to Fight Flooding


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission, DPPC said here yesterday that the Federal Government has swiftly acted to prevent the dangers of flooding resulting from the overflowing Awash River and its tributaries.

The DPPC issued a statement late yesterday evening accentuating the major and successful activities carried out by the government with utmost emphasis on saving the life of fellow citizens in flood prone areas of Oromiya, Afar, Amhara and South Ethiopia regional states.

In order to achieve the main objective of saving life by primarily preventing the danger, the government took urgent measure of setting up committees at the national level, the statement said and mentioned the different tasks performed by the committees that included the building of dikes, the transportation of people from where the threat is imminent to safe areas, and the apportioning of food and clothings to the displaced.

Intensified efforts were also made to prevent the natural disaster from damaging the Koka and Melkassa electric power stations and areas of agricultural development the DPPC emphasized and brought to memory that the inundation caused damage to the agricultural in Upper and Lower Awash of Oromiya and in peasant associations enroute the Awash Basin. 

The DPPC in its statement recalled that there was damage on the sugar cane plantation of the Metahara Sugar Factory and workers' residence but said the factory remained unaffected by the floods. Some farm lands in Metahara, Tibilla and Nura Era areas of the Upper Awash from which 40,000 people most of whom were workers of the Metahara Sugar Factory had been displaced were flooded, it added.

According to their statement except for some areas engulfed by floods, no danger of inundation has occurred so far in Afar Regional State it said. Adding about 10,000 persons were moved to highland areas as a precaution.

The necessary preparation is being made by the Amhara Regional State to prevent the possible danger of displacement that may result from the overflow of the great Tanna Lake, the commission indicated adding similar efforts are being made to halt the threat to life and property of the increasing volume of the Awassa Lake.

The commission also indicated that there is enough stock of food grain in its stores in Nazareth, Kombolcha, and Dire Dawa towns in case of the need for emergency assistance.

The statement stressed that the government has all the capacity to withstand the danger of flooding without additional assistance from within or from without adding it does never recognize or accept any assistance collected so far or aid to be solicited in the name of the flood affected compatriots.

The commission thanked all governmental and non-governmental organizations which responded on time to its urgent call.

Meanwhile, medical equipment and drugs have been dispatched to control possible outbreak of malaria and water-borne diseases in areas recently flooded by the Awash River, the Minister of Health said.

Dr. Adem Ibrahim, told journalists that health staff have been sent to Methara, Ayssaita Dubti, Gewane, Amibara, Nazareth, Fogera and other towns to assist local health professionals there in anticipation of the out break.

He added that victims of the recent floodings by the Awash River now sheltered in Gefersa, Mekonnen Boku, Alemtena, Chuka and Didimtu towns are getting sufficient medical care.

A technical team composed of sanitarians has been sent to several areas affected by the flooding to prevent possible outbreak of water-borne diseases, Dr. Adem said.

Meanwhile, more dikes have been built to protect Dubti town and the Tendaho Cotton Plantation from an eminent flooding by the Awash River, the zonal Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Committee said.

Ato Dagne Mesgana, member of the committee, said a total of 20 kms. dikes have been built, and the heights of bunkers was raised by 1.5 metres.

Workers of the plantation are working day and night in an effort to protect the plantation from the flooding, he added.

In another development, about 2,700 of the people encircled by over flooding Awash River in three districts of West Showa Zone were mover to the Tefki temporary shelter, the zonal administration head reported.

The head, Ato Ketema Weyesa, said the flood victims were evacuated from Alemgena, Ilu and Addis Alem districts over the past week. Members of the Defence Force and the Oromiya Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Bureau have played a significant role in evacuating the people.

The head said 361 quintals of food grain, 1,000 blankets and canned food were apportioned among the victims.

He said five sub-committees were set up to help and rehabilitate people displaced by flood.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

4 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 2, 1996


Business;
Pilots Warn Of Disaster


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Lusaka - President of the Zambia Air Lines Pilots Association (ZALPA), Captain Derrick Luembe, has supported the call by South African pilots for African governments to improve air-traffic management over their air spaces.

According to yesterday's issue of the South African Sunday Times , the Airlines Pilots' Association of South Africa (ALPA-SA) president, Captain Tony Van Heerden, warned that the lack of adequate radar and air-traffic control over Africa could lead to mid-air collisions.

Captain Van Heerden's warning comes days after a South African aviation magazine reported a recent near miss in which three aircraft, with cruising speeds of 1,600 km per hour, passed within a few hundred metres of each other.

"There is inadequate air-traffic control over Africa," Captain Luembe said in an interview yesterday. 

"The only reason there hasn't been a mid-air collision so far is because of the pilots' professionalism. They know the deficiencies and they tend to be more careful."

According to Captain Luembe, most navigation beacons in Africa, especially the region north of Zimbabwe, are out of service and instrument landing systems often do not work.

"Near misses between airliners are the order of the day and the growing traffic over Africa is increasing the risk as the broadcast frequency is being over-loaded," Captain Luembe said.

He was supported by another pilot, Alfred Mwenda, who said the only reason why a major disaster has been averted thus far is the International Air Transport Association (IATA) frequency known in airline parlance as "126 decimal 9".

"Pilots are now relying on the IATA frequency, 126 decimal 9, to maintain separation," Mwenda claimed, explaining: "It (the frequency) has become more or less the de facto controlling frequency in Africa. Pilots use this frequency for collision avoidance and safe aircraft separation."

A Zambian Express Airways pilot, who however declined to be named, said another problem is "under- trained, overworked and demoralised air-traffic controllers using dangerously obsolete and poorly maintained equipment".

ALPA-SA has refused to name the countries most at fault, but it has said that, with the exception of Egypt and Morocco, all flight information regions north of Namibia, Botswana and Zimbabwe, as well as east of South Africa as far as Perth airspace, are "critically deficient".

"There is little or no radar or Very High Frequency radio coverage over Africa north of Zimbabwe" Captain Van Heerden is quoted as saying, adding: " Most of the continent is dangerously lacking in anything approaching the definition of reasonable in terms of aviation aids. The problem can no longer be tolerated as it is a threat to the pilots and their passengers lives."

Captain Van Heerden indicated that if this situation continues, South African pilots might consider re-routing flights between Europe and South Africa "along the sanction-era route around the bulge of Africa".

"Near misses between airliners are occuring with monotonous regularity and the growing traffic over Africa is increasing the risk," Captain Van Herdeen said.

South African Airways (SAA) executive manager for flight operations, Captain Peter Cooke, is quoted as having confirmed this week that near misses were being recorded and warned that his airline might consider re-routing.

"Changes have to take place or we may have to consider re-routing around the bulge of Africa again," he said, advising: "Overflying airlines need to get together to form a united front against deficient African countries."

Three years ago, the Zambian government with assistance from the Japanese government, installed a radar system at the Lusaka International Airport but it is yet to be commissioned because the air traffic controllers are allegedly still under training.

"By the time it (the radar system) becomes operational, it will be obsolete and the whole purpose of installing it would have been defeated," Captain Luembe observed.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

5 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe's Civil Service Chief Asked To Resign as Strike Drags On


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The chairman of Zimbabwe's public service commission, Mariyawanda Nzuwah, accused of incompetence in dealing with the ongoing civil servants strike, has been called upon to resign.

Making the call, the affirmative action group (AAG) president, Philip Chiyangwa, said in a statement Tuesday his organisation was concerned by the apparent lack of "both competence and commitment to the protection of government credibility displayed by the PSC chairman, Nzuwah, in his handling of the current dispute."

The salaries dispute has cost the government millions of dollars through lost revenue. 

The civil servants went on strike more than two weeks ago, demanding salary increments of up to 60 percent.

Zimbabwean economists estimate the strike had cost the government over zd 1 billion (100 million U.S. dollars) in lost revenue, mainly through uncollected taxes, as well as customs and excise duties.

Chiyangwa said the dismissal of Nzuwah and officials at the PSC would help government "arrest the vast economic costs and human suffering resulting from the strike and avoid a recurrence."

"The AAG deplores the arrogant adherence to legalistic smokescreens that the public service commission has displayed as its only response to the expressions of genuine grievances by its employees," he said.

Chiyangwa urged striking civil servants to immediately suspend their action and resume work as the costs and burdens of the strike were being disproportionately borne by the black people.

"The AAG urges and requests the government to immediately extend to its employees an understanding that it will resume negotiations over disputed matters in good faith, and that there will be no victimization by way of either dismissal or other disciplinary action against strikers, " he said.

Meanwhile, the cabinet was on Tuesday morning expected to decide whether or not to rescind a decision to fire an estimated 7,000 workers who ignored an earlier order to return to work.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 3, 1996


South Africa;
Mandela-Machel Romance Confirmed and Welcomed


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - The African romance of the year - between President Nelson Mandela of South Africa and Graca Machel, widow of former Mozambican President Samora Machel -- has been confirmed.

A spokesman for the South African leader has revealed that President Mandela is in love with Mrs. Machel. 

Asked to comment on weekend reports that there was a relationship between the two, presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana said: "All I can say is the story is not untrue, but I am not aware of any marriage plans."

He added that the couple had confirmed their relationship, and would spend as much time as possible together.

The weekend reports quoted sources close to President Mandela as saying that, after months of speculation, it could now be confirmed that he and Graca Machel were involved in a steady relationship and were ready to go public.

They do not intend to marry, the reports add, but Mrs. Machel will spend two weeks of every month with Mandela at his home in Johannesburg.

Reports of a romance began early last year, and they have since been seen together during trips to Paris and Harare. Speculation was fuelled two weeks ago, when President Mandela was seen kissing Mrs. Machel at the wedding of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe.

Mozambican leaders and Machel's family elders have given their blessing to the relationship, and here in South Africa public figures, political leaders and the public have generally come out in favour of the news of President Mandela's romance.

The 78-year-old South African leader, whose marriage to Winnie Mandela began deteriorating soon after his release from prison in early 1990, was divorced earlier this year.

Mrs. Machel's late husband Samora Machel was killed in a plane crash in October 1986.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 3, 1996


Business;
South Africa in Multi-Million-Dollar Airports Expansion


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa plans to launch a 1.3- billion-U. S.-dollar expansion programme at its three international and six national airports between now and the turn of the century.

In its annual report tabled in parliament in Cape town, the Airports Company said that, compared with capital expenditure of about 22 million dollars in the past year, it would have to accelerate its capital development programme to around 300 million dollars per annum in the next four years. 

A major element of this expansion would be the preparation of Cape town's air facilities for the possible hosting of the Olympic Games in 2004.

"If South Africa wins its bid to host the 2004 Olympic Games," the report said, "the effect on Cape Town International Airport will be dramatic. It will bring forward by ten years the anticipated traffic flow. In other words, in less than ten years Cape Town International will have to develop facilities to handle at least 200 percent more passengers than it is managing today."

According to the report, Johannesburg International Airport is to be vastly extended, while Durban International Airport will be doubled in size.

Developments planned for 1996 include additional parking and retail facilities at Johannesburg, a major freight park at Cape Town, a large industrial site for long-term future development at Durban, and a terminus upgrade at East London.

In addition, sites for both hotels and service stations are being identified at each of country's nine international and national airports.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


8 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Tanzania;
Tanzania To Privatize Over 100 Firms


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - Tanzania has earmarked 128 state owned firms for privatization as part of its economic reforms, according to reports reaching here Tuesday.

Thirty-one of the firms will be sold by the end of September, increasing to 78 by the end of 1996. 

The former socialist-oriented east African country is also scheduled to open a stock exchange by the end of September, the reports added.

Tanzania embarked on privatization in 1993 as part of western backed economic reforms, but critics say progress has been too slow and dogged by corruption.

Meanwhile, petrol and diesel fuel prices in Tanzania were increased by up to 4.35 percent at the weekend. The Tanzanian Petroleum Development Corporation says that this increase reflects higher world oil prices.

Premium petrol now costs 360 shillings (58 U.S. cents) a litre - up from 345 shillings. Diesel costs 285 shillings (46 cents) up from 276 shillings.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

9 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Business;
Anglo-American Rejects Zambian Mines Privatization Proposal


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Anglo-American Corporation (AAC), which is bidding to invest into Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM), under the company's proposed privatization programme, has rejected recommendations by consultants to sell the company's power generating units as separate units.

The latest issue of Business Line, a journal of the Zambia Association of Chambers of Commerce and Industry (ZACCI) quoted ACC officials as saying that such an arrangement would make mining more expensive due to possible high electricity tariffs.

The corporation has instead proposed to undertake its own independent study of how best to harmonize the investment programme in the industry to minimize operational costs by private investors. 

The Zambian government recently approved recommendations by Merchant Bank N. M Rothchild which suggested that ZCCM power-generating units should be sold separately from the mining divisions.

ACC has offered to lead a consortium of foreign investors in the 600- million- dollar copper-mining project at the Konkola Mine Deep in the Northern Copperbelt region.

ACC chairman Julian Thompson was quoted as saying that offering ZCCM's electricity companies to separate investors would cause other mine operators to pay dearly for the power.

Apart from copper-mining, ZCCM also operates power-generation units under the Zambia Power Company (ZPC), a subsidiary responsible for supplying power to the various mining divisions.

Two years ago, government rejected a similar report by other international consultants who had recommended to sell ZCM in separate units. It has since set up an inter-sectoral committee comprising government and mine officials to liaise with foreign experts on the best mode of undertaking the company's privatization process.

The Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government of President Frederick Chiluba has said that it intended to fully privatize the mining industry, the country's major foreign exchange earner, by 1998.

ZCCM officials have over the recent past reported operational problems, caused mainly by obsolete equipment and inadequate capitalization which have led to a slump in copper production.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


10 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia Achieves Record Coffee Export


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopia exported a record 102,000 tons of coffee during the 1995-96 fiscal year ending June, earning the country 279.5 million U.S. dollars, the ministry of trade said at the weekend. But the amount was some 30 million dollars less than what the crop earned the previous year, when 30,000 tons more of the green beans were sold, Tesfaye Biftu, Minister in charge of trade and finance, said. 

Biftu was speaking here, during the annual coffee exporters' day at which private companies and the government agency that contributed to the record export figure were honored.

But as the decline in the world coffee price is expected to continue next year, Ethiopia hopes to earn close to 240 million dollars from an envisaged export of 108,000 tons of coffee in the 1996-97 farming season.

The minister exhorted coffee exporters to encourage the use of modern cleaning and processing machines to maintain the quality of Ethiopian export coffee.

He said the government is giving due attention for export promotion next year to earn more hard currency from coffee, hides and skins, oil seeds, textiles and garments and fresh flowers.

Although coffee accounts for 60 percent for Ethiopia's annual foreign currency earnings, about two-thirds of the green beans the country produces are consumed locally.

Its total production in 1995-96 was an all-time high of 300,000 tons.

Officials attribute the high production to the free market policies introduced five years allowing coffee farmers to sell their beans in the open market, instead of going through the state produce marketing board set up by the Marxist regime which was ousted from power 1991.

Ethiopia is also among the highest per head consumers of coffee in the world.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 3, 1996


United States and Africa;
Farrakhan Wants To Create A Third Political Force


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - The leader of the Nation of Islam, Louis Farrakhan, has said he wants to create a third political force to help African Americans and other minorities in the United States become more active in politics, particularly during elections.

Farrakhan, an African American, told reporters Monday in Tripoli that the force would not be a political party but one designed to help influence the direction of U.S. policy on Africa and the rest of Islamic world.

"Black people will, sooner or later, be entitled to have their say in United States policy," he said. 

The U.S. government, he said, was frightened by the increasing political and financial clout of African Americans.

Farrakhan was in Tripoli to attend the 27th anniversary of the Libyan revolution which brought Col. Moammar Kadhafi to power. The ceremony, whose highlight was the launching of the second stage of Libya 's artificial river, was attended by five other African heads of states.

He said that increasingly, over the past 30 years, there were businessmen and wealthy persons in the African American community.

"There are also more black politicians in the government than before," he added.

But, he said, since most minorities usually vote democrat, President Bill Clinton, the Democratic nominee for the November presidential elections, should take this fact into consideration in shaping his policies.

Farrakhan said that by the end of September, he would organize a rally and focus on the role African Americans, Asians and poor whites should play during the elections.

Questioned on what should be done to lift the blockades against Islamic countries such as Libya, Iraq, Iran and Sudan, he said that the Arabs would first have to end their division.

Except for Cuba, he said, all countries targeted by the U.S. were Muslim ones. That, he said, reflected United States fear of Islam.

Ample evidence of this existed in a book written by former U.S. President Richard Nixon, Farrakhan said. He cited Nixon's assertion that the Western world was more endangered by Islam than by Communism.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


United States and Africa;
Iraq Seeks Support From Non-Aligned States


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria - Iraqi Information Minister, Ghani Abdul Ghafour, called Tuesday for international condemnation of the latest military attack by the United States against his country.

Ghafour, who is attending the Fifth Information Ministers Conference of the 113-nation Non-Aligned Movement, criticized what he called "American military aggression and hegemony."

He urged the conference, in the Nigerian capital Abuja, to condemn in its communique the U.S. action which he said had resulted in unspecified " civilian casualties." 

United States warships and airplanes fired 27 cruise missiles against Iraqi targets Tuesday, in retaliation for Baghdad's attack on Kurds in northern Iraq. Washington said that Sadam Hussein's attack against the Kurds was a violation of U.N. resolutions imposed after Iraq's defeat, by a U.S.-led coalition force, in the 1991 Gulf War.

But Ghafour said the U.S. bombing Tuesday violated the territorial integrity of Iraq and respect for human rights which is often cited by Washington as the basic measure of what is civilized behavior by governments.

"Where are the human rights when American planes are bombing Iraqi children, women and residential areas?, he asked.

Ghafour said Iraq would continue to resist what he called the "American aggression and colonialism."

The attack on Iraq was the third since the end of the Gulf war, sparked by Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait.

Declaring the conference open earlier, Nigerian head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha, urged the non-aligned countries to close ranks and reinforce their bonds of cooperation at all levels to counter the negative portrayal of developing nations by western media.

"We should give impetus to the demand for a more equitable world information order," Abacha.

The meeting, focusing on the revitalization of NAM information and communication agencies, ends Friday.

Abacha told the participants to intensify research into information technology to redress the "disequilibrium in the world information order."

Represented by his deputy Lt. Gen. Oladipo Diya, Abacha said the Non- Aligned Movement, or NAM, should strengthen South-South cooperation at different international organizations and encourage effective media networking for sustainable development.

Part of the challenges faced by member countries, he said, were the enormous cost and rapid changes in information technologies of the third world being created by the western media.

Despite the obvious constraints, Abacha said developing countries should no longer be mere observers but active participants in efforts, "at correcting the distorted picture...being created by the western media."

He urged the 80 delegations, including 27 information ministers, to translate into reality the vision of the founding fathers of the 113-nation NAM, which came into existence some 35 years ago during the cold war era.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Liberia;
Africa's First Female Head Of State Sworn-In


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

MONROVIA, Liberia - Africa's first female head of state, Ruth Perry, was sworn-In Tuesday as the head of Liberia's six-member Council of State, or government.

She was elected unanimously at a meeting in August in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, by Liberia's warring factions. That meeting, a summit of the Economic Community of West African States Committee of Nine on Liberia, was another of a long line of efforts to bring permanent peace to Africa's oldest republic after just over six years of civil war. She replaced Wilton Sankawulo.

Speaking at Perry's inaugural ceremony, Nigerian Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi said Tuesday in Monrovia that West African leaders were determined to end the perennial cycle of derailed peace plans for Liberia. Ikimi warned the warring factions against testing this resolve.

Of Perry as chairwoman of the council, he told the warring parties that sanctions agreed upon at the Abuja summit would be implemented.

"The determination now exists for them to be applied under any circumstance of definite obstruction to the peace plan,", he said.

He cited the various unsuccessful attempts by West African leaders to bring peace to Liberia saying this was due to the lack of cooperation from factional leaders.

He called on Liberians to support Perry, urging the new chairwoman to be " neutral, dispassionate, evenhanded and fair-minded" in all her dealings to ensure the faithful implementation of the Abuja Peace Agreement on Liberia.

Ikimi urged Liberians to "resolve to forge a sustained consensus for peace."

Perry was a senator during the regime of late Liberian President Samuel Doe.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Business;
Justice Ministry In South Africa Cracks Down On Money Laundering


BYLINE: Tebello Radebe, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Johannesburg - Justice Minister Dullah Omar is confident that several key laws to curb the easy pickings made by embezzlers, thieves, insider traders, and fraudsters will be in place before year-end.

"This will be the culmination of a process we started two years ago to review our legal system because we inherited many laws that are hopelessly inadequate to deal with crime," he says. Omar believes this is one of the main reasons for South Africa's high crime rate.

He said the process took so long because "we started off with nothing and had to examine laws of different countries abroad first so that we stay in line with the latest trends. Ultimately, we will even surpass the Vienna Convention with our laws," he said. 

Parliament has been asked to prioritise these bills to ensure they are passed before the end of this session. The bills tabled in parliament this week include the Proceeds of Crime bill, which criminalises money laundering and allows the state to seize assets bought with funds from criminal activities; the International Co- operation in Criminal Matters bill and the Extradition Amendment bill -- aimed at bringing South Africa in line with international efforts to stamp out drug trafficking.

Reserve Bank Governor Chris Stals confirmed that former inspectors of foreign exchange controls in his staff were to be redeployed to facilitate the administration of the new money laundering laws. He added that it was possible these new posts would be operational before the end of the year.

Experts believe most of the staff and equipment at the South African Reserve Bank previously involved in administering exchange control regulations will be redeployed to form one of the main new structures to combat money laundering -- the Financial Intelligence Centre (FIC) -- in line with recommendations made by the South African Law Commission (SALC).

The FIC will oversee the reporting and initial investigation of suspicious transactions in the banks and other financial institutions; in addition, a Money Laundering Control Board will be set up to revise and control money laundering laws.

According to the Law Commission's proposals to the Justice Ministry, attorneys, accountants, executors, estate agents, dealers in securities, insurers and insurance brokers, unit trust schemes, banks, stokvels, gambling institutions, dealers in bullion, travellers' cheques and money orders will have to appoint officers, who will in turn report "suspicious transactions" to the FIC, which will pass on the information to the police where necessary.

The considerable costs of setting up and running these structures will initially be borne by the government, but in time will be covered by the provisions of the Proceeds from Crime Act. This will ensure that assets seized from the estates of drug pedlars and all other criminal activities will be used to fund the system to combat crimes.

Stuart Grobler of the Council of South African Banks, one of the organisations that made submissions to the law commission proposals, sees the new laws covering far more than just drug lords and robbers.

He said even most small businesses that are not registered with the taxman, as well as foreign exchange manipulators and fraudsters, are effectively engaged in money laundering, but since this practice has never been illegal in South Africa, they get away unchecked in too many cases.

But Grobler, like many other experts, says it is not possible to estimate the extent of money laundering, because "nobody keeps records of any of the ill-begotten funds as they get deposited into the financial system".

However, Pieter Smit, a researcher at the SALC, says: "There is already a lot of criminal (laundered) money in the South African financial system. It is hard to say how large the amount is, but the banking sector is aware of suspicious transactions going through the system, including monies coming into and out of the country."

A recent International Monetary Fund (IMF) publication states that the globalisation of the world economy and the growing efficiency of capital markets allows individuals and firms to shift vast sums of money freely between countries. Although difficult to measure, the magnitude of the sums involved and the extent of the criminal activities that generate this "income" have implications for both the domestic economy and the allocation of international resources and macro-economic stability.

Peter Quirk and Vito Tanzi, of the IMF, claim their research proves money laundering can corrupt parts of the financial system and undermine governance of central banks. Other major macro- economic effects include the destabilisation of interest rates, budget deficits brought about by large- scale tax evasion, as well as the creation of financial "black" markets where strict exchange controls are in place.

"Once a bank manager is corrupted, non- market behaviour can spread into areas other than those directly related to the money laundering, which undermines the safety and soundness of the bank," says Quirk.

Money laundering and measures to counter it have, therefore, become the focus of intense international attention. Last week's Southern African Development Community meeting in Maseru, Lesotho, saw the heads of its 12 member states signing a Protocol on Combating Illicit Drug Trafficking.

Omar said the protocol will afford mutual assistance among the member states, including co-operation on the communication of information, taking evidence, searches and seizes and the tracing of suspects or proceeds. " Special laws for drug trafficking and money laundering enforcement measures will also flow from this protocol," he said.

He will be hosting justice ministers of Commonwealth countries at a conference of money laundering in Cape Town in October, taking forward the process of establishing common money laundering laws in all the member states.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


15 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Business;
Technology Versus Development In South Africa


BYLINE: Aspasia Karras, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Johannesburg - The Technology Foresight study, recently completed in Britain, attempts to urgently determine where and how the country can gain the competitive edge in the increasingly chaotic global market.

This process is probably even more significant for South Africa, yet the word from the Departments of Post and Telecommunications, and Arts, Culture, Science and Technology is that our equivalent White Paper will take up to four years to produce. Developments on the ground point to an urgent need for a coherent policy.

Michael Kahn, head of the Gauteng Information Technology Department, explains: "It is a political question. We have a social commitment to development, and we need to become internationally competitive." 

The Information Society and Development (ISAD) conference of the G7 and developing states held in May, seemed to be heading towards a first phase of practicable measures to achieve this end. One of the lead projects for South Africa, taken up by the National Telecommunications Forum (NTF), is the development of infrastructure for multi-purpose community centres (MPCCs).

Peter Benjamin, who is co-ordinating the Community Access Task Team of the NTF, sees the centres as the logical extension of the information community, as opposed to the information superhighway and information society, highlighting the need to link information to community needs in developing states, rather than to the business needs of the technologically developed world.

The ideas informing the centres have evolved in a similar way. The ISAD was brimming with information idealists, who appeared to believe that access to the Internet would propel any disadvantaged community into the 21st-century overnight.

Critics were quick to point out that a rural community in the Transkei would need access to cheap telephony and basic services like a fax, even before the more obvious literacy campaign that would enable them to surf the world wide web. Access to the technology will not necessarily ensure development; a carefully studied and negotiated process is much more critical to link technology to the real needs of a community.

The concept is not new; in fact, practically each government line department has something equivalent on the go. The South African Police, for instance, have R200-million from the Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) fund to invest in "community safety centres"; the Welfare Department has built six community centres linked to local RDP councils in the Western Cape; the Gauteng Public Works Department is building in Khutsong South, West Rand, for R2-million; Eskom has donated computers to an MPCC in Rabie Ridge, facilitated by the Community Development Forums in the North East Rand.

In addition, a sum of R150 000 per MPCC has been promised by the United States for Deputy President Thabo Mbeki's Communications Task Team, with a proposal to build 10 pilot projects.

The list certainly illustrates the government's and international donors' commitment to the need for information dissemination, but more critically it points to the lack of integrated planning.

Al Karaki, a veteran proponent of MPCCs in the country, is adamant: " Lateral and vertical integration of planning is practically non-existent, this is massive wastage," owing to the way the budget is structured.

Each department and province has to submit their business plans by December 17, and spend the money by the end of September the following year. This leads to a panicked rush for projects that seem viable, but are neither consultative nor integrated, causing unnecessary duplication.

Another problem is that each department must be seen to deliver, therefore integrated projects may not have a high- enough profile, or enough quantifiable indicators for a specific department's needs.

"They have no time to consult each other, because of the time restraints. Ideally, an autonomous co-ordinating body should be formed to integrate planning. This lack of integrated planning is one of the great successes of apartheid."

A first initiative towards this end is being funded by the International Development Research Council of Canada. The project will audit and report on all organisations and projects that are related to the MPCC concept. Benjamin estimates that the network could number more than 2 000. More important, the country needs a policy framework.

Kahn concludes that by identifying those areas in which South Africa is different and in fact ground-breaking could show the way forward. He cites an ironic by-product of the apartheid era: the development of military expertise at encryption.

Using this technological advantage, Eskom has created the prepaid electricity meter cards. Significantly, this led to Siemens becoming a strategic partner in the project. But it also raised the spectre of a targeted population still without electricity as they cannot afford to buy the cards.

"It is the fundamental question: can we be both leaders and followers? In choosing where we head, we have to take into account who we are leading."

Kahn elaborates, "If our primary concern is development, then technology is a tool we should be using. The point is to identify what elements we can develop that are ground-breaking and therefore offer potential economic leverage.

"By providing computers and information centres to a largely illiterate population, we should be realising that we are in fact opening up a market in iconic programme development, and touch screen specialisation."


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Business;
Cigarette Excise Duties A 'Double-Edged Sword'


BYLINE: Lynda Loxton, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Johannesburg - Rembrandt chairman Johann Rupert this week shrugged off the growing anti-tobacco lobby in the United States but warned the South African government against trying to milk more excise duty from the local industry.

When asked at the annual meeting in Stellenbosch what the recent court ruling against US company Brown and Williamson (B&W) and President Bill Clinton's moves to clamp down on smoking would mean for the tobacco industry worldwide, Rupert said B&W had appealed against the court ruling and was fairly confident it would win.

This was because although the US had more ex-smokers than smokers, the jury system was reluctant to find against the tobacco industry. 

"Originally, it was argued that there was a health risk that the smoker did not know about, but the juries ruled that there was a voluntary assumption of risk because it was assumed that everyone knows about the health risk," Rupert said.

"Then people tried to say that tobacco was addictive. The lawyers said that if it was addictive, why do you know more ex-smokers than smokers?"

Rupert, who insists on a liberal display of ashtrays at his annual meetings so that people can smoke, admitted that "if a person has a sore throat, it is unpleasant for non-smokers to be in the same room. But claims that environmental tobacco smoke is a health risk are difficult to prove," he said.

Clinton has been pushing for tougher anti- smoking laws, especially in buildings, and higher excise duties on tobacco.

Rupert dismissed this as "a very populist approach in an election year, especially given that Bob Dole has different views."

Dole, who used to smoke heavily, has been reluctant to support the anti- smoking lobby, much to the dismay of conservatives.

"What irritates me is that I know one of Clinton's best friends and he assures me that President Clinton enjoys his cigars ... and he DOES inhale," Rupert said.

On the issue of excise duties, Rupert said they were a double-edged sword. It could be argued that they should be raised to discourage smoking and raise extra revenue for the fiscus, but this also encouraged the smuggling of imported tobacco.

South Africa, he said, was a prime example of this. Excise duties had been raised so high that illegal tobacco imports were flourishing and could now be found in 80% of all urban retail outlets -- without the health warnings that local brands carried.

He said most of the illegal imports were Brazilian and American brands.

Rupert blamed the illegal imports on the lack of trained manpower in customs and excise and doubted whether current efforts to jack up the department would yield results quickly.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Business;
Investment Trust In South Africa Treads Softly, But Surely


BYLINE: Madeleine Wackernagel, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Johannesburg - Eric Molobi, head of Kagiso Trust Investments, is not about to upset nine months of delicate negotiations with strong-arm tactics: "We have no immediate plans to change the existing management at The Citizen," he assures me, "or at Perksor for that matter.

"We cannot hold a gun to Perskor's heads and force them to transform overnight. By doing so we would just be shooting ourselves in the foot. I don't believe in turning everything upside-down for the sake of it. We have to tread carefully, but purposefully." 

Perskor and Kagiso may strike some as strange bedfellows, but to Molobi it made perfect sense.

"The writing is on the wall," says Molobi. "The government has made its position clear; no doubt there are many companies that turn away the opportunity of linking up with a black partnership, but that attitude is very short-sighted in this environment.

"In a time of transition, as South Africa is experiencing at present, one can either run away from the reality or engage it. We chose to do the latter. We must work together to close the gap between the polarised elements of our society."

But Rome -- and the new South Africa -- was not built in a day. The pace of change has been slow but not frustratingly so. "Africans and Afrikaners are very similar -- much more than is generally believed. Take the extended family and our love of culture ... It's just that one was the underdog.

"So the process of engagement is a slow one, but we will get there."

Certainly, that approach has worked well at Kagiso's other investments. Take the publishing group De Jager-HAUM. A very conservative instititution, the company changed, slowly, after Kagiso took over in 1994. Today, the managements work very well together, building on their respective strengths.

In Perskor's case, Kagiso will be represented by three members of a nine- person board, and its influence will be restricted to board level.

"We will not be involved in the day-to-day management," says Molobi. "That is a recipe for chaos. We must leave the management to do what they do best. We can't just tell them what to do; we must learn to understand the business, and from there develop a strategy for change."

There is no doubt in his mind that Perskor has to reposition itself and he has firm ideas on how to make it happen. "We will set up management committees, overseeing human resources, for example, as we have done, very successfully, at our other partnerships.

"But you cannot change a newspaper overnight. Repositioning the Citizen will have to be done cautiously and thoughtfully. It still has the image of being a bastion of right-wing thinking, but if you change a brand too drastically, you could end up killing it. The paper has a strong black readership -- maybe not for the news content -- but we have to consider that when debating potential changes."

'We will be canvassing other editors, marketing and advertising experts to come up with a feasible, workable solution -- and it will take time."

Editorial independence, however, is assured -- unless the editor is completely outrageous and "writes a lot of nonsense", he jokes. But over the years Kagiso Trust has lent financial assistance to many a struggling newspaper, including this one, and never attempted to get involved. "It is the best way," says Molobi.

Ever since the tie-up was announced, speculation has been rife that the Citizen will soon get a black editor. Molobi is keen to quash such rumours.

"Affirmative action for the sake of it is not productive. When it first became fashionable, people were being poached all over the place, earning more and more but not staying in any one job for long. I would question whether anybody really benefited -- the individual didn't stick around long enough to learn loyalty, to the company or the position, and the economy lost out because training costs money.

"But by the same token, one cannot ignore the need for positive discrimination. Companies will have to take the lead to defuse the argument for government legislation. Already we are seeing a bit of a backlash, with old mind-sets taking hold again."

Molobi reiterates the need for patience. "Training is a long-term undertaking and we need to emphasise skills and competency before colour when making appointments. But at the same time there is no room for complacency."

Kagiso, for one, is not resting on its laurels. It is actively looking around for other synergistic investments, but Molobi will not be drawn on specifics. "Shouting our plans from the roof-tops helps only to push up the price," he says. "We prefer to go about our business quietly." And assuredly, he might have added.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
