44 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


South Africa;
Torture Camp Found In KwaZulu-Natal


BYLINE: Riquadeau Jacobs, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Johannesburg - Kwazulu-Natal learned this week that in the early 1990s it had its own version of the infamous Vlakplaas torture camp at Camperdown in the Midlands.

Suspended policeman Colonel Andy Taylor has been fingered as the man who headed the camp -- effectively a subsidiary of Vlakplaas -- in an investigation by a magistrate Ashin Singh, now working for the Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

Taylor, who is suffering from cancer, is one of the five policeman accused of murdering lawyer Griffiths Mxenge in 1981. 

The farm -- which housed ANC operatives who were tortured and then turned into the police agents called Askaris -- is believed to have been the springboard for a host of assassinations, torture sessions and cross-border raids, according to an investigation published in the Natal Witness.

The paper quotes one of the camp's former Askaris, who is now providing information. The Natal Witness is also in possession of a number of documents about the farm's activities.

Investigators have linked Taylor to the death of Askari Neville "Goodwill" Sikhakhane -- one of the people convicted mass murderer Eugene De Kock was accused of murdering.

A list of the camp's top men includes Sergeant Larry Hanton, an explosives expert and Captain "Spyker" Myeza, believed to have been Taylor's right hand man.

The Askari said the farm was leased in Taylor's name. The camp's operatives acted on intelligence reports from police security branch units across the province. The Askaris and the black policemen at the camp would infiltrate the area, posing as MK operatives. Once they had identified their target they would either eliminate them or kidnap them.

Some of the information about the Camperdown operation and other farms leased by the police for anti-insurgency activities emerged in the De Kock trial and at the recent Motherwell hearings in Port Elizabeth, which lead to the conviction of several policemen.

The Transvaal attorney general is in possession of an impressive amount of information about Taylor and his colleagues, and prosecutions may ensue.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
Flood Recovery Work Opens Roads


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission announced yesterday that the Nazareth-Gefersa road has become functional following the beginning of the return to the river of the water that lay on the residential quarters of workers of the Wonji sugar Factory and the Factory's institutions including its cane estate.

In a statement it issued this afternoon, the commission said high level flood protection work has continued in Oromiya, Afar and South Ethiopia Regional States in which fruitful results were being registered in the move. 

Describing the success, the statement said the transportation of food and the necessary aid, mainly to Alem Tena, began Friday after the completion of the levelling of a new road that leads from Gefersa to Alem Tena, Dedemtu and Mekonnen Boka encampments.

As the level of water that flooded Tefki is on the decline, the statement said, some of the people who entered the encampment have begun returning to their home while the remaining are expected to return soon.

A 42 km road enabling aid workers to transport goods from Dera to the Chaka temporary shelter was also constructed as part of the effort to rescue flood affected people, according to the statement.

The commission reported that besides the three-horse-power boats sent to Gewane, in Afar, the transportation of two additional 25-horse-power boats began yesterday.

Residents in Awasa town have also continued reinforcing dikes in a bid to protect themselves from the possible danger that might be caused by Lake Awasa, the statement added.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
Commercial Bank Reports Profit


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Commercial Bank of Ethiopia, CBE, obtained a 576 million birr gross profit during the past Ethiopian fiscal year.

Speaking at an annual review meeting, the CBE president Ato Tilahun Abay said the amount of profit gained during the reported period surpassed that of the previous year by 19 percent. He further said the loss incurring central zone office has also earned a profit amounting to 2.9 million birr during the perio The number of profiting branches of the bank has increased from 94 to 111 this year, adding nine of the 11 zonal offices have also become profitable.

He attributed the success to the increase n the participation of private investors in the agricultural, industrial, foreign and domestic trade and the expansion of its loan services. Ato Tilahun said the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia has extended loan services amounting to 3.3 billion birr to business and state enterprises as well as individuals during the past fiscal year of which 2.4 billion was given to the private sector of the economy while the balance to government owned firms and public organizations.

Some 307.8 million birr was loaned to the agricultural sector and peasant associations with a view to helping Ethiopia achieve its goal of food-self sufficiency adding 212.4 million birr was spent on the purchase of fertilizers. ins returning to normal route

47 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


East Africa;
Weekly Roundup of Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2347 words


 

Nairobi - This is number 24 (26 August - 1 September 1996) in a series of weekly reports from IRIN on general developments in the Great Lakes region. Sources for the information below include UN agencies, NGOs, other international organisations and media reports. IRIN issues these reports for the benefit of the humanitarian community, but accepts no responsibility as to the accuracy of the original sources.

# The United Nations Security Council has given Burundi's new regime two months to hold broad-based peace talks or face punitive measures. In a resolution adopted unanimously on Friday, the Council expressed support for the sanctions imposed by Burundi's neighbours and other African states following the military-backed coup d'etat on 25 July. The Council called on all Burundian factions to stop hostilities and to initiate immediately unconditional negotiations "with a view to reaching a comprehensive political settlement". The resolution provides for the Council to review Burundi's compliance with its demands on 31 October. Punitive measures may include an arms embargo or other sanctions. France, which finally voted in favour of the resolution, had fought a paragraph expressing strong support for the efforts of regional leaders, including the 31 July Arusha meeting where sanctions were declared. A proposal for an immediate arms embargo was also gradually watered down during negotiations on the text. 

Burundi's new leader, Pierre Buyoya, said on Saturday that while he was ready to negotiate with Hutu rebels if they put down their arms, a decision on war or peace in Burundi would not be made by the UN Security Council.

# Heavy fighting was reported in Gatara village in the northwest province of Kayanza and nearly a dozen government buildings were looted and burned on Saturday - one day before Burundi's new prime minister was due to visit. The fighting was reported on the state-run radio. No casualty figures were released. Rebels also continued to block the main road north from Bujumbura to the Rwandan border. Attacks in Kayanza region were also stepped up during the week. Two truck drivers were burned alive in their vehicles during a series of ambushes on the country's main national route one which runs through Kayanza.

# Hutu peasants have accused the Burundian Army and Tutsi militia of killing more than 70 civilians in Murengeza village, about 20 kilometres north of Bujumbura. Eye-witnesses said that the Army and militia group, the Sans Echecs, shot, burned and used machetes to kill the villagers on 25 August during an operation to clear out rebels from the area. The Army says its troops killed 10 Hutu rebels but has denied slaughtering civilians. The human rights group, Amnesty International claimed last week that the Army had killed more than 4,000 unarmed civilians between 27 July and 10 August in the central district of Giheta.

Radio Burundi reported on Thursday that the new regime had asked the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights to substantially increase the number of human rights monitors deployed in Burundi. Currently there are only five international human rights monitors funded by the EU.

# Officials at Burundi's state run electricity company told Reuters that rebels had pulled down pylons as engineers were about to restore power to Burundi's capital, Bujumbura. The city has largely been without power since Saturday 24 August when rebels cut power lines in northern Bubanza province. The acts of sabotage have forced the capital to draw on dwindling fuel stocks for generators to keep water supplies, hospitals and schools running. As sanctions entered their second month, there were fresh warnings from doctors that a health disaster was imminent, particularly amongst the country's most vulnerable groups. Sanctions have forced the government to ration fuel and the cost of imported foods and goods have soared.

The regional committee established to monitor the sanctions will meet for the first time this coming week in Arusha, Tanzania. The committee, comprising the Ambassadors and High Commissioners to Kenya of Tanzania, Uganda, Ethiopia, Rwanda, Zambia and Zaire will meet together with officials from the OAU. The mandate of the committee is to monitor the effect of sanctions. Under the terms of the sanctions only human medicines and food for Rwandan refugees are exempt. UN agencies and other humanitarian partners are continuing to press for a range of humanitarian goods and materials for Burundi's vulnerable groups.

The Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), meanwhile, has denied threatening to attack planes breaking the air embargo. A spokesman for the CNDD said that no unilateral action on the ground or the air would be taken without prior consultation with the regional sanctions committee. WFP's internal flights, halted for two days were due to resume this coming week.

# The African Football Confederation (CAF) confirmed on Wednesday that Burundi had been disqualified from the African Nations Cup following the team's inability to travel for a qualifying round against Central African Republic.

# Former Tanzanian president, Julius Nyerere, chief mediator of the Burundi crisis met with Italian Catholic peace organisation, Sant'Egidio in Rome on Wednesday. The organisation has been nominated for the Nobel peace prize for its work. Sant'Egidio representatives also met with Howard Wolpe, the US special representative to Burundi who was in Rome prior to vacationing in Italy. Nyerere and Wolpe also met in Rome on Wednesday. A source close to the meeting said that the two agreed that an "exceptional diplomatic effort" was required to bring forward acceptable proposals to defuse the conflict in Burundi.

# A planned three-day census of Rwandan refugees in Goma, eastern Zaire was suspended on Sunday following what was described as "a highly organised and orchestrated" boycott by the refugees. No violence was reported but in Katale camp two sites where the census was supposed to have taken place were destroyed and plastic sheeting was stolen in Mugunga camp. UNHCR says that the census was organised to establish how many refugees were in the area so that aid could be better directed in the face of shortage of donor funds. Earlier, the Rwandan Hutu refugee organisation, the Rally for the Return of Refugees and Democracy in Rwanda (RDR), had called on refugees to be calm and had asked UNHCR to avoid any "policing approach" and to calm refugees by explaining the aim of the operation. The RDR said the refugees feared the census because they believed it could be used to help force them back to Rwanda. Zaire and Rwanda recently announced plans for "an organised, massive and unconditional repatriation" of the 1.1 million Rwandan refugees in Zaire.

# A statement issued by the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda says that the Rwandan Patriotic Army killed at least 111 people, many of them unarmed civilians, during sweeps carried out in five communes in Ruhengeri prefecture between 6-8 August. Some former soldiers, militia and cross border infiltrators were allegedly amongst those who were killed. About 300 males were arrested during the sweep, fifty-two of whom were still missing on 28 August. The regional Army commander says that civilian deaths occurred because people attempted to flee, resisted arrest or were caught in cross- fire between the RPA and insurgents.

# The Rally for the Return of Refugees and Democracy in Rwanda (RDR) accused the Government of Rwanda this week of terrorist acts on Rwandan refugees in Kenya. The RDR called on the international community for assistance and said that hit squads had been sent to many foreign capitals including Nairobi. It claimed that during the last three weeks four trucks belonging to Rwandan refugees in Kenya had been burned by people it suspected of being in the pay of the Rwandan government. The RDR statement also said there had been five assassination attempts on Rwandan refugees in Kenya last year. The Resistance Forces for Democracy (FRD), a group formed by former Rwandan Primer Minister Faustin Twagiramungu, on Tuesday also accused the Rwandan government of forming hit squads to assassinate Rwandan leaders in exile.

# A former Rwanda prefet, who is wanted in Rwanda, pleaded not guilty to being involved in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda and other related crimes at a court in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Wednesday. Colonel Alphonse Ntezilyayo is charged that while he was prefet of Butare he held meetings of Hutu Interahamwe militias and the presidential guard to plan massacres, helped killers escape to a safe zone controlled by French troops and later used death threats to force other Hutus to leave Rwanda. At his extradition hearing, Ntezilyayo said that he had only been prefet in Butare from 20 June to 2 July. The court will deliver its opinion on 4 September, but his extradition to Rwanda can only be ordered by Burkina Faso's President, Blaise Compaore.

Swiss authorities said on Wednesday that they had arrested a former Rwandan mayor now living in Switzerland on suspicion of violating human rights during the genocide. The man was not named, but the investigation is proceeding.

# Zairian President, Mobutu Sese Seko remained in Switzerland this week, reportedly after undergoing an operation for cancer of the prostate. Officials at the hospital where Mobutu is being treated would not confirm the operation. An official statement from Zaire said that Zaire's Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo had an operation to remove a lipoma (a tumour made of fatty tissue) in a Swiss clinic while visiting Mobutu last week. Kengo has reportedly resumed his normal activities and met with the deputy High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva on Saturday. Last week, Swiss television alleged that Mobutu had left Switzerland with 1.5 million Swiss francs (US$ 1. 2 million) in unpaid bills. The bills are said to relate to the rental of buildings, caterers, insurance companies and contractors working on the Mobutu's lakeside mansion.

# Tanzania has earmarked 128 state owned firms for privitisation as part of its economic reforms. 31 of the firms will be sold by the end of September, increasing to 78 by the end of the year. Tanzania is also scheduled to open a stock exchange by the end of the month. Tanzania began embarking in privitisation in 1993 as part of western backed economic reforms, but critics say progress has been too slow and dogged by corruption.

# Petrol and diesel fuel prices in Tanzania were increased by up to 4.35% at the weekend. The Tanzanian Petroleum Development Corporation says that this increase reflects higher world oil prices. Premium petrol now costs 360 shillings (US$ O.58) a litre - up from 345 shillings. Diesel costs 285 shillings (US$0.46) up from 276 shillings.

# Rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels are accused of holding more than 200 Ugandan youth hostage. The youngsters have been kidnapped from villages in the north of Uganda. The rebel's leader, Joseph Kony has been reported as saying that the LRA will abduct 10,000 Ugandans to Sudan for military training. Uganda's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs is reported to have left Uganda at the weekend for Khartoum, Sudan as part of ongoing attempts to normalise relationships between the two countries.

# A leading African politician said on Friday that an African campaign to have the continent's massive external debts written off or at least reduced is gaining support from Western donors. Kwesi Botchway, the economic committee chairman of the Global Coalition for Africa said officials from creditor institutions who attended last week's GCA meeting supported the initiative to grant debt relief to the heavily indebted African countries. Botchway, the former Ghanaian finance minister, said that the 33 least developed countries in sub-Saharan Africa owed around US$ 164 billion out of Africa's total US$ 223 billion external debt for 1995.

(This document is distributed via the UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs Integrated Regional Information Network. Tel: +254 2 441125; Fax: +254 2 448816; e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies.)


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

48 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


South Africa;
Tutu Says Truth Panel to Meet Ex-Police Heads


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town -Statement by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, chairperson of the Truth And Reconciliation Commission issued August 30:

A delegation of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission will meet former police Commissioners tomorrow to discuss their co-operation with the Commission's investigations into human rights violations.

Dr Alex Boraine, the deputy chairperson, Mr Dumisa Ntsebeza, the head of our investigative unit and Mr Glen Goosen, the national investigations director, will join me at the meeting in Cape Town.

The meeting was arranged by telephone tonight with General J V van der Merwe, former Commissioner of Police, after he had proposed a meeting including himself, General H G de Witt, General M Geldenhuys and General P J Coetzee. 

The background to the meeting is as follows. Some weeks ago Dr Boraine announced that the Commission had instructed its Investigative Unit to be in a position to begin, on August 29, the process of serving subpoenas to individuals who may have information which would help the TRC carry out its mandate to establish the truth about human rights violations between 1960 and 1993.

Also some weeks ago, Dr Boraine and I urged the Minister of Safety and Security to prepare a submission to the Commission which could help us to fulfil our mandate.

After press speculation this week on the identities of some of those who were about to receive subpoenas, the Ministry of Safety and Security, through Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, yesterday indicated to us that certain former police generals named as being on our list were helping the Ministry with its submission, and were willing to come forward voluntarily and work with the Commission.

We indicated to Deputy President Mbeki that if we were assured today by the generals concerned that they would work with the Commission, we would hold back on the issuing of subpoenas. General van der Merwe wrote to me proposing a meeting and, after discussions this evening, we agreed that it should be held this weekend.

The Commission has repeatedly invited all those with information which may help it to establish the truth to come forward. We are prepared to issue subpoenas, under Section 29 of the act which established the Commission, in order to get information. However, if we receive the full co-operation of those who have the information we are seeking, we will not need to pursue that course.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


South Africa;
Truth Panel Issues First Amnesty


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

Cape Town - The full text, issued August 30, of the decision and reasons of the Amnesty Committee in the matter of Boy Diale and Christopher Makgale follow:

Boy Diale and Christopher Makgale were charged and convicted of the crime of the murder of Glad Mokgatle. The offence was committed on 29th December 1990 between Luka and Rooikraalspruit in the district of Bafokeng. They had both pleaded guilty to the charge. The trial court found that there were extenuating circumstances and on the 8th October 1991, they were sentenced to imprisonment of 12 years and 15 years respectively. They are at present serving their sentences at the Odi District Prison.

The applicants were among a group of ten people who went by Kombi to a house in Tshaneng to get the keys of the Bafokeng Civic Centre from Glad Mokgatle, who will hereinafter be referred to as the deceased. This was done in pursuance of a decision taken at a meeting of the Action Committee earlier that day. The original intention of the group was to take the keys of the Civic Centre from the deceased, kidnap him and hold him hostage for reasons which I shall mention later. 

When the group arrived at the house in which the deceased was, they surrounded it. Some went into the house whilst others stayed outside. When they eventually encountered the deceased he came out of the house armed with a panga and appeared to be aggressive. The group overpowered him, put him in the Kombi and drove off. He was questioned about the keys to the Civic Centre, but proved to be unco-operative. Some members of the group assaulted the deceased and at a spot along the road the Kombi stopped, the deceased was pulled out and beaten up. The two applicants joined in the assault on the deceased and although initially they did not intend to kill him, emotions ran high and they were caught up in a frenzy of violence and although some members of the group did not want to kill the deceased the majority view was that he should be killed. When asked what the reason was for the decision to kill the deceased, Diale said "the main reason, we did not want him to identify us".

The assault on the deceased caused his death. When questioned about his precise participation in the assault on the deceased, Diale said:

"If it is a request from the Committee I will have to state it clearly. I kicked him, I hit him with my fists and I strangled his neck."

According to the evidence of the second applicant, the deceased was being attacked after he was pulled out of the Kombi and lying on the ground. His evidence was:

"I had a look at Mr Mokgatle and I could see that he was still alive. I took the sabre from him and I chopped him. I chopped him personally. I chopped him because I realised that we were heading for the prison. I wanted to sweep away the evidence."

The applicants were members of the Action Committee of the Bafokeng Tribe. There was overwhelming evidence that the killing of the deceased was due to the fact that he was chairman of the Tribal Council in the Bafokeng district. He had been appointed to that position by Mr Lucas Mangope, President of Bophuthatswana. The people of Phokeng looked upon the deceased as a person who was put into position to administer the affairs of the Tribe on behalf of the regime which the Bafokeng people did not recognise and had over a long period of time, strenuously resisted. The Civic Centre belonged to the Tribe, but control thereof had been taken over by the Mangope regime. The social, political and cultural activities of the Tribe could not take place in the Civic Centre unless it was assented to by the deceased in his capacity as chairman of the Tribal Council. The Civic Centre represented the symbol of the people's aspirations and they believed that in order to regain control of it, they had to get hold of the keys from whoever was in charge.

There was overwhelming evidence of the rejection by the Bafokeng Tribe of the Mangope regime as the Tribe did not want to be incor- porated into the homeland of Bophuthatswana. The rightful chief of the Bafokeng people, namely Chief Molotlegi had been driven into exile in March 1988 and he was replaced by an appointee of Lucas Mangope. The tribe's desire to get their chief back to his rightful place as Chief of the Bafokeng was the earnest wish of both the applicants.

The background and context within which the crime was committed was set out in their application for amnesty and a portion of it reads as follows:

"The applicant is a member of the Bafokeng tribe. The Bafokeng own most of the platinum reserves in South Africa. Approximately 300 000 members strong, it receives R75 000 000-00 per annum in royalties from Impala Platinum. Prior to the independence of Bophuthatswana, the royalties were kept in trust by the SA government, Department of Foreign Affairs on behalf of the Bafokeng. After independence, Mangope assumed trusteeship and the royalties were paid directly into the account of the Bophuthatswana Department of Finance. The contribution of the tribe to the economy of this "state" was enormous and in these circumstances the Bafokeng expected that the Bophuthatswana government would give them due recognition. Such recognition was not forthcoming and a steady deterioration of the relationship between Mangope and the Bafokeng started in 1977.

"In 1983 the tribe attempted to secede and as a result, Mangope visited Phokeng on May 14 and told them:

'I have come to tell you to go, you must trek - I say vacate ... I am going to conduct a Commission of Enquiry here. I want you to know that as from now we are going to declare a state of emergency in Phokeng.'

"After the attempted coup in 1988, Chief Lebone Molotlegi of the Bafokeng, his wife and numerous members of the tribe were detained without trial; and without any charges being brought against them. When Chief Lebone was released, he left Bophuthatswana and went into exile in Gaberone. Before leaving, he appointed his Rangwane Mr Cecil Tumagole as leader of the tribe to act on his behalf in his absence.

"During 1988, all meetings of the Bafokeng Tribal Authority, Tribal Council and the Bafokeng Women's Club were banned. Under these circumstances it became impossible for the tribe to administer its affairs - e.g. major construction contracts relating to ongoing work could not be complied with and new contracts could not be considered and/or approved. Furthermore, Mangope intervened in the tribe's affairs and general administration and literally forced the tribe to business with Impala Platinum. Impala Platinum refused to make available to the tribe certain information regarding their mining operations as allegedly they had been assured by Mangope that they would not have to disclose the information.

"Mangope, mindful of the tribe's opposition to him devised a strategy whereby persons sympathetic to him were appointed to positions of authority within the tribe.

"As a result, George Molotlegi was appointed as Acting Chief and Glad Mokgatle as Chairman of the Tribal Council. Others sympathetic to his government were also appointed and those who opposed the Acting Chief were dismissed. In this was a completely changed leadership was created.

"On 4 April 1990, members of the tribe wrote a letter to Mangope requesting an appointment to discuss the leadership of the Bafokeng. All the signatories were picked up at their homes and taken to Mmabatho as a form of intimidation. Letters were also written to the former State President F W de Klerk and the Minister of Foreign Affairs Pik Botha, but to no avail. Mangope refused to meet with members of the tribe unless the meeting was arranged by the Acting Chief. In spite of the fact that the Acting Chief was part of the problem, the members were so desperate at this stage that in June 1990, 25 of them wrote to him requesting a meeting. All twenty five (25) of the signatories (including the secretary who had typed the letter, who at the time was five months pregnant) were detained."

Although it might appear from the evidence that the applicants, more especially the second applicant, made sure that the deceased died of his injuries because they feared that had he lived, he would most certainly have implicated them in the assault on him, the evidence as a whole leaves no doubt that the attack on the deceased was associated with a political objective, that is regaining control of the Tribe. In this regard it should be noted that in sentencing the two applicants the Judge accepted the fact that their offence was politically motivated.

The applicants and their companions believed that they were acting on behalf of the Bafokeng people in furtherance of their political struggle against an oppressive regime.

The sons of the deceased were present and two of them gave evidence. They concede that the applicants had acted on behalf of the Bafokeng Tribe and expressed the wish that amnesty be granted to the applicants. They expressed the belief that reconciliation within the Tribe would be achieved if the applicants were released from prison and granted amnesty.

We have come to the conclusion that their conduct meets the requirements of the criteria set out in Section 20 (3) of the Act. They are hereby granted amnesty in terms of the Act in respect of the murder of Mr Glad Mokgatle on the 29th December 1990 in the district of Bafokeng.

Decision and reasons signed by Mr Justice H Mall, Mr Justice A B M Wilson, Mr Justice B Ngoepe, Mr C de Jager and Ms S Khampepe.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 3, 1996


South Africa;
Tutu Invites Questions for Political Parties


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Cape Town - The Human Rights Violations Committee of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission is issuing a public invitation to individuals and organisations to suggest issues which could be raised with political parties when they are recalled to the Commission.

Submissions made by parties last week are to be examined carefully by the Commission in the coming weeks. Once they have been thoroughly evaluated, the committee will consider recalling the parties to question their representatives further.

The Commission would value suggestions from members of the public on:

(1) Questions which could help the Commission in securing more information from the parties so that it can fulfil its mandate of establishing the truth about the past; and

(2) Issues which could be raised with the parties with a view to helping the healing of our country.

Detailed questioning of party representatives was deliberately held over until the Commission had an opportunity to study their submissions. When questioning takes place, it will be handled as an information-gathering exercise, not as a prosecution.

The public can send their contributions to the Chairperson, TRC, PO Box 3162, Cape Town 8000.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


South Africa;
Truth Panel Says Some Afraid to Testify


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Paarl - In a public meeting held in Mbekweni, Paarl, recently, TRC Committee member Ms. Pumla Gobodo-Madikezela found that a number of residents were concerned that if they gave statements to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, this would provoke threats from people who do not want the details of past conflict to be exposed. Ms. Gobodo- Madikezela wants to assure the Paarl community that the work of the Truth Commission is not about witch-hunting and pointing a finger at those who are seen as having inflamed the conflict.

Rather, the objective of the Commission is to help resolve conflicts of the past, and to find explanation for them. However, we wish to inform every one that the Truth Commission has a witness protection programme. If anyone feels that their safety will be compromised as a result of making a statement to the Commission, she/he has a right to apply for protection. We would hope that the people of Paarl will join together in reflecting on the struggle in Paarl, and in sharing their experiences of suffering on all sides of the conflict. More statement taking has been scheduled for Saturday 31st August. This will take place at the Huguenot Community Hall and the Mbekweni Community Hall from 11a.m. until 5p.m. at both places. Issued August 26, 1996.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


South Africa;
Amnesty Statement from Truth Commission


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - The Amnesty Committee of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission will hear amnesty applications next week from a number of professed African National Congress supporters who were jailed for killings in gold-mining centres in North-West Province.

Four alleged AWB members will also apply for amnesty at the same round of hearings, to be held at the Ikageng Community Hall, Potchefstroom, from September 9 to 13.

Eleven people are due to apply for amnesty at the hearings. 

Mpayipheli William Faltein, 23, and Johnson Themba Ncube, 25, who say they are members of the ANC Youth League, are serving effective 12-year prison terms on charges of murder and attempted murder. They were sentenced in September 1993, in the Circuit Court, Potchefstroom, for the murder in December 1990 of David Mayeko, allegedly a member of the "Vigilantes" gang, in Khutsong, Carletonville.

Peter Lebona, 24, and Thabo Solomon Lekitlane, 29, who describe themselves as ANC marshals, were each jailed for 10 years in October 1992 for the murder of J Z Dlamini in Kanana, Orkney, in July 199..

Mosiwa Meshack Popane, 29, Gcinisizwe Dlanjwa, 26, and Thamsanqa Patrick Mkontwana, 25, were convicted of killing Abednego Nzimeni Mazwi at the Khuma taxi rank, Stilfontein, in October 1990. The three, who say they were members of the SA Youth Congress and the ANC, were sentenced to terms of imprisonment ranging from eight to 12 years for murder and attempted murder.

Four brothers and alleged AWB supporters -- Adriaan van Straaten, Willem Jacobus van Straaten, Gideon van Straaten and Dawid Petrus van Straaten -- were convicted of murder and robbery, and sentenced on May 14, 1991. They murdered Mr Wanton Matshoba and Mr Sazise Cyprian Qheliso in Vereeniging in June 1989. Willem Jacobus van Straaten was sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment, and his brothers to 13 years' each.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 3, 1996


Zambia;
New Testimony: State House Killed Nkumbula


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 7507 words


 

Lusaka - Patrick Mubanga Kafuti, defence minister Ben Mwila's nephew, has repudiated the testimony he gave to the Commission of Inquiry into the accident and death of Baldwin Nkumbula last November, saying it was false and cooked up by police.

And now Kafuti says Nkumbula was shot by State House security personnel, whom he can identify.

Kafuti also reveals that President Frederick Chiluba begged him not to tell anyone the 'true' story about how Nkumbula was killed.

And he claims the President, who promised to take care of him in so many ways, has not honoured his words.

And fearing for his life, and permanent insecurity, Kafuti says, he has now been compelled to let the world know the truth about Nkumbula's 'mysterious' death in a car crash in Kitwe on August 27, last year. 

"I am not just living like a . . . normal life the way I used to do. I am also living in fear. Maybe those same people would just do something that no one gets to know. So what I thought was, if I told someone who was responsible, who will know such things and who would know how to take care of such things. Like if ah . . . anything had to happen, they would like ah . . . say something or do something to let the people know so that no one just dies a mysterious death just like that," Kafuti reveals in his Jamaican-like English.

Below is a verbatim transcript of an interview with Patrick Kafuti:

My name is Mubanga Patrick Kafuti and the date today is 29th, at 12:15 hours. And I am hereby saying this because of my own will and I want to leave this just in case something happened to me just that people can know exactly what happened.

Q: What's the date today?

Kafuti: It's 29th February, 1996. This is relating to Baldwin Nkumbula's accident which happened last year in August...27th. We were in Lusaka, let me just start from the beginning, we were in Lusaka, it was a Friday when we left Lusaka in the afternoon.

Q: With who?

Kafuti: We were me, Castro, Micko, Mwaba and Benjamin. For me it was, and for the rest, well what I knew it was for the intention of going for a funeral in Kitwe which happened to our, let me say, because, Benjamin my older cousin, that is Benjamin Mwila's first son, his wife's elder sister's husband died so that is why we had to travel to Kitwe for the funeral.

Q: What vehicle were you using?

Kafuti: We were using a GX.

Q: From?

Kafuti: From State House it is ACD 926, I can't remember very well now. So when we left, we were meant to leave in the morning, but I don't know what happened. So we left about late in the evening about 17:00 hours. We travelled alright until we got there. We just passed through Ndola and that is why we got there in the night.

Q: Where did you go in Ndola?

Kafuti: When we got to Ndola we first went to the guest house because Miko's elder sister Helen was there.

Q: The Presidential guest house?

Kafuti: Yes (the one) in Kabelenga Avenue. So we passed there. We were meant to sleep and then the guy said no, since we are going for the funeral we have to proceed.

Q: Do you remember anybody you could relate to who you had seen in Ndola on that day, before you proceeded?

Kafuti: No, we never saw anyone. We just went straight to the guest house and then from the guest house, we said no, because Helen were having a drink up at Aunt Sara's, Vera's young sister, late young sister. We passed through there, we just passed spent about fifteen minutes and then with all the guys we decided to proceed to Kitwe.

When we proceeded to Kitwe, we first went straight to the guest house where we were meant to sleep but we actually didn't sleep there.

Q: Which guest house?

Kafuti: The . . .

Q: Kafue river?

Kafuti: No, not the Kafue river one . . .. in town...

Q: Mine . . .

Kafuti: Jacaranda guest house

Q: In Kitwe?

Kafuti: In Kitwe yes. So we went to sleep there early in the morning about 04 O'clock since the guys wanted to go first to a party, the disco and all, so in the morning we had to go to the funeral since the burial was on Saturday.

Q: Where was the funeral?

Kafuti: The funeral was in Ndeke village. So when we went for the burial we went for burial and everything was finished we went back to the funeral house, I mean after a burial everyone goes to the funeral house. So when we went to the funeral house we just stayed there about two hours then we went to the guest house we had a bath, we went in town, we had our hair cuts then we went back to the guest house. We stayed up to about late in the night. And when we were leaving, we were meant to leave to come to Ndola because Helen wanted us to come to Ndola. We didn't come to Ndola because the guys wanted to stay in Kitwe. So we stayed in Kitwe the whole day. It was late at night when Castro came up to me and said let's go and see Baldwin (Nkumbula). I asked him to say why he wanted to see Baldwin at that time because we had been in Kitwe the whole day and for someone to . . .if he wanted to someone, we were going to do it in the afternoon because we were not doing anything in the afternoon.

Q: What time was this?

Kafuti: It was about 23 somewhere around 23:00 hours. So for me I refused to go to someone's house at . . .

Q: That hour?

Kafuti: At that hour, because it was late and why? Probably he was going to be sleeping by the way. But Castro insisted to meet Baldwin until I totally refused. And when I refused he said okay fine, I'll go alone and you guys since you want to go in town I'll find you in town. So we all, that's all the guys as we came from Lusaka jumped into the car the GX and he dropped us in town.

Q: Who was driving the car?

Kafuti: It was a driver, I can't remember his name . . . eh . . . eh . . . I remember the bodyguard. The bodyguards name is Mr.Banda.

Q: But you don't remember the driver's name?

Kafuti: The driver no but he is there (indicates the head) it's just that I can't remember him now.

Q: So all along the dirver was driving?

Kafuti: Yes he was the one who was driving. He dropped us. I mean Castro and the driver dropped us in town and the body guard remained at home. He said no since the car was full they had to drop us and then on their way to go and see Baldwin they were going to pick up the body guard. When they went, I mean they dropped us off so I didn't know what was happening there.

Q: So where did they drop you?

Kafuti: They dropped us at Cinderella.

Q: That's a night club?

Kafuti: Yes.

Q: What time was that?

Kafuti: Now it was about, going to somewhere about mid night. So if I can just go back a bit. For what I remember when Castro was saying let's go to Baldwin's house, he said something I didn't realise, even, that's why I even turned down going to Baldwin's house, he said let's go to Baldwin's house and I know why I want to go to Baldwin's house. You just have to be there and when everything is done that's when we come back and join the rest of the guys in town.

Q:That's what Castro was telling you?

Kafuti: Yes

Q: You didn't ask him what he was going to do?

Kafuti: What he wanted to go and do there? Why are you involved...what he said was like when everything is done, so I completed like saying there is nothing good that's going to be done or said such that after that we come and join the rest of the guys. Because if there was anything nice he was definitely going to tell me. And ah . . ., after he went...

Q: And left you at Cinderella?

Kafuti: Yes, after he went he got there and found Baldwin and some other people, like they were having a drink just chatting. He used a false name to get inside. He said he was Danny.

Q: Danny who?

Kafuti: Danny Nkumbula the young brother to Baldwin.

Q: Who told you that he used a false name?

Kafuti: He said he was going to do that if the guard didn't allow him to go in the house and that is what he liked doing every time he went there, so he used that name and when Baldwin came out he said "oh yeah it is Castro, so he then went in the house. So when Castro went in, he stayed there for some time I think until they came into town. He told Baldwin to say he wanted to go to the funeral house and I don't understand why he wanted to go there at that time such that we had been there and we had finished everything and we were meant to come back to Lusaka the next morning on Sunday. And according to Baldwin he didn't refuse and knowing Castro he has been there all the time and there was no way he was going to refuse and that's why I think everything had to happen through Castro because they knew that he won't refuse to Castro about anything.

Q:So when they came back they found you at Cinderella?

Kafuti: When they came back they found me at Cinderella and they called me down stairs and Baldwin said: "hi how are you, why did you not come to the house?" And I said sorry; I used to call him uncle myself, I said sorry uncle I thought it was late and there was no way we were going to come at that time because we had been here the whole day and Castro didn't think of coming to the house during the day.

And he said Castro wants to go to . . ..I don't know what he wants to go and do at the funeral house. He says he can't remember exactly it is you who can remember exactly where the place is. I said yes I can remember exactly where the funeral house is but I mean to go there at this time....and I asked Castro what he wanted to go and do there and he said I know what I want to go and do there. And just when we were standing there when I looked across the road where we were parked there was a BMW, there was a blue BMW with three people inside...

Q: Registration number..

Kafuti: I can't...I didn't read it ...but I know the BMW and I have seen it at State House and the people there they looked familiar and even if I had to see them now I would definitely point them out that these are the people who were in the car and when I looked at them they were like, you know . . . they got so guilty that I was looking at them. And I knew them and they were definitely maybe suspecting that I was going to walk across to go and say hi to them and ask them what they were doing there since we were all in Kitwe. If they were supposed to guard us they were supposed to come to the guest house to stay with us were we were staying and they didn't do that. So I said okay fine let me take you. When we got in the car, Baldwin started driving and after some meters that's when this other car also started coming-the BMW. We passed the first traffic lights they were green

Q: Which traffic lights?

Kafuti: The Edinburgh traffic lights. They were green, so we passed them. When we stopped at the second traffic lights near . . . as you go towards Jacaranda road there are traffic lights there just before that main road. So when we stopped they stopped about ah...I can say about ah..almost ah... about ah...50 to 60 meters away from where we had stopped. I mean every car which is coming from behind if you stopped at traffic lights it is supposed to come near you, close to you, next you to you. They did not do that and Baldwin became suspicious and said why is that car stopping at a far position from where we stopped at the traffic lights. And I said I don't know maybe they are just talking since it was in the night. So we started driving, they started following as well from a distance. When we turned into the main road they also turned. We passed those traffic lights by Mukuba House that new Mukuba House they were green and they were just following us as well and Baldwin increased the speed, from there. That's when he started increasing the speed he said no, he wanted to check if they are following us or not. When he increased the speed that's when they increased the speed as well. He got suspicious and ah..he was scared and said in the night why are they following us? When I increase the speed and they also increase the speed. When we approached towards the traffic lights those central traffic lights they were red but he didn't want to stop to see if they were going to stop. So when he passed they also passed so that's when he increased the speed.

Q: Now you were entering?

Kafuti: The dual carriage way. So when we entered the dual carriage way he increased the speed they also increased the speed. You know that former like.. .Starlight night club? We passed it and that's when they came fast and he went fast as well. So we were going towards that ah.

Q: Underbridge?

Kafuti:...flyover bridge which is at Wusakile that's when I heard something like a bang and he (Baldwin) said that sounds like a gun, are those people shooting at us or not?

Q: Who said?

Kafuti: That's Baldwin and what I said, I said they are definitely shooting at us because they can't be chasing us all the way from town. And just when we passed the . . . we were not very fast but we were going pretty fast since he was running away from those guys. So when we passed the flyover bridge that's when I heard the second shot and that's when I saw him like go in front like he was trapped over something. He just went in front and I saw the car had just lost control. And when I called out: Baldwin are you alright? He didn't answer me. Baldwin are you alright? He didn't answer me and it's when I told Castro that we are going to flip, we are losing control and that car behind was just there, still coming. So we lost control and begun flipping. And when we came to a stand still like everything was done so it was just quiet there was nothing. So I heard that car stop.

Q: Where in front or behind?

Kafuti: No we were on the opposite side. We were like on this other road which going to Ndola so I heard this car stop on the other road because myself I was still alright. So what I did was, I remained there as if I was just out of my mind. Like I didn't know what was happening. They came out I believe and I understand...I am pretty sure I heard two voices saying just check and see if eh..if he is dead and the other boy said he's dead. He's dead alright and these other boys they are just like, they don't seem to be dead but I think they can't remember anything. They don't know anything. I pretended like I was not hearing. And he said he's dead alright. He dead he's a right off. So let's just go. We've done our thing so we have to go back to Lusaka. Even now let's just start off now for Lusaka. That's how I heard the car went...

Q: Were they using English or?

Kafuti: They were using partly English and Nyanja. It was just mixed. So that's when I got up and even saw the BMW just going.

Q: You couldn't get the number?

Kafuti: No, I was bleeding as well and I was just trying to see myself if I was alright.

Q: If you can recall, the few moments from the first shot.

Kafuti: Yes.

Q:What did Castro say. Did you ask Castro anything apart from what you have said?

Kafuti: Castro wasn't say anything.

Q:He was quiet?

Kafuti: Yes

Q: Up to the time you were flipping?

Kafuti: Yes he was still quiet. Even when Baldwin said that sounds like a gun, like a shot, are they shooting at us or not, Castro wasn't answering I am the one who answer. But for me it looked like he was talking to Castro since they were in front together and I answered from behind after some time I said definitely it seems like they are shooting at us. It looks like it is coming towards us like they are coming to attack us or something.

Q: Did Castro meet these people during the day?

Kafuti: Well he went out during the day alone.

Q: You don't know where he went?

Kafuti: I don't know where he went.

Q: Why were you kept at a secret place after your discharge (from hospital)?

Kafuti: After the discharge, I was kept at Jacaranda

Q: In Kitwe?

Kafuti: In Kitwe.

Q: Under guard?

Kafuti: Under guard. There was no one who was allowed to see me.

Q: Why. And who did that?

Kafuti: Why? I don't know where the instructions came from but we were just told that we've been instructed no one is supposed to see you. No newspapers no journalist not anybody is supposed to see you apart from these guys who are here.

Q: For how long were you at Jacaranda?

Kafuti: I was there for a week and a half or two weeks.

Q: In Kitwe?

Kafuti: In Kitwe yes, then I came here at Kabelenga. I spent some time at Kebelenga.

Q: How many . . . how many . . .

Kafuti: I think a week. And I went to Lusaka and I stayed at State House for I think a week then I went and persuaded them that I wanted to go and stay with my sister where I usually stay, in Long Acres.

Q: After you had flipped what can you recall after those people had gone now, what happened?

Kafuti: I remember, after we flipped, when I came out Castro wasn't there at the seat. I looked for him and he wasn't there around the car. So I concentrated on Baldwin, I wanted to see how he was since I had seen him been struck before we flipped. And I went round I saw him like his head was totally smashed on the face and I couldn't even recall his face properly.

Q: Since your release have youn been contacted by anybody in Zambia?

Kafuti: Yes, I have been.

Q: Who?

Kafuti: They don't tell me their names they just pick me up. They park the car. They took me last time. Like last time they came, they didn't tell me who sent them like to pick me up. They just said they came to pick me up.

Q: From where?

Kafuti: From my house, from my sister's house.

Q: To where?

Kafuti: To, there is this house . . .when you're going to . . .I think . . . its President's lane.It's ah . . . a few houses before the eh....there's a brick house . . .there's a few houses before that brick house. That's where they took me. There is that room which has some windows like this but it is just dark you can't see outside and it's dark in the room inside but there is a light. And when they took me inside that room there was a light so, I sat there and they said no, we are coming and they went out. And it's like, it's is a very hard door which is on there and they switched off the light and it was very dark and I couldn't like see anything? I was kept there for about an hour or so. And then I just heard like voices asking me where I am and such things like that and if I remember anything from the accident.

Q: And what did you say?

Kafuti: I didn't say anything. I didn't ask them . . .they asked but I didn't answer them. And after I came out I was like sort of ....like ah... disturbed something like that because I had been kept in the darkness for too long.

Q: Then, after that what happened?

Kafuti: After that is when they like ah . . . they just take me like ah... just for like . . .they just put me in a car . . .they just take me for a ride. When I asked them where we were going they just asked me to shut up and just sit in the car. We just went round and round.

Q: You don't know which cars, registration numbers and so on?

Kafuti: No, they come, sometimes they used to come in ACC . . .what number was that ACC...no AAL 67 . . .49 yes 6749 if I remember very well; 6749. It was a Cressida, an old Cressida like this. In a Maroonish colour. And after wards that's when they just dropped me home. When I go home I never really used to tell my sister this. I used to tell my cousin what was happening. My cousin is the one whom I usually told.

Q: Does your cousin know about all this?

Kafuti: He knew about the accident but I didn't exactly tell him what I've said.

Q: Who else have you told what you are telling us now?

Kafuti: I have not told anyone apart from what I am saying here now.

Q: Eh when you were in State House

Kafuti: Yes.

Q: Did you speak to the President?

Kafuti: I spoke to the president and...

Q: What did he say?

Kafuti: What he said was . . .he didn't even say much. He just said how I am feeling and what I wanted for my health which I wanted him to provide. I said no, if I can see that I am alright, I can appreciate that. And he asked me if I can remember everything from the accident and I said yes I can remember. Definitely I remember everything and what happened at that time.

And he said everything would be taken care of. That was like around September . . .end of September. That was end of September it was a week before end of September he said I will have someone to take you down to South Africa to see a health Inspector and I don't want you to tell anyone about what happened that day what you saw.

Q: That's what he said?

Kafuti: That's what he said. I don't want you...I beg of you not to tell anyone or anybody of what happened, what you know or what you saw.

Q: That's what he said?

Kafuti: That's what he said.

Q: Himself?

Kafuti: Himself I was speaking to him.

Q:In Nkwazi house?

Kafuti: Yes.

Q: I see. Now how was your statement on T.V...what happened did you tell him that you were being taken to the T.V studio?

Kafuti: I was . . . first of all I was eh . . . I was approached by these people who came to say they wanted me to come and testify from Kitwe about the accident. They said before I go I am supposed to go to force headquarters at the police headquarters in Lusaka, the one which is opposite finance... Ministry of Finance. So when I went there these other two officers they just took me in an office and they said that we know exactly what happened that day and what we want you to say is that....we don't want you to say what happened that day. And they gave me a paper and I went through that...eh... It was just unfortunate I didn't make a copy of that paper . . .of what was written. That's why I said on T.V that...

Q: Who wrote that?

Kafuti: I don't know who wrote that.

Q: But they gave it to you to read?

Kafuti: Yes

Q: Who are these people at force headquarters?

Kafuti: Ah...If I check . . . I think I've got it in my old note book. Not the one I've got here. I think it is in Lusaka, the '95 one.

Q: You can't remember them?

Kafuti: No I can't you know these Eastern Province names.

Q: So they are the ones who coached you?

Kafuti: Yes, they told me that all I am going to say is ah. . . what happened is that: I was not going to say there was a car coming from behind...

Q: They told you that?

Kafuti: Yes. I was not going to say I heard shots, and there was nothing like coming in front or forward. I was going to say yeah he was ....okay he didn't appear drunk to me, but I was going to say he was drinking or something like that. Like he kind of looked drunk to me.

Q: Let's get backwards. When you were picked to go to force headquaters, who picked you.

Kafuti: It was ah...no they just brought..They didn't pick me. When they came to look for me I wasn't there so they said no . . . they just left a note to say no, come to force headquarters and come upstairs in room 112 or 115 . . . I don't know.

Q: You can't remember?

Kafuti: I can't remember it was the second floor.

Q: Second floor 112 or 115?

Kafuti: Yes I think it is the intelligence department.

Q: So when you went there?

Kafuti: When I went there that is when I was taken to the room just in the office there. Just in their office. They locked the door and there no one who could come in that is when they gave me the piece of paper.

Q: Okay. Let's get back again. Why has it taken you

so long to say this?

Kafuti: Why it has taken so long for me to say this? Okay fine, they said they would see to it that my . . . I am like ah...they were saying every time I'd be protected but I am not protected you see. Fine. They were saying they will take care of my health, they'd see to it that I am alright and everything my injuries are okay but they haven't done that. And like what I said I don't want . . . I am not just living like a normal life the way I used to do. I am also living in fear. Maybe those same people would just, like maybe, do something just that they make sure that no one gets to know. So what I thought was, if I told someone who was responsible, who will know such things and who would know how to take care of such things. Like if anything had to happen, they would like say something or do something to let the people know so that no one just dies a mysterious death just like that.

Q: So your family does not know?

Kafuti: My family does not know, I haven't told anyone.

Q: Your father, your mother . . . ?

Kafuti: No my father died in 1993.

Q: What type of relationship have you got with Ben Mwila?

Kafuti: He is, Ben Mwila is my uncle he my dad's young brother. And from what I see I think ah . . .

Q: What has he said?

Kafuti: He hasn't said anything to me. I've been there to the house though I was there once, and he was just in the house when I came he was in the bedroom he didn't come out. Twice . . . the other time I went there he wasn't there, there was just my aunt and just some other people.

Q: So what do you . . .

Kafuti (Cutting in): So what I know . . . if it was someone like who didn't know anything like I was just involved in an accident and he wanted to help me, he was going to come forward, you see. He's got money and he was going to come forward and say no, he's my nephew and I'll see to it that he is alright.

So I don't see why everything is just being like . . . (silence).

Q: So he's not helping you?

Kafuti: No, not at all

Q: What about the president what did he promise you?

Kafuti: He promised me that everything would be taken of. Such that I get to stay alright, I have security, and I am taken to South Africa for my medical checks.

Q: So were you taken to South Africa?

Kafuti: No, I wasn't taken.

Q: So what is wrong with you now medically?

Kafuti: Medically, what I feel is like.. even what I was told the doctor sometime from (University Teaching Hospital) UTH is that this..it's my pelvis. First when I was just involved in the accident my pelvis was swollen, like I wasn't able to move this leg and when I started moving this leg it was becoming small and they said it was my ligaments,....there was something wrong with my ligaments. It's like it's even moved inside such that..because it is even shorter than the other if I had to stand up somebody would say there is something wrong with you.

Q: Have been there since?

Kafuti: Yes I have been there, to State House several times to say or ask him or rather to remind him to say why did you say this? I am still waiting and he keeps saying he will get back to me. And when I sometimes go there to see him I don't know if it is his directives to them (State House security) to tell me that I cannot see him from the gate

Q: So you don't go there anymore.

Kafuti: I don't go there, because I just got fed up, you know it was so frustrating..

Q: Can you talk about Castro?

Kafuti: Castro is much better and its not like ah . . . I am not so much like ah . . . really allowed to come into contact with him.

Q: Have you spoken to him since the accident?

Kafuti: Yes I have.

Q: What is his position?

Kafuti: His position is that he is not very . . . alright and he remembers very little.

Q: He remembers very little?

Kafuti: Yes.

Q: What does he remember?

Kafuti: He remembers of . . . like he was just laker and doesn't really know what happened before. I don't know exactly because I haven't really spoken to him where we have to sit down and really...

Q: Where do you think he is right now?

Kafuti: He is South Africa . . . right now he has gone back to South Africa. He was at State House but he has gone back to South Africa for some review.

Q: Do you remember when the last time you went to State House was?

Kafuti: The last time I went to State House was...that time the national (soccer) team came back from South Africa. That's when I went to State House I wanted to speak to him, that was even before the football team got there, I wanted to speak to the president and he told me that I couldn't see him. I said okay fine, If I can't see him can I be allowed to . . . can you ask him maybe if I can be allowed just to see my friend and he said it was not possible.

Q: As of now do you think your life is in danger?

Kafuti: What I think is . . . I don't just think like I am going to live just a normal life after that accident. For I know something was behind that accident I don't think I'll ever just live a normal life. Okay I can live just nicely like this but one day definitely maybe, something will happen.

Q: Are you convinced that Baldwin Nkumbula was murdered?

Kafuti: Pretty sure, because if he wasn't meant to be murdered that car wasn't going to be following us, they were not going to be shooting at us. What I think is that it was made to just look like an accident while I know something else happened.

Q: If we asked you to go to Lusaka, can you identify the car which was following you and also identify the names of the officials whom you saw because you have said you can recognise them if you had to see them?

Kafuti: If I had to see them, If they have to come I can recognise them and if I have to see the car, even if it passed in the street and we happened to be driving in the street I can recognise it.

Q: What kind of vehicle was it?

Kafuti: From?

Q: The same vehicle which was following you?

Kafuti: It was a BMW. A 5 series BMW.

Q: The one used by police?

Kafuti: Yes.

Q: At State House?

Kafuti: Yes. That same colour and it has no semi corvers. They don't really like have corvers.

Q: Lastly what do you wish to put to the Zambia people which you want them to know regarding this?

Kafuti: I would wish that the Zambians had to know the truth from the beginning just when they took me for that same (Commission of) Inquiry. That is where I was meant to say the truth such that everyone was going to be satisfied from that same statement I gave. But even if anybody will say they were satisfied I am not satisfied.

Q: So what you say now is what you wanted the Zambia people to know?

Kafuti: Exactly, exactly.

Q: In short you did not tell the truth during the inquiry because you were promised some things?

Kafuti: Not even that because I was told that I had to read. I had no choice. I had to read. I had to say what was written there.

Q: Which was made from force headquarters?

Kafuti: Yes

Q: Were promised anything and by who?

Kafuti: The President..

Q: Who?

Kafuti: Mr. Frederick Chiluba, the President himself promised he was going to take care of my medicals, he was going to take care of my school fees if I got better because I was meant to go to college.

Q: Which college?

Kafuti: I was meant to go to any college in Lusaka for computer training.

Q: So medicals, school fees, what else?

Kafuti: And he said later on we can like as we go on we can like when I ask for anything that's when he just gives me.

Q: This was a promise after the accident?

Kafuti: Yes.

Q: For you not to say anything?

Kafuti: Yes. Most probably yes.

Q: How did this offer come up. Did you ask for it?

Kafuti: No, he just..when I went there he just found me in the living room and he spoke to me. He told me not to worry about anything because he was going to take care of my medicals, transport and everything.

Q: How do you feel now if...or suppose there was a way ..you were outside and there was an impartial tribunal would you be able to face President Chiluba and tell him what you are just saying here, have you got that courage?

Kafuti: I've got that courage. Even now if it means going there in person and just telling him the truth, I'd do that.

Q: Can you write him a letter to remind him of his promises and so you can have a record because you see it is your word versus the President of the republic and you can see the difficulties you are going through. Can you even remember the dates you saw him or he would claim he has never even seen you?

Kafuti: Yes I can but I can't remember the exact dates. Let me just say it was.. I think it was the week before the end of September. Not exactly but the week before end of September. I was going to be exact if I was writing.

Q: So you are saying because you feel...?

Kafuti: I feel somebody has to know. Someone responsible has to know.

Q: You have not said this to anyone?

Kafuti: I can swear here I haven't said this to anyone.

Q: There was a newspaper story that you had said that we were going to crash, the car is going too fast and you had pulled down Castro's seat?

Kafuti: It was written in the paper but I never said anything. I never spoke to any news reporter any journalist , any ZNBC (Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation) people. I never spoke to anyone but I don't know why that happened to be like I was the one who said it, because I don't know why it was in the paper and I was not allowed to say anything.

Q: So you did not say those things?

Kafuti: I never said and I want to know who directed those words to be writtenn in that paper.

Q: So you never said those words?

Kafuti: I never said that.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

Africa News


September 3, 1996


Business;
Anglo Against Piece-Meal Sale Of Mining Company


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - Though the date for the bidding of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) properties has been set for February 28, reports continue filtering through that the chairman of Anglo American Corporation, Julian Thomson, does not agree with the recommendations of the Rothschild Report.

The report on the privatisation of ZCCM recommends that the conglomerate be unbundled into four units, three mining units, and another unit comprising utilities, including electricity. 

According to sources from the company's London offices, Anglo is of the view that such a structure would lead to a possibility of the mining units having to buy electricity too expensively.

The result has been a protracted round of negotiations between the Zambian government and the largest of its B shareholders in ZCCM - Anglo.

Government sources, however, say Zambia will follow the way given by the Rothschild Report as it shows the best way out of ZCCM's present dilemma of crippling debt burden and inadequate resources.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwean Strike Ends, But Workers Issue Ultimatum


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Striking Zimbabwean civil servants grudgingly returned to work on Wednesday, but union leaders warned the strike will resume unless government opens negotiations on outstanding grievances by Sept. 27.

Thousands of government workers assembled at Harare's Africa Unity square to be briefed by members of the unified civil service negotiating committee on the outcome of Tuesday's marathon talks with public service, labor and social welfare minister, Florence Chitauro.

Similar briefings were held in various centers throughout the country, with large turnouts reported in Bulawayo, Mutare and Gweru. 

Chitauro told a news conference on Tuesday that cabinet had rescinded an order dismissing the workers who staged the 16-day strike that crippled essential government services. She also threatened to dismiss all workers who would not have returned to work by Wednesday.

The government last week conceded it had erred by awarding the majority of the 161,000 civil servants less than 10 percent in salary increases and agreed to add another 20 percent.

However, the civil servants were not happy with the government decision to withhold pay for the period they had been on strike.

"As a committee we are extremely disappointed. We are saying how can they take money from us when they know that we are already poorly paid," said Farai Jiya, a member of the negotiating committee, when addressing the workers.

He said the committee was also disappointed cabinet had not seen the urgency of the need to address workers grievances outlined in a seven-point document submitted to Chitauro.

The seven demands included increases in various allowances, a unified labor law encompassing all workers, including civil servants, and a 40-hour working week with anything beyond that being treated as overtime.

However, Jiya said the committee felt it was prudent to stage a strategic retreat by going back to work and then come back in full force along with the teachers after schools have opened, should government fail to open negotiations on outstanding issues. Schools open on Sept. 10.

"The seven demands put us on the streets. It is the seven demands that will get us back on the streets. We are giving them until 27 September to start negotiations on those demands. On that day we will report back to you," Jiya told the workers.

However, as the meeting broke up in disorder with the majority of workers apparently disappointed, the leaders continued to exhort the workers to return to work.

Some in the crowd shouted that the strike should continue until all demands are met by the government.

Others said the strike had been a failure as it had resulted in them losing half their salaries for the past month.

Analysts have put the cost of the strike at over Zimdollars 1 billion (100 million U.S. dollars) in uncollected government revenue, while hundreds of people could have died due to lack of care in government hospitals.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Ghana;
Accra's Kotoka Airport Expansion Project Due To Start


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - The second phase of Accra's Kotoka International Airport rehabilitation and development project will begin this year, the country's Transport and Communications minister, Edward Selia, said here Wednesday.

Speaking at the commissioning of the airport's passenger transit lounge, closed circuit television equipment and two fire tenders, Selia said the project would start with the reconstruction and refurbishing of facilities within and outside the terminal building at the cost of about 65 million U.S. dollars. 

He said the project will involve the doubling of floor space in the arrival and departure areas, and installation of new and long baggage conveyer belts.

The expansion will provide decent accommodation or holding area to minimize human congestion in front of the passenger terminal building.

A dedicated cargo aircraft apron in front of the cargo warehouse to take about four wide-bodied aircraft will also be constructed.

The minister said the capacity of the cargo warehouse will be increased by 50 percent and feasibility studies will be conducted to extend the runway.

Under the rehabilitation project, there will be duty free shops and an " airport city" complex will be developed.

The minister said there are more projects in the pipeline to make Ghanaian airports reflect "the new image of Ghana as the peaceful and investment haven. "

Phase one of Kotoka International Airport's development project was completed three years ago with financial assistance from the Overseas Development Administration of United Kingdom and support from the government.

In that phase, the major project component included the resurfacing of the runway, provision of visual aids, remodeling and expansion of the arrival and departure halls, refurbishment of the control tower and the construction of a dedicated freight terminal.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Business;
Zambia's Copper Mine Records Profit


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines limited (ZCCM) has reported an operating profit of k59,972 million (1,200 = 1 U.S. dollar) in the first quarter that ended June 30 this year.

A ZCCM report published in Lusaka Wednesday said the profit was higher than the k57,623 million recorded during the corresponding quarter of 1995. 

The document said the company made a net profit of k14,676 million compared with k12,051 million in the same period of 1995 after taking into account exchange losses, interest, taxation charges and other factors.

"The average sales realization for copper at k2.715 million per ton for the quarter, was 19 percent higher than the k2.275 million per ton realized in the corresponding quarter of 1995."

This has been attributed to the depreciation of the kwacha since the average copper price achieved for the quarter was US $ 2,226 per ton.

According to the report, the market experienced a significant drop in London metal exchange prices during the quarter from 2,841 dollars per ton on May 9 this year to 1,830 dollars per ton on June 27 and remains uncertain.

Meanwhile, cobalt sales increased to k59.546 million per ton for the quarter that ended June 30 compared to k49.745 million per ton realized in the similar quarter of the 1995.

Revenue from the sales of precious metals amounted to k300 million during the quarter compared to sales of k819 million during the corresponding period of the previous year.

The Zambian government has appointed consultants to come up with recommendations on how best to privatize the ZCCM under its ongoing economic liberalization programme.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Business;
British Airways Mistreats Passengers, Then Offers Free Tickets


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - British Airways, after admitting as "unacceptable" its treatment of London-bound passengers from Lusaka, has, instead of giving meaningful compensation, offered them "a free ticket to a destination of their choice anywhere in our network in the world".

The "free" tickets are not redeemable for cash, as is usually the case in such offers. 

The more than 200 passengers were delayed for 24 hours at Lusaka International airport on Saturday. They spent Saturday night in the plane as it could not take off because it developed a fault.

Arrangements to take them to hotels to eat were only made after mid-day Sunday. Irate passengers could not understand why British Airways did not book them in a hotel as per aviation regulations.

Some of the passengers accused the airline of racist treatment because the extended delay happened on an African route. But the British Airways officials denied this.

However, an official of the airline regretted what he referred to as "this series of events which were recognized as unacceptable for an airline which prides itself on providing the highest levels of customer service.".

To compensate the passengers for being virtual prisoners in the plane for 24 hours, he offered "every passenger on board a free ticket to a destination of their (sic) choice anywhere on our network in the world."

The passengers, who left Lusaka for London 9.00 p.m. (19:00GMT) on Sunday after the 24-hour delay, were met on arrival at Gatwick Airport by British Airway's head of customer relations, Richard Hill, and other members of staff who offered assistance and apologies.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
