Africa News


September 4, 1996


Kenya;
Iran Urges Support For Non-Aligned Movement


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - Visiting Iranian President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani has urged support to the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM).

He also called for the restructuring of the United Nations into a "neutral and democratic" organisation.

"The important responsibility of our two countries makes it necessary to put further emphasis on the survival of NAM, the democratic restructuring of the UN and presenting a logical and neutral interpretation of the relation between human rights and culture, religion and social traditions of developing countries," Rafsanjani said at a state dinner in Nairobi on Tuesday. 

He noted that many developing countries were not satisfied with the " discriminatory treatment and double standards" of some industrialized countries particularly in areas of human rights.

The rich countries, he added, were using the United Nations as an instrument with which to pursue their own political objectives in the non- aligned and poor nations by exerting undue pressure.

Speaking at another function, Rafsanjani, who toured the Kenyan Petroleum Refineries and the port of Mombasa, said his government was developing a friendly policy toward Africa, and will boost its investments in the continent.

He said his government was determined to penetrate the African continent to stop its exploitation by the "covetous West", adding that his current trip to east and southern Africa was just the beginning of the new thrust.

Rafsanjani promised increased trade ties and exchange of information with Iran's new African partners, whom he said had suffered since colonialism from unfair relationships.

"Iran has made tremendous strides in all forms of academic and industrial research and is willing to share her experiences with Africa in the brotherly spirit of Islam."

Kenya's president, Daniel Arap-Moi, urged greater cooperation between Iran and his country, saying Iran could benefit from Kenya's tourism and agro- based industries, while Kenya had a lot to gain from the latter's energy and transport sectors. "The push for such ties is more evident now in the face of current trends that seem to slow down the efforts of developing countries toward faster and sustained economic development," Moi said.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
OAU Urges Non-Aligned Nations To Make Information A Priority


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria - The OAU Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, has urged developing nations to accord the information and communication sector priority in their national development plans, if they are to achieve the desired breakthrough.

"Unless we keep our populations informed and fully involved, we would be far from realizing the desired objectives we seek to sustain," he said in a message to the ongoing conference of information ministers of the non-aligned countries in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.

Identifying the information sector as "very crucial to development," Salim urged the conference to "address in all frankness, the problems and envisaged bottlenecks and to draw realistic and implementable plans." 

Salim noted that "the world of communication has become another super-power. "

The developing countries, he added, should act swiftly together in response to the rapidly changing information technologies or "we shall be left behind in the cold gaping at the spinning space revolution brought about by the new information super-highway."

In addition, Salim named such challenges as "cultural invasion, legislation affecting the mass media, the right to know and access to information, media for democracy programme, media in conflict resolution, freedom of speech and how to nurture it, and the mass media, as a partner in nation-building."

To achieve a desirable new world information order, he advocated effective south-south cooperation, regional initiatives and the pooling of resources.

But he lamented the plight of inter-governmental media agencies, such as the Dakar-based Pan African News Agency, which he said, were usually starved of funds.

"The lesson to draw from this is that poorly funded intergovernmental news agencies should perhaps be better managed by the private sector."

PANA, the continental wire service set up by the OAU in 1979, is undergoing financial crisis, due to non-payment of assessed contributions by many member- countries.

Staff of the agency have not received salary for several months now.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Delta Gold Explores More Minerals In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Delta Gold NL, the Australian partner in Zimbabwe's largest mining venture, has said it is pursuing other mineral exploration activities in the southern African country.

In a report, Delta Gold said over 6.7 million zimdollars (670,000 U.S. dollars) would be spent on evaluation of new platinum deposits in the Mhondoro area, while metallurgical work on another platinum venture was in progress. 

Delta Gold said a geotechnical assessment of the areas selected for mining studies in the Ngezi Platinum area had already begun to determine the mineable areas and suitable mining methods.

"Metallurgical test work is in progress. Preliminary studies on hydrology, socio-economics and power supply have commenced," said the company Wednesday.

Other exploration was being carried out in the Kwekwe mining area, as well as north-east of Bulawayo, where Delta said several geophysical diamond targets had been identified.

Delta's Zimbabwe subsidiary, Masasa Mines, had also identified gold sites in Shamva and had taken a six-month option in the liquidated Kamativi tin mine.

The company has 33 percent share in the 260-million-U.S-dollar Hartley Platinum Venture, near Harare, currently Zimbabwe's single largest mining venture.

Delta Gold, together with another Australian conglomerate, BHP Minerals, hope to start commercial platinum production early 1997.

The company said total expenditure at Hartley Platinum as of June 30, 1996, was 200 million U.S. dollars and more than 229 million dollars had been committed as of that date.

"Final capital cost remains in line with the forecast of 2.64 billion Zimdollars (264 million dollars)," said the company.

Among other projects at Hartley, Delta said final purchases were being made on items required for the base metal refinery and technicians were focussing on the refinery and deploying more resources to speed-up construction.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Lay Empowerment A Major Concern For African Churches


BYLINE: Osman Njuguna, APS Writer, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

Nairobi - Should lay people be empowered to make greater contribution to the Christian ministry? If yes, how can the church achieve this goal? These are some of the concerns that confront the church in Africa today as it grows in numbers and is besieged by the countless challenges facing the continent's ordinary people.

According to a Ugandan church minister, the church in Africa can hardly ignore any discussion on the laity given that the latter comprise 90 per cent of the entire faithful in any given church.

Since "the laity accounts for the larger part of the church, with the clergy representing a minority, there is need to empower the former for greater and wider pastoral contribution," says the Ugandan clergy.

The Uganda Anglican church minister is the Executive Secretary of the pan- African Association of Christian Lay Centres in Africa (ACLCA), which marks its silver jubilee in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare from October 6 to 13 this year.

Founded in 1970, the ACLCA currently brings together 63 lay centres in 24 African countries. The centres seek to share ideas and adopt common strategies for action to fulfil together their common vision to the glory of one Father, Son and Holy Spirit. 

"The silver jubilee will help to prepare the centres for the year 2000 in the spirit of worship, binding together spiritually and the commitment to restoring right and just relationships in the human community," Rev. Katoneene told APS. The occasion, he says, will be a commitment to the keep the spirit of ACLCA for the next 25 years towards the golden jubilee and beyond.

Rev. Katoneene says the silver jubilee celebrations will be based on the biblical concept of jubilee, especially in the Book of Leviticus 25, which emphasises restoration, not just merry making. He sees the forthcoming celebrations as an opportunity to strike a balance between joy and a critical reflection on the life, mission, work and witness of the ACLCA, particularly as the 21st century approaches.

Rev. Kotoneene also sees in the silver jubilee an occasion to raise issues of justice, peace and reconciliation. It will also be a continuing process of redefining the vision of the African Christian centres in a continent full of oppression, conflict, hunger, illiteracy and deprivation.

A brochure announcing the ACLCA October assembly talks of major workshops including one for youth and women. The fora will reflect on the political, social cultural and economic implications of human rights, church as a healing ministry to the vulnerable, ethnicity, gospel and culture, HIV-AIDS, environmental abuse and homelessness among other concerns.

According to Rev. Katoneene, more than 100 persons are scheduled to attend the silver jubilee celebrations. These will include official delegates from ACLCA members, fraternal delegates from partner organizations such as the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), the World Council of Churches (WCC), the Africa regional office of the World Students Christian Federation (WSCF) and the Africa office of the Young Men's/Women's Christian Association (YMCA/YWCA).

The Ugandan clergy says the ACLCA celebrations will be a time to look at the strength, successes and weaknesses of the association under the common mission of leadership training, laity formation, and ecumenical learning.

Rev. Katoneene describes the main objective of the ACLCA as the promotion of contacts and the development of a common purpose between lay training centres in Africa, encouraging common planning and deepening the church's responsibility in the world.

The pan-African religious body also aims to strengthen the centres' programmes through closer fellowship, sharing of experiences, exchange of staff and/or students. It also encourages and co- ordinates research and study of common tasks, arranges joint training for staff and leaders in an effort to develop present and future ecumenical leaders and fosters dialogue between people of different faiths.

The ACLCA also produces materials and information related to lay training, offers advisory services in establishing and developing lay training activities in Africa, strengthens links with similar associations in other continents and works in close consultation with national Christian councils.

He told APS that one of the challenges facing ACLCA is the strengthening of the ecumenical spirit among the lay centres. "Currently we have only two Catholic centres as full members of the association. We would like to see more joining us for the common goal of empowering the role of the laity in Christian development," stressed the association's Executive Secretary.

On ACLCA's experiences in the last 25 years of existence, Rev. Katoneene said the lay centres' movement has trained more clergy than laity. "This trend will need to be reversed and we take it as one of the major challenges ahead of us," he noted.

Elsewhere, the father-in-charge of Kenya's metropolitan parish of the Holy Family Basilica, Nairobi, Fr. Anthony D'Souza, said highlighting concerns about the place of the laity in the church should not be misconstrued as some form of revolution.

"The fact that some of the lay people today carry out roles that they did not perform in the past, does not simply mean there is some kind of revolution doing rounds in the church. I would like to see the move as a spiritual development in God's kingdom," he told APS.

As part of the programme approved in 1992 by the head of the Nairobi Catholic Archdiocese Maurice Cardinal Otunga, the parish has already admitted four lay people to distribute the Holy Eucharist during mass at the Holy Family Basilica church. Fr. D'Souza describes the inclusion of the lay as a recognition of "talents within the vineyard."

Bishop Njeru Wambugu of Kenya's Independent Church of Africa, one of the independent churches in the country, commenting on empowering the lay people for greater contribution to the Christian ministry, says the mainstream churches are now recognizing the crucial role lay people play in ministry.

Adds Bishop Wambugu who is also the General Secretary of the Organization for African Instituted Churches (OAIC); "There is some push coming from the lay people in most of these churches, challenging the churches to admit them in their decision and policy making spheres."

For Zairean church minister, Ngoy Mulunda-Nyanga, who is also the Executive Secretary for the unit of

International Affairs at the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), the current struggle for democratic rights in Africa calls for the need to empower laity in their own churches.

If individuals fighting for their democratic rights in the political arena are the same Christians in church, then the church cannot escape the blame if it fails to stand up to the challenge of the ministry, adds Rev. Mulunda.

Eva Chipenda, the wife of the AACC General Secretary, Rev. Jose Chipenda, says empowering the laity fits in the context of the church in Africa more than in other regions because, the ordained lot can hardly cope with the pastoral needs of the Christian community.

Mrs. Chipenda summarizes her concerns thus; "One cannot expect the same clergy to be everywhere-burying the dead, distributing food to the hungry, healing the diseased and preaching the Word of God among other demands in the line of duty. He/she needs an extra hand and this can be provided by a well trained and prepared lay person."

Mr. Charles Koech, the Education Secretary for the Catholic Bishops Conference in Kenya, says contrary to general assumptions, the Catholic church in the country is not falling behind in the process of empowering laity.

He gave as an example the programme of building Small Christian Communities (SCCs), instituted in 1976 by bishops in Eastern and Central Africa as a case at hand.

Under their Association of Member Episcopal Conferences in Eastern Africa (AMECEA) the region's Catholic church leaders set up the SCCs programme in the church's desire to come closer to the people by placing most responsibilities in the hands of the laity, Mr. Koech explained.

In his book, Ecclesia in Africa (The Church in Africa) published in 1995 and dedicated to the bishops, priests, deacons, men and women religious and all the lay faithful on the African continent, Pope John Paul II says of the laity and political leadership; "We have not always done what we could in order to form the laity for life in society, to a Christian vision of politics and economics." A protracted absence of the lay faithful from this field had led them to believe that the faithful has nothing to do with politics, the Catholic pontiff regrets.

Among one of the many recommendations by the 6th General Assembly of the AACC, held in Harare, Zimbabwe in October 1992, was a resolution that the laity should be educated to appreciate creation. Creation theology and its practical implications, the AACC assembly stressed, must be introduced in the curricula of all theological colleges.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


63 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Are Women Merely Pawns In The Ecumenical Debate?


BYLINE: Florence Bamanyaki, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

Nairobi - Most existing world religions are patriarchal and define women as either inferior or surbodinate to men. Christianity, only until recently with a few exceptions, denies women the right to hold religious office.

Gradually, this status quo has generated a growing interest in questions relating to the place of women in Church and society. History on the other hand, demonstrates clearly the practice of discrimination against women in church and society.

With all due respect to the holy Book of Christian worship, feminists are concerned about the role and teaching of the Bible in Christian communities. Reading the Bible creates an awareness of the need to re-interpret many of its passages in the light of new experiences. 

Of concern it is not only what the Bible says, but how its message has been translated from a gender perspective to a gender sensitive language.

Much study has been going on regarding the language used in teaching, preaching and ritual. The repetition of prayers, hymns and scriptural passages which consistently refer to Christians as brothers or men and to God as He inculcates an idea that God is only male.

Last September, a new Bible entitled, The New Testament and Psalms: An Inclusive Version, was published in the United States of America with an attempt to appear more gender sensitive and less racial by eliminating references to God as Father or Son of man who is now referred to as the Human One in that translation. It was edited by Susan Brooks of the Chicago Theological Seminary and five other editors.

What is more interesting is the new translation of the Lord's Prayer; "Our Father, Mother who art in heaven. However in an interview with APS Mr. Jack O. Nandi, a leading scholar in religion argues that the Lord's prayer was handed down from Jesus Christ Himself hence it is original and without bias.

This, undoubtedly is the height of "feminist theology." But women have tried to bring out some changes to achieve a more inclusive language for the worshippers; men and women, sisters and brothers or inclusive terms like, people of God or Saints of God.

A renowned women's rights activist and Christian in Uganda, Ms. Maria Matembe says the (Book of) Genesis story on the creation of man and woman spells out the fact that man and woman should work side by side, that the story is not meant to exclude women from certain forms of ministry in the church.

Ms. Matembe is emphatic that the woman was not extracted from Adam's foot to be trampled on but from his side as a sign of equality and companionship.

The ordination of 100 women as priests at an international convention of women pastors in Kenya's Lake Victoria port town of Kisumu recently, can hardly go unnoticed at a time when women Christians are calling for the rectification of the men to women ratio in church leadership.

The August 14 to 17 forum organized by women from the Voice of Salvation and Healing Church in Eastern Africa and the US-based International Gospel Centre (IGC), among other concerns called for a proper interpretation of the Bible saying "...tradition and culture are not always Bible-based and should not be a basis for discrimination against women. Theological and historical debates are mustered both to deny and support the claims of women's ordination.

But one strong indicator against women's ordination remains the role and symbolic function of Christ in the ministry - the fact that Christ is the priest and the people he assigned to continue His good work were men, the 12 disciples. Further on, the teachings of the apostles like Paul seem to place women anywhere short of being ordained as priests.

The Assistant to the General Secretary of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) the Rev. Phylis Byrd, says the fact that priesthood is still very male dominated is a big challenge. Ordained in 1986, Rev. Phylis Byrd feels that women have "unique gifts to offer in the ministry." These include compassion which women can give out without any restrictions. Not that men do not have compassion, she adds, but society demands that they do not show compassion, especially publicly, as it might be a threat to their masculinity.

On the question of gender sensitive language in the Bible, Rev. Byrd, an African-American, is of the opinion that the question of the use of He or She is a grammatical issue only existent in the English language and not in the African languages. Besides, God is spirit so the question of gender does not arise.

For the General Secretary of the AACC, Rev. Jose Chipenda, the issue of women's ordination should not arise, what should be an issue is "how many women are already doing pastoral work?"

Rev. Chipenda, who hails from the Evangelical Congregational Church in Angola, believes that one does not have to be ordained to do God's work. What matters is if a woman is chosen as a leader of some sort in the church and she is recognized as a pastor when she is entitled to it. For such a person, says Rev. Chipenda, a space is being created for her to do more of what she does privately.

Christian feminists have little problem with the historical and symbolic figure of Christ. Their concern is that to deny women priesthood is to oppress and diminish them and at the same time impoverish the Christian community.

The AACC women's desk, established in 1987, is involved in empowering Christian women in Africa in reconstruction and development. According to the desk's consultant, Dr. Christine Sadia, in the absence of a clear-cut policy on women's ordination, women who are called to serve God should be encouraged to be involved in church leadership.

Women are very comfortable identifying themselves with the role of comforter, advocate, counsellor intercessor, helper, the principle of love and unity and the giver of life. Thus they will bring special talents to enrich the ministry. Besides, it is also the work of women on a human level.

While the issue of women's ordination is somewhat favourably received in most Protestant circles, the Orthodox and Roman Catholic churches do not ordain women.

In terms of numbers, these churches contain nearly three fifths of the Christian population worldwide. The question of ordination of women is often presented as an obstacle to greater unity among Christians.

But the question remains; Are women's legitimate aspirations and hopes to live their Christian life to the full to bear witness to the spirit in all the ministries of the church, simply to be ignored in order to achieve the unity of men and male dominated institutions?

The church has to acknowledge and recognize the seriousness of pastoral problems that the women's movement represents. Women no longer feel at home in a community whose leaders are all male humanity in the norm. The symbols of traditional Christianity have become empty for them. The church must treat the feminist movement with requisite theological seriousness and with all theological resources at hand.

The theological resources of the church should be mobilized to fashion a theology based on personhood. The perception of women in the church belongs to the long list of the publicly opposed exploitation of the weak by the strong, highlighting among others Blacks, Jews, children and the physically and materially handicapped.

One by one, all these forms of oppression have been exposed and are now generally regarded as morally unacceptable. Similar concerted efforts should go towards the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women in the church.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Prophetic Role Of Church In Africa Put To Test


BYLINE: Joseph K'Amolo, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1920 words


 

Nairobi (APS - More than any other world region, Africa has indeed experienced splendid growth in Christianity. In 1900 the continent had 8 million Christians, who included 2.5 million Protestants, representing 10 per cent of the region's population. By 1990, this figure had shot to 275 million, about 57 per cent of the entire population then.

Considering this increase, one would be forgiven for painting Africa as a place where Christian religious norms prevail. Contrary to this expectation, the continent is still gripped by evil deeds and pockets of it are simmering with a hate spirit.

No wonder the President of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Ghana, the Rt. Rev. Dr. Paul Kofi Fynn, once charged that many Africans have not felt the spiritual impact of the Christian growth. 

Rev. Fynn is not alone in his observation. Equally disturbed by the unfolding events in Africa amidst the unmatched growth in the number of those who profess Christianity, is the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) Coordinator of the Church Growth and Evangelism desk and Christian Education Rev. Chalton Ochola.

Rev. Ochola questions the growth of African Christianity, asserting that it has been quantitative and not necessarily reflecting quality.

He says the church has the mandate to mould the society by living according to the Gospel but regrets that it appears to have failed in this mission. And emphasizes that the church as a role model in the society, should work to influence growth and "love should be the core and pillar to effect this influence."

The clergy says Christian teaching is about selflessness, self- sacrifice, humility, forgiveness and pity, adding that love crowns them all. Love, according to the NCCK coordinator should not be limited to fellow human beings but should also be extended to all creation including the environment.

Rev. Ochola talks of a church that is influenced by the secular world as compared to one that influences the secular world, and qualifies this statement by citing un-Christian conduct that is witnessed not only in the secular world but also in the church.

A quick example he gives is the 1994 killings in Rwanda, whereby some church leaders were implicated. These clerics compromised their prophetic role and sided with individual ethnic groups in the widely publicised massacres which pitted the majority Hutu against the Tutsi, says the Kenyan clergy.

A book entitled THE ANGELS HAVE LEFT US, by Canadian journalist Hugh McCullum, apparently derived its name from the words of a Catholic Tutsi girl who survived the massacre in a church in Ntarama, southern Rwanda.

The irony of it all is that it was in Rwanda and neighbouring Burundi where the East African Revival Movement began in the late 1920s, reaching a climax in 1939 before it was embraced in Uganda

followed by Tanzania and Kenya in 1942/43. Rev. Ochola says he finds it difficult to reconcile the spiritual awakening in the Central African region then and the aftermath of the 1994 ethnic flare-up in Rwanda and the ethnic killings still going on in Burundi.

At home in Kenya, Rev. Ochola is baffled by the leadership feudings that have been going on in some churches particularly his Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK)-Anglican.

Against this background, he calls for the church to be liberated from all sorts of evil including immorality, materialism and tribalism. "The church needs to be transformed and renewed. It should review its mandate to be the salt of the earth and light of the world," he cautions.

Rev. Ochola regrets that although most church buildings in Africa are filled to capacity every Sunday, projecting a scenario of solidarity and other virtues as exemplified by Christ, the faithful's observance of Bible teachings outside the Sabbath do not reflect true Christian witness.

Vices such as embezzlement of public funds abound in many African states, yet the majority of leaders in these countries are Christians whose attendance at church every Sunday has become a public event. Political instability, mismanagement of the economy, social unrest and cultural brainwashing are common features in our countries.

On nepotism, deeply ingrained particularly in the public sector, Rev. Ochola advocates for church and church-related organizations which reflect a balanced tribal representation, especially those based in cosmopolitan centres.

"If one tribe tends to dominate such places in all categories of employment from managerial level to subordinate staff, then something is very wrong," Rev. Ochola quips. And wonders: "On what ground or moral justification can the church then question the state about tribalism or its lack of gender sensitivity?"

Christ wants the church to apply His words to the whole life. This means that preaching of the word should not be limited to spiritual matters but also issues relating to justice, peace, prosperity and material well-being of the people.

But Rev. Ochola goes further to say that Christians, and especially those in leadership positions should live exemplary lives and desist from exploiting cheap labour or oppressing those that work under them since by doing so, they display a negative perspective of what a Christian life should be.

He attributes the negative and anti-Christian behaviour displayed by some clergy to lack of spiritual commitment and to an extent rampant unemployment, which has pushed some people to priesthood only as a means of earning a living and not as a calling to this noble vocation.

Priesthood, Rev. Ochola says, still remains a vocation which should carry with it some element of sacrificing, whether salaried or not. "As God's representatives and servants, church leaders should reflect the very being and character of God who is blameless, just, righteous and loving," he advises.

Rev. Ochola's assertion is similar to that of Rt. Rev. Fynn, who, quoting Lord Pober, says: "How do you say you love me, when you are not aware of my sufferings.?"

Critical minds that have rubbed shoulders with some church leaders have expressed disillusionment with the church following the kind of attitude exhibited by some of those they have worked with away from the pulpit.

Owing to many unfortunate incidents in Africa including calamities like famine, drought and disease, many people have sometimes dismissed the region as a cursed continent while others have even doubted the very presence of God.

However, John Tusa, in an article appearing in Index on Censorship Vol.25 4/1996 explains that God has always been there, spurring the church to act effectively in its role of prophetic witness.

He contends that Christians are sometimes put to the supreme test of faith. This is what was witnessed in South Africa as now retired Archbishop Desmond Tutu discovered when faced with the unbelievable atrocity of the 1977 murder of African nationalist Steve Biko at the height of the liberation struggle, when the former cried aloud: "Is God here at all?"

Nevertheless, religion cannot be blamed for all evils but it is there to nurture good and a God-fearing attitude. Argues Tusa, lack of religious ingredient or just superficial application of it to ethical teaching leaves a breeding ground for evil behaviour.

Rev. Ochola appreciates that Africans are notorious religious but their faith is very superficial. He blames this superficiality on the evils that have besieged the continent. "Christianity has never taken root in Africa," he quips.

Other African critics identify the Christian religion with imperialism, arguing that it was used as a means to pacify Africans while the colonizers exploited their resources for personal enrichment. They say early evangelism while being used to liberate people from the domain of the devil also became an ideal tool to colonize, featuring the cross and the flag as one, much like the gun and the Bible.

But inspite of all these evils there is still hope. "He will never leave us without a witness even though evils seem to multiply. God is still God and if Christians can live practical lives according to the Gospel teaching, then there is enormous opportunity of transforming Africa," says Rev. Ochola.

Rev. Fynn shares similar sentiments of hope but castigates the preaching of the Gospel, saying this has changed only to suit people's physical needs, making it have no spiritual impact. Most pastors only preach sermons that help no one, he laments.

Elsewhere, Rev. Fynn is quoted rebuking the church in Ghana for concentrating on acquiring ill-gotten wealth and looking out for members who can assist them with money.

The scenario in Ghana is not news, it is played in many other African countries. Many churches are accused of hypocrisy as they look for wealth instead of worshipping God, a development that has made them lose touch with members.

Featuring the Church in Ghana, Africanews (July 15, 1996) says churches there seem to have put aside their mission of winning souls and turned to winning material wealth, in a setting where only the rich are being elected to Church councils.

The church seems to have closed its eyes to the welfare of its members as it has not developed any system to assist its majority poor who remain vulnerable, an attitude Tusa sums up as self- gratification.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Women Theologians Challenge Church Leaders


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Nairobi - Although the African woman in the church today has more awareness about her rights in the pastoral service, gender discrimination from the church leadership remains a stumbling block to her advancement.

Presenting a paper, Celebrating God's Transforming Power, during a week- long pan-African conference for African women theologians here , Kenyan theologian, Dr. Musimbi Kanyoro, wondered "what men mean when they call our initiated agenda women's issues."

"What exactly does such a terminology communicate?" posed Dr. Kanyoro to 100 African women theologians, whose discussions were centred on the theme, Transforming Power: Women in the Household of God.

The meeting was organised under the Circle of Concerned African Women Theologians Association (CCAWTA). 

The Kenyan theologian, who is currently the Executive Secretary for the Women in Church and Society programme of the Geneva-based Lutheran World Federation (LWF) wondered whether universally, people understood the so- called women's issues and what role these concerns played.

According to Dr. Kanyoro, there is a tendency in some African societies to refer to any agenda initiated by women as "women's issues". This naming, she stressed, defines those concerns as women's business with little or no relevance to men.

"We, the Circle women consider the issues that we address in our theology as societal issues and we seek to see the transforming power of God present in every man and woman, young and old, such that change for the betterment of all humanity in Africa can become a reality, experienced by all, not just us," Dr. Kanyoro stressed.

Challenging the men in Africa to take their place beside women, transforming societies according to God's power as opposed to men's power, Dr. Kanyoro added; "Both men and women are like the two wings of a bird..Both are needed to be able to fly."

The LWF programme executive noted that women's issues will only become an integral part of the church's prophetic voice when the church realizes that sexism is a sin that requires confession and repentance.

Illiteracy, poverty, lack of access to health care, violence against women, under representation of women in decision making circles are societal problems, which adversely affect the lives of women, but these in themselves are by no means issues of women only.

And the CCAWTA does not represent an exclusive theology of women, but one in which African women are claiming the power to name the agenda and bring to the theological table issues that drastically impact on the lives of women and need to be addressed by the larger community, said Kanyoro.

Noting that the African women are new in the formal study of theology, Dr. Kanyoro emphasized, for "theology to become inclusive of us, it must begin to look different."

According to Dr. Kanyoro, one has to dig a little deeper to understand what impact institutional expectation has on women who enter in previously male fields. In theology, she explained, the same fear exists for women, who may use terms such as Feminist Theology or Womanist Theology to describe their framework.

These terms are different from what has been established by male theologians, who were first in the field. It is for these reasons, that they are not so well accepted in communities both by women and men, explained the Kenyan theologian.

She observed that it has been sown in the minds of our societies that to call any concern or anybody feminist is to identify that person or cause with rebelliousness, foreign principles and even a dislike for men. "Hence in order to survive, feminine styles brought in by women have to be discarded or rejected," she added.

Dr. Kanyoro lamented that many sectors including the church are not prepared to change in order to accommodate women. "The gates look wide open but rules for entering have not changed in the least. The consequences of this is the creation of an unhealthy environment for women," she added.

Thus, the African woman in theology can no longer just call for the opportunity to participate in the process but should be part of a redefining and redesigning process, understanding very clearly that what women are calling for is radical change.

"Hence we may have to say that one of the tasks of the Circle is to help change the structures of our churches so that women will no longer be at a disadvantage," Dr. Kanyoro stressed.

She also called for the eradication of African traditional values which continue to militate against women, citing among them female circumcision.

The conference opening was marked by the launching of two major books, Groaning in Faith and Violence Against Women, both written and edited by members of the CCAWTA.

The book launching was presided over by renowned Ghanaian theologian Dr. Mercy Oduyoye and was witnessed by among others, the head of the Theology department of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) Prof. Jesse Mugambi.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


66 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Sudan;
Norwegian Agency Confirms Release Of Clergy In Sudan


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

NAIROBI - Norwegian People's Aid (NPA), an NGO working in southern Sudan has confirmed the release of six foreign missionaries held by the rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) in Marpourdit near Akot near Bahrel Ghazal in south- western Sudan.

Graham Wood, a spokesman for the NPA said their man on the ground at Akot, Mr. Dan Eiffe, an Irish national had facilitated the release of the missionaries on August 28. A NPA plane reportedly left north- western Kenya for southern Sudan on August 28 and it was expected to pick the three sisters, two priests and a brother from Marpourdit where they have been running a parish primary school for 1,500 children and a medical dispensary. 

"We understand they are free to move about as they wish, but chose to stay on at Marpourdit," Mr. Wood told APS.

The six missionaries are Sister Moir Lynch, 73, Australian, Sister Mary Batchelor, 68, also Australian, Father Michael Barton, 48, an American, Father Michael Riel, 48, Sudanese - the Vicar General of Rumbek Diocese, Sister Maureen Grey, 52, Australian, and Brother Raniero Iacomella 26, Italian. The first four missionaries listed were actually held in Row Prison in the area while Sister Maureen and Brother Raniero were held in the compound of their mission.

Monsignor Caesar Mazzolari, Apostolic Administrator of Rumbek Diocese and Father Sesana Kizito of the Sudanese Catholic Information Office in Nairobi, told APS, the missionaries were seized at daybreak on August 17 when the mission was surrounded by SPLA fighters.

Both Monsignor Mazzolari and Father Kizito flew from Nairobi to Marpourdit on August 23 and were allowed to see but not to talk to the imprisoned missionaries. "We were allowed to see them for less than two minutes. I am sorry they were treated as if they were dangerous criminals," lamented Father Kizito.

The local SPLA commander cited three reasons for the arrest of the missionaries: That they had obstructed the recruitment of youth in their ranks; They spied for the regime in Khartoum; They were spreading Islam under the guise of the cross.

"These are ridiculous charges. I think the local commander has grudges against the church," said Father Kizito. He said there was an informal arrangement that the SPLA would not recruit students at the mission school.

George Garang, a senior official of the SPLA in Nairobi said they deeply regretted the misunderstanding. He said the delay in releasing the missionaries was due to poor communication with field commanders in Marpourdit.

Indeed, according to Mr. Wood, the NPA initially got involved because of their communication facilities that enhanced the negotiation process.

The NPA supports agriculture, livestock and food projects in areas of Southern Sudan.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Tanzania;
Tanzania's Lutheran Church Endorses University Plans


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

ARUSHA-TANZANIA - The Executive Council of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Tanzania (ELCT) has unanimously endorsed plans to set up a university which will have five constituent colleges in different parts of the country.

Presenting a report of the planning committee here, some 650 kilometres north-west of the capital, Dar es Salaam, Bishop Dr. Erasto N. Kweka said on August 24 that the first private university in this East African country shall be known as Tumaini.

Members of the planning committee were Bishop Dr. Kweka (chairman), Dr. Anza Amen Lema (organizing secretary), Prof. Dr. Cuthbert Omari, Prof. Dr. Hubert Kairuki, Dr. Rogate Mshana, Dr. Christa Held (adviser) and Mr. Samwel Kilimhana. 

Others are Prof. Dr. Abel Ishumi, Prof. Dr. Geoffrey Mmari, Hon. Minister Jackson Makwetta MP, Mr. Amani Mwenegoha (ex-officio), Dr. Mrs. Martha Mvungi, Prof. Dr. Alkaeli Kweka and Dr. Wilson Niwagila.

Bishop Kweka told the members of the Executive Council that the committee which was set up during the ELCT General Assembly in 1990 to plan the establishment of the university, submitted its report to the Presiding Bishop Dr. Samson Mushemba, on May 3, 1996.

He said the committee proposed that the main campus would be at Monduli, some 30 kilometres from Arusha while a number of church institutions shall be upgraded to form constituent colleges.

In the next two years three of the colleges will be operational at the Makumira Lutheran Theological college which becomes the Makumira University College (MUGO); the KCMC will become the University college of Medicine, Moshi (UCOME) and the Iringa Theological College becomes the Iringa University College (IUCO).

Initially the proposed college at Makumira would have the following faculties; Theology, Philosophy and Liberal Arts. While Iringa College will have Business Administration, Engineering Law, Urban Planning, Journalism as well as Architecture and Design.

In addition, the following institutes may be established; Institute of Missiology and Evangelism; African Studies; Middle East Studies; Institute of Languages and the Institute of Peace Studies and Conflict Resolution.

The proposed Medicine College at KCMC would have the following faculties; Medicine, Pharmacy, Dentistry and Social Medicine.

Other colleges in the pipeline are Monduli University College (MOUCO) which shall have the faculties of Agriculture, Veterinary and Wildlife Sciences, Forestry and Food Science at its initial stage.

Another proposal is the Uyole Lutheran Teachers College to be transformed into the Mbeya University College (MBECO) with the following faculties: Education, Arts, Social Sciences and Science and Technology.

Dr. Rogate Mshana who is the Director of Planning with the ELCT said after getting the go-ahead from the executive committee, a university planning office shall be opened at the ELCT head office to set the plans in motion.

He said as soon as the government approves and registers the Tumaini University the college at Moshi, Iringa and Makumira can take off immediately.

Tanzania with a population of 26 million people has got two public universities with an annual enrolment of about 2,000 students. These are the University of Dar es Salaam and the Sokoine University of Agriculture.

Tanzania's north-eastern neighbour Kenya, with a similar population, has four public universities namely, Nairobi and Kenyatta in the Nairobi area, and Moi and Egerton in the Rift Valley Province. The four enrol about 30,000 students every year.

Uganda, north-west of Tanzania, has one such public institution of higher learning, the Makerere University.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 4, 1996


Ghana;
Ghana's Catholic Church Prepares For Third Millennium


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Accra - The Catholic Church in Ghana has launched a "pastoral congress" to study and redefine its role in society towards the new millennium. This will include education, health and other developmental areas.

The first ever National Catholic Pastoral Congress launched here on August 23, is also expected to propose modalities for "a genuine co- operation which should exist between the Church and the State." 

The event is scheduled to take place from April 7 to 14, 1997 in Cape Coast, where it will draw up action programmes that will "deepen the spirit of evangelisation" throughout Ghana. The theme of the congress is Ecclesia in Ghana: The Church in Ghana and her Evangelising Mission in the Third Millennium.

Speaking to APS in an interview, Father Anthony Kornu, Assistant Secretary General of the national Catholic Secretariat said the Congress was "inspired by and is a celebration" of the African Bishop's Synod held in Rome in April/May, 1994.

"This is a process to actualize the vision and recommendations of the Synod within our local Ghanaian situation or else the Pope's exhortations on the Synod may remain a continental idea on the shelves," he said. Father Kornu said that the idea is to make the church "relevant, responsive, both truly African and Ghanaian and at the same time universal."

In some areas, father Kornu said the process will start at the parish to diocesan level building into the congress bottom-up, while in others the process may effectively start only after the actual congress. All the faithful, the clergy and the other religious, experts and consultants will participate in the process and in the main event.

At the congress, the church intends to undertake a deep internal analysis of herself, discover her weaknesses and areas of strength, said Bishop Francis Kofi Anani Lodonu, President of the Ghana Catholic Bishops' Conference and Bishop of Ho who performed the launching ceremony.

Bishop Lodonu, reiterated the Catholic church's commitment to justice and the defence of people's human rights and dignity. He said the church will also strive to draw the attention of "all categories of citizens" to their responsibilities.

He singled out national reconciliation, the Gospel of love and forgiveness as important elements in the process of building one national family in diversity, tribal, religious, political or other.

Other issues to be discussed at the 1997 congress will include the history of the church in Ghana, methods of evangelisation, charismatic renewal in the church, ecumenism, Islam and modern means of communication.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Uganda;
Uganda's Anglican Bishops Call For Ban On Lotteries


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

KAMPALA - The Church of the Province of Uganda House of Bishops has called on the government to ban scratch-for-cash lotteries saying they were impoverishing families.

The bishops' resolution at the end of their 13th Provincial Assembly on August 20, said the Anglican clergy were concerned about the lotteries because "they encouraged crime and laziness."

The House of Bishops resolution on lotteries clearly targets the scratch- for-cash games operated by Asian businessman Mr. Sudhir Ruparelia, whose Premier Lotteries has penetrated deep into the rural areas of this East African country. 

Premier Lotteries regularly offers huge prizes which would make many winners rich over night by Ugandan standards where rural poverty is endemic. In one of their most recent draws, top prizes of USh.50 million ($50,000) were given out to each of the five top winners. Furthermore, numerous smaller prizes may be won besides houses and vehicles.

The Asian proprietor has reportedly made millions of US dollars in the last six months.

The House of Bishops Secretary the Rt. Rev. Christopher Senyonjo said the government should "immediately take steps to abolish the lotteries as this will help boost morals in the country."

Prior to the bishops' concern, a number of the country's Members of Parliament in the new legislature called for drastic control of the scratch- for-cash games, saying many people in the villages had abandoned productive labour to devote their energies to the lotteries.

Captain Mike Mukula, MP for Soroti Municipality in eastern Uganda, said an age limit to gambling in the lotteries should be established.

"If we encourage young children to gamble - even at the age of two years - then we will end up with and irrational society," he cautioned.

Most Ugandan MPs expressed anger that the government had charged taxes payable by Premier at 15 per cent instead of the 30 per cent stated in a contract with the firm.

Observers believe that while the government will now be obliged to do something about the Asian owned lottery, there will be a serious problem with what to do with thousands of youth who are employed as ticket sellers by the company.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Church's Role Crucial To Ending Female Circumcision


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Nairobi - Any intervention efforts aimed at reducing the widely practised female circumcision (FC) in Kenya must incorporate a role for church leaders.

Speaking during a dissemination seminar on research findings on female circumcision by the Programme for Appropriate Technology in Health (PATH) here on August 23, PATH staff revealed that churches are a major institution for community out-reach on female circumcision.

According to PATH, a non-governmental organization (NGO) interviews with church leaders during the research confirmed that the position taken by churches in the community is crucial in determining the extent of female circumcision in that community. 

PATH however cautioned the Catholic church's silence and lack of position on the practice, saying that the church commands a large following in the country and particularly in the three districts under study namely Nyeri (Central Province), Embu and Machakos (both in Eastern Province).

Research findings in the three districts also revealed that many Catholic church members are practising female circumcision because their church does not condemn it.

In particular, Catholic leaders interviewed said the church should not dictate abandonment of the practice to its members but should also provide information on female circumcision.

Moreso, church leaders agreed that female circumcision results in harmful health effects and as a practice, it has outlived its cultural usefulness, the research found.

While some church leaders felt that their church should actively oppose female circumcision, others believed that its practice or non-practice should be left to individual church members," added the report.

However, PATH said it did not establish unanimity of views on the question of the role the church should play in encouraging abandonment of female circumcision.

Other church leaders interviewed belong to the (Anglican) Church of the province of Kenya (CPK), Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA) and the Independent Church.

Any meaningful efforts to end the practice, PATH found out, should involve stake holders as well as encourage active participation of both men and women.

The organization called for combined effort from churches, government officials, schools and community organizations to help in educating the community on the dangers of female circumcision.

PATH also called on the Kenyan government to clear its stand on FC saying that many people believe the authorities are indifferent to its existence.

Because mothers, mothers-in-law and grandmothers play a key role in decision making on FC, PATH advocated that these women must be particular targets of information which can help them change their attitudes.

Speaking during the seminar, an Assistant Minister for Education Mrs. Agnes Ndetei said there is need to incorporate lessons on harmful traditional practices in the school curricula. Circumcisers should also be part and parcel of the process when developing alternative rituals or practices to female circumcision, the seminar was told.

Female circumcision is practised in about 30 of Kenya's 60 districts and it is estimated that 50 per cent of girls and women in the country have been circumcised. Women (and girls) comprise 50 per cent of the national population of 26 million people.

PATH has conducted an extensive research on female circumcision in the districts mentioned earlier on.

The organization has also collaborated with the National Association of Nigerian Nurses and Midwives (NANNM) in sensitizing and mobilizing the nursing profession to fight for the eradication of female genital mutilation (FGM) in the West African country.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Egypt;
Copts Ask Congress To Probe Egyptian Killings


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Washington - The American Coptic Union (ACU) has urged the United States Congress to investigate killings of Christians in Egypt and postpone aid to Egypt until basic rights and security are secured for all citizens.

In a statement issued here on August 25, the ACU also issued a plea for help from US President Clinton, Roman Catholic Pope John Paul II, and "our Jewish brothers" following a string of violent attacks on Coptic Christians by Muslim militants in Egypt.

In its statement, the ACU also criticized the Egyptian authorities for taking away guns owned by Coptic Christians as part of a partial weapons ban. 

The ACU, which claims to speak for the 2.5 million American Copts, as well as "the 12 million-plus Egyptian Copts in a country where they now have no voice," declared: "The American Coptic Union requests that the US Congress immediately send a fact-finding commission to investigate murders and persecutions of Coptic Christians.

It also urged that the 2.1 billion dollars a year in "US-Egyptian foreign aid be postponed until basic human rights and security for all citizens are secured."

The call came only four days after Egyptian police said that two Christian brothers were killed in southern Egypt on August 21 by Muslim militants who accused them of cooperating with the authorities.

Hanna Maurice Ayub, 35, and his brother Ayub Maurice Ayub, 25, were shot to death while returning to their field in the village of Kalandul in the Malawi area, 300 kilometers south of Cairo, police said.

The militants suspected the Coptic, or Egyptian Orthodox brothers of giving information on their hideouts to the authorities, police said.

A third Copt, Mukhtar Hanna Mikhail, a 47-year-old farmer, was critically wounded on August 21 by Muslim fundamentalists in al-Rod village in Malawi and was hospitalized with gunshot wounds in the stomach and chest, police said.

The militants also accused the wounded man of informing on them, police said, adding that the attackers in both incidents were still at large.

Earlier on August 17, the Islamic militants shot dead two Coptic Christians and injured three other people in a series of simultaneous raids on jewellers' shops in the southern Egyptian town of Tahta, police said.

Five militants armed with automatic weapons struck three shops in the same road in Tahta, situated 480 kilometres south of Cairo in Sohag province.

They killed two Coptic jewellers, Metri Atta Ateya and Safwat Shafiq, and injured three other people including a six-year-old Coptic boy and a Muslim engineer hit by bullets as the gang made their escape.

Police said the attackers escaped in a hijacked lorry with large quantities of gold and jewels, adding that they were from Egypt's main armed militant Islamic group the Jamaa Islamiyya.

So far, the killings brought to 1,052 the number of people gunned down by the Islamic extremists in the wave of militant violence that began in March 1992.

-0-)

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Church Of England To Consecrate First African Bishop


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

London - The Church of England will on September 25 consecrate Ugandan clergy Canon John Sentamu as the first African bishop in the province.

Rev. Sentamu, 47, who was ordained priest in 1979 after reading theology at Cambridge University, England, has been the Vicar of Holy Trinity and St. Matthias, Tulse Hill in the Diocese of London, since 1983.

He has also been a member of General Synod since 1985 and co-Chair of the Southwark Diocesan Synod since 1994. 

Mid-May, this year, the Church of England appointed him as bishop of Stepney in the London Diocese.

A press release here announcing his appointment as bishop quotes Canon Sentamu saying; "My first priority is God, seeking God's rule of justice, righteousness, peace and love. Secondly change, to be a part of God's movement of change and discovering the landscape of hope, meeting real concerns with real life and thirdly outreach, loitering with intent by standing at the intersection, where human need and God's love meet."

And when he is finally consecrated, Rev. Sentamu, a former junior judge of the High Court of Uganda, the homeland he fled for England during the terror reign of dictator idi Amin in the 70s, will become the third black bishop in the Church of England after the Bishop of Rochester and the Bishop of Croydon.

In a telephone interview with APS, Rev. Sentamu said; "I am not being consecrated for the Church of England, although that is what it is, literally. But I see myself being consecrated for the Church of God."

He elaborated that when one is ordained for the Church of God, the question of where one pastorally serves does not arise. Whether in Africa or England, the end result will be the same.

On the generally held opinion that churches in Europe are not "filled to capacity" as is the case in churches in Africa, Rev. Sentamu said; "It is true, sometimes a church minister may come face to face with a half-packed church during worship as compared to the booming mood, on the African continent but that would vary from place to place."

He stressed; "In my case, I have not yet come across that type of situation. Wherever I have served and preached, the church has been full. Maybe one has to think seriously on what to chip in pastorally in order to liven the congregation as a way of avoiding a situation of half-attendance."

The bishop-elect added, "I have always tried to incorporate the African singing and the playing of African drums as part of my strategy to liven the church. This, I can tell you, has made a lot of differences in terms of church attendance."

On the relationship with his home Anglican church, Rev. Sentamu said he believes his elevation to the bishopric will strengthen this bond but this will also depend on the issues being handled.

He talked of his scheduled travel to Uganda next year to participate in the centenary celebrations of the Church of the Province of Uganda Ruwenzori Diocese.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Church Leaders Stress Importance Of Communication


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Lome - African states have been urged to "examine, adapt and master" the emerging new communication technologies such as Internet and the Information Super Highway which on the eve of the third millenium offer both "promises and threats to our societies".

In a four-point statement issued at the end of a three-day meeting held here, 12 church leaders from eight Central and West African Francophone countries also called on African countries to stop immediately the arbitrary use of the media in total disregard of "the present socio-political contexts of our countries."

Using the media at random, they said, had contributed to the fratricide fragmentation, sectional clashes and violence that are now more widespread on the continent. In addition, the practice and especially untruthful information and false denials, had resulted in a "confidence crisis" between governments and the governed. 

The meeting organized from August 14 to 16 by the Service d'Information des Eglises d'Afrique (SIEA), the churches press agency for Francophone Africa based here, was called to sensitize church leaders and functionaries on the important role of communication in their work and on the promises, problems and challenges of new communication technologies.

Participants included church leaders from the Central African Republic, Congo, Gabon, Cote d'Ivoire, Senegal, Benin and the host country, Togo.

Others who attended the consultation included officials from the Nairobi- based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) led by General Secretary Rev. Jose Chipenda, the World Association for Christian Communication (WACC) represented by General Secretary Carlos Valle and Regional Coordinator Africa and Middle East Ms. Julienne Munyaneza from Rwanda, officials from the Evangelical Community for Apostolic Action (CEVAA) in Paris, SIEA staff, among them the Executive Director Pastor Andree Moussanga from Cameroon and the local press.

The meeting was an eye opener that challenges us to take the role of communication and the implications of new communication technologies more seriously, Sr. Odile Homawoo of the Social Communications Department of the Togo Catholic Secretariat told APS.

Mr. Rudolf Apedo-Amah, Vice-President of the Methodist Church in Togo shares similar sentiments. In addition, he intends to encourage his church to give some priority to the training of communication professionals.

World Wide Web, one of the newest and fastest growing communication technologies, offers computer users increased access to information in the form of pictures, sound or voice and colour mechanisms. Ghana, Togo's western neighbour is believed to be the first country in the West African sub-region to benefit from this facility.

As the consultation in Lome was coming to an end, in Ghana, 100 participants drawn from financial institutions, universities, and research organizations were taking part in a one-day seminar on Internets's World Wide Web in the capital city, Accra.

Organized by Network Computer System (NCS) Limited for its users and potential users of the Internet, the seminar was the fourth in a series this year. NCS is committed to strengthen the country in terms of information technology through software development, Dr. Nii Quaynor, NCS Executive Chairman said.

In their statement, church leaders participating in the Lome consultation also called on the churches and National Christian Councils to develop a more positive mentality and critical awareness of communication.

Communication they said, is a modern and necessary vehicle through which biblical messages, Christian witness and service as well as social and other education for all the people of God could be mediated.

On networking, the statement called for the creation of a sub- regional pool to promote the collection and sharing of information on the life of churches in order to "initiate and intensify inter- ecclesiatic solidarity."

The clergy emphasized the need to "diversify methods of communicating the Christian message, particularly in the animation of religious programmes on radio and television," especially given the new challenges facing society.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Zambia;
Term Of Office


BYLINE: Masautso Phiri, Column, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Lusaka - My Dear Readers,

Two things are worrying me of late. First are the ongoing "bilateral" talks being conducted by President Frederick Chiluba. The President announced his intentions in Maseru, Lesotho where he assured leaders of the Southern African development Community (SADC) that he was ready to met the opposition.

Since that announcement, he and his press aide Richard Sakala have insisted that the talks will be one on one. I do not know what the President expects to achieve with that approach especially that there is little time left before an agreement can be reached. 

The question of time leads me to the second point of my writing this article. The MMD mandate expires on October 31, 1996. I concur with the views of Zambia Democratic Congress president Dean Mung'omba and I repeat them here.

"We would like to remind President Chiluba that his term of office comes to an end on October 31. At that time whether he likes it or not Zambians will not allow him to continue," Mung'omba said in an interview on Monday. He went on to call on the Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube to be ready to takeover in an interim administration. In the present circumstances this makes sense because we cannot allow President Chiluba to continue destroying this country as he has already done.

I know that government chief spokesman, minister of information Amusaa Mwana-mwambwa is on record claiming that the MMD mandate ends on November 30. That is absolute nonsense. The 1991 elections were on October 31 and by November 2 it was clear that Kaunda had reached the end of the road and he immediately conceded defeat.

Our system of government did not allow Kaunda to stay a day longer. He immediately handed over power to Chiluba. And in any case, if Kaunda had tried to stay a little longer not only would Chiluba and the MMD not have allowed but they would have agitated for unrest. They would have regarded Kaunda as a bad loser.

Thus effectively President Chiluba's mandate started on November 1, 1991.

The statement by Mwana-mwambwa arises from desperation. Somehow MMD leaders now realise that they have squandered their five years in power and have nothing to show for it. They have done everything against people's expectations and wishes.

They failed to conduct local government elections last year and somehow in their warped logic they hope they can do the same for the presidential and parliamentary elections. That is unacceptable, morally wrong and unconstitutional.

In 1991 the MMD made calls for a transitional government. The call provided pressure on Kaunda's government and he listened and accommodated the dmands of the opposition. But President Chiluba has shown how incapable he is in handling matters of state. Already, despite the agreement by his cabinet that Kaunda should finally be allowed to contest this year's election, he is dragging his feet on the matter. He and his government is failing to accommodate the opposition on the electoral process, the messed up voters register prepared by Nikuv and the apartheid constitution they have imposed on the people. This failure to listen to the majority supports Mung'omba's view that come October 31, 1996 Chiluba should cease to be president of this country.

I am aware that his legal advisers are trying to play around with the law by tying the presidency to parliament.

In this regard they are deliberately delaying the dissolution of parliament because doing so would tie them to 90 days within which elections should be held and a new National Assembly be convened. Thus Chiluba is waiting for the last moment, possibly last week of October to disolve the house, a move which would give him upto last week of January, 1997 for the new National Assembly to convene.

This scheme by Chiluba must be stopped at all cost. Elections must be held in October, 1996.

I love you all,

Masautso


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Zambia;
Re-Open Inquiry On Killing


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition politicians and civic leaders have demanded for the re- opening of the Baldwin Nkumbula Commission of Inquiry following the confession by Patrick Mubanga Kafuti that late former National Party president was killed by State House agents.

And there were, however, unconfirmed reports that police had yesterday picked Kafuti following The Post story.

"Kafuti was picked up for questioning by the Inspector General (IG) of Police and deputy minister in the Office of the President Eric Silwamba," a police source claimed.

Attempts to confirm this, however, failed as the IG refused to answer Post calls and Silwamba could not be contacted at the office or home. 

In a video recorded confession, obtained by The Post, Kafuti says Nkumbula was shot by State House security personnel and claims President Frederick Chiluba begged him not to tell anyone the "true" story about Nkumbula's tragedy.

But the opposition and civic groups called for the immediate resignation of the MMD government unless Kafuti's claims can be disproved.

According to Zambia United Front (ZUFRO) chairman, Mike Kaira, President Chiluba should resign immediately.

"ZUFRO demands the immediate resignation of Chiluba, his Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda, Minister of Home Affairs Chitalu Sampa and the Inspector General of Police, Francis Ndhlovu," said Kaira in a telephone interview yesterday.

Kaira indicated that ZUFRO "will put up a petition to the highest court in the land to stop President Chiluba from contesting public office over this matter.

"Baldwin's death cannot be in vain," Kaira said. "If we leave this matter as it is, tomorrow it may be you or me."

Opposition Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) president, Dean Mung'omba, added that his party had never been satisfied with the Nkumbula Commission of Inquiry report, especially that it was released three months after it was handed over to State House.

"These accusations are directed at President Chiluba and his family. We leave it up to him to exculpate himself within two days to show that he was not involved," Mung'omba said at a press briefing yesterday. "That is the problem of lying. Lies always catch up with you."

Former vice president in the UNIP government, Mainza Chona, said: "I call upon the government to re-open the Nkumbula Commission of Inquiry in order to give an opportunity to this young man, Kafuti, to give his evidence".

According to Chona, President Chiluba's son, Castro, should also be made to give evidence.

"The Commission of Inquiry is completely inadequate without the evidence of Castro," Chona said. "If Castro is not well, as they claim, then the Commission of Inquiry should adjourn sine die until he is well enough to give evidence."

Inter-African Network Human Rights and Development (AFRONET) executive director, Ngande Mwanajiti, said Kafuti's revelation was "shocking" and stressed that "nobody has the right to take away life".

"I was shocked at Kafuti's confession," Mwanajiti said after watching

the video of Kafuti's confession yesterday. "If what he said is true, it does raise a few concerns and certainly calls for clarification. The man has said what he has to say. He was there and it becomes difficult to dismiss what he has said."

He, however, said it was unfortunate that Kafuti decided to tell lies during the Commission of Inquiry.

"Although he does explain the context why he lied, the law has to take it's course," Mwanajiti said.

Late Nkumbula's close friend, Mweene Hamazila, called on President Chiluba and security officers not to victimise or harass Kafuti for "spilling the beans".

"I am asking the President and his defence minister Ben Mwila, not to victimise or harass Kafuti," Hamazila said, explaining: "Kafuti is a patriotic Zambian and his conscience has been troubling him ever since the accident."

Inspector General of Police Francis Ndhlovu, who was invited to come and watch Kafuti's recorded interview, sent his detective chief inspector Mbangu Mbangu.

Hamazila also added his voice to the demand for President Chiluba to resign.

"If Chiluba is a Christian, as he claims, then he should resign immediately, " Hamazila said. "The state repudiated Stanley Hamusonde's testimony during the Commission of Inquiry but his testimony tallies with what Kafuti has said. The Commission of Inquiry didn't go to the root of the investigation."

National Lima Party co-chairman, Guy Scott, however, declined to comment stating:

"It is difficult to make a comment from someone's confession. However, we will soon be sitting as a party and we will definitely make our stand known," Scott said in a telephone interview yesterday.

State House press aide, Richard Sakala, refused to be drawn into any discussion over the matter.

"I don't want to comment on that," Sakala told The Post in a telephone interview yesterday before hanging up.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

September 4, 1996


Zambia;
New Party Launched


BYLINE: Masaautso Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - The National Lima Party was launched last Saturday at a rally in the farming town of Mum-bwa, some 173 kilo-metres west of Lusaka.

The new party's co-chairmen - former Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) president Ben Kapita and former agriculture minister Guy Scott - took turns to launch the Lima Party with a promise to improve the lot of farmers.

"People ask why I am in partisan politics when I have spent the last 20 years fighting for a better deal for farmers. I have found that because we have allowed too many town boys they don't understand farmers," Kapita said on Saturday. 

Dubbed "the big one" in advertisements before the rally and with "power to the farmer" slogan the launch took off to a slow start with less than three hundred people ready to listen to the party's message.

"People say we have come late," Scott said. "We have come late because we were waiting for all other parties to die."

Scott added: "If we had come at the same time as National Party, Zambia Democratic Congress and Liberal progressive Front, you would have been confused. Now in the whole country executives from MMD, NP, ZDC and LPF are joining us because everyone has seen what the Lima Party stands for."

Scott, who appealed to his audience to vote for his party warned farmers not to allow a one party state whether under UNIP or the MMD.

"Let's get the fire going. We don't have time. If you allow a one party state to continue under MMD or UNIP next year don't come crying to me or Ben Kapita," Scott said. "We are doing something about it now but you have to come with us."

And Kapita who laid out his agricultural based manifesto also promised that his party will give power to the farmers who grow our cotton and to those who have been retrenched as they will go back to the land.

"Today is a great day for Zambia. Enough is enough. Power to the farmer. Today is a great day for Zambia as we launch the national Lima Party," Kapita said.


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 1996

Africa News


September 4, 1996


Business;
Zambian Copper Prices Uncertain


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - The ZCCM operations quarterly report released in Lusaka yesterday indicated that the price of copper would remain uncertain because of prevailing low prices on the London Metal Exchange.

"The market experienced a very significant drop in LME prices during the quarter ended June 30 from US$2,841 per tonne on May 9, 1996 to US$1,830 per tonne on June 27, 1996," the report disclosed. 

It revealed that the average sales realisation for copper, at K2,715 million per tonne for the quarter, was 19 per cent higher than the K2,275 million per tonne realised in the corresponding quarter of 1995.

But the statement further explained that the higher returns came as a result of the depreciation of the Kwacha - the average copper price achieved for the quarter was US$2,226 per tonne compared to $2,668 for the corresponding period of the previous year.

According to the report, ZCCM recorded an operating profit of K59,972 million in the quarter ended June 30, 1996.

"After taking into account exchange losses, interest, taxation charges and other items, the Group made a net profit of K14,676 million, compared with a net profit of K12,051 million in the same period of 1995," read the statement.

Also, revenue from sales of precious metals amounted to K300 million during the quarter, compared to sales of K819 million during the corresponding period of the previous year.

The statement confirmed that copper production at 83, 892 tonnes for the quarter was lower than the 87,420 tonnes achieved in the June quarter of 1995.
