260 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 15, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2080 words


 

MEKELE (NA) - An experience sharing meeting was held in Mekele town between the Tigray and Southern Peoples' Regional States focusing on economic activities of the two regions.

Senior officials of the two regional states in their discussions exchanged views about experiences of utlization and conservation of natural resources, provision of potable water to urban and rural areas, the prevention and control of communicable diseases as well as issues pertaining to the implementation of the investment proclamation.

Participants at the meeting also discussed human resource development and structuring of bureaux based on experiences of the two regional states.

The delegation of Southern Peoples' Regional State led by Ato Dereje Dokogucho, Deputy Head of the Regional Administration also exchanged views on project execution experiences with various governmental and non-governmental organizations operating in Tigray.

Speaking at the meeting, Ato Gebru Asrat, Head of the Tigray Regional State said farmers, youth and women associations play key roles in promoting public participation in development activities of the region. 

Development activities carried out in rural areas of the region have so far been successfully executed because they are very much related to the day-to- day life of farmers Ato Gebru said, adding the experiences shared between the two regional states will have mutual benefits for the development of peoples of the respective regions.

15 Million Birr Project Launched 170 Completed In Time

HARAR (ENA) - Some 38 development projects have already been launched in Harari Regional State during the current Ethiopian fiscal year, the Regional Economy and Planning Bureau said.

Bureau representative Ato Muhdin Ahmed said the projects include agricultural, educational, health as well as water development activities.

The representatives said the projects will be undertaken with 15 million birr allocated for the current budget year.

He further said the budget allocated for the current fiscal year for the sector surpassed that of the previous year by 4 million birr.

Meanwhile, of the 224 projects planned for last year in North Shoa Zone, the construction of 170 has been completed in time, the zonal planning and economy department reported.

Ato Menberu Alebachew, head of the department, said the projects whose construction has been completed were under the categories of agriculture, education, health and water supply.

With regard to agricultural projects, 87 residential houses of development workers, 24 animal cross-breeding stations, eight veterinary clinics and other service rendering facilities were built during the stated period, the head added.

He said 31 schools were renovated, three clinics built and three water wells sunk besides the improvisation work on the Debre Birhan potable water service.

Ato Mekonen attributed the failure of the remaining 54 projects to delays in releasing budget and facilitating the work on the part of contractors.

According to the head, a total budget of 8 million birr was allotted to all the projects planned for the just ended year.

Bureau Files Charges Against Corrupt Officials

ASSOSA (ENA) - The justice bureau of the Benshangul - Gumuz Regional State disclosed that t has filed charges against 19 heads in two bureaux for misappropriation of government fund amounting to over one million birr.

Bureau head Mekonnen Argaw said the charges were made pursuant to the decisions made by the peace, development and democracy conference held last June in the region and the assessment the council carries out in various bureaux.

The regional council has sacked corrupt officials besides brining their case before court, he added.

The allegedly corrupt officials were serving as heads at various levels in the trade and tourism bureau and the police commission.

Urban Land Leased On Auction

ENDALILASSIE (ENA) - The Endaslassie Town Municipality in Western Tigray announced that it has prepared urban land meant for construction of residential quarters and business centres to be leased to residents.

It said 12 separate places with areas ranging from 870 to 2,890 square meters were prepared following the completion of the study to fix the rate of rents.

In case these places are not sufficient to meet the demands of the public, additional urban land will be prepared for lease, the municipality added. September 17,1996

ERA envisages new organizational structure, work system

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA) has disclosed plans to adopt a new structure which it said would enhance the country's rudimentary road network.

ERA made the announcement yesterday at the opening of a two day meeting called to discuss the new structure which has been under security for the past twelve months.

The General Manager, Ato Tesfamikael Nahusenay said existing structure which has been put in practice over the past 25 years is not capable of producing the required effect.

According to a think-tank report, the new structure would positively alter the authority's management system, streamline accountability pay considerable attention to manpower development and augment financial resources of ERA.

Ethiopia envisages to upgrade and maintain 10,000 kms of highway roads and construct 5,000 kms of new rural roads at a cost of 15 billion birr in five years time, the general manager said.

He said the fund required for the construction and maintenance of the roads would be covered primarily by foreign assistance and government budget as well.

A draft proclamation authorising ERA to own road construction activities and carry out the new structure would be presented to the Council of Ministers in just a month, Ato Tesfa-mikael added.

He said a proclamation will be issued to create conditions in which the authority increases its revenue to care for the roads by charging mainly public and freight transport owners and all other users of the roads.

He added that studies proved that the expenses incurred by vehicle owners for maintenance resulted from bad conditions of roads is two fold higher than the expenditure to rehabilitate the roads, the general manager said.

He said discussions with the employees of the authority was needed to let then comment on whether the new work system and organizational structure prepared in collaboration with GTZ, a German aid organization, could be efficient or not.

Deputy Prime Minister Tamirat Layne said the task ahead of the authority have their own contributions in speeding up other development endeavours, adding, the new system and structure were designed in such a way that they promote the country's development strategies.

Ato Tamirat expressed the hope that while executing the country's strategic plans through new and efficient mechanisms, the authority will prove effective and change the lives of the workers for the better.

Sodore Resort Centre Re-opens To Public

NAZARETH (ENA) - The Sodore resort centre which had been shut because of the overflow of the Awash River, has begun catering services on the eve of the Ethiopian new year, the manager said Saturday.

Ato Assefa Teklu told the Ethiopian News Agency that the recreation centre was closed for a couple of weeks.

He said the mini-swimming pool, bars, and the resort's 99 well-furnished rooms are ready for operation.

Ato Assefa said the major swimming pool will be open to public this week.

He said 2000 litters of pesticide was spread to avert mosquito breeding.

Sodore is located some 120 kms south east of Addis.

Bureau Says Unable To Vaccinate Pets, Eliminate Stray Dogs

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Region 14 agriculture Bureau said that it has found it impossible to either vaccinate properly raised pets or eliminate stray ones in Addis where there are bout 400,000 dogs.

Dr. Yetimwork Tessema a veterinarian in the bureau, told ENA Saturday that the absence of medicinal drugs and shortage of professionals were the major constraints that hindered the activities of the bureau.

She further said most of the stated number of dogs are ownerless.

Dr. Yetimwork said it has been impossible to avoid stray dogs sleeping together with street children mostly at bus stops and major streets.

The vet said the society should cooperate in bringing the dogs for inoculation or killing those infected with rabies.

She said it was utterly impossible to separate the dogs form the street children because of strong resistance encountered from both sides.

Dr. Yetimwork said although it was planned to vaccinate about 20,000 dogs last year, only half of the number were inoculated due to lack of medicines.

About 10,720 stray dogs with rabies were killed during the reported period to halt the transmission of the disease, according to the vet.

Ato Badeg Zewde, representative of rabies vaccine production section in the Ethiopian Health and Nutrious Food Research Institute, said that his section could not meet the demand of the region for it is the sole producer and distributor of the vaccine in the country.

He further said the vaccine is produced based on the request of regional administrative bodies and added priorities are given to human rabies patients.

Besides, the section should get respite in order to be able to produce the required amount of vaccine.

Ato Badeg said, however, the problem would be solved when the Debre-Zeit national veterinary laboratory begins producing the vaccine.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

261 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 15, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Secretary-General Urges More Support For African Development


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1787 words


 

United Nations - To consolidate and extend the significant economic and political gains that have been achieved in Africa over the past five years, the continent's reform process requires greater commitment by both African governments and the international community, says Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

In a new report on the United Nations New Agenda for the Development of Africa in the 1990s, the Secretary-General notes a marked improvement in Africa's economic performance over the first half of the decade. In 1995, he reports, 12 African countries registered a gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate of 6 per cent or more, while in 1992 only three countries had reached that level. Although citing this and other "signs of tangible progress", the Secretary-General also points to shortcomings, including a stagnation in external aid to Africa, with net flows of official development assistance to the continent declining from $25 billion in 1992 to $23 billion in 1994. 

The report was prepared for the General Assembly's Ad Hoc Committee of the Whole, which will conduct a week-long review of the implementation of the new Agenda, beginning on 16 September. The review will hear assessments of the efforts made to meet the objectives of the New Agenda by African countries and by the international community. It will also hear proposals for enhancing the New Agenda's implementation over the next half decade. The views of governments, non-governmental organizations, multilateral institutions and regional bodies such as the Organization of African Unity will be considered.

"At this critical point," the Secretary-General's report says, the international community should "accelerate its support to these countries in order to sustain the momentum leading to recovery and sustainable development" . In particular, he argues, the international community must improve the level and scope of aid and take "additional and decisive measures" to resolve Africa's debt crisis. It also must take concrete steps to help African countries adjust to the new global market environment.

In response to the particularly difficult development challenges facing the African continent, the New Agenda was adopted by the General Assembly in December 1991 as a framework of consensus and partnership between Africa and the international community. It outlined complementary actions to be taken by both African countries and their international partners in the 1990s, in order to meet priority development objectives. African countries agreed to intensify efforts in such areas as economic management, regional cooperation, democratization, investment promotion, social services, agriculture, environment and population. The continent's external partners pledged to reinforce those efforts with the necessary financial and technical support, especially through higher net resource flows including deeper debt relief, and improved market access for African exports.

The Ad Hoc Committee of the whole was established by Assembly resolution 42/163 as a mechanism to review the United Nations Programme of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development 1986-1990.

Signs of Progress

In his report on the New Agenda implementation, the Secretary-General finds that "the great majority of African countries have consistently taken appropriate actions to achieve sustained and sustainable growth and development." Those actions include a range of political and economic reforms which have brought signs of progress:

-- In addition to an increased number of African countries with GDP growth rates of 6 per cent or higher, the number with negative growth dropped from 19 in 1993 to three in 1995.

-- A growing commitment to regional and sub-regional economic cooperation and integration.

-- Marked progress in democratic and constitutional reform, with a dramatic growth in multi-party elections and intensified efforts to prevent and resolve conflicts. Non-governmental organizations also have increased their role in national development programmes, emphasizing community participation and self-help efforts.

-- Greater promotion of the domestic and foreign private sector in economic development.

-- Reforms to boost agriculture and improve access to food by the poorest groups, as well as programmes to safeguard the environment and address population issues.

Critical Issues for Africa

The Secretary-General devotes a significant portion of his report to a series of recommendations to both Africa and the international community, with the aim of enhancing the implementation of the New Agenda over the next five years. The primary responsibility, he affirms, rests with Africa, and the continent's leaders must acknowledge that "Africa's future is in their hands".

To consolidate the democratization process and improve governance in Africa, the Secretary-General recommends that African countries provide for wider popular participation in decision-making, encourage the emergence of a strong and vibrant civil society, ensure the independence of the media and adhere to the rule of law with an objective judicial system. They should also create mechanisms to promote political stability and to prevent or resolve conflicts.

Turning to capacity-building, African countries need to improve health care systems, intensify efforts towards universal primary education and literacy, integrate population policies into their development strategies, address problems of unemployment and empower women to participate fully in the development process.

On domestic resource mobilization, the Secretary-General suggests that measures should be taken to improve taxation, control public expenditures, increase private savings and attract domestic and foreign investment. And to raise the continent's earnings, African economies need to boost external trade and diversify away from dependence on a limited number of primary commodities. Efforts should also be made to strengthen African regional and sub-regional institutions.

Noting that the New Agenda for Africa emphasizes the principles of "shared responsibility and full partnership" between Africa and the international community, the Secretary-General also highlights a number of areas in which the continent's development partners should reinforce their support for Africa.

During the first half of the New Agenda period, financial flows to Africa had "stagnated at a level below what was expected", the Secretary-General observes. But there is a "strong case" for increasing both the volume and the concessionality of development assistance to Africa, he argues, given that the economic difficulties of many African countries make access to private funding impossible. In addition, the Secretary-General suggests, donors should re-channel aid to Africa's key development priorities, switch to non- debt creating forms of assistance, link humanitarian and development assistance and better coordinate their various aid programmes.

Progress Needed on Debt and Trade

While there has been some progress in resolving the international debt crisis, the Secretary-General notes, this has been less marked for low-income countries, especially in Africa, where external debt servicing claims nearly one fifth of average savings. He recommends that commercial banks be encouraged to accept deeper discounts in buy-back operations and that more resources be provided to the World Bank's debt-reduction facility for low- income countries. The Paris Club of official creditors should be encouraged to improve its terms for reducing official bilateral debt, while the World Bank and International Monetary Fund should be encouraged to implement recent proposals on relief of multilateral debt, which now accounts for nearly half of Africa's debt servicing obligations.

The Uruguay Round agreements on international trade offer long-term possibilities for African products to gain greater access to world markets, says the Secretary-General, but in the short term they may have negative effects as African countries lose their trade preferences in European markets and face higher food import bills. He therefore urges support for appropriate compensation, including further tariff reductions on African products, as well as assistance with food imports. In addition, the Secretary-General urges donor countries to help finance the preparatory phase of commodity diversification programmes in African countries.

Further information may be obtained from the Office of the Special Coordinator for Africa and the Least Developed Countries, Department of Policy Coordination and Sustainable Development, Tel. (212) 963-5006/4780, and Africa Recovery, Tel: (212) 963-6857.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


262 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Uganda;
Child Defilement Prompts Awareness Campaign In Uganda


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Nairobi - Sexual abuse of minors or children is a growing problem worldwide. In Kenya and Uganda newspapers carry reports on sexual defilement of children nearly on a daily basis. However, increasing social awareness of the problem may help curb this vice.

One of the main criticisms of the recently concluded International Congress on the Sexual Exploitation of Children held in Stockholm, Sweden from August 26 to 30, was that it emphasized commercial exploitation yet in many countries worldwide sexual abuse of children occurs without any money changing hands. Government, and communities worldwide are seeking solutions to this growing vice that often leaves children ruined for the rest of their lives. 

For example late August, tough new legislation was passed in the American State of California. The Bill passed by State Assembly requires that any man convicted of two sex attacks on minors or children submit to either physical castration (surgical-which is permanent) or to what is called "chemical castration" which is effected with regular injections of the drug depo- provera. This drug is regularly used by women in family planning but in men it causes a loss of sex drive which is reversed when the injections are stopped.

But if depo-provera administration turns out to be effective in reducing the incidence of repeat sex attacks, such solutions may be difficult to manage and supervise in Third World nations like Uganda where extra-mural penal institutions - punishment outside of prison in the form of community penance of one kind or another - are very poorly developed or non-existent.

The problem of child defilement is still rampant in Uganda despite the fact that both rape and defilement of minors are capital offences. In this East African country, the law treats anybody below 18 years as a minor.

An overwhelming fact that emerges in studies of sex abuse of children in Uganda is that relatives, neighbours and acquaintances are most to blame.

One study has shown that between 20,000 and 30,000 adults living in Kampala were victims of sex abuse in childhood. Kampala has a daytime population of 1 million people.

Recent research done by the Glad Tidings Bible College Counselling Centre at Makerere, Kampala, emphasises that most of the victims have been sexually abused by acquaintances, and relatives including fathers, step-fathers, uncles, brothers, cousins, trusted family friends and neighbours.

These findings are similar to a completely unrelated earlier survey carried out by the New Vision, a state-owned daily. The newspaper gave a breakdown of the relationship of the child defiler (offender) to the child victim based on 190 newspaper reports on sex crimes that were published from 1992 to 1993.

The results were as follows: neighbour, 33 per cent; teacher, 9 per cent; relationship not stated, 33 per cent; complete stranger, 12 per cent; pastor, 3 per cent; father, 3 per cent; brother, 3 per cent and cousin 3 per cent.

According to the recent study by Glad Tidings Bible College Counselling Centre, the victims suffer long term damage that is carried into adulthood with repercussions such as feeding and sleeping disturbances, feelings of guilt, shame, lack of self appreciation, anxiety, and hidden anger.

Dennis Olwenyi Auto, Maxine Hancock and Karen Burton Mains who did the study, point out that far too many people tend to believe that child sexual abuse does not happen, thus permitting it to continue unabated.

According to Dennis Olweny Auto, one of the researchers in the current study, most of the people who seek counselling at the Glad Tidings counselling centre at Makerere are suffering extreme guilt and show other deep seated emotions like hatred. They have tried everything to get rid of these feelings, including witchcraft.

A typical victim of sexual abuse in childhood is generally withdrawn from other people and many develop behavioural disorders including repetitive compulsive actions. This may take the form of repetitive washing of hands or some abnormal preoccupation with cleanliness.

Auto was quoted by a section of the press in Uganda saying that "many victims feel dirty and are often obsessive about neatness." A woman may unconsciously become obese because being overweight may make her less attractive. This may be an unconscious signal that she does not wish to engage in sexual activity.

One woman is quoted saying: "When I was 15, I was raped by my step- father and had a child by him. I kept telling him it was wrong, he said it was not, as he was not a blood relation of mine. My mother went to the grave blaming me, but she ought to have known better as my step-father was 40 years older than I."

Mr. Auto emphasizes that no child has sufficient understanding or grasp of the situation to be sexually responsible. "The craving for love and attention that renders a child vulnerable is the result of a natural instinct to trust adults," he adds.

Meanwhile, one of Uganda's leading crusaders against child defilement has come up with a 10-point plan to help parents, children and the society in general reduce the incidence of child defilement in Uganda or cope with its aftermath.

Points stressed by Ms. Alleluya Ikote, a Member of Parliament representing women of Pallisa District in Eastern Uganda include; To sensitize children not to go alone or agree to be lured by someone to secluded places; That adults-even relatives-fondling their private parts is wrong; Under no circumstances should pupils go to teachers' houses; Policies should be put in place at all levels to strengthen the family unit by ensuring that families are not fragmented; Ensure that there is a welcoming, effective place and organized system where a child can take complaints so that she/he is totally not afraid of victimization.

In the German city of Cologne where child defilement is reported to be on the increase, a psychologist on the police hotline advises parents not to force their child to hug a stranger or relative if he or she does not want to.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


263 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Madagascar;
Guardian Of Madagascar's Third Republic Bows Out


BYLINE: APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Nairobi - Only three years since taking office in democratic elections that ousted long-time Marxist ruler Admiral Didier Ratsiraka, President Albert Zafy has himself been forced out of office after the Malagasy Constitutional Court upheld his impeachment by the national assembly last July. But he vows he will run for this country's presidency in the forthcoming elections.

Political turmoil continues to dog the Indian Ocean island republic of Madagascar off the East African coast following the forcing out of office on September 5 of the country's President Albert Zafy.

The court officially announced its decision to uphold the national assembly's impeachment on September 5, but only after Zafy had himself earlier gone on the national radio to announce that he would step down on October 10. 

The court named 58-year-old Prime Minister Norbert Ratsirahonana, who is also accused by his critics of precipitating the crisis, as interim head of state. The new head of state was himself previously head of the constitutional court, before being named premier in May.

Zafy was finally relieved of his office by Madagascar's Constitutional Court, which upheld his impeachment by the national assembly in July, after a long constitutional battle starting several months earlier that also forced the country's then prime minister Emmanuel Rakotovahiny to resign in May following his failure to dispel the government's unpopularity.

The deputies had accused Zafy, who was elected three years ago with a large majority, of violating the constitution by failing to set up the Senate, or upper house of parliament, and reorganize the judiciary.

Zafy, 69, a former professor of medicine and Health Minister who led the Vital Forces Movement that forced Ratsiraka to bow to democracy in 1991, was a key figure in the pro-democracy movement that eventually ended his 17-year rule in February, 1993.

Once elected to the presidency with diminished powers, Zafy had pledged to be the guardian of the new constitution of Madagascar's Third Republic, but the considerable initial enthusiasm that followed the political changes gave way to increasing concern over the depression in the country, amid reports of food shortages and other economic and social problems.

Political pundits had immediately believed that the new developments could trigger yet another long constitutional battle, this time between the constitutional court and the national assembly, currently sitting in special session.

Some political analysts contested the authority of the constitutional court to appoint an interim president, noting that Zafy had announced his own " virtual resignation" before the official announcement by the court, which gave him a chance to stand for re-election in an election which will have to be held now following the constitutional court's ruling.

The move also meant that national assembly speaker Pastor Richard Andriamanjato was also entitled by the constitution to stake a claim for the interim presidency, but this has since failed to materialize after Andriamanjato decided during a special parliamentary session later on September 5 to endorse the court's ruling.

One Malagasy journalist had maintained that "legally, everything would depend on establishing which came first: the high court's decision or Zafy's virtual resignation."

On July 26, 99 of the 138 members of the national assembly, or lower house of parliament, voted for Zafy's impeachment. Two months earlier, Rakotovahiny resigned as premier after his government received a no-confidence vote in the national assembly.

The court's decision was widely seen as punishing the once highly popular Zafy for failing to meet the high hopes of the Malagasy people when they swept him into power after his "quiet revolution" against long-time ruler Admiral Didier Ratsiraka.

The 58-year-old prime minister, who once presided over the constitutional court that designated him as interim head of state, belongs to no political party and was entrusted by Zafy with the task of getting Madagascar's economy back into shape. He has already occupied several senior administrative posts. Ratsirahonana is seen as a master of the political game after he managed to marginalize Zafy, a move that will put few obstacles in his way as the fight to try and bring back Madagascar on the rails intensifies.

Ratsirahonana immediately said after the court's ruling that priority plans will be to go to Washington to sign financial agreements with the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

He believes that this was the priority that others before him had failed to see, particularly his predecessor who was forced out of office following a no- confidence vote against his government due to economic disaster.

Last April, the IMF Director-General Michel Camdessus spent three days in the island republic for talks with political leaders on Madagascar's dire financial straits.

During the visit, Camdessus called for a range of reforms including monetary discipline, the opening of international trade, a campaign against corruption as well as programmes for health and education.

IMF and World Bank agreements with Madagascar were suspended in 1991 because of the poor state of the country's economy, and the situation had not improved.

Ratsirahonana, who has made the re-establishment of negotiations with global financial institutions a priority since his appointment in May, has already signed a "letter of intent" with the World Bank.

"Our commitment to reach agreement with the institutions of Bretton Woods (the conference which founded the World Bank) is dictated by the deep conviction that only such accords and structural adjustments will help us out of this rut," Ratsirahonana declared recently.

But one man who must be wondering whither goes Madagascar since he was ousted from power three years ago is former President Ratsiraka.

Reacting from Paris to developments at home, Ratsiraka who was forced to bow to democracy in 1991 and allowed multipartyism to take root in the Indian Ocean island, said he considered that the latest developments in his home country were "dangerous and explosive" since they were "completely illegal".

Ratsiraka, who has lived in France for the last 17 months, criticised what he described as a government "founded in insurrection, on the streets, which has given birth to a monstrous constitutional bastard riddled with contradictions.

"The current constitution was drawn up against my person, to prevent my eventual return, and not for Madagascar, which means that the presidential role was deprived of all its substance to give all power to the prime minister.

"Now all this has boomeranged back" at the current leaders, he added.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
