264 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Traditions That Hold Key To The Future


BYLINE: Joseph K'Amolo, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1467 words


 

Nairobi - Traditions play an important role in the way people relate to nature. An international environmental agency recently organised activities that highlighted the role of African traditions in preserving the future.

Important plants and animal species face the risk of becoming extinct as a result of fast and progressive removal from their habitat. Forests disappear, deserts spread and millions of tonnes of top soil end up in oceans every year as over-population leads to desperate efforts for survival which eventually end up destroying the environment. 

In Africa, environmentalists are concerned about the preservation of African traditions that help guard against environmental degradation. They are seeking a return to old traditions whose observance in the past often reminded people of their obligation to nature and fellow human beings.

It is in this respect that organisers of a week-long workshop, 'Festival of the Living Traditions: 'Old Ways to the Future', set aside a day to honour and "cleanse" Mt. Kenya, Kenya's highest mountain (17,058 feet) and Africa's second highest after Mt. Kilimanjaro in neighbouring Tanzania.

Prior to the workshop that ran from September 2 to 8, 1996, elders from around Mt. Kenya and from Uganda's governing clans on August 31 held a cleansing ceremony on the mountain. The workshop and mountain spiritual cleansing events were organised by the Nairobi-based Environment Liaison Centre International (ELCI) and sponsored by the Ford Foundation.

The Festival explored sustainable ways of living throughout East Africa by linking traditional knowledge and modern technology. The ways of living were demonstrated through lively and practical exhibitions, cultural performances and public fora, all of which served as a means to highlight the value of Africa's threatened traditions and make clear their role in the future. The festival complemented the Fifth International Congress of Ethnobiology that was also held at the same time.

The Mt. Kenya cleansing ceremony was presided over by a Meru traditional high priest, Mr. Stanley Airagua, who donned a traditional outfit that constituted an animal skin coat, white and black headgear made from a columbus monkey skin and a narrow band of a ram's skin tied around his forehead.

A fly whisk, the traditional three-legged stool, a gourd holding some herbal concoction mixed with honey and two calabashes formed part of the high priest's tools of trade.

As he led the procession towards the cleansing site, he took some of the mixture in his mouth, sprinkling it in all directions. On nearing the shrine, women were asked to stay away as tradition bars them from entering the sacred site.

Taken by surprise, some white ladies who had travelled to Mt. Kenya to witness the ceremony reluctantly obliged to this demand as they felt they were not bound by any African culture. In fact it took one of the organisers to explain to a lady sent by the Ford Foundation that the ceremony would not begin without them leaving the scene as demanded. With no option, the bewildered visitor left.

Men were then asked to encircle the shrine but were not allowed to set foot in the inner circle which is regarded as the holiest place, reserved only for the high priest.

A most peculiar process of the cleansing ceremony which was attended by about 50 people including journalists, was the manner in which the ram was killed. Not supposed to make any noise, the animal was strangled and died of suffocation. A mockery of good stewardship and care for the dying animal was done by the presiding traditional priest. To symbolize the grazing of the animal, a blade of grass was put in its mouth.

After the ram was confirmed dead, a knife sharpened on a small stone fetched from the peak of the mountain was used to slit its throat. Then the high priest took blood collected in two calabashes down the stream, and facing the mountain, raised them in supplication as further sacrifice to the gods.

That was not all. The high priest then disappeared into a secluded part of the forest, warning that no one should follow him. Even the curious journalists who kept tab on the ceremony's proceedings were no exception.

Prior to this final event in the Marania Forest at the slopes of Mt. Kenya, some elders and selected youth who will succeed the incumbent elders, had climbed up to the mountain peak where the special rituals were performed. They set up camp for two days at the sites used by the Mau Mau fighters (freedom fighters) during the emergency period in 1952.

This group brought with them sacred stones, some of which were placed at the base of tree seedlings which were then given out only to those who committed themselves to take good care of the plants.

Dr. Jack Githae of the School of Alternative Medicine explained the philosophy of having these stones at the base thus; Stones unlike plants would not die and spiritual blessings given at the mountainpeak would remain.

Offering sacrifice meant that Mt. Kenya was henceforth regarded as a sacred place whose environs should not be defiled by any acts, including unwonted felling of trees in the surrounding forest for timber and firewood.

Dr. Githae and Prof. Gilbert Ogutu, the Dean of the Department of Religious Studies, University of Nairobi, blame deforestation in the mountain forests to the coming of the white man to Kenya.

They contend that the reverence in which the mountain was held died when these foreigners brought their religion (Christianity) and imposed it on the indigenous people. In their teachings, the colonialists dismissed everything African as primitive and heathen.

The result was gradual loss of respect and fear for African deity. This new trend did not spare Mt. Kenya and man has gone ahead to exploit its forest reserves, destroying a resource base for useful herbal medicine and threatening the survival of these medicinal qualities.

Mr. James Dhikusoka Nsobani, the Secretary-General of the Busoga heads of clans council led the Ugandan delegation.

A representative of Kenya's Luo community from Nyanza Province, raised with APS the concern that there are conflicting approaches to the conducting of ritual ceremonies.

For instance, Luos do not use a sheep in a cleansing ceremony. When used as a sacrifice, this animal is normally associated with exorcising evil spirits as in the case of a family possessed with evil spirits.

The method of killing the animal in the two communities also differs. The Luos kill the animal by slitting its throat as opposed to the strangling method used by the Mt. Kenya community elders.

The ELCI Media Coordinator Louisa Lockwood, told APS that her organization attached great importance to the Mr. Kenya ceremony since such an activity would ensure that environmental conservation becomes a priority of the local people who have been alienated by modern day environmentalists.

It promotes use of traditional knowledge which people can identify with and hence understand the implications of conserving the resource base of some of their cherished herbal medicines.

Lockwood noted that protection of forests is not only important for traditional healers, but also for pharmaceutical firms and others concerned in the production of medicine.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


265 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Burundi;
Pope, Burundian Leader Appeal For Calm


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Bujumbura - Burundi's military ruler Major Pierre Buyoya has moved to defuse a potential blood bath in his troubled nation of 5 million people, following the death of Archbishop Joachim Ruhuna, leader of Catholics in Burundi killed in an ambush on September 9.

Buyoya himself from the minority Tutsi who are over represented in the army, went on national radio on September 10 to appeal for calm.

"I ask people not to commit any acts of vengeance. His blood unjustly spilled could be used to heal our own wounds," he implored. 

Archbishop Ruhuna, a Tutsi, was killed while travelling with two nuns, two schoolgirls, an accountant, and a driver when his vehicle was ambushed at Murongwe near the central town of Gitega. At least three bodies have been recovered while two more people are missing. Among the dead is a Burundian nun from Mother Teresa's Missionaries of Charity.

The Archbishop's driver who had gone missing for 24 hours, said on the fateful day, their vehicle was fired at by a number of men who suddenly appeared on the road. The archbishop was killed instantly.

The driver said he escaped by jumping out of the vehicle, and hiding in the bush. He was uncertain about the identity of the attacker.

The authorities in Burundi have blamed the killing of 62-year-old Archbishop Ruhuna on Hutu extremists. He had received numerous death threats due to his constant campaigns against tribal extremists among both the minority Tutsi and majority Hutu ethnic groups. These threats reached a peak during the mass funeral for 300 massacre victims held in Bugendana on July 24.

However the hardline National Council for the Defence of Democracy which speaks for the largest Hutu rebel group, claimed the army, composed mostly of Tutsi, had killed the archbishop because he was a moderate.

Meanwhile Pope John Paul II issued a statement at the Vatican saying the killing had filled him with great sadness.

"I renew my heartfelt appeal for reconciliation in truth and charity," implored the Catholic Pontiff.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


266 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Uganda and Sudan;
Iranian Leader Restores Goodwill Between Uganda And Sudan


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Khartoum - Iranian President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani has successfully mediated an end to the long running hostility between the East African nation of Uganda and its northern neighbour, Sudan.

On September 10 here, Rafsanjani who is on a six-nation tour of Eastern, Central and Southern Africa witnessed the signing of the agreement ending hostilities and restoring diplomatic ties between the two countries.

The agreement called for "immediate" restoration of diplomatic ties which were severed in March 1995 soon after Ugandan rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) massacred 110 civilians in the northern Ugandan District of Apac. President Yoweri Museveni angrily charged that Sudan had armed the rebels. 

As part of the agreement to end hostilities, a tripartite committee comprising Iran, Libya and Malawi - the latter two nations previously tried to mediate peace between Uganda and Sudan - will oversee the implementation of the peace pact that calls for immediate cessation of propaganda campaigns against each other and, more importantly the curtailment of the activities of hostile elements using each other's territory to wage war.

If the agreement is observed in totality, it means rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), who regularly use Ugandan territory for sanctuary and replenishment of supplies will no longer find refuge there.

Neither will the LRA whose leader Joseph Kony is reliably believed to be camped near Juba at the moment, expect support from Sudan.

Both Uganda and Sudan regularly deny supporting rebels fighting in either country but the recent agreement signed by the two nations calls for a supervised clampdown on rebel activities by the SPLA and the LRA.

Uganda will face a major burden as the agreement requires that refugees and all hostile elements be moved 100 kilometres away from the border area. Uganda has more than 250,000 Sudanese refugees on its territory, most of them camped close to the border with Sudan. Observers expect severe logistical problems for Uganda and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) as a consequence of the agreement.

Before leaving Uganda on September 8, President Rafsanjani was already confident that his mediation would bear fruit.

"Considering the goodwill on both sides, I am quite optimistic the problem will be settled," Rafsanjani told the press as he prepared to leave the East African country.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


267 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Nigeria;
New Christian-Muslim Violence In Nigeria


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lagos - A new outbreak of violent fighting between Muslim fundamentalists and Christians has left two people dead and several wounded at Kafachan in Nigeria's northern Kaduna state, military administrators there said here on September 11.

The clashes broke out on September 8 after a Christian preacher, Monday Yakonat, was seized by Islamic extremists as he delivered a public sermon in the mainly Muslim town.

Yakonet's kidnappers threatened to kill him if he did not renounce his faith and accused him of blaspheming against Islam. A group of Christians then stormed the house where the preacher was being held and rescued him. 

In the fighting that followed, a Muslim and a Christian were killed and several people were injured, mainly with stab wounds, according to the local military authorities.

Nigerian press reports had put the toll at five dead and 15 injured and said that, according to witnesses, it took the police several hours to put an end to the fighting, during which a number of vehicles were set ablaze.

Kaduna state's military administrator, Lieutenant-Colonel Hammeed Ibrahim Ali, went to the scene of the violence and visited the injured in hospital.

He warned that he would give a lesson to those who stirred up violence in the name of religion.

Two similar incidents occurred in June in Kaduna state and neighbouring Niger state, claiming at least four lives. About 50 Muslim fundamentalists were subsequently arrested.

Northern Nigeria is inhabited mainly by Muslims, who make up almost 45 per cent of the country's total population estimated at more than 100 million people.

Meanwhile, robbers on September 9 shot and wounded Roman Catholic Bishop Francis Alonge of Ondo Diocese south-western Nigeria, stole his car, money and other valuable items, press reports said here on September 11.

Alonge was attacked late on September 9 by gangsters who stopped his car as he was heading for Benin City, the venue of a Catholic Bishops' Conference which started on September 10.

The hoodlums shot the cleric in both legs and beat up his driver, though he did not resist them, a spokesman of the Catholic Secretariat, Father Emmanuel Ade Badejo, was reported saying.

The bishop, 60, who was ordained 30 years ago, is currently recuperating in a private hospital in Benin City.

The recurrence of the religious violence in the north came despite a decision last July by Nigeria's military rulers to curb religious fundamentalist violence that has caused bloody unrest in northern Nigeria.

A communique issued on July 14 after a military administrators' meeting in Kaduna said the 16 northern states of the federation would combat religious fundamentalism, which had lately claimed three lives, including that of a policeman. This was the first time the north's chief executives had taken a joint decision to tackle the fundamentalist problem.

In December 1994, Muslim fanatics in the town of Kano beheaded Gideon Akaluka, a southern Christian trader of the Ibo ethnic group, accusing him of insulting the Islamic faith.

In May last year, religious riots erupted in the same city and at least 30 people were killed. More than 50 people are currently standing trial before a special tribunal set up by the federal government on civil disturbances.

Joshua Obademi, military administrator of Benue state, said at the end of the Kaduna meeting: "We are concerned that activities of these fanatics have posed a serious threat to security and development of the affected states."

Workable strategies had been put in place to curb religious disturbances in future, he added.

The official did not disclose the strategies, but said they would soon be implemented.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


South Africa;
Truth Commission Vows To Protect Apartheid Era Abusers


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Johannesburg - Truth and Reconciliation Commission chairman retired Archbishop Desmond Tutu has promised legal protection for those who testify about abuses they committed during the apartheid era, as the commission's probe entered a critical stage.

Tutu acknowledged that the commission, which is probing politically motivated crimes between 1960 and 1993, has encountered difficulties in convincing perpetrators to testify.

"I understand that people are scared to speak before us, but we need to know your stories and will protect you once you have spoken," Tutu told a hearing in Nelspruit, a small town about 400 kilometres east of here on September 2.

Of the 1,800 people who have applied so far to the commission for legal amnesty, only "a few dozen" have not been imprisoned or charged with crimes, according to press reports here late August. 

The reports cited unnamed human rights lawyers, commission officials and apartheid-era leaders as believing that many perpetrators are worried that testifying to the commission would lead to imprisonment or other legal problems.

However, the recent indictment of a top intelligence official, Dirk Coetzee, and several of his former police colleagues, has increased perpetrators' uneasiness about the commission. Human rights lawyer Brian Currin, who represents a number of perpetrators, was quoted saying; "This has become a major problem. I have even advised some people not to apply."

While courts are forbidden to use the Truth Commission confessions as evidence, individual testimonies may aid prosecution officials to develop their own new evidence in unsolved cases, Currin was reported saying.

Meanwhile, a number of witnesses in Nelspruit, recently cancelled testimony about the activities of a notorious police-linked gang that operated during the apartheid era, after two witnesses were allegedly assassinated two months ago, the South African Press Agency (SAPA), cited government officials as saying.

Several witnesses told the commission on September 2 that white policemen brought their children into the police holding cells in Nelspruit during a student uprising in 1986 to show them what "terrorists" looked like, the SAPA said.

The unseasiness came at a time when the major combatants during the apartheid era were charging and counter-charging each other on roles they played during the bloody struggle for majority rule in South Africa.

On September 5, Zulu nationalist leader Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi demanded that South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission investigate the killings of 422 leaders of his Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP).

Submitting to the truth body a thick volume of evidence, including a list of 422 IFP local political leaders killed since 1985, Buthelezi said the commission "owes the public of South Africa" an explanation for the deaths, as "nowhere else in the world could killing on such a grand scale go unchallenged and unexplained."

The IFP was the last of South Africa's political parties to make an official statement to the commission, and did so despite an earlier decision to stay away because of what it perceived as the commission's bias towards the ruling African National Congress of President Nelson Mandela, chief rivals of the IFP.

Fierce feuding between IFP and ANC supporters in Buthelezi's powerbase, KwaZulu-Natal province, has resulted in nearly 20,000 deaths since 1985, with both sides claiming to be victims of the other's aggression.

Alex Boraine, deputy chairman of the commission tried to reassure the IFP leader, however, saying all of the party's inquiries would be tackled by a team of truth commission investigators.

On September 9, ANC Secretary-General Cyril Ramaphosa blamed Frederik Willem de Klerk's conservative National Party for the massacre of 29 ANC marchers four years ago.

Testifying at a hearing of the commission at Bisho, Ramaphosa said the September 1992 massacre, in which soldiers fired on several thousand marchers, should be "squarely" blamed on the regime in the then tribal homeland of Ciskei and de Klerk's former white-led government.

Ramaphosa said Ciskei leader Brigadier Oupa Gqozo had been responsible for allowing the deaths, adding that the latter "would not have had the courage to do what he did without" the support of de Klerk's government.

South Africa's homelands, intended as small, semi-independent states to house the country's majority black population, were abolished in the country's transition to democracy in 1994.

Gqozo, who has been invited to speak to the commission, was ordered a week earlier to pay a fine of 10,000 rand (about $2,500) or go to jail for two years after being convicted of illegal trafficking in diamonds.

According to a psychiatric report submitted to court, the ex-leader suffered from feelings of uselessness, guilt and paranoia and was in danger of committing suicide, or believes he has become a target for assassination.

But Tutu said the truth body would seek a second medical opinion on Gqozo's condition, saying: "We don't want to subpoena him although we have the power to do it. We do want to set a tentative date for a special hearing when we would be able to hear the brigadier's testimony."

Other top ANC and NP officials, including former Foreign Affairs Minister Pik Botha, are later expected to testify to the commission about the massacre.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Christian Councils Review Operations


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Harare - A series of consultations on National Councils of Churches (NCCs), round tables and ecumenical enablers bringing together church leaders from 26 African countries ended here on September 8.

A press release from the Ecumenical Documentation and Information Centre for Eastern and Southern Africa (EDICESA), said the consultations were organized by the World Council of Churches (WCC) Unit IV and hosted by the Zimbabwe Council of Churches (ZCC).

The main purpose of the consultation on ecumenical enablers was to consult with people who provide service and those who usually require services in order to define how the services can be regularized.

Ecumenical enablers were identified as people with special ecumenical experience and technical skills to help churches and church related institutions to deal with issues which hinder their effectiveness and efficiency. 

The consultation aimed to put in place some form of structure so that people who need help can get the correct information on how to get assistance.

It was pointed out that the concept of ecumenical enabling ensures that when an organization is in difficulties, it can contact the WCC Africa Desk for assistance, an indication that one can get that expertise from another part of the ecumenical family or from another part of the world.

The participants also agreed on needs that require enabling services and qualifications that an enabler should possess.

Major areas of needs were identified as constitutional, management or stewardship issues, human resource development and utilization, finances and resource mobilization, documentation, theological issues, managing change, pastoral and conflict resolutions as well as information technology.

Meanwhile, at a two-day Round Table Consultation here, participants who included general secretaries of National Councils of Churches (NCCs) and staff from the World Council of Churches (WCC) defined a Round Table (RT) as an "instrument of ecumenical sharing."

"The concept of a Round Table (RT) is indicative of the fact that everyone has a responsibility, that everyone has something to give and has a need," said the General Secretary of the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) , Rev. Mutava Musyimi. NCCK's RT is expected to convene in February 1998.

The participants called for change of attitude on the part of all parties if the essence of ecumenical partnership is to be beneficial.

While the overall aim of an RT should be the mobilisation and sharing of resources, the Harare meeting advised countries that do not have RTs but are anticipating to have one, not to regard the facility simply as a fund raising mechanism.

They noted that for RTs to continue serving their purpose, they must be evaluated by stakeholders and external evaluators at set times. In the period 1994, there were 35 RTs in the world, 14 of them in Africa.

In another development, African church leaders made an appeal for more ecumenical response to the socio-economic and political issues currently facing their continent.

The call was made following a three-day consultation of general secretaries of National Councils of Churches (NCCs) which ended here on September 3, 1996.

Discussions in group and plenary sessions focussed on issues of ownership, relationships and finance of the NCCs.

"We cannot continue to do business as usual. We cannot ignore the changes and the impact they have on our work," said Rev. Richard Murigande, head of the Africa Desk at the WCC, who sighted the fall of the Berlin Wall, the demise of one-party states in Africa and Eastern Europe and the globalization of economies as having impacted directly or indirectly on the work of the church.

Rev. Murigande said the changes in Central and Eastern Europe brought new needs in that region and some of the funds that used to support church work in Africa are now channelled to the new needs. He also pointed out that non- governmental organizations (NGOs) in the North are now collecting money for their own constituency to counter new forms of poverty and marginalisation of people in those countries.

Financial support for the church continues to be reviewed downwards because where the church used to be the only group concerned with the alleviation of poverty, human rights and other socio-economic issues, there are now various organizations working in the same fields and approaching the same donors for funding.

The chief executives of the NCCs noted that the new challenges demand that the councils are run by competent and professional staff who are capable of managing change. Thus they resolved to improve working conditions and introduce incentives that attract and retain qualified staff.

The NCCs undertook to develop local fundraising which could go a long way in promoting self-dependency. However, it was realised that local fundraising could only succeed if NCCs are capable of meeting the aspirations and needs of their members. This could be achieved through regular critical self evaluation of the councils and through information sharing and exchange.

The General Secretary of the Zimbabwe Council of Churches (ZCC), Rev. Murombedzi Kuchera said, for NCCs to remain relevant, they should enable the churches to come together through the councils.

The church leaders also took time to discuss trouble spots in Africa, among them Burundi, Rwanda, Liberia and Sudan. The general secretaries of NCCs from these countries briefed the workshop on the situation in their countries before it was resolved that peacemaking mechanisms should be strengthened at local, sub-regional and global levels.

"The prayer for peace is the prayer of every African," said Rev. Murigande.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Sudan;
Sudanese Churches Speak On Human Rights Advocacy


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lokichoggio, Kenya - The New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) recently organized a workshop to discuss human rights and its biblical context.

The first of its kind, the workshop ran from August 12 to 15 here, some 1000 kilometres north-west of Nairobi. It was jointly supported by the United Nations Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS), the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), Church Ecumenical Action for Sudan (CEAS) and the Maryknoll Catholic congregation, whose experience was based on the role of the Latin American churches in the struggle for human rights and social justice. 

The four-day workshop last month sought a common working ground for the OLS, UNICEF and NSCC in the area of human rights education and advocacy.

The NSCC which is the umbrella of Sudanese churches in exile acknowledges the hope of the Sudanese for a better future by enabling church leaders in Southern Sudan to get involved in monitoring human rights issues based on biblical teachings.

Churches and Christian agencies like the Norwegian Church Aid (NCA), World Vision and the Catholic Relief Services (CRS) are also incorporated in the process of human rights advocacy in the Sudan.

"We think the church has a big role to play in its moral authority to reach the people without political boundaries because human rights are a Christian issue. God created us equally and we should respect each other," the NSCC peace and justice coordinator Mr. Festus Ufulle Gaaro told APS.

The peace and justice desk, sponsored by the NSCC, proposed the organization of future human rights workshop whereby the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), the Southern Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM), the SPLA-United and other factional groups involved in the conflict in the south would be invited.

Churches, non-governmental organizations and the community at the grassroots would also participate at such future meetings.

The 20 participants at the workshop focussed on concerns like child protection, women and the elderly and other victims of the 13 year- old conflict in Sudan.

At the close of the deliberations, participants called for the organization of more similar workshops so that churches can be better equipped in advocating human rights.

The meeting also called for training of trainers in human rights to enhance efficient ways of disseminating human rights materials. The workshop also urged Sudanese churches to fight the forced conscription of children into the government army and the liberation movement forces as well as enslavement of children.

Founded in 1989 the NSCC comprises the Episcopal Church of Sudan (ECS), African Inland Church (AIC), the Catholic Church, Presbyterian Church, Pentecostal Church and the Sudan Interior Mission (SIM).


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


271 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Church Media Urged To Re-Shape Africa's Image


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Johannesburg - Communication and education should play a positive role in re-imaging the African continent and church media in particular must make conscious effort to change the stereotypes projected about the continent.

This was disclosed at a World Council of Churches (WCC) Unit III meeting held here from August 24 to 30. The forum urged church communicators to avoid being mouth piece of politicians who propagate "cheap politics" and instead play the important role of fostering democracy and peace in society. Communicators were called upon to practice Christian values so as to communicate them. 

Speaking on leadership, the Director of Mindolo Ecumenical Foundation, Canon Clement Janda, observed that in Africa, there are three categories of leaders: those who lead by virtue of their birth, those who are appointed by others to lead though sometimes they may not be willing or able to serve and " the most dangerous category" made up of those who impose themselves as leaders because they think they are able to lead.

"The third category will use money, influence, guns...anything to coerce people to accept their leadership," he said. Canon Janda, however, emphasized that the trend in service and ministry today is that "a leader is to be served, to be listened to and not the other way round as ought to be." He called on leaders (both church and secular) to emulate Christ's example of teaching by example. "While Jesus taught by example, we are teaching by coercion," he lamented.

The Director of Communication in the Methodist Church of Benin, Rev. Raphael Houessou (Service de Communication Journal la SENTINELLE) observed that politics (and consequently leadership) have become a quick means of acquiring resources and is no longer a means of sharing what one can offer by way of leadership.

He noted that the church must be united if it is to fight poverty. He however observed that more attention is paid to theological differences rather than unifying factors among churches thus retarding progress. Rev. Houessou called on the church to "respect its diversity but work together" for the churches' unity and progress.

Madame Agathe Okumba D'Okwatsengue of the National Council of Communication (Conseil National de la Communication) in Gabon, pointed out; "The fight for leadership in our churches will bring disaster" and appealed to churches to be "the light of the world."

Mme Okumba also criticised communicators who show off and work for personal glory. She likened this state of affairs to "showbiz", lamenting that it has greatly contributed to lack of objectivity in reporting.

The Director of the Harare-based Ecumenical Documentation and Information Centre for Eastern and Southern Africa (EDICESA), Ms. Tendai Chikuku Nyahoda, lamented the arrogance with which some Christians used God-given gifts. " Everything comes from God. Some church leaders assume it is because of their own abilities that they are leaders, an assumption that leads to strife" within the churches.

She also called on South Africa as a nation "to become part of the region through identifying with others in the region" so as to strengthen the region's economic and political position. The EDICESA head added that South Africa "owes a debt" to neighbouring countries (and others) for the contribution they made to that counry's liberation struggle and that South Africa should reciprocate by working with them not in isolation.

Father Roger Tessier, a correspondent for the Brussels-based Africa News Bulletin (ANB), pointed out that there can be no spiritual healing without recognition of what the problem is. "There can be no social change without the recognition of what is to be changed. The church must invest in personnel and resources in order to be equipped for the service of the church to bring change," he noted.

Participants at the meeting concurred that there is need to re-orient church communication personnel and to encourage creative approaches to communication by providing relevant training.

A journalist with the Protestant Methodist Church in Cote d'Ivoire, Rosine Diodan, called on churches to review women's role in the church. She shared Mme Okumba's sentiments that "the church has not succeeded in overcoming gender discrimination."

She noted that women are not seen as complete human beings, adding that the question about whether or not women have a soul is still valid today. That " there is no place for women in the church" is a moral issue especially among Christians, said Diodan.

According to the convener of the meeting, Rev. Daniel Ntoni-Nzinga, the study group of Communication is one of the four that are aimed at deliberating the broader theme: Towards a Reconstruction for Africa. The study groups are; Democracy and the Ethics of Good Governance; Land, Labour and Capital; Communication and Human Dignity; and Ecumenism, Partnership and Human Rights.

In 1991, the WCC Central Committee invited all WCC member churches and the ecumenical movement at large to "view Africa with new eyes." Consequently, in 1995, the Unit III Programme on Justice and Creation adopted a programme for peace with justice as an ecumenical contribution towards reconstruction in Africa. To achieve its goals, the Programme has been promoting solidarity with Africa through ecumenical exchange visits and study groups which have been taking place since June 1995.

The meeting was held at the Technikon SA Conference Centre in Johannesburg, and deliberated on the subject; Communication and Human Dignity: The Cost of Mediated Reality. Participants came from Angola, Benin, Cameroon, Congo, Cote d'ivoire, Gabon, Kenya, Mozambique, Togo, Zambia and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


272 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Tanzania;
Civic Eeducation Programme Targets Tanzanian Public


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Dodoma, Tanzania - A bishop of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Tanzania (ELCT), has told politicians and church leaders in this East African country to bear in mind that the Church was not partisan to any political party during the last general elections in Tanzania.

Bishop Dr. Peter Mwamasika of the ELCT, Dodoma Diocese, on September 8 told a day-long seminar on parliamentary civic education programme at the new parliamentary complex in this central Tanzanian town, that the country was among the few nations which went into plural politics peacefully.

Bishop Dr. Mwamasika, a former legislator, also told the seminar participants who included MPs, church leaders among them Bishop Mathias Isuja of the Catholic Diocese of Dodoma, prominent political leaders, ministers and representatives from media institutions and non-governmental organizations, that the church was committed to pray for peaceful elections as well as solving problems facing people regardless of religion, sex, race, tribe and political party.

However, he wanted to know the origin of the daily prayers said in the (National Assembly) House and suggested the setting up of a chapel whose chaplain would conduct services before every session. 

Responding to the questions raised by Bishop Dr. Mwamasika, National Assembly Speaker Mr. Pius Msekwa said, daily prayers conducted in the House before the start of business embraced beliefs of all religions and denominations and that words contained in the prayers were not directed to specific denominations.

Mr. Msekwa also said there were no plans to open a chapel at the House premises as Tanzania is a secular state and if a chapel was opened, that would mean the National Assembly would be directing itself to specific religions. He said jokingly that the speaker is the House's chaplain and admitted that the prayer was copied from the British parliament.

The speaker also enlightened seminar participants on the current structure of the National Assembly and how it has implemented its various responsibilities.

Dr. Willbrod Slaa, former Secretary-General of the Tanzania Episcopal Conference (TEC), currently the MP for Karatu constituency in the Arusha region and member of CHADEMA Party, presenting a paper on the role of the opposition parties in the National Assembly said opposition MPs were in the House constitutionally and should not be regarded by the people as trouble makers.

He also said the introduction of multi-party politics in developing countries was perceived as a threat to the government especially by the ruling political party.

Contributing to the discussion, Dr. Aman Kabourou (CHADEMA MP for Kigoma urban) said during the early stages of political reform in East Africa, people agitating for more democracy were regarded as enemies.

Another opposition MP Mr. Isaac Cheyo, representing Bariadi West called for education on the legality of opposition parties in the country to enhance political harmony.

He noted that during the 1995 general elections, the electorate was influenced to hate the opposition as a bad "animal" that should not be entertained. "The artificial hatred was caused by lack of education on the new political system," explained Mr. Cheyo, who is also Chief Whip of the Opposition in the House.

He added that people were made to believe that voting for the opposition was suicidal and was related to the 1994 genocide in neighbouring Rwanda.

A secondary school teacher Ms Asia Maalim, said literature on civic education must be made available in schools to ensure the programme succeeds. She claimed that teachers at seconday schools in Dodoma have not been able to teach civic subjects due to lack of materials, thus implying that most schools in Tanzania are lacking essential materials for studies.

Inaugurating the civic education programme, Prime Minister Mr. Fredrick Sumaye asked experts, institutions and political parties to assist the government to educate the masses on the importance of the programme, "as this could not be done by the National Assembly alone."

The Tanzanian Premier stressed the use of means of media including seminars, lectures, radio programmes, newspapers, use of short film shows, printed materials and public addresses to boost the programme so that it can reach the remote rural areas where majority of the voters are ignorant of civic education. "The focus should be to reach majority of the people who live in rural areas where newspapers do not reach easily," he emphasized.

Mr. Sumaye also mentioned the three pillars of the state - judiciary, legislature and executive saying, where they worked in harmony and with respect for one another, democracy flourished and was seen to exist. "The three should never suppress each other," he cautioned.

Earlier on, National Assembly Clerk Mr. George Francis Mlama, explained that the civic education programme was focussed on the public as a way of informing them of the way in which parliament conducts its business. He said parliamentary civic education will also be taught in schools to enlighten students on how the National Assembly operates.

Mlama confirmed that the Ford Foundation has offered to sponsor the programme through publication of printed materials and radio programmes but did not disclose how much money would go into the venture.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


273 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


South Africa;
Religious Leaders Differ On President Mandela's Romance


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Johannesburg - South African religious leaders are divided over whether President Nelson Mandela and his newly declared love, Graca Machel, wife of the late Mozambican President Samora Machel, should live together out of wedlock.

While most wished happiness for the 78-year-old leader, they disagreed on how he should proceed in his affair with the 50-year-old widow of the late Mozambican president.

Last week, former Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, a friend of Mandela's, raised eyebrows when he urged that the couple marry as a good example to the country's youth. 

But on September 9, Sadullah Khan, director of Cape Town's Islamic Centre, echoed Tutu's sentiments when he said that the Muslim faith could not support a casual or permissive relationship, even in the case of a revered leader like Mandela.

"Mandela is close to a saint in our hearts, but if we are to believe reports that he is having a teenaged relationship, then we cannot condone it," he said.

"We would urge (Mandela) to be a bit more cautious in his personal life for the sake of our youth," Khan added.

The couple, who announced their relationship early September, have no plans to marry, according to a Mandela spokesman, although Machel intends spending two weeks a month at Mandela's home in the Johannesburg suburb of Houghton.

Machel will spend the rest of her time with her family in Mozambique, doing charity work, the spokesman said.

"As both are national figures," Catholic Archbishop Lawrence Henry was quoted by the Star daily here, "I am confident that whatever they decide on their future together will be done with careful consideration."

Another Catholic official, however, named in the newspaper only as Father Blaser of the South African Catholic Bishops' Conference, said: "This would be (Mandela's) third marriage and the Catholic Church would certainly have a problem with him going for his third marriage."

Greek Orthodox Archbishop Paul Lingris said his church could not condone any couple living together out of wedlock, "but (Mandela) is of an old age -- he wants company, that's what he wants."

Ray McCauley, head of the Evangelical Rhema Ministries, called on Mandela and Machel to wed because the president is lonely and elderly.

"It would be wonderful for him to have a woman companion to care and look after him," he told the Star.

W.J. Botha of the mainly Afrikaner Dutch Reformed Church offered personal blessings, saying: "I'm very happy and very glad he's met someone. I hope she will be a blessing and will find joy."

South Africa's chief Rabbi Cyril Harris was reported saying he was delighted that Mandela had found love, and said: "People are entitled to their happiness and Judaism would say it is far, far better for two people to be together than to be lonely."

Mandela was divorced from his second wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela in March after a four-year separation.

The couple, who were married in 1958, lived together only briefly after Mandela was released in 1990 from 27 years in prison under apartheid. They have two daughters.

Mandela has a son and daughter from his first wife, Evelyn Mase Ntoko.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


274 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Egypt;
Another Copt Beheaded By Islamic Militants In Egypt


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cairo - Islamic militants shot dead a Coptic Christian and hacked off his head in a village in Minya region of southern Egypt, police announced here on September 5.

The armed fundamentalists attacked Asham Nabi Tawfiq, 45, a municipal worker, in Gala Basha in Minya province before decapitating him and escaping with his head.

Police said the militants were probably from the outlawed Jamaa Islamiyya (Islamic Group) and targeted Tawfiq because he collaborated with security services and took part in police raids in local villages. 

It is the third time Muslim militants have decapitated their victim. Last September, they killed and beheaded a farmer in a crowded market place in Minya then left his head on an electricity pylon as a warning to police informants.

In July, a rural guard suspected of collaboration was beheaded, also in Minya province, a militant stronghold.

The killing came in the wake of the shooting and killing on August 25 by unidentified gunmen of four people and wounding of a fifth in southern Egypt, according to a statement issued by the Interior Ministry on August 26.

The attack took place in the village of Qariyat Roman in the district of Abu Qurqas in the province of Minya province.

The attackers opened fire at a group of people standing outside a house, killing four men and wounding a fifth.

Three of the dead were identified as Christians and the fourth as a Muslim while the injured man was also thought to be Christian, according to a list of names provided by the ministry.

Nearly 1,060 people -- including many Coptic Christians -- have been killed since Islamic militants spearheaded by the outlawed militant group, the Jamaa Islamiyya, launched a violent anti-government campaign in March 1992.

The latest attack came after the American Coptic Union urged the US Congress on August 24 to investigate killings of Christians in Egypt and postpone aid to the North African nation until basic rights and security were secured for all citizens.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


275 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 16, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria's Methodist Church Approves Ordination Of Women


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lagos - Nigeria's Methodist Church has approved the ordination of women as priests, the church's leader Sunday Mbang announced here on September 5.

The decision to ordain women was taken at the end of the just-concluded 35th annual conference of the church held at Ikot-Ekpene in Nigeria's south- eastern Akwa Ibom state, Mbang said.

The training, qualification, screening and ordination of women to priesthood would be on the same terms as their male counterparts, he added. 

Mbang, who is also the national president of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) said, "women will be trained, just like men, we would not lower their grade or give anybody who is not qualified ordeserving the post any opportunity."

With this decision, The Methodist Church of Nigeria has become the first member of the CAN to approve the ordination of women.

Early last year, an attempt by the Ilorin diocese of the Anglican Communion in Nigeria to ordain women as priests was rejected by the Anglican Church hierarchy and the three women who were ordained by the Anglican bishop of Ilorin diocese were later de-robed by the headquarters of the Church.

The Catholic Church in Nigeria is still opposed to the ordination of women as priests.

Early this year, Rev. Maureen Elizabeth Jones of the Methodist Church in Kenya made history by becoming the first woman bishop in Africa.

Consecrated bishop on January 14, 1996, Rev. Jones who beat three other male contestants told APS in an interview then; "To be honest, I did not expect it...I am very moved and very honoured..."

Born in England in 1939, Rev. Jones said that working as a bishop, and particularly being a white woman bishop among blacks does not make her feel discriminated against. "I have lived with these people for many years and I have never felt discriminated," she added.

She came to Kenya in 1969.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

September 17, 1996


Zaire;
Secretary-General Rejects Zaire's Allegations Against UNHCR


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

United Nations - The following was issued by the Spokesman for Secretary- General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. 

The Secretary-General has learned with deep concern about accusations made by the Government of Zaire that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) has been providing logistical support to armed groups infiltrating Zaire from Rwanda and Burundi with the deliberate intention of destabilizing Zaire.

These accusations have been carried on local television and have caused serious security problems for United Nations personnel working in the region.

The Secretary-General categorically rejects these allegations as completely unfounded and urges the Government of Zaire to take steps to clarify the situation.

Africa News


September 17, 1996


Sports - General;
Boxing: Zambian Goes For World Title


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - National Cruiser-weight champion, Joseph Chingangu, will tomorrow night step into the ring against Hungarian champion, Laios Eros, for the vacant International Boxing Federation (IBF) heavyweight title.

According to Chingangu's Italian trainer, Alberto Pasotti, the fight is billed for the Italian town of Montichiari in Brascia province at approximately 20:00 hours Zambian time. 

"In the same tournament, I am looking forward to featuring Paul Kaoma (the national featherweight champion)," Pasotti said in a fax message to the Zambia Professional Boxing Board of Control (ZPBBC) dated August 31, 1996 and obtained by The Post. "I therefore request a clearance letter for the two boxers and if possible give to Kaoma before he leaves for Italy."

Kaoma left for Italy with the clearance letters on Saturday.

International boxing referee, Felix Phiri, said this is a big day for Zambian boxing and called on all boxing lovers to pray for Chingangu.

"This is a big day for Zambian boxing," Phiri said in an interview yesterday. "We should all pray that he brings the IBF heavyweight title to Zambia."

Former Commonwealth and African light heavyweight champion, Lottie " Gunduzani" Mwale also said it was good that Chingangu was fighting for the world title.

"It's good for the young man. I wish him luck," Lottie said.

This is the third time that a Zambian will be fighting for a world title. The other two times were when Lottie fought for the World Boxing Council (WBC) light heavyweight titles against Saad Muhamad and Muhamad Quayi, respectively.

278 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 18, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

AMBO (ENA) - The number of hides and skins dispatched to the central market from West Shoa Zone during the just ended Ethiopian year has decreased by 100, 000 from that of the previous year, zonal agriculture department said.

Acting department head Ato Tamirie-Mariam Wolde-Meskel said about 512,000 pieces of hides and skins were supplied to the central market during the last budget year.

He attributed the decrease in the amount of hides and skins presented to the central market to the plummeting prices. 

The price of unprocessed skin per kilo which was 2.25 birr has fallen to 0. 26-0-27 cents.

Tourist inflow

ARBA MINCH (ENA) - The konso Woreda culture and information office says the number of tourists coming to the woreda is showing a marked progress.

The office said the number of tourists who visited the attractions of the Woreda jumped from 20 two years ago to over 100 last Ethiopian year.

The income derived from the tourists also increased from 5000 birr in the previous years to 80,000 birr last year, the office said.

The office cited lack of tourist-class-hotels as the major problem impeding the tourist business in the woreda.

Girls join training centre

MAKALLE (ENA) - About 2,500 girls drawn from all zones of Tigray have joined the Abiyade National Service Training Centre, central zone of Tigray, to take part in a three-month training that would be followed by a nine month free service in the region.

The trainees will be given lessons in national and regional development policies, history of Tigray and the role of women in the fight that deposed the Derg regime.

On completion of their training the girls will be assigned in rural areas in Tigray and give free service for nine months.

The centre has so far trained about 6,000 youths for similar purpose.

Pesticide being sprayed in flooded areas

NAZARETH (ENA) - The health department of East Shoa Zone said that pesticide is being sprayed in towns and 125 kebele associations recently flooded by the Awash River to prevent the possible outbreak of malaria.

The Ministry of Health has supplied 2,800 kgs of DDT and 4000 liters of malatine for the operation, Ato Dereje Olana, head of the malaria prevention section of the department said, adding that so far more than 11,000 houses have been sprayed.

The operation is being carried out by 147 people, whereas 80 other people have undergone a six day training to be deployed to the areas soon, Ato Dereje said.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 18, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Prosecutor Focuses on Corrupt Officials


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Office of the Prosecutor General announced yesterday that it has plans to give special attention to cases pertaining to corrupt public office holders running for personal gains.

The Deputy Prosecutor General Ato Mesfin Girma told ENA that his office has sued offenders including robbers, terrorists and anti-peace elements in the past few years but this year it will focus on higher officials bent on misappropriation of public fund. 

Office holders bent on embezzling public property and power abuse will be brought before the court of law as part of the measures to be taken in implementing the principles enshrined in the constitution.

The Office of the Prosecutor General is presently engaged in consolidating its organizational structure, logistics and manpower, he said adding it will employ prosecutors in the coming three months.

He said, the office, beginning last may, has started to investigate into crimes committed in the capital in addition to the cases of the Federal Government.

He cited the five million birr coffee plantation promotion project as one of the cases under investigation.

Business;
Zambia Won't Retaliate Against Unfair Trade


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia will not retaliate against South Africa's unfair trade policies, President Frederick Chiluba said in Harare yesterday. 

President Chiluba, attending a World Solar energy meeting in the Zimbabwean capital, said as a member of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) , Zambia will talk to South Africa to sort out the trade imbalance existing between the two countries.

There have been worries among the Zambian business community that South Africa is pushing its exports cheaply into Zambia while it is expensive to export into South Africa from Zambia.

And President Chiluba said he hopes Zambians will take full advantage of the use of cheap solar power.

Africa News


September 18, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: Under-20 Squad To Break Into Two Training Camps


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Under-20 soccer team will soon break into two training camps: Copperbelt and Midlands to help the players retain their fitness while awaiting their next game in December this year.

This programme follows the sudden withdrawal of Malawi from the competition. Malawi should have played Zambia on September 29.

Speaking in an interview in Lusaka on Monday, Phiri, who had assembled a battle-tested 26-player squad for the match said the team will not disrupt its current training programme but will reorga-nise it to minimise costs.

"We will not break camp as such. But whilst we will not be training all together, we will continue with the training programmes in which Copperbelt- based players will be training at least three days a week," said Phiri who added that the same arrangement will be used for the Lusaka-based players.

Zambia will now have to wait for the winners of the Namibia-Botswana match, for the second round matches to be played in December.

"Because of the transport problems, we will just be monitoring the progress of Kabwe players from the league matches. We do not want to lose to either of our likely opponents," said Phiri, who is also coach for premier side, Lusaka Dynamos.

282 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 18, 1996


Business;
Zambian Farmers Call For Maize Purchase


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Kalomo - Village farmers in many parts of Kalomo district are stuck with maize because they have no market and they appealed to government to intervene.

At Chief Siachitema's palace, 95-year-old Mrs Mudenda Masiye, the mother to the chief complained that they had no empty grain bags and no genuine buyers. 

Siachitema's capital has 12 maize barns full of maize grain.

Chief Chikanta said that his subjects were being robbed by crooks who offered K7,000 per 90kg bag and people had no choice but to get some little cash to solve family problems.

''Government should give a floor price to protect villagers from being robbed'', Chief Chikanta said.

Such a price would limit all to within its levels so that nobody would offer anything below.

Chief Sipatunyana told deputy minister Elias Miyanda that, ''my people are hungry for money. Open agriculture depots to buy maize,'' he told the government.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

283 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 18, 1996


United States and Africa;
Secretary Christopher to Visit Africa October 7-15


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Washington DC - Following is a statement on September 17 from the U.S. Department Of State on Secretary Warren Christopher's visit to Africa.

Secretary of State Christopher plans to make a five-nation trip to Africa from October 7-15. The Secretary is scheduled to visit Mali, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Angola, and South Africa. Secretary Christopher will underscore during this trip the United States' firm commitment to help further democracy, economic development and trade, regional integration and conflict resolution on the African continent. 

The first stop on the Secretary's itinerary will be Bamako, Mali, where he will meet with President Oumar Konare and other Malian officials to discuss their country's efforts to strengthen democracy and further national reconciliation. Regional issues and the environment will be on the agenda as well.

The next stop will be Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, where the Secretary will meet with Prime Minister Meles Zenawi and other prominent Ethiopians to discuss various bilateral and regional issues. The Secretary will also hold discussions with Organization of African Unity Chairman Salim Ahmed Salim on how the United States can best support conflict resolution efforts underway in Africa.

From Addis Ababa, the Secretary will go to Arusha, Tanzania, to hold talks with President Benjamin Mkapa, former President Julius Nyerere, and regional leaders on economic integration and development, conflict resolution, the environment, the Rwanda War Crimes Tribunal, and other topics of concern to the region.

The Secretary will then head to Luanda, Angola, where he plans to meet with President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos and other key leaders in an effort to stimulate further movement toward full national reconciliation in Angola. Secretary Christopher also plans to visit UNAVEM (United Nations Verification Mission in Angola) headquarters, and to observe land mine eradication activities taking place in the country.

The final stop on the Secretary's trip will take him to Cape Town, South Africa, where he will have meetings with President Nelson Mandela, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, and other key South Africans on a broad range of bilateral, regional and global issues.

The Secretary will return to Washington on Tuesday, October 15.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 18, 1996


Zaire;
Boutros-Ghali Phones Mobutu About His Health


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

United Nations - The Spokesman for the Secretary-General Sylvana Foa began today's noon briefing by announcing that the Secretary-General had called Switzerland to speak with Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko to inquire about his health following recent medical treatment. The President assured the Secretary- General that he was in excellent health and intended to return " very, very quickly" to Zaire. The Secretary-General offered his best wishes and they had a good talk.

(...)

To a question regarding whether or not the Secretary-General had asked President Mobutu of Zaire about the situation of staff members of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in his country, Ms. Foa said that the conversation had been confined to Mr. Mobutu's health. Discussions were under way between United Nations agencies in Zaire and that Government, she added. The incidents in question were being taken very seriously. She had heard of several minor incidents recently, including incidents with staff of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) riding in a vehicle of the World Food Programme (WFP). As the incidents had taken place in a very remote region, information was taking up to five days to reach Headquarters.

(...)

285 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 18, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Welcomes Decision To Restore Burundi Assembly


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Washington DC - Following is a statement by White House Press Secretary Mike McCurry.

The United States welcomes the recent announcement issued by the Burundian authorities lifting the ban on political parties and restoring the National Assembly. We view this as a significant step in the right direction. At the same time, we look forward to clarification of some aspects of the announcement and to the effective and impartial implementation of these decisions.

The United States again urges all concerned parties in Burundi to launch, immediately and unconditionally, a negotiating process aimed at ending the killing and establishing a framework for all-party negotiations. This is the way to address the root causes of the conflict and to bring about a better future for all Burundians.

As we continue to call on the Burundian authorities to take further steps to achieve national reconciliation, we stress that the National Council for the Defense of Democracy (CNDD) and all opposition parties must take up the offer of talks and not obstruct them. It is time to stop the killing and start talking. The United States condemns in particular all attacks against civilians and population centers. U.N. Security Council Resolution 1072 emphasized the international community's readiness to consider additional measures aimed at any party, inside or outside Burundi, that is not demonstrating a commitment to a peaceful resolution to the conflict.

Since the July 25 coup, the United States has consistently called on the Burundian authorities to guarantee safe passage out of the country for President Ntibantunganya and others who continue to be accorded refuge in the U.S. and other Embassies. Their freedom to depart the country would be another important indication of the seriousness of the Burundian authorities in seeking an end to the current crisis.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


286 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 19, 1996


South Africa;
Graca Machel Speaks On Romance With Mandela


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Graca Machel, widow of the late President Samora Machel of Mozambique, has spoken out in public on her romance with President Nelson Mandela of South Africa, dubbed the African romance of the year.

In an interview on South African national radio, Graca, 50, said that she and Mandela were happy to have found each other after lives filled with suffering. 

"It's just wonderful," she said, "that after so much pain I have gone through--and I believe that is also from Nelson's side--that finally we have found each other and can share a life together." After months of speculation, the Mandela-Graca romance was confirmed at the beginning of this month. It was stated at the time that the couple had not made plans to marry, but that Graca would be spending two weeks of every month at Mandela's Johannesburg home.

There has been some criticism of this decision, and certain sources have suggested that if Mandela does not actually marry Graca, he would not be setting a good example to the youth of southern Africa as the new Chairman of the Southern African Development Community.

Speaking on South African radio this week, Graca would not go into any further detail about the romance, describing herself as a very private person. All she would add was: "It is just wonderful. There were times when I thought it couldn't happen any more in my life."

Graca's husband was killed in an air crash 10 years ago, and Mandela divorced his wife, Winnie, earlier this year after a steady deterioration in their marriage since his release from prison in early 1990.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


287 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 19, 1996


Cameroon;
Cameroon Gets New Prime Minister


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (PANA) - President Paul Biya of Cameroon Thursday appointed Peter Masani Musonge, a 54-year-old engineer, as the country's new prime minister.

Musonge, who hails from Buea, in the country's Anglophone south-west province, replaces Simon Achidi Achu as head of government, according to a presidential decree issued here. 

He is expected to form a government within the coming days, observers in the cameroonian capital said, pointing out that the rather expected change could be connected with forthcoming presidential and legislative elections whose dates are yet to be announced.

Musonge was born in Buea, capital of the south-western province on Dec. 3, 1942. He attended secondary school at saint Joseph's secondary school in Sasse in what was then known as the Fako division of former western Cameroon.

He later studied in the United States, obtaining his first degree in civil engineering from the Dext Institute of Technology in Philadelphia, and a master's degree in structural engineering from Stanford university, California.

On returning to Cameroon in 1969, the new premier worked as an engineer with the public works department where he occupied various top level positions.

In 1984, he was named director of the national civil engineering pool and elevated to the post of general manager of the pool in 1987. He later became general manager of the Cameroon Development Corporation, a vast public agro- industrial concern.

Musonge is married with four children.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


288 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 19, 1996


West Africa;
Nigeria Accuses Cameroon Of Aggression


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria Thursday accused neighboring Cameroon of renewed aggression in the Bakassi peninsula, barely 24 hours after the United Nations goodwill mission concluded its visit to Cameroon over the disputed territory.

"As I speak to you now, reports that we received in the past day or two is of hostility unleashed again by Cameroon in the Bakassi area," Nigerian foreign minister, Tom Ikimi, told members of the visiting U.N. mission in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.

Ikimi alleged that the resumption of hostility by CameroOn has cast doubt on that country's commitment to the current mediatory efforts of the U.N. Secretary-General represented by the mission. 

"We complain that if this visit was accepted by Cameroon and us, why should they (Cameroon) unleash hostility only 24 hours ago?" the Nigerian minister asked.

Both countries claiming ownership of the oil-rich peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea, have clashed repeatedly in the area since 1994. Both have troops on either side of the disputed peninsula.

Ikimi restated Nigeria's commitment to the resolution of the conflict through dialogue in the spirit of good neighborliness.

"Nigeria would not wage war on Bakassi because waging war on Bakassi would be waging war against our people," he noted.

"All Nigeria is doing," the minister explained, "is to exercise the legitimate responsibility of the government to protect its citizens."

He blamed the dispute on the "unfortunate" legacy of the partitioning of Africa in a way that not only left "brothers and sisters on different lines" of international boundaries, but has saddled the continent with boundary disputes within the last century.

The four-member U.N. team is led by Omar Halim from Indonesia. It includes Willy Vanstraelen from Belgium as well as Mpazi Sinjela and N'tumba Makombo from Zambia and Zaire.

Cameroon has also reported the dispute to the International Court of Justice, at the Hague, and the Organization of African Unity.

Halim said the mission was sent to help reduce tension between both countries through confidence building.

He insisted that the initiative was not intended to undermine the efforts of the International Court of Justice and that of President Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo in trying to resolve the dispute.

"The (U.N.) Secretay-General is concerned that skirmishes could inevitably affect the relationship between both brotherly countries and feels that perhaps he could play a role," Halim added.

The delegation will be briefed by Nigerian government officials and tour the disputed area during the visit.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 19, 1996


Mozambique;
Mozambican Politician's Wife Stabbed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Maria Da Luz Guebuza, wife of Armando Guebuza, who heads the parliamentary group of Mozambique's ruling Frelimo party, was stabbed Tuesday evening, it was reported here Thursday.

According to today's issue of the independent newsheet 'Nediafax', Maria Guebuza was attacked by two men armed with knives near the presidential palace, where she had just driven her niece to an apartment bloc. The two were talking outside the car when the attack occurred. 

Guebuza suffered stab wounds to her chest and legs. But her son and hospital sources confirm that she is out of danger - although doctors were refusing to allow anyone, even family, to visit her on Wednesday.

Armando Guebuza, who is also member a member of the frelimo political committee was the chief government negotiator of the 1992 peace agreement, that ended a 16-year old civil war which was waged by the rebel Renamo movement against the Maputo INL002 from SSS.058 (960919-18:32) QN PANAINL . PANADKR MSG057G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) administration. He is currently on a visit to China.

Guebuza son, 17-year old Mussumbuluku said the motive was car theft, and that his mother's vehicle, a "Ford Telstar", was stolen.

Mediafax also reported Thursday that on Tuesday, at roughly the same time as maria guebuza was attacked, armed men raided the Maputo offices of two European non-governmental organizations, Handicap International and Action Nord-Sud.

The raiders immobilized the two guards on duty (employees of a private security company), beat up the people they found in the offices and made off with 8,000 US dollars and 20 million meticais, the Mozambican currency (about 1,740 dollars).

On Wednesday morning, unknown assailants brutally murdered a 60-year old housewife in a ground floor flat on one of Maputo's principal avenues. The raiders strangled the women, tied up her servant, and stole a variety of goods.

In a second raid on the same street later in the day, the police say that the victim, a man named Rassul Baby, died of a heart attack, brought on by the shock of the attack.
