290 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 19, 1996


Science;
First Africa Solar Car Race On The Cards


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The first ever solar car race in Africa has been planned for March 1998, a spokesperson for Africa Solar Race Private Limited, a Zimbabwean company jointly organizing the race with Unesco, disclosed here.

Sixty solar cars, including 20 from Africa, are expected to cover the 2,745- kilometer (1,716 miles) journey from Harare to Cape Town in 10 days, with a stop-over in Gaborone, Botswana.

The race is intended as a follow-up to the just-ended World Solar Summit in Harare, to create public awareness of the potential of solar energy utilization in industry. 

A number of universities in Zimbabwe, South Africa, Botswana and Ghana have indicated their willingness to develop appropriate solar cars for the race. Tunisia and Cote d'Ivoire were also said to be interested in participating in the race.

The spokesperson said participating universities and institutions were expected to finance construction of the cars or seek the collaboration of car manufacturers such as General Motors, Honda, Mitsubishi, among others, which usually sponsor similar events in the United States, Japan and Australia.

The Africa race is expected to start from Harare's International Conference Center, venue of the world solar summit which ended Tuesday.

Leaders at the summit launched the 10-year World Solar Programme, which underscores the potential of solar energy to contribute to sustained global social and economic development and utilization new renewable sources of energy.

The Unesco-sponsored programme, which is expected to be executed between 1996 and 2005, is an open-ended global attempt by governments in partnership with other organizations to popularize the adoption and wider use of solar power.

It is to evolve over the decade through development and implementation of some 300 top priority national, regional and global solar projects in various fields. The programme will be overseen by a 16-member Solar Commission comprising world leaders chaired by Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe.

Unesco estimates that some 2.4 billion people, mostly in developing countries, lack access to electricity, a major cause of poverty and lost opportunity for concrete social and economic development.

The Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity, Salim Ahmed Salim, said at the summit that Africa had an obligation to increase the continent's per capita energy consumption by exploiting the abundant unconventional energy resources.

"The successful harnessing, development and utilization of this energy source will clearly have far-reaching positive impact on the development of our (African) countries.

Africa will tremendously benefit from the successful utilization of solar as it will constitute an appropriate alternative to the use of firewood which is the cause of serious deforestation and considerable environmental degradation in our continent," Salim told the gathering.

The summit stressed that new renewable sources of energy including the sun, wind, biomass, ocean currents, among others, were cheaper and environmentally- friendly alternatives, when compared to fossil-based fuels like coal and petroleum.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


291 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 19, 1996


Sports - General;
Mozambican Government Rewards Mutola


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano, on behalf of the government, Wednesday handed a cheque for 15,000 U.S. dollars to Maria De Lurdes Mutola, bronze medalist at the Atlanta Olympic Games in the United States in July.

Mutola won bronze in the women's 800 meters (880 yards), becoming the first Mozambican athlete ever to win an olympic medal. 

Chissano handed the cheque during a reception given in honor of the Mozambican delegation to the Atlanta games, at his official residence.

The president also announced that the government will make an apartment provisionally available to Mutola when she comes on holidays and that the state is currently building a permanent residence for her. Mutola currently lives in the United States.

Chissano thanked the Mozambican athletes for their performance at Atlanta. He attributed Mutola's failure to secure the gold medal to poor health at the time of the race.

He revealed that after Mutola's victory, he received congratulations over the phone from leaders of other countries, including President Nelson Mandela of South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


292 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 19, 1996


Arts;
Southern Africa Film Festival Opens Friday


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Leading African film-makers are due here on Friday for a week-long Southern African Film Festival (SAFF), which seeks to boost the film industry in the 12-nation Southern African Development Community.

During the biennial event, being held for the first time as a SADC culture and information sector project, over 20 African feature films will be screened as well as 34 documentaries and short films.

SAFF director, Isaac Mabhikwa, said Thursday that the main objective of the festival was to bring together the continent's film-makers to review progress made to date, and to chart the course for the industry's future development. 

"The development of the film industry of our region is lagging behind and the festival will look at what we can do and how we can do it to improve the situation," Mabhikwa said.

Regional integration through co-operation in production, distribution and exhibition of African films, which have been major hurdles for African artists, will be discussed as an important feature of the festival.

The festival also provides an opportunity for SAFF to lobby SADC governments to carve policies conducive to the development of the film industry.

Running concurrently with the festival would be two workshops on film financing and the Pan-African Union of Women film-makers, which will discuss ways of boosting the involvement and participation of women in film-making.

"Film financing will be a major topic for discussion during the SAFF workshops because there is a serious need to boost production quality as well as output in order to sustain a viable film industry," Mabhikwa said.

SAFF is expected to create a self-sustainable film production unit and discussions on film financing are targeted to improve the quality and step up production.

Nearly all of southern African countries have not achieved their film production potential, with an average of one film being produced each year by one country, said Mabhikwa.

He said Zimbabwe had potential to produce about three feature films per year.

Countries failed to achieve their optimum largely due to financial handicaps and the establishment of a film fund was envisaged.

The festival was supposed to have been held in 1995 as a follow-up to one in 1993, but it had not been possible because there was no permanent SAFF office, making communication difficult.

"SAFF needs a director in a permanent office to follow-up, develop, present and report on the film festival," he said. The festival will organize public screening - from Sept. 20 to 26 in Harare and from Sept. 27 to Oct. 3 in Bulawayo - and screen films which won prizes at the continental festival in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, in 1995.

A film competition is to be held comprising feature films, short films and documentaries from east and southern Africa which were produced after October 1993.

Mabhikwa said for SAFF to be successful, it needed to create links and relations which will ease access to African films.

"Various factors contribute to this difficulty, including poor transport and communications infrastructure in many countries on the continent."

Three Zimbabwean films will be featured - I Am The Future, Flame and Everyone's Child. From South Africa will be Soweto Green, Cry The Beloved Country and Jump. Seven feature films from north and west Africa will also be screened. Three Kenyan female film-makers were expected to attend the festival.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


293 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 19, 1996


Zambia;
Zambian 'Diplomats' Won't Need South African Visas


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Lusaka - All Zambians holding diplomatic passports will no longer have to obtain visas when travelling to South Africa. 

According to a joint communique signed by the South African and Zambian passport authorities, those holding diplomatic passports and going to South Africa on official business will no longer need visas as long as their period of stay in that country does not exceed thirty days.

The two countries also agreed to provide experts during travel document court cases.

Mid this year, South Africa imposed a visa requirement for all Zambians holding diplomatic passports when travelling to South Africa.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 19, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia, Oman Draw


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia national soccer team was held to a goalless draw in their first international friendly match against the gulf nation of Oman.

According to information obtained from the Football Association of Zambia, (FAZ), the Zambians displayed some unmatched skill but were unlucky not to get a goal. 

The team which is on a 14-day trip to the Middle-East plays the Saudi Arabian national team today at Riyadh Stadium, before playing another match against the Saudis next Tuesday in Dammam City.

The squad returns home on September 28 in time for the Africa Cup of Nations match against Mozambique at Lusaka's Independence Stadium on October 8.

And Ethiopia has advanced as the next opponents for the Zambia national under-17 side after beating Sudan, 3-0.

Zambia qualified to the second round of the Africa Youth Cup following the withdraw of Namibia early this month.

The match between Ethiopia and Zambia will be played on the weekend of February 8 and 9 next year.

September 20, 1996


Zambia;
Home Affairs Minister Confers With Buthelezi


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Post of Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Lusaka - Home affairs minister Chitalu Sampa yesterday disclosed that issues pertaining to migration and other matters concerning the movement of the people were top of the agenda in the meeting with his South African counterpart Mongosutu Buthelezi. 

Sampa, who returned yesterday from an official visit to South Africa, said upon arrival at Lusaka International Airport that the deal to grant visas and diplomatic passports to Zambian and South African officials was agreed upon.

Other issues which were discussed included crime and related matters.

Sampa said the talks between the two nations will continue to iron out most outstanding cases and revealed that another meeting for senior officials has been tabled for the middle of next year.

September 20, 1996


Sports - General;
Boxing: Zambian Boxer Out-Guns Opponent


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - TWO-FISTED national featherweight champion, Paul Kaoma, completed a double for Zambia on Wednesday night when he outpointed a Syrian boxer on the day national cruiserweight champion, Joseph Chingangu, won the International Boxing Federation (IBF) heavyweight title.

According to a fax message sent by Kaoma's trainer, Alberto Passoti, to the Zambia Professional Boxing Board of Control (ZPBBC), Kaoma out-gunned Mohammed Omar over six rounds. 

"The fights took place at Montichiary and Joseph Chingangu stopped Laios Eros in the second round of the scheduled 12 rounds championship fight for the IBF international title," reads part of the message.

The message that has cheered the ZPBBC chairman, Hillary Matyola, further reads: "In a supporting bout, Paul Kaoma fought and won against Mohammed Omar of Syria on a unanimous points decision in a distance of six rounds," .

And Matyola, said it was a great day for Zambian boxing, and hinted that the two pugilists would be treated to a hero's welcome.

"As a board, we are very happy and we shall give them a hero's welcome when they come on Saturday," Matyola said.

Africa News


September 20, 1996


Sports - General;
Track: Zambian Medalist Wins Circuit Meet


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga and Peter Fredricks, The Post of Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's silver medalist at the Atlanta games, hurdler Samuel Matete, last week Saturday scooped the men's 400m hurdles dash in Tokyo, Japan.

Matete, who has not been performing at his best since the Olympics, emerged winner ahead of six other runners . 

Incidentally, it was in Tokyo that Matete, first emerged as a world beater when he scooped the 400m hurdles world championship in 1991.

Among the victims of Matete's grand return to Japan was the American, Derrick Adkins, who beat the Zambian at the Atlanta Olympics to win the gold.

But it is still not clear if his other rival, American Kelvin Young was also among the participants.

However, it was announced that among the losers was the Kenyan Daniel Komen, who recently beat Matete in a meet held in the Italian city of Milan.

And the Zambian star runner is now among the top nine runners in the world after selections done at the end of both the European and Japan meets.

Kenyan hurdler, Daniel Komen leads the pack with 103 points. Jack Edwards of Britain is second with 99 points. On number three is D. Mitchell(USA) with 95 points while N. Morcel of Algeria is fourth with 93 points.

American, Derrick Adkins, who beat Matete to win the Olympic gold medal is fifth with 91 points, while the Zambian super star, Matete, is sixth at 90 points. Canadian D. Bailey is seventh with 85 points while Russian, M. Tarasov is the ninth with 70 points.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


298 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Zambia;
Civic Groups Hold Convention


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - Civic organisations will tomorrow hold a national convention on Zambia's political future at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Centre.

According to a statement drawn up by the Legal Resource Foundation on behalf of the civic organisations and released by Inter-African Network for Human Rights and Development (AFRONET) executive director, Ngande Mwanajiti, in Lusaka yesterday the organisations have decided to hold the convention because of the worrying political situation in the country. 

"For the past months we, as civic organisations, have seen events unfold which threaten to undermine the forth-coming presidential and parliamentary elections and the prospects of democracy in Zambia," part of the statement reads. "The MMD and the government on one hand and the opposition parties on the other are not agreed on the way forward. This situation has provided the basis for our involvement. The issues raised touch on matters which fall within our areas of interests as civic organisations."

This is the second time the country's civic organisations will convene over the political situation in the country.

Last September the organisations convened at the same venue, Mulungushi International Conference Centre, and resolved to hold a "Citizen's Convention" .

During the Citizen's Convention, the organisations came up with what was called a "Green Paper" which outlined their stand on various issues, among them the adoption of the Constitution, the Public Order Act and the electoral process.

Tomorrow's convention is expected to focus on these issues and, according to the statement, "determine the way forward".

"The deliberations of the convention will not be in a vacuum but will be guided by the fact that Zambia has committed itself to democracy and the resolutions of the convention will be assessed in terms of how we can enhance and consolidate democracy in Zambia," the statement says.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


299 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Zambia;
President Chiluba To Sue Opponent Kaunda


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Lusaka - State House has accused UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda and Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) chairman Roger Chongwe as the source of first lady Vera Chiluba's drug story which was published by German and the South African newspapers and on Wednesday quoted by The Post newspaper.

President Frederick Chiluba's public relations and press assistant Richard Sakala, at a State House press briefing yesterday, also disclosed that the President has decided to seek legal redress against former president Kaunda, Chongwe and The Post newspaper for publishing, "patently malicious lies aimed to injure the first family".

"State House has fully investigated the circumstance and sources of the story published in The Post Newspaper of Wednesday, September 18, 1996 entitled 'Vera linked to drugs' ," the statement issued by Sakala to government owned and controlled media read. "We have since established the fact that the source of the story is former president Dr. Kenneth Kaunda." 

But Kaunda in an interview with ZNBC yesterday wished President Chiluba good luck in his efforts to sue him and could neither deny nor confirm that he was the source of The Post story.

And Chongwe, who is an eminent human rights lawyer, said as long as the President waives his immunity they were prepared for him.

"The President is just like any other person and he should realise that under the Constitution of Zambia he does not have immunity when it comes to such cases," Chongwe said in an interview yesterday. "Once he continues taking people to courts his immunity wanes. We are prepared for any action he is going to take."

Sakala claimed in his briefing that between 11 and 14 August 1996 Robert Von Lucius, theESouth African correspondent of the German daily newspaper, the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ), visited Zambia

and it was during the same visit that he met former president Kaunda and Chongwe who told him that President Chiluba wasEEactively involved in drug trafficking.

"Dr Kaunda further told Lucius that he was at the Jan Smuts Airport on October 11, 1996 when the first lady Mrs Vera Chiluba was caught with 4 kilos of cocaine,"Sakala said. "The same reporter interviewed Dr. Rodger Chongwe who also told the reporter and I quote, 'Mr Chongwe maintained that the President was himself a drug dealer'."

Sakala further told the press briefing that the President was deeply concerned by the continuing malicious defamation and slander orchestrated by former president Kaunda overseas.

"The attack on Mrs Chiluba in The Post, which incidentally was availed this information, is seen as the continuing crusade against the Zambian leadership, " Sakala said. "The President has therefore decided to seek legal redress against Dr. Kaunda, Dr. Chongwe and The Post newspaper for publishing patently malicious lies aimed to injure the first family."

And in a telephone interview, Sakala angrily refused to reveal when the President will take the matter to court.

"What is your problem, what is your problem you people?" Sakala asked before slamming the telephone receiver down.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Sports - General;
Zambia: 200 Golfers Enter Viking Open


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - The Nordic Golf Association (NGA) will hold their annual Viking Open Golf tournament on Sunday, September 22 at the Lusaka Golf Club.

NGA chairman, Christer Agren, said in an interview yesterday that this year's tournament will attract around 200 players while the guest of honour will be youth and sport minister, Samuel Miyanda . 

"As in previous years, many prominent people like honourable Alfeyo Hambayi, President Chiluba's Chief of Staff Alexander Chikwanda, diplomatic heads of mission, prominent lawyers, different politicians, leading bankers and businessmen will participate in the event," Agren said.

The NGA (Zambia) was formed in 1987 and consists of representatives from the four Nordic countries -- Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden.

"The aims and objectives of the association are mainly to assist to promote golf in Zambia, promote relations and knowledge about the Nordic countries and businesses represented in Zambia and the region as well as a promote relations and collaboration between the Nordic people in the region," Agren said.

Africa News


September 20, 1996


Kenya;
Kenya Bans Local Liquor After 20 People Die Of Poisoning


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya Thursday instructed police and local administration officials to crack down on the brewing and consumption of illicit liquor, following the deaths of some 20 people in the country's central province after consumption of a local brew, chang'aa', which also left six others irreversibly blind.

Reports in Friday's daily newspapers indicated that the mysterious alcoholic brew was pure poison which the victims mistook for chang'aa. 

Moi expressed concern over the deaths, saying the incident could have been prevented. He warned that any law enforcement officer who will be lax in implementing the directive would be sacked.

Police said the 26 victims took methanol, a colorless flammable toxic liquid which even in small doses may cause blindness, whose water content was a negligible 0.1 percent.

The poisonous chemical is usually used in the manufacture of paint thinner, varnish and other related chemicals specifically meant for industrial use.

Chang'aa has always been an illegal drink but, the government has in the past allowed the brew during traditional ceremonies, with the permission of local chiefs.

Moi recalled that he had banned the illegal brew in 1980, when he told Kenyans he wanted to lead a healthy nation. However, he said, the brew had slowly resurfaced in many parts of the country.

Africa News


September 20, 1996


Kenya;
Government Confirms Devil Worship In Kenya


BYLINE: Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - The Kenya government has confirmed that devil worship cults exist in the country and advised the public to desist from getting involved in the practice which is in its formative stages.

A government statement broadcast over the government-owned Kenya Broadcasting Corporation, Friday, said self-confessed devil worshippers practiced such rituals as human sacrifice, the drinking of human blood, eating of human flesh and the celebration of black mass by nude worshippers.

The revelations came from a government-appointed commission of inquiry set up on March 1, 1995, following widespread public concern over the alleged devil worship in the country. 

The government first appointed a committee in October 1994, which was later upgraded into a commission owing to the seriousness of the matter, the legal implications and the general complexity of the assignment.

The commission was also to establish the extent and effects of satanic infiltration in educational institutions and society, establish its reported linkage to drug abuse and other anti-social activities and make the necessary recommendations to deal firmly with the menace. The commission's report, which has since been submitted to the government, confirms that devil worship does indeed exist in Kenya and its horrible practices were even more bizarre than the Kenyans ever imagined.

Other rituals listed are incantations in unintelligible languages, sexual abuse and rape of children and minors, black magic, use of narcotic drugs and holding snakes in reverence.

"After carefully considering the reports from the individuals with personal experience in the cults and evidence from self-confessed devil worshippers whose submissions were confirmed by credible independent sources, the commission found ample corroborative evidence of the devil worship," the government said.

The commission had also received information of horrifying criminal cases including kidnapping especially of children, rape, child abuse, murders, and the severing of body parts such as the tongue and the limbs and gouging out of the eyes.

The cult members also use strange symbols, signs and codes, and are obsessed with sex and especially homosexuality and lesbianism. They use frightening names such as the killer, cobra, scorpion, and the python.

According to the statement, the government had carefully studied the commission's recommendations which had far reaching implications on learning and other institutions.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 20, 1996


Mozambique;
South African Settlers Arrive in Mozambique


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The first batch of South African farmers has arrived in the northernmost Mozambican province of Niassa, reports Friday's issue of the Maputo-published daily, Noticias. The newspaper quoted the Niassa provincial director of agriculture and fisheries, Inocencio Sotomane, as saying they were "more than 20" settlers. 

Reports of the settlers' arrival came shortly after an announcement by the South African Chamber for Agricultural Development of Africa (SACADA) that they were not expected in Mozambique until the end of September.

The white South Africans are expected to invest in Mozambique's agricultural sector under a joint Mozambique-South African bilateral programme called the "Mosagrius Development Corporation" agreed upon by the two governments in May this year.

The chairman of the Niassa agro-industrial and trade association, Fazal Laca, has said the Mosagrius project brings hope for the development of the province, which is poverty-stricken despite its excellent natural conditions.

According to Laca, the Mosagrius programme will consist of a variety of projects where Mozambicans and South Africans are expected to invest, particularly in the area of services.

He said the programme will involve the improvement of transport and access routes, the building and repair of roads, to allow easier marketing of agricultural production.

Meanwhile, Sotamane said that areas have already been allocated to the South African investors. He said that Majune district will be for agricultural projects, whereas Sanga and Lago districts will be for livestock raising and eco-tourism projects.

Lago contains the spectacular mountain scenery and unspoiled beaches of Lake Niassa.

The Mosagrius agreement, endorsed by Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano and his South African counterpart, Nelson Mandela, is renewable every ten years.

It paves ways for the settling of South African farmers in areas of low incidence of land conflict, particularly the northern provinces of Cabo Delgado and Niassa.

September 20, 1996


Business;
South African Company To Boost Mali's Gold Production


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - A giant South African mining group plans to boost production by 60 percent in southern Mali's Syama Gold mine, one of West Africa's biggest.

The company concerned is Randgold Resources--the exploration and new business arm of Randgold and Exploration Company, which took over control of BHP Minerals Mali this month from Australia's Broken Hill Proprietary Company (BHP). 

The agreement included a 65-percent stake in the Syama Gold Mine, as well as BHP's exploration interests in Mali at a cost of 30 million U.S. dollars in cash; a 23-million-dollar loan claim; and a US 31-million-dollar loan to be retained by BHP and repaid over a six-year period.

The South African company intends to raise output at the Syama Gold Mine from 125,000 to 200,00 ounces a year, but has given no indication of the time- frame for this production increase. A company spokesman said that this would be achieved by modernizing machining methods and improving staff morale.

He said that SOMISY--the Syama mine's operating company--had enormous potential and could be revitalized with the correct rehabilitation strategies.

Syama's gold reserves are estimated at 110 tons. Production at the mine began six years ago.

September 20, 1996


Business;
Heavy Foreign Trading On Harare Stock Market


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Foreign investors have since June 23, 1993, purchased shares worth more than 2.9 billion Zimdollars (290 million U.S. Dollars) on the local stock exchange, now one of the world's top five emerging indices.

Statistics released by stockbrokers, Edwards (Amper) Company, showed that purchases since government announced foreign investors could participate on the exchange had as of Sept. 13, reached 291 million U.S. dollars. 

The net inflow after sales during the same period totalled 122 million dollars.

The stock market's capitalization had increased from 4.4 billion U.S. dollars in the week ending Sept. 9, to 4.7 billion dollars a week later, reflecting heavy trading on selected key industrial counters.

In a review, the firm said foreigners were generally sellers while local institutions and individual investors remained strong buyers.

Selling by foreigners was noted in the food manufacturing firm, Cairns, the blue-chip conglomerate, Delta Corporation and sugar grower, Hippo Valley Estates.

Deals took place in the Barclays bank, the tobacco group TSL and the largest hotel and leisure group, Zimsun.

The firm cautioned the recent bull run on the stock market, which has seen the industrial index hitting daily records since Sept. 4 could be short-lived.

"Despite the lower than expected inflation figures for August at 17.65 percent, we feel that the 19 percent rise in the market since the beginning of September indicates that the market has become overheated. A small correction and return to reality may not be too far off," the firm said.

Foreign investors were recently allowed by the central bank to increase their holdings in listed companies from 35 percent to 40 percent, and from 5 percent to 10 percent purchases in a single stock.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


306 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Kenya;
Clamor For Constitutional Reforms In Kenya Heats Up


BYLINE: Ruth Nabakwe, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - As the saying goes, there is always light at the end of the tunnel, but for Kenya, where the clamor for constitutional reforms among opposition politicians, churches, NGOs as well as professionals and individuals continues, it is hard to visualize where the debate is headed.

Since the repeal of section 2A of the country's constitution in 1991, ushering in multiparty politics, no other issue has generated as much political passion and controversy as the calls for constitutional reform.

From the time the opposition in Kenya lost the 1992 general elections, won by the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU), they have come to regard the current constitutional arrangement as the major stumbling block to their collective political ambition.

Political analysts say the opposition have come to regard constitutional reforms as the only way to ensure a level playing field which they consider crucial in their campaign to dislodge KANU from power. As a result, they have concentrated a lot of energy on the issue. 

According to Professor Henry Mwanzi, the constitutional reforms stem from the fear of the 25-percent rule, passed by parliament in 1992. The rule requires that a winner in the presidential elections garner at least 25 percent of the vote in at least five of the country's eight provinces.

"The desire by opposition parties to have the 25-percent rule changed stem from the fact that they do not have a candidate who can get votes outside tribal area," observes Mwanzi.

The bone of contention in the constitutional furor between KANU and opposition parties has been the forum for effecting the required constitutional reforms and when this should be done.

President Daniel Arap Moi has made it clear that the forum at which constitutional changes would be effected was parliament.

However, according to a Nairobi lawyer, Joseph Mutava, parliament lacks the professional capacity to comprehensively review the constitution.

"The partisan interests in the current parliament and the huge majority the ruling party, KANU, has," he argued, "would make it almost impossible for the house to give rational and fair views on the constitution."

He said the parliament could not effectively debate constitutional changes as the members would be fronting for their own interests.

He told a recent Nairobi workshop on constitutional reforms that parliament did not have the capability to handle the complex process of constitutional reform without input from elsewhere.

Other interest groups have now joined the bandwagon for the reforms.

The Catholic church, in a recent a pastoral, said it could not avoid dabbling in politics as it dealt with social and political issues.

The church and state, it noted, had the same goal--to improve the welfare of Kenyans.

The opposition and interest groups would prefer that constitutional reforms be effected before the next general elections in 1997.

The Attorney-General, Amos Wako, says the need for constitutional review should not he tied to the next general election, not only because of the time factor but also because most of all the issues concerning the election can be dealt with at legislative and policy levels.

Opening a constitutional conference in August at the Kenya coastal city of Mombasa, Wako advocated for a national constitutional review committee and not a national convention or conference as the best way to effect constitutional change.

Such a committee, he said, would traverse the country collecting views and make recommendations based on consensus. The recommendations would then be debated in parliament which is the only institution that can effect a constitutional amendment.

As the constitutional debate rages on, analysts and observes of the Kenyans political scenario agree that the opposition have continued to wrangle and split and form new alliances.

Their talk of "the grand march to state house" and "Moi must go" have come to be viewed by the general population as efforts aimed at self-serving aggrandizement at the expense of issue-centered mechanisms that address the myriads of problems facing Kenyans.

"Their call for constitutional reforms emanate from the fear of imminent defeat and they would like to explain it away by blaming the constitution," says Mwanzi.

Analysts say the majority of opposition supporters feel let down by those they expected to effect a system of check and balances on the governing party. And dissolution continues to grow as the opposition continue to be divided.

The recent remarks in London by the British high commissioner to Kenya, Simon Heman, that President Moi was poised to win the 1997 election drew the wrath of opposition party operatives who viewed the remarks as biased.

However, given the disarray among the opposition parties and the absence of direction, indications are that the ruling party is poised to win again.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


307 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Constitutional Changes Rile Zimbabweans


BYLINE: Julius Zava, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Harare - Zimbabweans are concerned that the ruling Zanu-PF party is amending the constitution willy-nilly, and is trampling on human rights and eroding judicial independence in the process.

Since independence in 1980, Zanu-PF, which has 147 MPs out of a total 150, has amended the constitution 13 times. The 14th amendment has just been submitted to parliament.

Justice Minister Emmerson Munangagwa responded to opposition over the latest proposed amendment by saying, "We (Zanu-PF) make constitutional changes that are necessary to us."

In the last five years, the Constitution has been amended four times to reverse decisions made by the supreme court, notably in cases where the government had previously lost in court.

Tendal Biti, a human rights lawyer, says: "in a democracy, the erosion of the rule of law is demoralising and unacceptable."

In addition to eroding the rule of law, the government is accused of having eroded human rights protected under the constitution.

A University of Zimbabwe Constitutional law lecturer, Welshman Noube, says: "I think it's the height of madness to amend the Bill of Rights."

The latest proposal is an amendment to section II of the constitution the " pillar of Zimbabwe's human and individual rights", Noube says.

The amendment imposes strict regulations on foreign spouses who will no longer get automatic citizenship.

"There are a lot of intermarriages in Southern Africa and a lot of people will be affected, not just whites marrying blacks as politicians think," said Everjoice Win of an organisation called Women in Law and Development in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Madagascar;
Malagasy President Impeached


BYLINE: Chris McGreal, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Johannesburg - Madagascar has called a snap election, pitting the island's impeached populist president against parliament in a struggle with roots in a bizarre effort to revive a decrepit economy with loans from drug traffickers and scam artists.

Madagascar's former military ruler, in exile in France, has also said he will compete in the presidential ballot set for November 3.

The vote was called after the high court upheld parliament's impeachment of President Albert Zafy for exceeding his powers, and ordered his removal from office until elections have been held. Zafy said he is the victim of a constitutional coup and would not be prevented from regaining office. 

"I am not a murderer and I have not committed any crimes. I therefore intend to stand for re-election and nobody can stop me from doing so," he said.

Zafy (70) overturned 17 years of military rule when he handily won the presidency in 1993. But he swiftly ran into a political mire over Madagascar's economy which was reeling from mismanagement by the former Marxist- turned-reformist regime. The island is $4-billion in debt and unable even to meet interest payments. It has the lowest international credit rating possible, putting it on a par with Zaire where the formal economy barely exists.

The government is divided over how to handle the crisis. Madagascar's former prime minister led one faction in favour of following an International Monetary Fund austerity plan, without which the country found it all but impossible to borrow money through the normal channels.

But Zafy rejected the social cost of large public- sector job and service cuts as too high on an island where nearly half the children suffer retarded growth or acute malnutrition.

When the World Bank refused new loans, officials sought alternative sources of money with the president's backing. The administration called it "parallel financing". The World Bank called it money laundering.

Among other deals, the Malagasy government attempted to borrow $450-million through the bank account of a goat farmer in Texas. The World Bank warned Madagascar the money was being laundered by drug cartels.

In a series of other bizarre schemes -- involving an array of characters claiming to be anyone from the board of governors of The United Nations of America to a relative of the Prince of Liechtenstein -- Madagascar's treasury appeared to lose more money than it gained.

In the ensuing political battles, Zafy tried to fire the prime minister. Parliament said he could not. A year ago the president called a referendum on the issue, which he won handily among poverty-striken islanders fearful of yet more austerity.

The legislature responded by impeaching the president on the grounds that the referendum and subsequent dismissal of the prime minister were unconstitutional.

Zafy's principal rival in the election will be the speaker of parliament, Richard Andriamanjato, a former ally who led the charge for impeachment.

This week Zafy accused the speaker of using the crisis to further his own presidential ambitions and of pursuing an alternative parallel financing plan by agreeing to a $300-million scheme to dump toxic waste in Madagascar.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Angola;
Treasure-Seekers Find Only Trouble


BYLINE: John Liebenberg, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africans who are plundering Angola's diamond fields have no respect for the country's laws or Angolan sovereignty, according to officials in Luanda.

Eighteen South Africans were imprisoned for eight days due to an " unfortunate mistake" by the Angolan government over their visas and the mining equipment they had imported, the group's leader, Cicero Combrink, said on their return to Johannesburg International Airport on Wednesday night.

Combrink said the charges against them had been dropped, and this was confirmed by Angolan diplomat Jorge Morais. Combrink said he planned to return to Angola in "10 days" to continue mining in northern Angola. 

There are unconfirmed reports that another 10 South Africans are being held hostage by Angolan soldiers at a diamond concession on the Chicapa River in northern Angola.

South African miners, like many others, have been lured to Angola by the promise of untold wealth contained in the fabled diamond fields of northern Angola. According to a statement by the Angolan government, the 18 were rounded up as part of Angola's "Cancer Two" operation, which is intended to halt the illegal arrival of South Africans and their equipment.

They were originally charged with illegally importing mining equipment, illegally working in the country and three of contravening flight regulations.

Combrink, from Vereeniging, was formerly a part-owner of an unregistered South African company called the Esperanze Group, which went bankrupt earlier this year. Combrink was trading under a new company called Cacom Diamonds, at the time of his arrest.

According to his wife, Anel Combrink, Combrink had earlier this year mined a concession under the name of Esperanze at Dundo in Lunda Norte, in a venture with partners he eventually sacked. Lunda Norte, which borders Zaire, and Lunda Sul, are known as Angola's "diamond provinces".

The concession yielded few diamonds and Combrink abandoned the project and his equipment, and returned to South Africa, where he formed the new Cacom Diamonds company with four directors, one of them himself and one his wife.

His wife said this week that Cacom Diamonds had recently formed a partnership with an Angolan company called Sicofal, which owns diamond concessions in Lunda Norte. One of Sicofal's directors is an Angolan general.

Combrink left South Africa early this month with 14 employees and investors for the Angolan border. He crossed into Angola from Namibia but got no further than Ongiva in Kunene province, 30km from the border, where he was arrested by the Angolan authorities.

According to Anel Combrink, their troubles began after her husband provided information about a former partner, Malcolm McAlpine, to the Angolan embassy in Pretoria.

The Angolan authorities have now refused permission for McAlpine, who is well-known in diamond circles, to enter the country.

Thousands of foreigners, including many South Africans, have taken advantage of ineffective government controls to illegally enter the country, often using light aircraft.

An estimated 2 000 foreigners have been expelled in the last eight weeks, their warehouses closed and goods worth millions of rands confiscated.

According to a Johannesburg-based diamond miner who was employed by Combrink as a diver (many of the gems are recovered from Angola's diamondiferous riverbeds), who asked not to be named, South Africans often put up the costs for the expensive mining equipment that is needed and go into partnership with Angolans who are legally able to obtain mining rights.

The diver said South Africans seeking the riches of Lunda Norte often entered the province with a 30-day temporary visa, but were always forced to surrender their passports on arrival by border authorities. He said they were then approached by Angolans and promised permanent work permits which invariably failed to materialise.

The diver said that sooner or later the South African miners were forced to leave Angola either because they lacked the correct immigration documentation, ran out of funds, or their equipment was seized by the authorites.

"The South Africans are like the Russians in Kinshasha and have little regard for Angolan sovereignty and common law," claimed Paulo Carmo, Angolan airlines' operations manager in Johannesburg.

He said the prospective miners often flew into Angola with false flight plans, then faked emergency landings at airfields near remote mining towns. Once on the ground, Carmo claimed the pilots offloaded their cargoes, often without paying tax or customs duty.

According to new legislation, all aircraft will now have to report to Luanda before travelling further in the country.

Back in Pretoria there is little sympathy for the plight of South Africans who venture illegally into Angola in the search for diamonds.

A Foreign Affairs Department representative said that South Africans often did business in Angola without informing the department of their whereabouts or business intentions.

He added that the South African authorities only heard from the miners when they got into trouble.

Although many would-be investors have accused the South African government of not warning them about the difficulties of operating in Angola, the representative said, "how can we if they do not tell us they are there?"

Not all South African diamond miners ignore Angolan laws or go broke. Three of them -- Brian Atwell, Leon Gerber and Piet Cronje -- are reportedly doing well on their concessions on the Luachimo River, 100km south of the Zairean border.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


310 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


South Africa;
Catholic Bishops Ready To Fight Abortion Law


BYLINE: Gaye Davis, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africa's Catholic bishops intend challenging the liberalisation of the country's abortion laws in the Consitutional Court.

The Southern African Catholic Bishops' Conference (SACBC) has instructed Durban advocate Noel Pistorius to prepare its case and will launch its challenge should the Termination of Pregnancy Bill be passed into law.

Lobbying by the Catholic Church is understood to have included President Nelson Mandela himself, who was visited informally recently by Archbishop Wilfrid Napier of Durban, Archbishop Lawrence Henry of Cape Town and Bishop Louis Ndlovu of Swaziland -- the president and two vice-presidents of the SACBC.

And on Monday, the day before the Bill was tabled in Parliament, a six- member SACBC delegation led by Napier met African National Congress national executive committee members, including Deputy President Thabo Mbeki. 

Other ANC members present were Health Minister Nkosazana Zuma, ANC Deputy Secretary General Cheryl Carolus, Deputy Finance Minister Gill Marcus and Mpuma-langa Premier Matthew Phosa.

The SACBC delegation asked the ANC to allow its members in Parliament to vote according to their consciences on the Bill, in a free vote. ANC policy, however -- spelt out in its election manifesto -- unequivocally backs women's right to safe, legal abortions, and the ANC's national executive committee (NEC) recently took the position that its members must vote in line with policy.

For Christian and Muslim ANC MPs and others who oppose abortion on moral grounds, this presents a dilemma. When it comes to the vote, there could be many empty seats as MPs find themselves having to attend to urgent constituency business.

The ANC's parliamentary caucus has yet to discuss the issue. "If the NEC has taken a position, the caucus must follow the line," said Mbeki's parliamentary counsellor, Mavivi Manzini. "If there are problems, the matter must be referred back to the NEC."

"We know there are ANC MPs with differing views," said the SACBC's associate secretary general, Father Emil Blaser. "It is such an important issue of conscience -- we feel there should not be a whipped vote."

He was unhappy that ANC officials at the meeting had not informed the SACBC delegation that the Bill was to be tabled the next day. "They would surely have known, yet they did not say a word."

If the Bill was passed, the SACBC would go to the Consitutional Court and argue against it in terms of the Constitution's guarantee of the right to life, Blaser said. "As far as the church is concerned, life begins at conception and ends with natural death."

He said the church, which ranked as the largest Christian denomination in South Africa, with between 3,5-million and four million members, might consider a joint Constitutional Court challenge with the National Party.

The NP this week said it would oppose provisions in the Bill that allow for abortion on demand in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. Sheila Camerer, NP representative on women's issues, said the party would take the issue to the Constitutional Court "if necessary".

Blaser said "even the status quo" was preferable to what the new Bill was proposing. At present, abortions are allowed under certain conditions. But red tape and lack of access to doctors means the current law is discriminatory against the majority of women. Many end up resorting to unsafe backstreet abortions. Many die, while treating women who have had illegal procedures costs the state millions.

These are among the reasons why the Bill has been welcomed by abortion- reform campaigners. It provides for abortions within a health-care framework that will see the service provided across the country, at primary and secondary health-care facilities, not just state hospitals, as is the case at present.

The Bill will be gazetted for public comment and the National Assembly's Health Portfolio Committee must hold hearings before it goes to Parliament for approval.

Efforts were this week under way to arrange for the Bill to be dealt with during the last session of Parliament this year. However, a brace of criminal justice Bills has been marked top priority by the Cabinet and Parliament must deal with them first in what will be a very short session.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


311 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


South Africa;
Student Congress Support Dwindles


BYLINE: Joshua Amupadhi, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africa's biggest student body, the South African Students' Congress (Sasco) is sliding in popularity just as it celebrates its fifth anniversary.

Recent campus polls show Sasco is losing its grip on students' representative councils (SRCs) -- turf it had secured over the last few years at most tertiary institutions.

Elections are still taking place on some campuses, but results so far indicate the balance of power is tilting in favour of "born-again" Christians and independents at traditionally black universities. At formerly white, English institutions, such as the University of Cape Town (UCT), the University of the Witwatersrand (Wits) and the University of Natal (UN) Sasco has lost the majority it held before. 

Sasco national president David Makhura said many factors, among them the new political order, have contributed to a change in voting patterns.

While Makhura argues that SRCs were not a fair barometer of whether Sasco was losing student support, he concedes "in some cases Sasco may not be taking seriously the social interests of students, such as 'bashes'. And that is why when it comes to elections they tend to elect socialites -- people who throw parties and are well-liked for that."

At the University of the North last year Sasco lost heavily to the Student Christian Movement (SCM), winning only five out of 19 seats -- after having a majority on the SRC for years. Last month at UCT, Sasco gained only two out of 15 seats with the Christians again doing better.

Makhura is not happy with the situation: "They (SCM) did not fight for democratic SRCs. They did not even dare to participate then (during apartheid) but now they are reaping the benefits. However it is their right to participate."

He criticised "born-agains" saying they did not have programmes which mattered to students.

"What worries us is that sometimes it (the election of SCM candidates and independents) becomes a setback for the transformation forums," because those elected were unable to "make effective input", he said.

Makhura said corruption at some of the formerly black institutions dented Sasco's image. But he attributed Sasco's poor showing at institutions like Wits, UN and UCT to the emergence of "elite" black students not affected by issues traditionally taken up by Sasco such as exclusion of students for financial reasons.

Former Sasco national deputy general secretary Sidney Modiba, who is a student at UN's Durban campus, agreed there were more "elite, affluent African students, including Indians and coloureds. The issues we (Sasco) are raising are more oriented towards the poor."

But at the University of the Western Cape, where many students are from disadvantaged backgrounds, Sasco took all 12 seats in last month's elections.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 20, 1996


South Africa;
Pressure On Public Service Review


BYLINE: Marion Edmunds, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - Public Administration Minister Zola Skweyiya has had to bang heads together in the Presidential Review Commission -- the body appointed by President Nelson Mandela to investigate transformation in the public service - - to get it to do some work.

Before this week, the multi-million rand commission met only four times since it was inaugurated in March. And while there is evidence the commission has belatedly squared up to the enormous challenge ahead, MPs are concerned it has been fiddling while the demoralised public service burns. 

The commission must, by the end of its tenure, provide a medium-term and long-term plan for restructuring the public service. This is crucial to save the African National Congress's promises of delivery before elections in 1999.

In its defence, the commission says it has spent the past six months developing a business plan, identifying personnel and agreeing to an operating budget of R18,5-million.

One of the commissioners, Professor Fanie Cloete of the University of Stellenbosch, told MPs at a parliamentary portfolio meeting this week that progress had been held up by complicated negotiations with donors who had refused to release promised funds until its business plan had been refined.

Sources in the public service said problems with donors developed partly as a result of the unfortunate negotiating style of the commission's chairman, Professor Bax Nomvete.

It was also pointed out that much time-wasting has been caused by infighting among commission staff. Particular acrimony developed around Nomvete, whose authoritarian manner demoralised commissioners and staff, and it was only after a meeting with Skweyiya and some "hard talking" in early August that difficulties were patched up and "everybody kissed and made up".

Nomvete has since acquired an official adviser from the public service, Professor Patrick Fitzgerald.

This week the commission has been meeting in Pretoria, working out its strategy of investigating the public service. This includes going to every government department in the country, evaluating its performance and reporting back. An interim report will be presented to Mandela at the end of next March.

An ANC MP said sceptically: "It may well be that they do get down to work, but if their past performance is anything to go by, they need pressure on them to know they have to deliver."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


313 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


South Africa;
Why Generals Are Silent While De Kock Sings


BYLINE: Stefaans BrUmmer, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

Johannesburg - Truth commission investigators have been left frustrated by an "intervention" of Deputy President Thabo Mbeki and Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi which they say gave former police generals a strategic breather before they face tough questioning on apartheid crimes.

The truth commission is also under fire from within its own ranks for having acceded to the political intervention, which some say could create an impression the commission is not as autonomous as it should be.

But Mbeki this week said the initiative had originated with the commission itself, while the generals put the blame on the truth body -- saying it had caused the delay as it has not yet responded to a plea for certain assurances before all can be told.

The Mail & Guardian learnt this week that four of apartheid South Africa's police commissioners have handed a written submission to the truth body. The submission was voluntary, which was one of the terms of a deal in which the body dropped its plans to subpoena them and other senior officers. 

But truth commissioner Dumisa Ntsebeza, who heads the commission's investigative unit, this week slammed the generals' submission as a " philosophical" treatise which did not live up to the commission's expectations to be given at least some particulars on specific instances of serious human rights abuse. "I certainly did not get the feeling we got what we wanted," he said.

The submission is under embargo and the contents are to become public only when the generals appear in person. No date has been set.

The commission's original plan last month was to subpoena seven senior police officers, including former commissioners Johan Coetzee, Hennie de Witt, Mike Geldenhuys and Johan van der Merwe, to answer questions about apartheid crimes.

Ntsebeza said the strategy had been to hear at least some of the generals' testimony concurrently with that of former Vlakplaas commander Eugene de Kock, who took the stand in mitigation of his own sentence in the Pretoria Supreme Court this week.

The investigative unit believed the threat of De Kock telling all in court about his former masters would have encouraged them to give detailed and truthful answers to the commission. Had they given less than the full truth -- De Kock's evidence could have given useful tips on that -- they might have prejudiced their chances of successful amnesty applications later.

The deal Mbeki helped broker after a request by Mufamadi gave the generals a breather to prepare their submission on their own terms -- and pass the crucial time frame of De Kock's evidence. Said Ntsebeza: "The generals did not want to be put on the spot; they first wanted to hear what De Kock said. Then they could trim their sails to suit the wind."

Ntsebeza hinted at unhappiness within the commission that political intervention had been allowed. "There is something to be said about the correctness of a criticism that may be levelled at the commission that it may ... appear to have been influenced, however well-meaning (the intervention) may have been.

Another commission official said Mbeki's intervention had been " extraordinary".

On September 29 Mbeki met the commission's head, Desmond Tutu, and national director of investigations, Glen Goosen. The view was forwarded that a non- confrontational approach would be more likely to succeed, as the generals' co- operation was necessary to encourage lower-ranking security force personnel to apply for amnesty.

Two days later generals Van der Merwe, Geldenhuys and Coetzee met Tutu, his deputy Alex Boraine, Ntsebeza and Goosen. At a media conference afterwards, Tutu said it had been agreed the subpoenas would not be issued.

He said the thrust of Mufa-madi and Mbeki's intervention had been "that these former commissioners and other high-ranking police officers were ready to co-operate with the commission and (they) thought the use of subpoenas would be counter-productive ...

"They were saying -- and we have agreed -- that they would want to voluntarily make an ... omnibus submission ... Then there would be a supplementary list ... in which they would list certain incidents -- they spoke about, at this stage, 50 or so incidents where they would be able to speak in general terms initially."

Tutu warned that while it would be mostly "generalised", if there was nothing more specific, "we will obviously not be satisfied".

Mbeki's spokesman, Ricky Naidoo, this week said Mbeki's intervention was only another step in a process initiated by the truth body itself. It had earlier approached the government, through Mufamadi and Defence Minister Joe Modise, to encourage former security force members to appear voluntarily before the commission.

"Consequently, the ministers met (the generals) to put forward the commission's request. At these meetings they agreed to appear, voluntarily, before the commission. These ministers then requested Mbeki to meet Tutu ... It was agreed at the meeting ... that the issuing of subpoenas was entirely the prerogative of the commission."

A top officer close to the former police commissioners this week said it was not true that their approach through Mbeki had been merely in reaction to the subpoenas. There had been a series of meetings long before the subpoenas were mooted, laying the groundwork for the generals to encourage their former subordinates to make their own approaches to the commission.

He said it had been proposed that a broadly philosophical document be submitted by the generals to the commission, contextualising the apart-heid struggle from the old South African Police point of view.

The officer charged the truth body itself was holding up the signal that the generals would give their subordinates to confess, as it had not yet replied to a request that legal obstacles be dealt with first. One concern was that operatives who confessed to involvement in cross-border operations would not be safe from prosecution in their countries.

He said the generals also needed assurances that security force members would not lose their right to state legal representation, should a matter come to trial in ordinary courts, when a confession is made to the commission. At present security force members only qualify for state legal representation when they plead not guilty, which they cannot do if they have already confessed to the truth body.

The officer confirmed the generals had mooted the possibility of helping the commission get closer to the truth in an estimated 50 cases, and was ready to put out a signal to former subordinates to confess. But he said that could only be done once the assurances had been given.

"We want to act as a catalyst, but we have to be convinced first ... We don't have the military authority anymore that we can say (to former subordinates), 'Left, right, left, right, you go there.'"


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 20, 1996


South Africa;
Mandela Placates East Timorese From Sick Bed


BYLINE: Gaye Davis, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Johannesburg - A delegation from Indonesian-occupied East Timor left South Africa this week with an assurance from President Nelson Mandela that donations to the African National Congress by the Indonesian government would not make "a hostage" of South African foreign policy.

Jorge Ramos Horta, who represents the East Timorese resistance movement, said Mandela gave the assurance during a "very frank" 30-minute meeting which took place in the bedroom of Mandela's Houghton home on Sunday, where he was recovering from knee surgery.

The delegation, which came as guests of the ANC, left ruffled feathers in the Indonesian embassy following an incident at an international fair in Pretoria on Saturday, which resulted in the Indonesian ambassador lodging a protest with the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA).

At issue was the warm welcome extended to the East Timorese delegation by a DFA official at the fair, organised by the Junior Foreign Service Officers' Club and Pretoria University's rag committee. Ramos Horta was given the opportunity to speak and the Indonesians' affront was compounded when a club official, owing to a misunderstanding, lowered the flag flying above the Indonesian stall. 

Foreign ministry representative Pieter Swanepoel confirmed that on Tuesday the Indonesian ambassador met Tutu Mazibuko, deputy director general in charge of Asia and the Middle East. Mazibuko stressed that the event had not been an official DFA function.

South Africa's diplomatic relations with Indonesia -- - which annexed the former Portuguese colony by force in 1975, sparking a struggle for independence which has seen some 200 000 East Timorese die -- is one of the more glaring contradictions of South Africa's post-apartheid foreign policy.

Ramos Horta said Mandela explained to the delegation during the meeting that he had not raised the issue of the East Timor people's struggle when he first visited Indonesia to solicit funds for the ANC's election campaign as he was not well informed about the situation.

"After the elections the ANC still needed money so he went a second time. He said the donations would not make South African foreign policy a hostage and said that he did raise the issue of East Timor. He said he had a lot of objections to his going from within the ANC and from non-governmental organisations," Ramos Horta said.

ANC MP Raymond Suttner, chair of the National Assembly's foreign affairs portfolio committee, said: "A number of us feel quite strongly in support of the right of the people of East Timor to self- determination and about the human rights violations in Indonesia. It is important the president did stress that the fact we received donations will not determine our foreign policy in this area."

The delegation gave Mandela a letter from imprisoned East Timorese resistance leader Xanana Gusmao. Mandela said he would reply to it and handed over a copy of his biography, Long Walk to Freedom, to give to Gusmao with the inscription: "With best wishes to an outstanding freedom fighter."

Ramos Horta said the delegation had asked Mandela to speak to United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali ahead of the next round of talks between Indonesia and Portugal in December.

'For us it is the last round if Indonesia does not want to come with a more flexible position," said Ramos Horta. "We want Indonesia to agree to release all prisoners and stop the torture. In return, we would call a moratorium on guerrilla activity and street demonstrations."

Mandela displayed "enormous understanding and real sympathy", Ramos Horta said. "We leave with complete satisfaction, partly because we did not come expecting too much."

The delegation understood the conflicting interests which had to be juggled to further South Africa's own agenda, even if this meant the ANC "taking certain steps that could be shocking when looking at its position on human rights".

Presidential representative Parks Mankahlana confirmed the meeting took place. "It would be inappropriate at this stage to make any statement about the content of the discussion because of the sensitivity of the issues involved," he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

September 20, 1996


South Africa;
Battle Begins As Pan Africanist Congress Plots New Route


BYLINE: Gaye Davis, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Johannesburg - On the eve of a four-day convention aimed at mapping a new direction for the party, Pan Africanist Congress president Clarence Makwetu has declared his willingness to continue to lead the organisation and his confidence of members' support.

But it's likely the Convention of Africanists, at Vista Mamelodi this weekend, will see intense lobbying. Dissatisfaction with Makwetu's leadership within and outside the party was what prompted a high- powered group of African intellectuals, professionals, trade unionists and businessmen to organise the convention in the first place.

Makwetu's unpopularity extends right up into the PAC's highest structures, but what supporters he has are fighting a desperate battle to keep him in place.

An expected 500 delegates, including members of breakaway PAC groupings such as the Revolutionary Watchdogs, will discuss ways of putting the PAC back on track and turning it into a left-of-centre party promoting Africanist ideals.

Key challenges for the party are reorganising its structures and chaotic finances, discussing its leadership and forging new policies. Decisions taken will have to be ratified by the PAC at its December conference.

Convention convenor Ike Mafole said there was no vendetta against Makwetu -- but at the same time, no one was indispensable. "There is a place for the PAC as the only legitimate opposition in this country. But we need to get our act together," he said.

"The convention will bring together people of divergent views, some favouring capitalism, some socialism. The fundamental aim is unity. People should be able to express views without fear or favour."

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 20, 1996


South Africa;
The 'Long Knives' Are Out In The ANC


BYLINE: Stefaans BrUmmer, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Johannesburg - Gauteng Premier Tokyo Sexwale this week refused to bail Deputy President Thabo Mbeki out of his embarrassment over allegations that he had been behind a drugs probe into Sexwale after the 1994 elections.

In the process, Sexwale and National Party leader FW de Klerk emerged unlikely bedfellows in a shared view that Mbeki had initiated an attempt to damage the political career of his own African National Congress colleague.

Claims surfaced in press reports last weekend that in mid-1994 Mbeki had asked De Klerk, who at the time headed a Cabinet committee responsible for intelligence, whether there was any evidence in state files connecting Sexwale to the drugs trade. 

In a letter dated August 19 1994, Sexwale wrote to De Klerk questioning the probe. The Sunday Independent published excerpts of a tape recording of a meeting a month later between De Klerk and Sexwale, where De Klerk told Sexwale the probe had not begun with himself -- and that "there were long knives out for you" from within the ANC.

Well-placed members of Sexwale's circle this week confirmed Sexwale refused, after publication of the article, a request from Mbeki to engage in a damage- control exercise.

They said Mbeki had asked Sexwale that they put out a joint statement, pinning the origins of the drugs probe on De Klerk. Sexwale declined.

Instead, Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi, a close ally of Mbeki's, came to the rescue with a statement saying the drugs probe had originated with a 1994 election speech by De Klerk in which he said he had information on Sexwale that would have him "running all the way to Japan" -- and that Mbeki merely wanted to establish whether the speech was a reference to drug allegations.

Sexwale's liaison officer Sefako Nyaka this week refused to confirm that Sexwale had declined Mbeki's request. But he did say Sexwale would not take a position. "We are not saying Thabo approached De Klerk, and neither are we saying Thabo did not approach De Klerk."

Members of Sexwale's circle claimed the tiff had its origins in the intense jockeying for position within the ANC after the elections -- a time when Sexwale was still regarded by many as a serious contender to become future president. They said Sexwale believed the drugs probe had been an attempt by Mbeki to see if it was not possible to rid himself of a competitor.

De Klerk this week confirmed the version as published at the weekend. He said: "It is an untruth that I took any initiative in this connection, or that I approached Deputy President Thabo Mbeki ... I was requested by Mr Mbeki to determine whether there was any information on record with reference to such allegations."

De Klerk also said: "It is untrue that I, as Mr Sydney Mufamadi alleges, linked in any way whatsoever a remark -- that Mr Sexwale would move to Tokyo - - to such information in my possession ... What is indeed true is that I said in Johannesburg on April 16 1994 that if the results in the PWV area were announced ... Sexwale would want to move to Tokyo ... At that stage I was blissfully unaware of any allegations connecting Mr Sexwale to drug trading .. .

"The ANC should, rather than blaming me by means of untruths, look for the culprits in their own ranks."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
