Africa News


September 20, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
South Africa: Madida's Magic Back In The Squad


BYLINE: Andrew Muchineripi, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Johannesburg - After being overlooked for a long time Fani Madida is back in the South African squad for the Four Nations tournament, and after their first two matches the team tops the log

Running onto the field against Kenya last weekend in the first game of the Simba Four Nations Cup was a victory in itself for Fani Madida, who in the process gained his 10th cap for his country.

The game was also historic for Madida in that it was at Kings Park Rugby Stadium in 1992 that he made his debut for Bafana Bafana, in the isolation- breaking game against Cameroon on July 7.

Until the announcement of the squad for the tournament was made by national coach Clive Barker, it was accepted by many a football fans in the country that the 29-year-old Turkish- based striker was a spent force as far as playing for South Africa was concerned, especially after the comments he made about Barker in the press a few months before. 

He had attacked Barker for not giving a valid reason for not leaving him out, speaking to anyone who would listen and seemingly burying his chances of playing even further. "To me the story of Barker having to wait for a progress report on my performances in Turkey is just a bluff as far as I am concerned," Madida said at the time.

Madida's outburst against the coach was more frustration than anything else from a player who believes that he still has what it takes to be in the national team.

"Maybe my style of play does not suit the current coach, but I am the striker that scored the record number of goals in South Africa," he said. Many, including the man himself, felt that it was because he refused to tour Australia in 1994 that his problems with Barker started. Madida said he was tired after a hectic season in Turkey and was entitled to a rest.

He played his last game for South Africa on October 15 1994, a Nations Cup qualifier against Mauritius, which was won 1-0 by Bafana Bafana via a Phil Masinga goal.

Since then, Madida, who currently plays for Turkish first division club Antalyaspor, seemingly disappeared from the limelight. This is the player who still holds a South African scoring record -- in 1991 he scored 34 goals in 42 games for Kaizer Chiefs.

Though a prolific scorer at club level, Madida could never produce the same form at national level. Not possessing the speed of old, Madida these days plays in a midfield striker role, scoring his goals from the deep.

Some time ago when asked if he would ever smoke the peace pipe with Barker, Madida replied, "Well, there is a truth commission in the country now, so anything is possible."

And judging by the way things turned out for Madida and Barker, there is hope for the country in more ways than one. The fact that Barker has seen fit to choose Madida also shows a maturity on the side of the coach who has acted in the interest of the team, wheras many others would have marginilised the player.

Madida is hoping to return to South Africa in 1998, and end his career in the country of his birth.

* After beating Australia 2-0 on Wednesday night South Africa take on Ghana in Pretoria on Saturday, while Kenya face Australia


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


339 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Arts;
Tales From The South African Heartland


BYLINE: Bafana Khumalo, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Johannesburg - Friday morning at the Market Theatre complex, Johannesburg. A bearded, pipe-smoking man is trying to contain himself. The source of his discomfort is the cast of a play who are drifting in with varying degrees of tardiness. "We really need to give them a talking to this time, we are professionals you know," he says to a young publicist who's been buzzing around the office seemingly not achieving anything.

Ryk Hattingh settles himself down on the concrete ground and lights his pipe. He's the director of One Voice, a workshopped musical drama billed on the Arts Alive festival. 

While the idea behind One Voice is ultimately to be found within Hattingh's bearded persona, the real creators are the actors themselves. Ten high school children first met in June and, through a process of exploration, learned to trust one another and eventually tell the diverse tales of growing up in turbulent times. On hearing the concept, one can't help but wonder whether this was an attempt to imitate Athol Fugard's 1995 hit, Valley Song. "No," is Hattingh's emphatic answer, "he (Fugard) had a lot of time, so he could get the kids to keep diaries, which I did not have."

Hattingh had only three months to audition 40 children and out of these choose a cast. "Do you want a racial breakdown? " he asks, a cynical smile hovering at the corner of his mouth. "Six black, two coloured, one white and one Indian."

They are scheduled to perform in Tladi in Soweto and one of the cast members is late beyond embarrassment. Hattingh wonders out loud whether or not the play can go on without her. While we wait we speak about who he is, as an Afrikaner intellectual who was involved in the process that ultimately helped destigmatise the language in the eyes of many lefties.

His play, Sing Jy Van Bomme (1988), caused quite a stir with its scathing criticism of the SA military. A career that spans publishing and writing has included stints with the now defunct alternative Afrikaans weeklies, Vrye Weekblad and Die Suid Afrikaan. And then a particularly strange career move; editing an Afrikaans porno magazine, Loslyf. "Afrikaners have always been portrayed as khaki-clad repressed people and I wanted to show them as normal, sexual, fucking human beings".

The missing cast member arrives -- she had a surprise test at school. All is forgiven and the show can go on. The venue is Prudence High School, a dress rehearsal. On the drive over to Soweto, Hattingh had been wondering whether the venue would prove good enough. He knows that it is not exactly going to be Broadway, but hopes that it'll be better than he suspects.

His instinct is right -- it's quite terrible; an outdoor venue with the audience a group of high school pupils waiting to attend a fund-raising event. They would far rather be listening to Whitney Houston than to Nonini Nquma tell how her father was tortured by the security branch; are visibly uninterested in Laurence Horn's poignant travelogue through the journey of his abandonment by his parents. After the performance, Horn seems quite hurt by the reaction but tries to be adult about it: "I understand where they come from. Why should they be interested in the life of a whitey who was left by his parents ... "

Throughout the performance Hattingh is a bundle of nerves, listening to every word "the kids" utter from the makeshift stage. "She started that in the wrong key," he says, half to himself, as Thobeka Gumede powers through a religious song. If she did, no one noticed, because this young woman has a voice so charged it is almost upsetting. It's the kind of voice that saps one's emotions while feeding the soul. She holds the restless audience's attention quite admirably with her tale of how her older brother, an ANC member, was abducted and later found murdered in a sports field. She says that she has forgiven her brother's killers, "I don't know how, but I have ... " It is just a pity that the audience is not very appreciative of the depth of her emotion and at what it took to get it all out.

Later we all sit at the Wimpy and the heart-rending stories seem to fade as the cast dance to piped music, a song called Thobeka by Boom Shaka. They have become teenagers again.

They are still quite excited by having actually performed in front of a real audience. That there were no acoustics to speak of doesn't seem to diminish the thrill of having told a story and sung and rapped. Rap? Somehow the rap seemed out of place in a collection of songs ranging from choral to traditional. I ask Hattingh about it. "The kids absolutely insisted on including rap," he says.

After the baptism by fire in Soweto, the next performance is scheduled for the following day at the Civic Theatre. This is to be a walk in the park by comparison and some of the proud parents are present to see their children on stage.

With the professional facilities and the girls all made up, the two performances are worlds apart. The play hasn't lost its edge, but everything goes smoothly in front of a decidedly more restrained audience that claps in all the right places even though it might not fully understand where the music is coming from. Fifty-five minutes and it is all over.

"So what is going to happen to these kids after these performances?" I had asked after the Soweto show. "It's not in my hands. Some of them would like to continue in the theatre and others don't ... I would not have liked that this raw talent be left to go to waste," Hattingh had said.

It's this talent that has told a story with the power to touch someone so profoundly that he felt it should be heard by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. After seeing the Saturday evening show, Hugh Lewin of the TRC has subsequently arranged that exactly that happen.

One Voice will be staged at various venues until September 27. Call 838- 4563 for details


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


340 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Arts;
Durban Sculptor Lands The Big One


BYLINE: Suzy Bell, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Johannesburg -

Greg Streak is the first South African artist to win a place in one of the world's great sculpture schools.

At last, a white male South African who doesn't spend his days whingeing about feeling dislocated, alienated and oh so lonesome in the new South Africa.

Instead, Durban artist Greg Streak (25) whacks all those emotions into a unique style of pop comic sculpture that is gratefully void of sentimental semantics. Very possibly, this is the reason he's been selected above 678 other applicants from New York to Hong Kong to study at the prestigious Rijksakademie van Beelende Kunsten in Amsterdam next year. 

His work is big, bold and beautiful. It deals with his loss of faith in contemporary value systems, his sense of global dislocation and an overwhelming desire to toss even Mother Mary onto the cross. Well why not? In one sculpture, Compromise and Prejudice, Streak deals with the notion of male sacrifice using the crucifix as a methaphor. It's not a naturalistic figure but a massive human cut-out of a bald, white male wearing silver lead gloves for protection, yet equally, and ambiguously, denying a sense of touch. Like the goggles that protect his eyes but don't allow him to see.

Currently completing his Masters Degree in Fine Art on bursary at Technikon Natal, and having worked as an assistant to that mighty talented South African sculptor, Andries Botha, Streak was born in what he still calls " Rhodesia", and unabashedly admits he doesn't know what it's like to be South African.

"I have a Eurocentric upbringing and education and this perpetual onslaught of America blasting at me ... and in South Africa we have this incredible social transformation happening right now. So yes, I'm searching for a sense of stability and belonging through my art". He believes in the poetry of the visual language instead of the sledgehammer approach. He also believes strongly in the traditional hands- on approach where the artist is physically involved in the craftsmanship, which is why he's quite content spending three months on a sculpture, working with fibreglass, resin, wax, found objects and various mixed-media.

Greg Streak's sculptures are on group exhibit at Durban's NSA Gallery until October 3


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


341 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Arts;
Cape Conventions


BYLINE: Julia Teale, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Johannesburg - The insularity and complacency of the Cape Town art scene has become a commonplace of South African art journalism. The only solution for artists is often to move northward.

But the last few years have seen the birth and maturation of a number of exhibition spaces, such as The Castle and the Planet Cafe Contemporary Art Site, which could slow this migration. They have cultivated off-beat work that often takes swipes at the more "blockbustery" shows. 

The newly opened Labia Gallery, under the curatorship of Gwynneth Harris, is more traditionally Capetonian -- elegantly done-up; no-smoking; paintings hanging politely on the walls. Situated on the periphery of the CBD, it has the potential to be one of the most visited galleries in Cape Town. There is even a balsamic-vinegar-and-sun-dried-tomato restaurant and bar next door.

But the opening exhibition of 21 artists does not do enough to distinguish the Labia from the many Cape Town galleries providing a space for art destined for the boardroom or the well-heeled sitting room.

Although the overall selection and hanging of the works seems to be a bit arbitrary, there is an encouraging blend of established artists -- Willem Strydom, Gail Caitlin, Andrew Verster -- and younger, lesser-known artists such as Reuben Matemane, Johan Louw and Luliette Armstrong.

Still, the strength of the exhibition rests on too few shoulders. Among these are Verster's Two Interiors, which draw part of their vitality from the painter's longstanding dialogue with Matisse, combining incisive line and flat, vigorous colour, playing the two formal propositions against one another. These works celebrate the decorative as an ingredient of good painting, and explore its potential as a means for imbuing subject matter with an intensity that is disquieting.

Louw's desolate, near monochromatic landscape is another example of painting that is both pleasurable and disturbing. The paint that renders the foreground rocks is dragged and pulled across the surface, evoking a kind of fleshiness reminiscent of Lucian Freud's figure paintings or Clive van den Berg's pastel landscape drawings.

On a similarly painterly tack, Claire Menck's small, charged works reflect a mature, sensitive artistic intelligence alive to the constraints and freedoms offered by the limited format.

By contrast, the balance of the work on show seems unfocused and lightweight. A perhaps disproportionate amount of wall- space has been given over to Elaine Jeacock's large watercolours of largely nude or partly clothed women. The use of watercolour in a large format is both unusual and ambitious, and may bear fruit for this artist in the future. For the moment, though, the rendering of bodies and the quality of paint barely falls within the category of "adequate".

Even more worrying are the tired seductions of trite metaphors that feature in some of the works -- in Woman in a Red Dress, the figure's splayed legs serve as backdrop to a table decorated with the inevitable split paw-paw.

On the whole, the exhibition is fraught with the problems of assembling such a large body of work in the absense of any clear criteria for selection. The quality of the work is uneven and although there is a largely figurative and painterly emphasis in the show as a whole, the styles and intentions of the works have little to do with one another, little to say to one another and pose few questions about what is going on in painting in South Africa at present.

On the other hand, the forthcoming exhibitions by Verster and Berlin artist Mark Hipper signal that the Labia Gallery can, with a bit of daring, provide a valuable venue for artists and audiences interested in traditions that need not seem uncritical of their defining conventions.

The show runs until September 21


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


342 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Arts;
Recapturing The Vision


BYLINE: Hazel Friedman, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Johannesburg - Playwright and poet, Maishe Maponya, is Johannesburg's latest high power cultural appointment.

'I was called an angry young man, you know," Maishe Maponya laughs gently at the recollection. With bene-volent smile and trademark scull cap framing his face like a tight-fitting halo, he looks positively papal in disposition (perhaps an inappropriate metaphor, given his undisguised distate for titles).

It's impossible that the cultural officer-to-be of Johannesburg's Southern Substructure could be described in anything but benign terms. Yet anger (and hunger) have been two of the driving forces in his life. And when the fury threatened to consume him, he channelled it through ubuntu. It is this unflagging belief in the African principle of humanism that informs Maponya's cultural vision today. 

"I'm a firm believer in collective responsibility", he says, outlining his plans for transforming one of Gauteng's most neglected (and contradictory) cultural turfs -- parts of Mondeor, Lenasia and Soweto -- into vibrant cultural communities. "It wasn't a political appointment. I see myself as serving a broader community in order to help arts and culture become part and parcel of communities in a non- partisan way." He adds: "Without deference to protocol."

Maponya can hardly be described as a yes man. A renowned playwright, director, poet and performer, his work -- for example, plays like Hungry Earth and Jika (written in the late 1970s and 1980s, respectively) -- have been infused with a militant, yet fiercely individualistic political consciousness.

To many, his writing -- passionate, metaphorically dense and inescapably didactic -- typified the black consciousness protest theatre of the times. Yet there remained something strongly aloof within Maponya.

This might to some extent explain the title of his most recent work, a performance for Biko week in September called Monuments/ Bambata: I Read what I Like. Written between 1992 and 1994, it offers a collage performance comprising epic poetry and excerpts from his play Gangsters, performed against a backdrop of percussive instruments. Critic Gwen Ansell described it as "quite brilliant" and bewailed the fact that it was not part of the September Arts Alive lineup.

Then again, Maponya is used to being sidelined. In 1981, after failing repeatedly to gain sponsorship, he took Hungry Earth overseas "out of my own pocket".

But he did not join the brothers and sisters in exile because "the struggle was here, on many fronts. And, despite his widely acknowledged intellectual acumen, Maponya has remained curiously low key, and his voice, at times, surprisingly soft. Although he sits on the board of the (will-it won't-it be transformed?) Performing Arts Council of the Transvaal (Pact), his outspokenness against the presence of the cultural old guard is less vociferous than one might think.

Presently a senior lecturer in the drama department at Wits university, he's been invited to perform his work at Unisa, but never on home turf. Maybe the reason he takes a less visible seat in the front row is because he does not see cultural achievement as golden goose of self-gratification. "I really don't mind being side-lined," he says

"I'm not sure yet how I will implement my vision. I just want to go in and see what's in place, understand the existing structures and their shortfalls. That will entail delegating and putting competent people in positions of responsibility. This will mean assuming a less visible, more humble, but no less committed role in cultural transformation." He adds: "We need to understand who we are, acknowledge how our history has informed where we are and embrace the need for co- operation without blind consensus ..."

He quotes from I Read What I Like: "... recapturing ourselves in the rubble of facades, / Every piece a victory, / We'll have to create, / A monument of pieces, / every calendar day a monument, / every monument a victory, / every victory a monument ..."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


343 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Arts;
Jazz: The Sexiest Sound


BYLINE: Gwen Ansell, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Johannesburg - Forget screams, moans and squishing noises. The sexiest sound in the world is a big fat horn line playing jazz. Irakere, or "The Forest", last week's jazz guests for Arts Alive, feature four horns. On saxes, Cesar Lopez provides the intellectual acrobatics and an ironic take on the more florid ballad numbers while Alfres Thomson's warm tenor adds guts and heart. On first trumpet, Mario Hernandez effortlessly has the highs without ever sacrificing roundness and warmth. He's a wonderfully old-fashioned player -- old-fashioned as in Clifford Brown. His dreadlocked partner, Basillo Marquez offers a sharper, dizzier approach. 

But there's also leader Chucho Valdez's scholarly, swing piano and arrangements, Mayra Valdez's inspired scatting and soulful shouts, a drum team that leaps between the Yoruba forests and Birdland -- so many riches, crammed into one band.

The programme mixed Afro-Cuban rhythms and structures (rhumba, bolera, salsa) with jazz standards; these latter often taken at breakneck unison speed in idiosyncratic mixes -- like the medley which combined a brief excursion to Georgia with I'll Remember April. By the end of the evening, the whole audience was sweatily invoking Oludun, critical faculty totally suspended.

And after the high subsides, what can we learn from Irakere -- particularly in the context of an evening which began with a sloppy and lustreless set from Mike Makhalemehele? Strong rhythm work, Bush Sestlolo's distinctive keyboard style (given full rein for once, on a great instrument), and Bheki Khoza's astute, intricate driving guitar solos all won hearts, as did the charm of Makhalamele's own compositions. But the set began ten minutes late, the opener, Moraledi, was disjointed and uneven -- and it is no longer charming (if it ever was) to confess that you only met the piano-player yesterday and don't know his name. It simply makes us all wonder how much preparation you put in to what we are paying for.

However, let's look again at Irakere. They come from Cuba where music education is freely available for the talented; where it is a source of pride to be a musician, and where the cherishing of cultural roots is a national mission. Here, we force talented musicians to run around cap-in-hand to raise cash for their own music schools; "musician" is often uttered with a disparaging curl of the lip, and a prominent jazz critic can dismiss our South African variant of the genre as "tribal pop" -- and get away with it. Add to that the grotesque resource inequalities inherited from apartheid and you begin to understand why South African musicians don't always deliver on their promise.

Irakere are nothing phenomenal. They are simply a great, jazz-rooted dance band; enormously talented, tight and hardworking -- and out of a cultural context which has made it positive for them to hang together for nearly a quarter of a century to get that way. The fuzzy equivocations of our latest culture White Papers suggest we've a way to go before we reach that point.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


344 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Arts;
Enraged Artists Pull Out of South African Festival


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Johannesburg - Johannesburg's annual Arts Alive Festival might be alive and kicking, but several Gauteng-based artists are digging in their heels over the alleged flagrant "disrespect paid to local talent", while overseas participants are "treated like royalty". Poets Lesego Rampolokeng, Lisa Combrinck and Boitumelo Mofokeng are just three of a growing number of enraged artists who have either boycotted or threatened to withdraw from festival events due to inadequate payment for their labour.

Their gripe revolves around the fact that they receive a pittance compared to artists brought in from overseas, such as jazz poet Jane Cortez, who performed at a poetry gala evening at Carfax last Friday night. The performance was held under the auspices of Arts Alive and hosted by The Congress of South African Writers (Cosaw). The Arizona-born Cortez was flown in with her band courtesy of the US Fund for Artists. But Arts Alive coughed up an unspecified amount to make their sojourn as comfortable as possible. Yet local artists -- particularly those living in surrounding townships -- complain that they are provided with hopelessly inadequate rehearsal space and facilities. Also, they say that their payment barely covers transport to and from the performance venues and that when they request taxi fare they are fobbed off. 

Rampolokeng, who refused to participate in the Carfax poetry gala event, was also invited by Combrinck and Mofokeng to perform at a poetry reading held at Rand Afrikaans University (Rau) on September 10, organised by Dirk Klopper from that university's English Department. When he inquired about payment he was told that local artists were expected to perform for free. He was later offered the sum of R200, which he angrily refused.

"I was told by the Arts Alive organisers that the festival provides exposure for artists and I should be grateful because poets get paid more than musicians for their labour," he said. "But their attitude is unbelievably arrogant. The organisers are simply into empire- building. I have been to festivals overseas and I have seen that all artists get equal pay. The bottom line is that despite its hype, Arts Alive just uses local artists to boost its credibility, then treats them like shit".

Combrinck and Mofokeng were initally invited onto the poetry platform at Rau University without being informed that Arts Alive was behind the event. When they found out they withdrew.

"Initially we gave our support to the endeavour without thought of payment because we believed we were would be reading to Rau students. But once we heard it was a festival event, we couldn't be associated with it," says Combrinck, a lecturer in the English Department at Vista University and a Cosaw executive member.

"The festival has a budget. If it includes sufficient remuneration for international artists, it should also provide adequate payment for local artists". She adds: "We are not looking for handouts. We simply want respect and recognition. Yet year after year we are faced with inferior facilities, compared to overseas artists, and unequal payment for our labour."

"Arts Alive is essentially a good thing and we welcome genuine exchange between local and international artists," says Mofokeng. "But it is repeating the mistakes of the past by recognising international artists who essentially contribute nothing to this country at the expense of local artists who are its cultural lifeblood."

Roshnee Moonsamy, festival manager, insists that international artists invited to South Africa to participate in the festival are funded entirely by overseas agencies.

"We are a non-profit organisation and we treat all artists with the same respect. However, international artists attract bigger audiences than their local counterparts. Their takings at the door help to cover costs incurred during their stay."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


345 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 20, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Common Market Gets Shot In The Arm


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) today got a shot in the arm when the European Union (EU) gave it a grant of K2.4 billion.

Head of the delegation of the European Commission in Zambia, Charles Brook, said at the signing ceremony held at COMESA offices in Lusaka that the grant seeks to assist COMESA to further strengthen the foundations of the cross border trade initiative (CBI). 

Mr Brook said COMESA plays a major role in the process of regional intergration in Africa in an effort to broaden trade and cooperation among member countries.

He said this regional intergration in trade would not succeed unless there is a driving force which can both stimulate and coordinate cooperation and action.

"It is for this reason that EU has decided to assist COMESA to accomplish this goal of crossborder initiative which was started in 1992," he said.

And COMESA Secretary General, Dr Bingu Mutharika, thanked the EU saying the grant is a milestone towards the implementation of CBI aimed at promoting cross border trade, investment and payments in the region.

He told Mr Brook that COMESA was the first regional organisation in the region to give CBI a political validation due to the complementarity that exists between the activities of COMESA and CBI.

Dr Mutharika said in targeting the inter-linked areas of crossborder trade, investment and payments through a comprehensive approach, the CBI constitute a substantial step forward towards intergration.

He expressed the hope that the reduction of obstacles to cross-border economic activity in the context of CBI would help create growth of economies in many african countries.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

346 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 21, 1996


Malawi and Zambia;
Zambia-Malawi Trade Fair Opens


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Chipata - Minister of state in the office of the president in Malawi, Joseph Kubwalo, has called on the two governments, Zambia and Malawi to introduce a duty-free bilateral trade agreement to curb smuggling between between the two countries.

Speaking in Chipata today when he officially opened the Malawi-Zambia Trade Fair Exposition 96, Mr Kubwalo said smuggling of goods was adversely affecting the smooth flow of cross boarder trade between the two countries.

Mr Kubwalo said smuggling between the two countries was a source of worry and we urged the two governments to act without any further delays. 

"This problem could be resolved if our two governments concluded a duty- free bilateral trade agreement whose draft has been under consideration for nearly two years now," Mr Kubwalo said.

Mr Kubwalo who commended the Malawi Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Zambia Association of Chambers of Commerce and Industry, said that the exposition was an eye opener aimed at promoting cross border trade and investment between the two countries.

He said that the practical measures taken by the private sectors of the two countries should be supported by the two governments as far as possible in order to create an enviroment that was conducive to the development of the bilateral trade and investment flow.

Mr Kubwalo said Malawi's participation in the trade fair was symbolic of his country's practical commitment to the strengthening and consideration of economic and political ties existing between the two countries.

He said that Malawi and Zambia attached great importance to promotion and strengthening of trade within the region and it was for the same reason that both countries were members of COMESA, SADC and CBI.

Mr Kubwalo said he was happy to note that the diversity and high quality of goods displayed at the show by both countries and this showed that there was a great trade potential between them which should be fully exploited for the mutual benefit of the two countries.

On the theme of the exposition, which is "produce, process, promote and prosper" Mr Kubwalo said that the theme was appropriate under the circumstances of the two countries.

He said Malawi and Zambia are major producers and exporters of a number of aagricultural and other primary commodities which are exported in raw form to overseas markets.

Mr Kubwalo said that the aim of the trade fair was to encourage and promote further processing of our resource endowments in order to ralise greater spin- offs to our economies.

"We need goods which have high unity values. Given the duty free market unfolding in the region, it is imperative for our two countries to look for markets for the processed goods within, thereby ecxploiting the emerging market opportunities," Mr Kubwalo said.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZIS


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 21, 1996


Sports - General;
Boxing: Zambian Champion Returns Home


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - Zambian professional boxer Joseph Chingangu returned home today with his World International Boxing Federation (IBF) crown - making him earn Zambia the only title not held by Mike Tyson.

Chingangu, who was flanked by Zambia professional boxing association board chairman Hillary Matyolo, said he will defend his title against Mike Tyson. 

"I want to do more training because I want to defend the title, even when it may mean fighting Mike Tyson," Chingangu said.

The IBF crown is the only title Tyson does not have and there is a possibility that he might challenge the new world champion Chingangu for it. But Chingangu said that he is ready for him and will do anything to defend the title that has elevated Zambia to the international arena of boxing.

He was speaking today at intercontinental airport on his arrival from Italy where he knocked down Laios Eros in the second round.

Heavily surrounded by government officials and fans, Chingangu, who started professional boxing in 1991, said he has always looked forward to becoming a champion and will work flat out to bring back professional boxing in Zambia.

The 12 round fight only earned him 6,000 United States dollars because his opponent Eros was not the holder of the title but will earn him a lot if he successfully defends it.

Zambia has not produced such a boxer before and Matyolo wished the man all the luck and success and going by his strong punches, he was optimistic that he could withstand Mike Tyson. Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


348 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 21, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The African conference on the improvement of women held recently in Kampala, Uganda, has declared that girls domestic household work- load should be reduced drastically.

According to an OAU press release, the conference underscored the need to reallocate the work-load in the family equitably as a means of improving girls' enrolment and retention in school.

Governments have to introduce and develop appropriate technology especially in rural areas to ease the manual labour to which the girl child is subjected, the conference noted. 

The conference further called upon African governments to provide education for all girls in mainstream schools through diversification of the educational delivery system and by promoting alternative mode of schooling.

The curriculum should be reviewed and made relevant to life during and after school in order to promote the overall interests and concerns of girls in science and technology, gender and civic education and the teaching of life skill, it stated.

The conference urged parties concerned to institute, measures to ensure the protection of girls from all forms of insecurity, violence defilement and rape in school, on the way to school and in the community at large.

About 30 OAU member states participated in the conference, out of which ten were led by ministers. Also present were representatives of international organizations and donor agencies, the release said.

Ministry warns farmers not to apply chemicals in fields

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Ministry of Health warned farmers against applying anti-malaria chemicals in agricultural fields for the purpose of killing weeds and insects.

According to Dr. Desta Alamirew, an expert in the ministry, the chemicals, if sprayed on crops, would constitute serious health threat to people and animals.

"We have discovered that some individuals in conspiracy with trades wrongly use the chemicals to destroy weeds," the expert said.

The used of chemicals for agricultural purposes has been nullified internationally, he said and called on pertinent bodies to closely oversee such 'wrong' usages.

Workers demand corrupt officials be dismissed

DIRE DAWA (ENA) - Workers of the Dire Dawa Cement and Lime Factory stages a demonstration Thursday demanding the dismissal of various administrative executives who they said are corrupt and embezzlers and the administration of the factory by a board.

Delivering their demand to the Dire Dawa administrative council, a representative of the about 260 demonstrators said that though the workers repeatedly reported the corrupt administration in the factory to pertinent bodies, they were not given any practical response.

Sector heads of the factory at various levels, including the acting manager, are replacing diligent workers by inefficient ones forging secret links in pursuit of personal gains, the representative indicated.

He disclosed that the factory's expenditure and revenue were not audited for the last five years and the workers could not gain any benefit which they are entitled.

The factory is now supplying its products to eastern regions, he said.

In a response to the demonstrators, the economic sector head of the Dire Dawa administration Ato Mohammed Sheik Adem said the administration will do its level best to address the demands of the workers.

Ato Mohammed Abdurahiman, acting manager of the factory, however, denied the allegation of the demonstrators that embezzlement was rampant in the factory.

Africa News


September 21, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Death Sentences for Mubarak's Accused Assassins


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Central High Court yesterday sentenced to death three terrorists who attempted to kill President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt here in Addis Ababa in June 1995.

According to its spokesman, the court pass the verdict as it found the Egyptians Sofit Hassen Abdul Kabi, Abdul Kerim Abdul Naddi and Al-Arib Sadik guilty of committing the crime. 

The spokesman said the prosecutor has provided the court with evidence proving the terrorists guilty of attempting murder, killing two policemen on duty at the time of the incident and wounding seven other civilians as well as smuggling prohibited fire arms into the country.

The defence lawyer tried to produce defence but in vain, the spokesman pointed out adding the court which held the trial in camera inflicted capital punishment on the criminals saying it was appropriate for the crimes committed.

The convicts who went by false names and carried Yemeni, Sudanese and Ethiopian passports alternatively for criminal purposes illegally entered Ethiopia in 1995 after receiving military training at a clandestine camp in Afghanistan, according to the prosecutor.

Elaborating on the seriousness of the crimes and the cruelty of the criminals, the court said the bomb prepared to kill President Hosni Mubarak was so powerful that it could have devastated all in the vicinity.

Ethiopian law dictates that death sentence should get the approval of the head of state before it is executed.

Africa News


September 22, 1996


Zambia;
Two of Zambia's Neighbours In Coup Plot?


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - The Defence Ministry has revealed that two of Zambia's neighbours, with the help of a donor country, are in a plot with an opposition political party to unseat the government of President Frederick Chiluba and already the plotters are training the unnamed party's cadres.

Deputy Defence Secretary in the Ministry of Defence, Colonel Timothy Kazembe, would not name the countries involved nor the European power but he maintained that the army will remain committed to the public service and the defence of the nation and its citizens.

Colonel Kazembe also said it was not true that the defence force was planning a military coup as alleged by some opposition political party leaders. 

Recently two independent newspapers, the Chronicle and the Post carried front page articles quoting retired Generals Malimba Masheke and Kingsley Chinkuli as having warned the nation of an impending army coup.

The two papers also quoted another retired military man, Colonel Douglas Mbiya, who described the political situation in Zambia as "frightening".

Colonel Kazembe said the Ministry of Defence found the statements by retired army commanders now holding senior political positions as irresponsible and subversive.

He said the statements were an attempt to undermine the loyalty and confidence of the defence force to the government of the day and the nation as a whole.

"It must be noted that the defence force is founded on professionalism consistent with democratic principles, and it operates within the Republican Constitution," Colonel Kazembe said.

Colonel Kazembe warned political parties not to bring confussion in the defence force by trying to draw its personnel into partisan politics.

"We have confidence in the steps that the government is taking to resolve the contentious issues. We, therefore, appeal to political parties to use this avenue to resolve political problems instead of inciting the defence force.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

Africa News


September 23, 1996


Zambia;
Parliament Resumes Sittings


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - The Fifth session of the Seventh National Assembly resumed sitting today at 14.30 hours,after a three month recess.

During this sitting, parliament is expected to debate and ratify three names of High Court or Supreme Court Judges to be members of the Electoral Commission, following the recent decision by governemnt to make the electoral commission indepepndent. 

The Public Order Act is also likely to be amended due to the reduction of the notice period, required by any political party to hold a public meeting, from 14 to seven days.

The pronouncements were made by President Chiluba after the bilateral talks that he held with different political parties including UNIP and ZDC.

The house is also expected to dissolve during the same sitting following the expiry of the first five year term of office for the MMD government.

And during the last sitting, which adjourned on May 22, MMD members of parliament passed the controversial 1996 Constitution Amendment Bill with no opposition.

President Chiluba assented the bill despite massive protests from the opposition parties, Non-Governmental Organisations and the donor community.

Walkouts by the opposition members of parliament characterised the last sitting including the refusal to contribute to debates on the adoption of the 1996 Constitution.

The house's sittings ended with the expulsion of National Party (NP) MP for Mongu Central Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika by Speaker of the House Robinson Nabulyato for contempt of parliament.

Mr Mbikusita-Lewanika later challenged the expulsion and the Supreme Court granted him a stay of execution which the Speaker intends to ignore.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

Africa News


September 23, 1996


Zambia;
Kaunda's Back - UNIP Names Him 'Sole Candidate'


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Kabwe - UNIP leader, Dr Kenneth Kaunda, momentarily relived the bygone days of 'one party-one man' rule last night when the carefully chosen delegates to the party's National Council meeting picked him as sole candidate for the state Presidential elections due in Zambia soon.

True to the party's long cherished trait of violence and blood letting the meeting almost ended on a tragic note after a group of vengeful UNIP cadres set upon journalists covering the event and two internal security officers from Office of the President (Special Division) who were allegedly attempting to enter Masiye Motel - venue for deliberations of the national council meeting.

Trouble started when the two suspected security officers failed to identify themselves by producing their identification cards. 

Party militants demanded that they leave the premises, but when the officers allegedly resisted a fight broke out at the entrance to the reception lounge.

In the midst of the scuffle, one of the men bolted, leaving his colleague at the mercy of angry party militants who started beating him mercilessly.

The man was only saved by a hotel worker who locked him in one of the rooms for his own safety.

However, the blood thirsty crowd of UNIP cadres surged forward and forced its way into the reception lounge demanding to be handed the man 'so we can teach him a lesson' a euphemism for jungle retribution. They shouted insults at the man and accused him of being a "spy".

The incident took place between 21.00 hours and 21.15 hours in full view of journalists covering the UNIP national council and so when it turned out that the alleged spy whom the UNIP thugs had wanted to lynch had been escorted out of the hotel the unruly militants descended on three local journalists covering the event.

Reporters from the Times of Zambia, Zambia Daily Mail and the Zambia News Agency were showered with insults and rude invectives for their alleged 'biased reporting.'

As the situation became sticky with some cadres advancing menacingly on them the journalists had to plead their innocence by feebly waving their Press Cards and prayed hard that what had befallen the alleged State Security 'spies' would not befall them.

Indeed they would have been lynched had it not been for the providential intervention of Central Province UNIP chairman, Richard Banda, Chairman for finance Rabbison Chongo and youth chairman, Sam Moyo, who saved them from a sure beating.

There were bitter exchange of words between the Motel attendants and the cadres who demanded that militants leave the reception lounge.

But the UNIP cadres continued to hurl insults at the journalists accusing them of writing negatively about UNIP.

As some cadres scrutinised the journalists' press cards others derided and insulted them for no apparent reason.

Later the three journalists had to be shielded and whisked away from obvious danger by Dr Kaunda's press aide, Muhabi Lungu, who explained and pleaded that the three were not " enemies of our party.'

After the official closing of the council by party president Kenneth Kaunda, Mr Lungu had to escort the pressmen to their vehicle for their own safety.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 23, 1996


Zambia and Angola;
Angolan Repatriation Exercise Deferred


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Chililabombwe - The repatriation of Angolan refugees based in Zambia scheduled to take place this month has been deferred to May 1997.

Commissioner for Refugees, Lameck Mwaba, who confirmed this today attributed the postponement to the recent vandalised facilities including tents at a prepared reception camp in Lumbala-Nguimbo district in Angola's Moxico province.

Mr. Mwaba said today that the recent decline by UNITA to let its leader, Dr Jonas Savimbi to take up the position of Vice-President in the proposed unity Angolan government, has had a negative effect on the repatriation exercise of Angola refugees living in Zambia. 

Mr. Mwaba said the decision to defer the exercise was reached at a recent tripartite meeting in the Angola capital of Luanda between the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) and governments of Angola and Zambia.

He said in reviewing the preparations, Angola government officials expressed concern at vandalised facilities at the reception site and proposed that the exercise be deferred to May 1997.

"The new repatriation date came from Angola government officials themselves. We were told the reception centre had been vandalised after UNITA expelled aid organisations and their workers from its held Moxico province where Lumbala-Nguimbo district is located," he explained.

After the expulsion of aid organisations and with no security guards, the centre was left at the mercy of vandals who have ransacked the premises.

The stand by UNITA against the vice presidency taken at its third extraordinary congress held in the central highland of Malungo last month, has also affected the repatriation exercise and made some of the refugees who enlisted for voluntary repatriation, be apprehensive about returning.

"Any negative development towards implementing the November 1994 Peace Protocol on Angola is bad news for Angolan refugees," Mr. Mwaba said without ellaborating.

Asked for a comment, Lusaka-based representative for the UNHCR, Claire Hamlisch, said through a secretary: "All what Mr. Mwaba has told you is correct and there is nothing I can add."

About 105,000 of the estimated 360,000 Angolan refugees scattered in about 35 countries are in Zambia. There are 200,000 in Zaire and 12,000 in Congo.

It is estimated that the repatriatioin exercise will cost the UNHCR US$44 million dollars.

Plans to repatriate the Angolans from Zambia were worked out at a July 1995 meeting in Lusaka between the UNHCR and governments of Angola and Zambia, and fine tuned at a follow-up meeting between the three parties, held in Angola in Luanda, the Angolan capital.

Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975 after a bloody liberation war, but fighting broke out around independence between the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) and rebel groups, mainly UNITA.

The hostilities sent thousands of Angolans fleeing to neighbouring Zambia and Zaire as well as other nations. A few returned home after a 1990 peace pact that led to the holding of elections in October 1992.

The re-scheduled repatriation exercise will only take off when the peace process holds in Angola between the two protagonist - UNITA and the Angolan government.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 23, 1996


Business;
Sugar Shares Get Sweeter In Zambia


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - The Lusaka Stock Exchange last Friday recorded a 36 per cent increase on the Zambia Sugar Plc share price.

According to the Lusaka Stock Exchange's yesterday's Daily Stock News, the shares enjoyed a K4 increase over the privatisation floatation offer price of K11 - a development which the stock exchange has attributed to the heavy discount on the offer price. 

"The K4 increase probably reflects the fact that the K11 offer price was a 'heavily' discounted price in line with the privatisation objectives of encouraging broad and wide share ownership,"read the stock news in part.

LuSe also reports that the Chilanga Cement Plc share price enjoyed a K5 increase on September 9 to close trading at K54 from K49.

The company's September 9 trading recorded a trade volume of 167,865 shares with a turnover of almost K8,857,941.

And Rothmans shareholders are set for a boost with an 80 per cent increase in dividends for this year. Rothmans dividends have been set at K1.84 per share.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


355 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - The government is reviewing the employment Act in order to curb discrimination of people living with HIV/AIDS, disclosed National AIDS, STD and Leprosy manager at the ministry of health, Dr Moses Sichone.

Dr Sichone, in an interview at a one-day workshop on the 'Protection of Human Rights in the context of AIDS in Africa' organised by the Network of African People living with HIV/AIDS(NAP), said there was need to look at " pieces of legislation that are discriminatory on the basis of HIV and the act is being reviewed accordingly".

He said that though the epidemic was serious at 25 per cent in urban areas and 13 per cent in rural areas, there was need to work towards reasonable solutions to the problem. 

"That means one person in every four is infected. But rather than introduce restrictive laws against people with HIV/AIDS, we need to harness their efforts in trying to control transmission," Dr Sichone said.

And UNAIDS country programme advisor Olowo-Freers Bernadette, addressing the same workshop, said fighting human rights violations was high on her organisation's agenda.

"The strategic plan is to involve a wide range of partners, NGOs, community based organisations and representatives of people living with HIV/AIDS," Bernadette said.

NAP president, David Chipanta, warned that the result of restrictive laws was further spread of the disease.

"Children and adults with HIV/AIDS should have the same rights as anybody else," he demanded.

Bernadette disclosed that 11 million of the population with HIV are found in Africa and thus continent's partnership in the fight against the disease was vital.

She said the involvement of people living with the disease in setting the agenda would help to deal with the reality faced by the vulnerable people.

"We urge governments and societies to wake up from the present conspiracy of silence and find solutions which will eliminate the present divide of 'them' and 'us'," she said.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Zambia;
Save Zambia's Democracy ...


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu and Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's fragile experiment in democracy building is under threat and friends and the international community must urgently move in to save it.

This is the conclusion of the Commonwealth Human Rights Initiative (CHRI) which visited Zambia on a fact finding mission between August 27 and September 5, this year and the findings are being released today silmuteneously in Lusaka,London and New Dehli.

The CHRI also warned against any delays in helping Zambia in her situation because "the shortage of time is a critical factor."

The CHRI which made a 16 point summary of their impressions of the Zambian situation also gave a 13 point recommendation on how Zambia could come out of her situation. 

Among the recommendations are that government opens itself up to dialogue, considers a constituent assembly for broadened constitutional debate and desists from forcing an election on Zambians without ironing out the pressing problems.

On dialogue CHRI says this should include opposition parties beyond the main opposition UNIP. The CHRI also observes that interparty meetings should be chaired by a neutral personality other than any of the heads of the key players.

"But if necessary, recourse could be to the standing asset of the Commonwealth Secretary General or other suitable international personalities," the statement said.

Although the CHRI is not dictating an agenda for such talks it specifically says dialogue should concentrate on meeting short terms goals "which would facilitate an early election and limit the need for special extensions of the life of the present parliament."

They also proposed that the voter registration exercise and the qualifications for the presidential candidates be given special attention in the talks.

The CHRI however recommends the re-opening of consensus building on the constitution.

"The government could lower the political temperature markedly by simply making the statement that its recent constitutional amendments were stop gap measures and that it acknowledges the need for a proper national debate of the 1995 constitution commission proposals in constituent assembly," the statement said.

The conclusions and recommendations signed by Kamal Hossain, Anita Raynell Andreychuk and Neville Linton were obtained by The Post last Friday and have been simultaneously released in London and New Delhi.

The CHRI says the government should not go ahead with an unpopular election merely on account of its 'right' as to do so "might soon force it into the policies of an escalating authoritarianism."

"It should not risk undermining the gains made through its tough economic programme by now having to put new acute strains on the economy due to the donor's suspension of aid."

President Chiluba has also been urged to maintain moral uprightness and be decisive on indiscipline within his government.

"If the office of president is to keep its luster, it is important that the President distances himself convincingly from ministers whose behaviour readily leads to charges of corruption being made, even by donors and from ministers who bring the government into disrepute by seriously ill-judged statements smacking of prejudice or of contempt for the judiciary."

They warned further; "In terms of his stewardship President Chiluba, if he is to maintain the international respect which he gained in 199, needs to govern in a manner which ensures that this, the first multiparty regime is marked by fairness, flexibility and progress."

According to the CHRI all political parties must ascribe to some code of conduct in the period of elections and uphold their obligation to keep Zambia peaceful by refraining from issuing inflammatory statements.

The CHRI has also recommended that the donor community consider funding opposition parties as a way of strengthening the opposition and consequently democracy.

Government has not reacted to this release yet but its four man international relations delegation led by foreign minister Christon Tembo which visited west and north Africa has maintained that all was well for Zambia.

''We went on this trip to West Africa and Egypt to try to clear out the misrepresentation on the government constitutional stance. Everywhere we went, we explained to them that our constitution is what Zambians wanted and we are merely putting up the wishes of all Zambians," said Tembo at a press briefing shortly after his arrival at the Lusaka International Airport on Saturday.

He, was accompanied by former foreign affairs minister, Vernon Mwaanga, legal affairs minister, Luminzu Shimaponda, deputy minister in the office of the president, Eric Silwamba.

The four met Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, President Abdul Diouf of Senegal, Konan Bedie of Ivory Coast, Jerry Rawlings of Ghana and Nigerian military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha.

"We had meetings with the five leaders and afterwards they accepted our stand because they all felt it is an internal matter, and we assured them of continued relations," said Tembo


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Zambia;
African Activists Protest To Zambian President


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 173 words


 

Lusaka - A Harare-based alliance of scholars, business people, professionals and students, the Lavender Africa Forum, has written an open letter to President Frederick Chiluba over what they have termed as "a wave of vicious and seemingly well coordinated attacks directed at the forces of democracy and the civil society in Zambia".

The letter specifically protests against attacks on the church, the harassment and persecution of judges and lawyers, allegations of judicial involvement in politics and allegations of rape levelled against the Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube.

The 16 page letter is also being sent to all heads of state in Africa and specifically to South African President Nelson Mandela in his capacity as chairman of the Southern African Dvelopment Community
