LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


358 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Liberia;
Liberia's Woman Head Of State Optimistic About Peace


BYLINE: Nernlor Gruduah, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Nairobi - Weary of numerous political factions and as many violated peace accords, Liberians this time around are hopeful that the first-ever lady to hold the mantle of power in their country, will not only restore trust where it had been lost but also put back this West African country on the road to real recovery.

Modern Africa's first woman head of state takes over a government -- effectively controlled by fierce warlords -- that has seen the exit of three male predecessors after unsuccessfully attempting to end six years of vicious civil war.)

Chosen last month following the signing of what has been dubbed "Abuja II" peace accord, Ms Ruth Perry has a tall order of guiding Liberia through disarmament to democratic elections in May 1997.

According to the 57-year-old former senator from Grand Cape Mount county, Liberia's principal warlords regard her as "their mother." As such, she counts on their fullest co-operation to sift through the ravages of war and put the country back on its feet. 

But inevitably, two conclusions await Perry: if she succeeds, one theory is likely to be that she entered the scene when the warlords had already worn themselves out and no longer had the desire to fight on, coupled with threats of sanctions and war crimes tribunal from West African leaders. If she fails, the second and obvious theory would be that cynics would consider it foolhardy on her part to dare tread on where men have failed.

Whatever the outcome of the new transitional government, whichever conclusions are drawn, one thing is certain: Ruth Perry has inscribed her name onto the annals of history. Had it been under normal circumstances, perhaps, messages of congratulations from women leaders would have poured into Monrovia from all corners of the continent, but apparently most women are keeping their fingers crossed.

At home, Perry is seen as a no-nonsense woman, though soft-spoken, and one who would deal even-handedly with the rival warlords, unlike the men-folk who have gone before her. She was proposed and unanimously endorsed on August 17 by a special meeting of the committee of nine on Liberia, mandated by the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS). The committee comprises Nigeria, Ghana, Senegal, Ivory Coast, Guinea, Gambia, Burkina Faso, Benin and Togo.

The meeting, held in Nigeria's federal capital, Abuja, was attended by all key Liberian factional leaders, Charles Taylor of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), Alhaji Kromah of the United Liberation Movement of Liberia-K (Ulimo-K), George Boley of Liberia Peace Council (LPC) and Roosevelt Johnson of Ulimo-J. They all signed the new peace agreement, now known as "Abuja II", which maintains the Transitional Council of State but replaced its head, Wilton Sankawulo, with Perry.

It followed an earlier ECOWAS heads of state summit at the same venue during which West African leaders heavily criticised factional leaders for failure to implement a dozen or so previous peace accords. They were threatened with individual sanctions if any of them obstructs the new plan.

These include travel restrictions, freezing of assets, exclusion from the elections, expulsion of family members from West African countries, restriction of imports and the recommendation to invoke a call for Bosnian and Rwandan-style war crimes tribunals.

Sankawulo was a product of the first Abuja accord signed in August, 1995. He replaced David Kpormakpor, who was installed as a result of the July, 1993 Cotonou accord, itself based on "Yamoussoukro IV". The first interim head of state, Dr. Amos Sawyer, was appointed in 1990 by West African leaders at the height of the civil war, launched by the NPFL in 1989.

United Nations estimates that more than 150,000 people have been killed in the civil war. Most recently, over 1,500 people are reported to have been killed when a failed attempt to arrest Ulimo-J leader, Johnson, sparked off weeks of renewed bloody fighting, widespread looting and destruction of property in the capital, Monrovia, from April 6 to May 27.

The new plan provides for all warring factions to complete disarmament and demobilisation of an estimated 60,000 fighters by January 31, 1997. This would be followed by general elections on May 30 and the installation of an elected government on June 15. Members of the current council of state who wish to run for office are expected to resign by the end of February.

Said Perry of her appointment: "The proposition frightened me a bit... I didn't lobby for the job, but the good Lord has made his choice and I will continue to pray for guidance. I told the faction leaders, I have the touch of velvet, but when it comes to taking a firm line I am as hard as steel. We owe this pledge to God and to the Liberian people. We have no illusions and shall endeavour to have no other loyalties to any group or faction."

She believes things are different now and the factions would abide by the agreement. "I am going to have a cordial working relationship with the factions, we can't afford to judge them just by the past. I am a very strong woman, I can tell you," Perry is reported telling Nigerian state television shortly after her appointment.

Meanwhile, things have already begun moving in favour of the new head of state, with Kromah's Ulimo-K faction handing over heavy weapons to the ECOWAS Monitoring Group, ECOMOG, just days after she was officially installed in Monrovia on September 3. The handing over ceremony, attended by Ms Perry and the new ECOMOG Commander, General Samuel Victor Malu, took place on September 7 in Ulimo-K's stronghold of Voinjama, North-Western Liberia, near the Guinean border.

Reports indicate weapons handed over include heavy mortars, anti- aircraft guns and rocket-propelled grenades, and Kromah announced he was prepared to stand in elections scheduled for May. "I am seriously available and I think I'm qualified to represent you and will do so when the appropriate time comes, " he told supporters.

ECOMOG had requested West African leaders during their July summit to raise the size of its force from 10,000 to 18,000 in order to deploy throughout the country to implement the peace plan. However, fresh troops are yet to be sent to Liberia, although the leaders agreed to do so.

Receiving the weapons, General Malu, whose Nigerian contingent is the largest in ECOMOG, said: "The process of disarmament as you have done today should continue and not wait for our deployment. You don't have to wait for other factions."

Earlier in the week, the two feuding Ulimo factions signed a separate agreement to reconcile their differences, thus opening up Western Liberia for relief agencies to reach thousands of starving civilians trapped by factional fighting for the last seven months. Aid workers reaching the provincial town of Tubmanburg speak of desperate conditions for its over 35,000 inhabitants and of people living on wild roots and leaves. The region had been without relief food since February.

Perry's swearing-in ceremony was marred by fears over the absence of leader of the most powerful faction, Charles Taylor of NPFL,with some suggesting he could be an obstacle to the new plan. But Taylor sought to allay the fears soon after his return to the county by calling on the new state council chairperson.

He is quoted as reassuring Ms Perry that his absence from the country during the ceremony did not mean hatred for the new head. Taylor outlined plans to disarm and demobilize his fighters and hoped to do so before the official deadline on January 31.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


359 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Sudan;
New Education Centre An Eye-Opener For Southern Sudan


BYLINE: Nyakwar Aketch, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Nairobi - Like in other countries subjected to civil war, the maintenance or even establishment of a formal schooling system has been one of the most difficult tasks in southern Sudan. However, all is not lost as efforts by missionaries working in the area have borne fruit in an alternative in neighbouring Kenya.

One of the many consequences of the protracted civil war in the Sudan has been the virtual breakdown of the formal education system in the country's southern region. But thanks to the spirited efforts of missionaries, a small proportion of southern Sudanese population has had access to some semblance of formal educational, a basic human right. 

Determined to keep the fire of enlightenment burning in the midst of the Sudanese gloom, the Comboni Missionaries have established a Ksh.28.5 million (about $500,000) educational institution for the Sudanese on the Kenyan soil.

Located in Kitale in Western Kenya, about 407 kilometres north-west of Nairobi, Blessed Bakhita Formation Centre was formally inaugurated on August 21, this year, in a colourful ceremony, presided over by Max Macram Gassis, the Bishop of El Obeid in the war-ravaged southern Sudan.

Interestingly, the inauguration coincided with the capture of some six missionaries in the Sudan by the Sudanese People's Liberation Army-United (SPLA-United) forces. The missionaries, who run an elementary school at the village of Mapourdit were accused of, among other things, hindering SPLA- United recruitment of the young people from their institution.

The six victims who were to be detained for nearly two weeks from August 17 were; three Australian Sisters Moira Lynch, 72, Mary Batchelor, 67, and Maureen Carey, 52, American priest Fr. Michael Barton, 48, Italian Brother Raniero lacomella, 26, and Fr. Raphael Riel, 48, Sudanese Vicar General of Rumbek Diocese.

Named after Josephine Bakhita, a Sudanese slave girl who rose to become a Catholic Sister in Italy, and was later in 1992 proclaimed Blessed by the Pope, the Kitale-based institution will serve the dioceses of Rumbek , El Obeid, Torit and Tambura Yambio. It is a brainchild of Monsignor Caesar Mazzolari, the Apostolic Administrator of Rumbek Diocese and has as its prime objective, the formation of young people as agents of evangelization, education and development.

Those to join the Formation Centre, says Msgr. Mazzolari, will comprise of Sudanese teachers, catechists and seminarians. "They will be duly selected from the most deserving areas and will be asked to give total commitment to their training, contributing also with their work to the running of the Centre and the production of the food needed."

"After training they will be asked to commit themselves to work in their different capacities (catechists, teachers and development agents) at the service of their own people," Msgr Mazzolari explained.

The centre which expects the first lot of 80 students in October, has on its 26-acre compound

classrooms, refectory, dormitories and all other physical structures that are necessary for the efficient running of a modern-day learning institution. All the buildings have been built in a strong but simple and practical style, ensuring that they are easy to maintain.

The decision to have the institution in Kenya, and specifically on the outskirts of Kitale town was a well thought idea as Msgr. Mazzolari explained. It is essentially a rural location, he says, and will allow the students coming from the most isolated areas of Sudan to avoid the impact with the big city centres.

The Blessed Josephine Bakhita Formation Centre has been established in Kitale because the present situation of civil war in southern Sudan does not allow the implementation of any consistent education programme inside Sudan. Not only is it difficult to find a place and personnel for formation, but the war, as it has been experienced, would continually destabilise any attempt at the formation of the youth."

Msgr Mazzolari, who has been in charge of the Rumbek Diocese since 1991 went on to explain: "In southern Sudan, the formal education system has ground to a halt for more than 10 years. Many Catholics have been left without a priest for 10 to 15 years. While the old catechists and teachers have done an incredible work and shown a lot of dedication, there is the need for a new generation of catechists, teachers and development agents."

Kenya offers a good atmosphere for teaching and studying. Teaching staff in all subjects can easily be found. The young people would be able to concentrate in their studies without being continually subjected to distress and appeal from their families and the villages."

Since 1983, Southern Sudan has been fighting a bloody war with the Islamic regime in Khartoum. The bone of contention has been the desire by the southerners, who are mostly Christians and traditionalist, to have all their fundamental rights recognised by the Islamic government. At the onset of the war, the southerners fought under one rebel group, SPLA-United, led by Colonel John Garang. With time, however, internal conflicts within the SPLA- United have given rise to several factions that have seen the southerners turn against each other.

To this day, it is estimated that not less than 1.2 million lives have been lost in the war. Hundreds of thousands have suffered injuries of various nature and degree while equally large numbers have been forced into exile especially in the neighbouring states. Thus the several consequences of the Sudanese war have spilled well beyond the expansive state's borders.

Besides Fr. Robert Tumukwase, who is the first head of the institution, Blessed Bakhita Formation Centre has four permanent teaching staff. There is provision for involvement of resource persons from outside whenever there is need.

But what would become of the centre if normalcy returned to the Sudan? Msgr. Mazzolari says; "While it is hoped that the conflict in Sudan will end soon, the period of rehabilitation for civil society as well as for the church at all levels will take a long time. So the Bakhita Centre will continue to be useful for many years to come, even if the peace and justice we all pray for will come tomorrow."

Fr. Tumukwase hopes that the Sudanese will leave the centre for Kenyans. When such a time comes, the Comboni Missionaries, who are the trustees of the institution, "will use it according to the needs of the time."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


360 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Ghana;
Extraordinary Cleric Looks Into Churches' Shortcomings


BYLINE: Robert N. Kizito, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Nairobi - A lot of "positive attractions" that are said to lure youth and other faithful from mainline, traditional or historical churches to new charismatic religious groups on the one hand and to independent or indigenous churches on the other, continue to be debated. Now Rt. Rev. Dr. Paul Kofi Fynn, President of the Lutheran Church in Ghana discusses some shortcomings of both the new groups and historical churches.

Most if not all African independent or indigenous churches have incorporated indigenous cultural traditions into their worship and other socio-religious ceremonies.

On the other hand, the new charismatic Christian movements have lively but equally long worship services. But their Bible readings and sermons are shorter. 

The sermons are, however, particularly more powerfully eloquent in praising the Lord than relating the Gospel to the non-spiritual day- to-day problems of the followers.

"Nevertheless, some of what appear to be pluses may be enough to lure a number of baptised Christians within the historical churches to the new groups," admits Rt. Rev. Dr. Paul Kofi Fynn.

But if the mainline churches were to carry out a genuine and critical self- analysis they would stem "this undesirable flow," he contends. He adds: " Mainline churches have an edge over all others."

Dr. Fynn appreciates the new efforts of "other churches" to win more souls for Jesus. This would go a long way in establishing "God's Kingdom on earth where peace, caring love, unity, reconciliation, and dignity for all human beings is the norm rather than the exception."

His concern, however, is that their gospel is based purely on biblical truth which they take as given. The knowledge and changed historical, social and cultural circumstances of later-day generations is assumed to be irrelevant.

The exclusive concern of the charismatic groups in particular is spiritual salvation, sometimes making doctrines out of single verses.

For the social, political and economic situation of the human being, this has inevitably been predetermined by God and only Jesus can change it, perhaps miraculously. Not surprisingly, dictatorial regimes and authoritarian local administration officials find the new groups and some indigenous churches a relief to deal with.

Hence in Kenya for instance, the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) finally split into two in 1995, with a breakaway group forming the Regional Fellowship of Churches of Kenya (RFCK).

The RFCK is more pentecostal, evangelistic or charismatic in membership and orientation. It seeks, it would appear, to distance itself from the more worldly social, political and economic concerns that affect Christians and non-Christians alike.

Dominated by mainline churches, the NCCK on the other hand continues not only to be concerned with evangelization and the spiritual needs of the people, but also with the social economic and political issues of the day as they affect the populace. "Spiritualization and 'engagement in society' is the full mission of the church," NCCK argues.

In a recent move, the RFCK has vowed to disrupt NCCK peace and reconciliation seminars. Initiated in areas worst hit by tribal clashes at the hight of the clamour for multipartism in the early 1990s, President Moi has termed the seminars as "subversive activities."

On spiritual matters however, charges Dr. Fynn, mainline churches have failed to explain in a clear, penetrating and easily discernible language or fashion some fundamental religious doctrines and issues. These include such matters as trinity, the Holy Spirit and others.

Often these have been explained away simply as mysteries because "lucky are those who believe without seeing." The insistence on the "mystery of speaking in tongues and on miracles" on the part of charismatics has been equally harmful.

But today, people are more educated and learned in modern disciplines that have made them more inquisitive, says Dr. Fynn. They will therefore go to groups that either put less emphasis on such fundamental issues or provide answers to these mysteries however superfluous.

One of the major faults of mainline churches is eliticism of church leaders and institutions. This contradicts the brotherhood prescribed in the scriptures. There are now "inner circles" and at the same time "strangers" within congregations instead of fellowship, says Dr. Fynn.

Some elites have reserved seats on the pews irrespective of their apparent conduct. When elites want to baptize their children or are in need of funeral services, no "embarrassing questions" are asked, he adds. "These are reserved for the more lowly."

In the independent churches as well as in charismatic movements, real brotherhood flourishes both in times of happiness and sadness.

When death occurs, unemployment hits or marriage takes place in a family, it becomes a collective concern of the entire group that worships together. This solidarity is reminiscent of the early church, and it is a major attraction given today's social economic hardships.

Dr. Fynn recommends a minimal interest (as in his church) or completely interest free revolving fund to help Christians start small enterprises as one way of fighting unemployment, dependency and alleviating poverty.

A related phenomenon is the domineering relationship between the church and clergy, and their followers. The relationship which, however, is found in both groups is manifest in excessive belief in the established institution of the church or its pastors than in God and the Holy Spirit.

While a stand on fundamental issues such as Christian doctrines and worship must be firmly elucidated, Dr. Fynn argues, there is a need for flexibility, tolerance of constructive criticism and willingness to learn new things and experiences.

Quoting the Bible, Dr. Fynn also urges mainline churches to make their services not only more lively but also more participatory, because afterall " priesthood is for all believers." The clergy may be trained but they do not have the monopoly of gifts of the Holy Spirit, he declares.

Something also needs to be done about the length of services and sermons. The same goes for "the three readings which sometimes are not even readily connected," making theological sense only to the priest but confusing to worshippers.

Born to parents who could neither read nor write, Rt. Rev. Fynn knows only that he was born on a Friday because of his middle name, "Kofi". Kofi in his native language means Friday, after which he was named.

After receiving his secular education in Ghana, he stayed with a Lutheran missionary from the United States. It was through this experience that he made the decision to attend seminaries in Obot Edim in Nigeria and in Makumira, Tanzania in the late 1960s. He later did a certificate course in journalism at the Africa Literature Centre at Kitwe in Zambia.

He also studied in the United States in the greater Chicago area, earning a bachelor of arts degree from Wheaton College and a master of arts degree in journalism from Northwestern University. Following his graduation he worked for two years as a journalist for the Chicago Tribune.

After returning to Ghana, he became pastor of St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Accra, which he continues to serve today without salary as a "worker-priest." He received an honorary doctor of divinity degree in 1995.

As president of the Lutheran Church in Ghana, since 1978, the number of Lutherans in Ghana increased from 4,000 to 20,000 in five years and continues to rise.

In addition to his priestly vocation, Dr. Fynn is an accomplished businessman. He is engaged in commercial mixed farming, trucking and taxi businesses.

He started business as a taxi driver when he was already a priest. He borrowed money to buy his first taxi which he drove himself whenever he was not pastoring to his flock. Dr. Fynn is married and has three children.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 23, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigerian Methodist Leader Defends Ordination Of Women


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

LAGOS - The head of the United Methodist Church in Nigeria went on the air on September 15 to defend his decision to ordain women as priests, saying it was time to end sexual discrimination.

"The church has been discriminating against women for so many years for no just reasons," Sunday Mbang said in last weekend's television interview, and maintained that "most of the reasons advanced by those opposed to it are cultural."

"There should be democracy in the church...We should not deprive women of leadership positions in the church," Mbang said. 

Mbang stirred up controversy in Christian circles with his announcement on September 12 that the Methodist Church in Nigeria had decided at its recent annual conference, in Ikot-Ekpene in south-eastern Akwa Ibom state, to ordain women as priests.

The training, qualification, screening and ordination of women to priesthood would be on the same terms as their male counterparts, and that women will be trained, just like men, and their grade would not be lowered, nor would anybody who is not qualified or deserved the post be given any opportunity, he added.

More than one-third of all Nigerians are Christians and some 45 per cent of the national population of more than 100 million are Muslims.

Mbang, who is also the national president of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN), pointed out that Methodist women were already being ordained as priests in England and the United States.

With this decision, the Methodist Church of Nigeria became the first member of the CAN to approve the ordination of women.

Early last year, an attempt by the Ilorin diocese of the Anglican Communion in Nigeria to ordain women as priests was rejected by the Anglican Church hierarchy and the three women who were ordained by the Anglican bishop of Ilorin diocese were later de-robed by the headquarters of the Church.

The Catholic Church in Nigeria is still opposed to the ordination of women as priests.

LANGUAGE: English
