Africa News


September 23, 1996


Uganda;
Ugandan Traditionalists Launch Pagan Rites Prayer Book


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

KAWOLO, UGANDA - A prayer book modelled on one commonly used in the Christian faith has been produced by followers of traditional religion in Uganda. It is published in Luganda, the language of Uganda's largest ethnic group (Baganda) comprising about 3 million people. 

The new pagan rites prayer book, Ebiggwa By'abalanzi (Temples of the Prophets), was launched at the industrial town of Kawolo near Kampala on September 10, during a get together of the Traditional Healers and Herbalists Association.

The Chairman of the association, Ssalongo Ben Ggulu, told a big gathering at the function that the book was "an answer to an outcry by healers for a suitable prayer book for use particularly at funerals."

Ggulu said quite often, believers in traditional religions were denied a decent funeral by Christian and Muslim priests.

Faithful of other religions were advised to stop despising traditionalists. Said Ggulu to his followers during the launch: "Followers of our faith, you must stop begging Christian and Muslim priests to pray for your dead since the government recognises us."

The prayer book is divided into sections including common prayer, readings, canons of traditional belief, hymns for funerals and last funeral rites.

One of the authors of the book, a healer named Katumba, lamented that for a long time traditionalists had been ridiculed as pagans "yet many Christians and Muslims frequent our shrines."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


363 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Malawi;
Malawi's Catholic Bishops Launch Church Programme


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

LILONGWE - The Catholic Church in Malawi has launched a massive national ecclesiastical programme, aimed at preparing the faithful for the third millennium.

In a pastoral letter, Walking Together in Faith: Our Journey Towards the year 2000, released here on September 14, the Episcopal Conference of Malawi said the programme designed under three phases from March 1996-2000 would also help the local Catholic church implement recommendations of the historic 1994 African synod as requested by Pope John Paull II.

The national ecclesiastical programme will also prepare local Christians for the year 2001 centenary celebrations marking the arrival of the first Catholic missionaries in this Southern African country.

"Our church has grown from very humble beginnings with four White Fathers who arrived at Mponda village in Mangochi district south- east of the country, on December 28, 1889, and three Montfort Missionaries, who reached Port Herald in Nsanje district, south of the country, on June 24, 1901, to what it is today," the Malawian Catholic bishops said in their pastoral letter. 

Giving a breakdown of Malawian faithful in the church, the bishops said their country of 11 million people has some 1.9 million Catholics who include 65,800 catechumens, 270 priests, more than 560 religious and eight bishops.

"These are impressive and encouraging statistics. However, the cause of appreciation and rejoicing depends more upon whether Christian values have become part of us and whether our lives influenced and shaped our social and cultural values," the Catholic clergy observed in their pastoral letter signed by seven bishops among them the Conference chairman Bishop Mkhori (Diocese of Chikwawa) and the Archbishop of Blantyre James Chiona.

"We encourage you to keep your eyes directed towards the Father, who beckons and calls us to go beyond our limited possibilities and by our witness of life enable all to be transformed into God's "own image and likeness. In this way all of us will be part of the great human pilgrimage to the house of the Father," the bishops have appealed to the faithful.

According to the programme, each diocese will adapt the national plan to suit its local situation. And the diocesan commission, guided by the bishop, shall have the duty to co-ordinate and direct the jubilee preparations and the implementation of the African synod.

On their contribution to the nation, the Malawian clergy said; "As Catholics, we can modestly be proud and grateful for the contribution we have made and are making in the fields of education, health and human development in our beloved country, Malawi."

The bishops vowed to continue to do whatever is within their power to minister to the sick and needy, especially those suffering from HIV/AIDS which threatens all and takes "so many of our dear ones, and leaves so many widowed and orphaned open to every kind of injustice."

And on their famous 1992 pastoral letter, Living our Faith, the first ever since independence to openly challenge democratic governance in Malawi, the bishops said; "We give thanks to the Lord that by his grace we were able, through that letter, to be the "voice of the voiceless at that critical moment of the history of our young nation.

"Since then, with the various contributions of Malawians, our sister churches, here at home and abroad as well as individuals and organizations overseas, Malawi has peacefully achieved a democratic society in a multi- party system," the Catholic bishops noted.

The bishops also underscored the need to improve their manner and methods of evangelisation. They noted that in the past their orientation has been towards mass conversions rather than individual conversion, tending to preach a gospel of fear with emphasis on evil and fires of hell instead of on the God of love.

They resolved to plan better formation programmes for all agents of evangelization and especially devise training programmes geared towards empowering the laity in their tasks of evangelization and building the church, and fostering a truly human society.

The Malawian clergy also condemned corruption in very strong terms, vowing to join all those who courageously speak out against this malpractice.

"This evil must be removed from our society. We urge you to say NO to this sin, which has become a way of life for some," they urged their fellow countrymen.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


364 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Burundi;
Archbishop's Body Found As Violence Persists In Burundi


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

BUJUMBURA - Burundian soldiers have recovered the bodies of the country's assassinated Roman Catholic archbishop, Joachim Ruhuna, and that of a nun who was murdered with him, a military spokesman announced here on September 18.

Army spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Longin Minani said the bodies were found buried in a field after Hutu rebels and troops of the Tutsi-dominated army exchanged fire on Mwumba hillside, not far from the scene of the killings in central Burundi.

Ruhuna, a member of the Tutsi minority regarded as a man of peace and reconciliation in a country torn by ethnic violence, died on September 9, along with the nun and another woman travelling with him, in an ambush during which his car was also set on fire.

The army, which restored Major Pierre Buyoya to power in a bloodless coup on July 25, has blamed rebels of the Hutu majority for the attack, but the guerrillas in turn blamed the military. 

Minani said soldiers spotted a group of "terrorists" in a sorghum field on the hillside north of the central town of Gitega and three kilometres from the site of the ambush early on September 17, leading to the rebels first opening fire and the soldiers shooting back. The guerrillas then fled.

But after searching the area, the soldiers found freshly turned earth in the sorghum field. They dug and found the two bodies, but as they did not recognise them, their commander then went to Gitega, Minani added.

The corpses, which bore gunshot wounds, were identified by a priest from the archbishop's diocese in Gitega and a doctor who were taken to the field. It took five hours for the army to get the bodies back to the road, Minani said.

A member of the archbishop's staff told journalists that the bodies would be buried in Gitega on September 19 after a requiem mass to be said at 9:30 a. m. (7:30 GMT).

Four other people who were travelling with the archbishop were found alive after the attack. They included the driver, who was shot and wounded, but who said that a "crowd of people, some almost in rags, but armed to the teeth" had attacked the car, which was "riddled with bullets."

On September 17, the army said it was certain that the Forces for the Defence of Democracy, the armed wing of the main Hutu organisation, the National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), killed the archbishop.

However, CNDD spokesman Jerome Ndiho has denied responsibility, saying that "as opposed to the rest of the Catholic hierarchy -- strongly pro-Tutsi and discriminatory -- Monsignor Ruhuna was a man of reconciliation."

The discovery of the bodies came as Hutu rebels continued to intensify their bloody campaign against the minority Tutsi-regime in Burundi. They wounded at least four people in ambushes on the highway between Burundi's capital Bujumbura and Gitega in the centre of the country, the army announced here on September 18.

An army officer, his wife and another person were injured on September 17 afternoon in an attack at Rutegema, 70 kilometres east of Bujumbura, while a civilian was wounded in nearby Gatabo the same day, military spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Isaie Nibizi said.

Rebels also carried out an ambush at Matongo, 77 kilometres north- east of the capital, but the casualty toll was not known, an informed source said.

Ethnic strife between the Hutu majority and Tutsis who dominate the armed forces has rocked Burundi for three years now. The fighting has escalated into a civil war which has claimed more than 150,000 lives, according to the London-based human rights organisation, Amnesty International.

The conflict flared up after the assassination of the first Hutu president, Melchior Ndadaye, in October 1993, the year he took over from Buyoya following Burundi's first free elections.

Buyoya, who seized back control two days after Hutu President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya took refuge in the United States embassy called for calm following the cleric's murder.

Let nobody use this unhappy event as a pretext to perpetrate acts of vengeance or plunge into extremism," Buyoya said last week.

The pope's special envoy Cardinal Jozef Tomko called for an end to the slaughter in Burundi in an emotional plea at a memorial service for Ruhuna.

"In the name of God, it is up to you, the political leaders, members of different parties, the military and armed groups, to stop massacring the people of Burundi, to stop the killing," Cardinal Tomko pleaded.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


365 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Uganda;
Ugandan Bishops Concerned About Aids Vaccine Safety


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

KAMPALA - Two bishops of the (Anglican) Church of Uganda have indicated the church will oppose the imminent human trials of the HIV/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) vaccines called ALVAC-HIV vaccine, if a number of outstanding issues are not resolved.

The principal fears are over safety considerations but legal, ethical and social issues are also outstanding. Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni is expected to make a final ruling on the matter following recommendations of a recent workshop that Ugandans should participate in the vaccine trials. The HIV vaccine trials conference was held in Kampala from September 8 to 10. 

Bishop Michael Senyimba of Mukono Diocese said emphatically: "True the church is tired of conducting endless funerals but the end does not justify the means. Measures have to be taken to ensure that people made in the image of God are not used as subjects to be disposed of when the experiments fail."

Retired Bishop Misaeri Kauma who is the chairman of Uganda's AIDS Commission equally wanted to be sure that Ugandans were not unduly being exposed to danger by the vaccine trials. He commented; "The church is the people and the people need to know whether it is safe before we start these trials."

Prof. Roy Mugerwa of the Medical School, Makerere University said trials of the vaccines have already been conducted in the United States, France, Thailand, Brazil and China.

Uganda had been chosen because of the high prevalence of HIV in the population. It is believed as many as 1.5 million out of Uganda's population of 18 million people are HIV positive.

Participation in the trials is entirely voluntary but Prof. John Rwomushana of Uganda AIDS Commission called for an independent counselling body in the recruitment of volunteers to ensure participants were fully aware of what they were doing.

The workshop heard that many parents in Mukono and Tororo District were now scared of taking their children for routine immunization against the six killer diseases such as polio and tuberculosis, for fear that their children would be injected with the French-made experimental vaccine.

Mr. Paul Kaggwa of Uganda's Ministry of Health Education Department said parents in Mukono "related national immunization days to the AIDS vaccine trial and were pessimistic about ordinary post-natal vaccines."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


366 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Liberia;
Aid Workers Deliver Assistance Following Ceasefire


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

MONROVIA - The full scale of human suffering in the western Liberia town of Tubmanburg emerged recently as aid workers reached there for the first time in seven months.

It follows a ceasefire between two rival Ulimo factions operating in the area, about 70 kilometres from the capital, Monrovia. Relief agencies withdrew from Tubmanburg in Bomi county last February when fresh fighting broke out between the United Liberation Movement in Liberia-J (Ulimo-J) and Ulimo-K, leaving thousands of people without food and medical supplies. 

Many fled their homes into the surrounding jungle following harassment by rebels, and have been barely surviving on wild roots, leaves and fruits. Scores, probably hundreds have died of starvation. Reports quote aid workers as saying skeletal, pot- bellied children discovered in the town displayed some of the worst symptoms of malnutrition seen in the country's seven-year- old civil war.

About 150 severely malnourished children were evacuated to a special feeding centre in Monrovia. The Chairman of the Ruling State Council, Ms Ruth Perry, is reported to have broken down and wept after seeing a video taken from Tubmanburg to the capital by aid workers.

"This is the worst thing we have seen in the seven-year history of the war in Liberia," an official with the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), told journalists. The aid workers estimate that over 80 per cent of the town's 35,000 population is seriously malnourished, adding that hundreds of civilians have emerged from the forest as word of relief operations spread.

"Hundreds have emerged from the jungle along the road to Tubmanburg. We set up a distribution point along that road today (September 11)," Daniela Deane of the World Food Programme (WFP) is quoted

telling reporters. The precise death toll arising out of widespread hunger is difficult to gauge, but local people have been quoted saying up to 16 people have been dying daily before relief arrived.

In neighbouring Grand Cape Mounty close to the Sierra Leonean border, however, skirmishes have continued between the two factions, making it difficult for relief workers to reach about 3,000 starving people trapped there. And Ms Perry has appealed to the factions to stop fighting and allow help to reach the needy.

Meanwhile, reports reaching APS shortly before going to press indicate that two generals of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), led by Charles taylor, have been arrested and detained by George Boley's Liberia Peace Council (LPC) in Grand Gedeh County, to the south-east.

The NPFL generals were part of a joint assessment team, including the two factions, officials from the Economic Community of West African States intervention force, ECOMOG, UN Observer Mission and the United States embassy. The men were arrested shortly after a helicopter landed in an area of Grand Gedeh controlled by LPC, who demanded that the team proceed to Greenville in neighbouring Sinoe County. Each of the two factions claims it is occupying Greenville.

The NPFL generals were arrested in the presence of all the officials, and observers say the incident threatens to derail the entire peace process. The team immediately abandoned its mission and returned to Monrovia, and urgent negotiations are said to be underway to defuse the tension and release the men.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


367 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Church Group Changes Peace Prize Name To Honour Tutu


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

NAIROBI - The All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) peace prize has been given a higher profile and will now be referred to as the AACC Desmond Tutu Peace Prize.

This was decided at the just-ended annual General Committee meeting in Douala, Cameroon from September 10 to 13. 

Dr. Setri Nyomi, the Executive Secretary of the Christian and Family Life Education department and a member of the committee, revealed that the members saw it fitting to award a peace prize at every

AACC General Assembly, following that those Africans working for peace on the continent need to be recognised and rewarded. The Assembly meets once every five years.

Dr. Nyomi said the name "Desmond Tutu" was in recognition of the retired South African Archbishop's efforts in reversing the distressing trend of civil strife in South Africa and Africa as a whole. The former head of the Anglican Church in South Africa is also the current president of the AACC.

The first AACC peace prize was awarded before the 1992 General Assembly to Anglican Archbishop Dinis Segulane of Mozambique.

Meanwhile, the properties of the AACC shall be name after the late Dr. Francis Ibiam of Nigeria and late Lutheran Bishop Josiah Kibila of Tanzania who initiated the idea of forming a binding force for African churches in the name of AACC.

According to Prof. Jesse Mugambi, a member of the AACC General Committee, it was necessary to acknowledge the two clergymen because initially the idea was to form a Lutheran body but the two argued for a body that would accommodate all churches in Africa.

The properties named include a five storey building that houses various international organizations and the AACC headquarters in Nairobi.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


368 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigerian Police Plan Tough Action Against Extremists


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

LAGOS - Nigerian police have warned Islamic extremists that they would face a tough response if they used violence to try to free their leader, who was arrested after bloody clashes on September 13, the Nigerian press reported on September 17.

The police chief in the northern Kaduna state, where at least six people were killed and several hurt in fighting between fundamentalists and police, told reporters to "tell them that if they want to commit suicide, we have our men on the ground and they are ready."

"If they are bent on breaking the laws of the land, we are ready to break their legs," the independent Guardian and Tribune dailies quoted state commissioner of police Yakuba Sahibu as saying. 

On September 16, Islamic extremists in northern Nigeria warned that they will launch a holy war if the authorities failed to free their chief, who was arrested after clashes with police left six dead, according to press reports.

The fundamentalists in Zaria in Kaduna state said they would begin their jihad or holy war, if the security services did not free Sheikh Ibrahim Ahmad Zak-Zaki by September 19.

Supporters of the preacher battled police in Zaria on September 13 at the cost of six lives, according to police figures, but independent press reports said the toll could be higher, while a fundamentalist said that 14 people were shot dead.

Shaibu said that police did not open fire and only used tear gas to disperse demonstrators, adding: "In fact, they may have tied wood together and put it in coffins and claimed that the police killed their members to attract public sympathy."

But a Zaria Muslim reached by telephone on September 17, Mohammed Ciroma, dismissed this allegation and said his movement would soon produce proof of its claims, including videotapes of the victims and the spent bullets fired by police.

Ciroma neither confirmed nor denied the press reports about the warning of a jihad.

The clashes in Zaria followed a demonstration by Muslim fundamentalists protesting against the arrest on September 12 of the 34-year-old sheikh Zak- Zaki, a mystic preacher renowned for inflammatory sermons.

He was detained with at least 20 of his supporters after battles on September 8 between Shiite Muslims and Christians in another Kaduna state town, Kafanchan, where at least two people were killed and 15 injured.

A section of the press on September 16 reported that Zak-Zaki was believed to have been transferred to a detention centre in Port Harcourt at the other end of the country, on the coast in the southern Rivers State.

The security forces in the north were placed on a state of high alert at the weekend, when witnesses said that police and army roadblocks had been set up on the road from Zaria to Kaduna town and along the main routes linking Kaduna state with the neighbouring states of Kano and Katsina.

According to his associates, Zak-Zaki has already spent nearly nine years in prison because of his militant activities.

Shaibu has since stated that Zak-Zaki's arrest was completely unrelated to the violence in Kafanchan, saying that instead, the sheikh had been held for producing and presenting illegal radio programmes, jamming and using the frequencies of the government-owned radio in the state.

Northern Nigeria is populated mainly by Muslims, who form about 45 per cent of the country's total population of more than 100 million.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


369 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Science;
Zimbabwe's Electrical Engineers Studying Lightning Pattern


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

HARARE - Zimbabwe's electrical engineers have installed lightning strike detectors on 26 locations countrywide in an ongoing exercise which will eventually see the whole country's lightning distribution system mapped out.

The project, at a cost of more than Zimbabwe dollars 700,000 (about US$70, 000) is being jointly undertaken by a parastatal, the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA) and the University of Zimbabwe's Department of Electrical Engineering.

Zimbabwe has a high lightning strike toll. On average 250 people in this southern African country are killed by lightning each rainy season. Related information will be of vital importance to the country as the general lightning pattern will be determined. Initial indications are that lightning activities increase as one moves towards the Zambezi Valley which is in the country's northern borders. 

The detectors, which cover a radius of 20 kilometres each, are being installed at ZESA establishments in Bindura, Chinhoyi, Marondera, Mutare Rural, Masvingo, Kwekwe, Gweru, Bulawayo and Hwange. Other districts will be covered later. ZESA officials will collect data and pass it on to the Department of Electrical Engineering for further analysis.

Sudden black-outs and other electrical faults on households are sometimes a common feature in Zimbabwe's residential areas during the rainy seasons. Most of the faults are attributed to direct lightning strikes on installations, and trees falling on power lines as a result of the strikes.

Available data shows that over 90 per cent of ZESA's faults are caused by lightning. It is hoped that this information on lightning will help ZESA in routing its transmission lines and in the design and location of substations. It will also help Zimbabweans to desist from building homesteads in areas that are prone to lightning.

Various theories have been advanced about lightning, with some Zimbabweans believing that some people are capable of directing killer lightning bolts to their foes.

About two years ago, ZESA exhibited some lightning conductors designed mainly for rural communities but the response so far has been hopelessly poor. Given that the conductors are relatively cheap, this reaction may be explained by ignorance and superstition on how lightning operates among the majority of the peasants.

Most huts in the communal lands (where the majority of the country's population lives) are built of pole-and-dagga (mud-walled) and usually grass- thatched, thereby making them vulnerable to lightning strikes.

At an international conference on lightning conductors in 1995 which was held in Harare, a traditional healer challenged scientists to stand on a platform so that he could demonstrate whether he could not create or redirect a lightning bolt. None of the scientists took up the challenge!

Meanwhile, South Africa is the only African country which has a map with isokeraunic curves - lines showing places with similar lightning activities.

When this project is completed Zimbabwe will be the second to have such a map.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


370 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Cameroon;
Environmentalists Query Bank's Project In Cameroon


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

LONDON - Although Cameroon's Transport Sector Project is well intentioned, the way World Bank officials have gone round the planning of the project has created doubts in the minds of some environmental campaigners who say the country's environment has been sacrificed.

If the project goes ahead, it would help rehabilitate and maintain some of the country's worst kept road networks especially the Abang Mbang - Lomie and the Gari Gombo - Moloundou roads.

But the project has run into controversy with the London-based Friends of the Earth (FOE), leading a campaign to prevent it from taking off because it is likely to destroy one of Africa's best rainforests.

World Bank staffers argue that "delaying the improvement of road maintenance country-wide would contribute to the isolation of rural communities, and thus have a detrimental effect on poverty alleviation and the protection of the environment." 

The project itself shows how World Bank staffers mislead their officers to force projects that would otherwise not have taken off. The World Bank is trying to force the government of Cameroon to go ahead with a road project that the African Development Bank (ADB) withdrew from because of the effects that it would have on the country's environment.

FOE says "one of the roads on the map is a pure and simple logging road that ADB rejected on environmental grounds following an environmental assessment."

According to FOE, it has secret document to show that "World Bank staff misled their own Board of Directors in order to force through a project that will lead to new logging" in the area considered Africa's most spectacular rainforest."

A memo dated May 16, 1996 and written by a World Bank staffer Robert Tillman, which APS has seen, said the United States Treasury had raised concerns on the project and the US Agency for International Development (USAID) has written to the US Environment Department "asking for postponement and to oppose the project." The Rain Forest Coalition has contacted the UK Environment Department to raise the issue.

"As a result of the map, it appears that we may be funding road maintenance that ADB rejected and without our own environmental assessment," Tillman added.

A technical team sent to assess the project also said "the road was never considered for funding since they will focus on high traffic roads nearer urban centres and markets."

"There is very serious opposition to the project and it is possible that the US Environment Department will either abstain or oppose the project and is likely to be joined by the UK Environment Department."

In another memo, Tillman suggested that "assurance should be sought that the annual review of the road maintenance programme to be organized with the participation of sector stakeholders, Government and donors representatives should include specific environment criteria and should verify that a satisfactory mitigation plan is in place."

But according to the Friends of the Earth, one Maryvonne and her team operating in Cameroon drafted a letter purported to have been written by the Government of Cameroon, indicating that environmental precautions had been taken for all the maintenance and rehabilitation work to go ahead.

Tillman then wrote in a memo that "I have received the letter and Maryvonne is going to send us a copy in English and French."

Reacting to the tricks that the World Bank staffers used in attempting to force the implementation of the project, Tony Juniper, FOE's deputy campaigns director said "the World Bank is a smoke screen behind which environmental and social destruction is carried forward in the name of development. World Bank policies to protect forests and the poor are not worth the paper they are written on."

Since the UK's executive director of the World Bank is British, FOE says " the British government must demand an inquiry and heads must roll."

Even though the executive director was initially against the project, it has now been proved that he voted in favour of the project on May 30, 1996.

The organization has also decided to lobby UK MPs not to approve money for the World Bank.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


371 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Uganda;
Ugandan Church Blames Financial Mess On "Many" Sees


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

JINJA-EASTERN UGANDA - A report by the Anglican Church of Uganda indicates that the formation of many dioceses is the cause of financial problems in the province.

This was disclosed by the Church of Uganda Provincial Secretary, the Rev. Canon William Magambo, in a press interview on September 14.

He said the House of Bishops had decided that no new dioceses would be formed within the existing ones in the province until 1998. 

Rev. Magambo was reacting to a report that Kamuli and Iganga archdeaconaries in Busoga Diocese, eastern Uganda, which support Bishop Cyprian Bamwoze's leadership, were seceding from Busoga Diocese and forming their own fully-fledged dioceses.

A leadership wrangle in Busoga diocese has been going on for the last four years with one section of the laity saying they did not recognise the Rev. Bamwoze as bishop.

The House of Bishops, under the chairmanship of Archbishop Livingstone Nkoyoyo decided two months ago to retire Bishop Bamwoze prematurely in February next year, to allow the cooling off of tempers.

Bishop Bamwoze is currently on forced sabbatical leave until next year. He is to retire in 1997 although he would be reaching the retirement age a year later.

The retirement of Bishop Bamwoze seems not to have satisfied all parties concerned. No sooner was the bishop's retirement made public than several archdeaconaries supporting him announced they would form new dioceses, separate from Busoga diocese.

Two years ago, a committee set up by the House of Bishops to look into the problems of Busoga diocese, recommended that the diocese be split into three dioceses so that Bishop Bamwoze could take one where he had support. But the Bishop and his supporters as well as enemies said they were opposed to the splitting up of the diocese.

Two years ago, there were efforts to create more sees in the central region kingdom of Buganda so that the kingdom could set up its own province, independent of the Province of the Church of Uganda.

The laity in Buganda were at the time complaining bitterly that although the first Protestant missionaries arrived in their kingdom and set up churches there before moving to other parts of the country, no Muganda had been elected Archbishop of the Church of Uganda up to then. Partly due to their pressures, the House of Bishops last year elected his Grace Livingstone Nkoyooyo as Archbishop.

Rev. Magambo said due to demands from several parts of the country for the creation of new sees, the House of Bishops had instituted a committee to visit those places which want to form new dioceses and provide a report to be considered in 1998.

In a country with more than 40 ethnic groups, there has been a tendency in the church to create tribal bishops who have been sent to administer in their home regions. There has been a struggle therefore, for every tribe to clamour for a bishop from their own kind as a form of parity among several tribal groups.

Wherever dioceses have been created, the Christians in the area have been forced to contribute towards the purchase of an expensive vehicle for the bishop, construct and furnish a big residence for him and his family and contribute every Sunday for his fat salary and upkeep.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


372 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Libya;
Libya Reports to UN on Sanction Damage


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2227 words


 

United Nations - Following are excerpts from the Report on the Impact of the UN Sanctions against Libya which was transmitted to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali by the Libyan Mission to the UN in September 1996.

Sixth comprehensive report on damage caused by the implementation of Security Council resolutions 748 (1992) and 883 (1993) during the period from 15 April 1992 to 31 December 1995

The substantial damage caused in the humanitarian, economic and social spheres by the coercive and unjust measures taken against the Libyan Arab people under Security Council resolutions 748 (1992) and 883 (1993) continues to worsen day by day. In addition, all infrastructure development programmes and plans have been adversely affected, thereby dashing the hopes and aspirations of the Libyan Arab people to achieve progress, well-being, development, stability, security and peace. Some particulars of the enormous physical, material and financial damage sustained by the Libyan people during the period indicated above are given hereunder.

HUMANITARIAN CONSEQUENCES -- HEALTH AND SOCIAL WELFARE

The sector aims to provide for the health care and social well-being for all members of society and to achieve the noble goals established by the international community through its international and regional organizations and agencies. The goal of "Health for All" must be pursued so that all social groups and segments of society can make solid progress and objectives in the areas of health and social welfare can be achieved. 

In this connection, it should be pointed out that the sector has sustained enormous material and humanitarian damage, affecting the Libyan population as a whole and most of the expatriates from Arab and other friendly countries living in the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, as can be seen from the following examples.

1. Some 15,750 persons living in the Jamahiriya are suffering from serious medical conditions (cardiovascular disease; fractures of the spinal column and thorax; fractured skulls; chronic eye diseases; detached retinas: serious burns; cancer and malignant tumours) which require emergency treatment (neurosurgery; spinal marrow transplants; kidney transplants; corneal transplants; fitting of prostheses). Owing to the continuation of the aerial embargo, these individuals, who could not be treated in local hospitals and health-care facilities, could not be evacuated by air for treatment in other countries or for necessary medical examinations and surgery in hospitals and specialized health-care facilities with modern equipment. Because they could not obtain treatment, most of these patients died in tragic circumstances.

2. More than 780 seriously injured patients (most of whom were the victims of road accidents) died in ambulances en route to airports in neighbouring countries so that they could be transported by air for treatment abroad in spite of the difficulties of the overland journey.

3. There have been 1,135 stillbirths and 514 women have died in childbirth in the various hospitals owing to the shortage of medicines, serums and vaccines. Prior to the aerial embargo, such supplies had been imported regularly by air, with the usual precautions being taken to preserve their efficacy and usability. The Libyan Arab Jamahiriya was able in that way to meet its needs in this area, particularly in emergency situations.

4. Owing to the aerial embargo and the consequent increase in overland traffic, there has been a rise in the number of road accidents. As Libyans have had to take to the roads linking the major cities in the country, hundreds have been involved in accidents in which they have been killed or suffered permanent disability. There have been some 15,260 victims of road accidents, including 2,560 fatalities. The remaining 12,700 victims are suffering from serious injuries or permanent disabilities.

More than 18,200 public and privately owned vehicles have been damaged, for an estimated cost of $1,450,000.

5. The number of diabetics who have died has increased, owing to the unavailability of serums and medicines.

6. The shortage of poliomyelitis vaccine, which continues to worsen, has impeded the implementation of periodic or annual therapeutic, preventive and awareness-raising programmes connected with national and international immunization campaigns with specific timetables. Many Libyan and other children have thus been prevented from receiving doses at the prescribed times in accordance with the guidelines of the World Health Organization (WHO) and national public health laws and regulations.

7. Therapeutic and preventive services for school health programmes have been suspended, as have the programmes and activities of mother-and-child health-care centres and centres for the mentally retarded and physically handicapped.

8. International pharmaceutical companies have been slow in supplying the health and social welfare sector and hospital establishments with essential pharmaceuticals and equipment needed to treat and prevent diseases.

9. Companies specializing in the maintenance of air ambulances have refused to supply the spare parts needed to maintain the country's fleet and other on- board equipment. These aircraft, which service Libyan citizens and expatriates alike, are no longer able to perform fully their humanitarian mission, whether in Libya or abroad, given the country's extensive land area.

10. Delays have consistently occurred in the delivery of some medical supplies (serums, vaccines, blood products, hormones, reagents used in AIDS testing, radioactive iodine, etc.) because they are now shipped overland or by sea. Such supplies are usually shipped by air (so that the normal measures can be taken to preserve their efficacy); special permission must now be sought for the purchase of such items. When they arrive in Libya, most of these supplies (in particular, poliomyelitis vaccine) have lost their efficacy (having been stored under improper conditions) which has resulted in an increase in the number of deaths among infants and women, particularly in childbirth, and disarray in the provision of health services generally.

11. Losses estimated at around $180,800,000 have been experienced in the health and social welfare sector owing to the maintenance of the aerial embargo against the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, which has caused delays in the shipment of medical supplies. The Libyan Arab Jamahiriya obtains supplies from specialized international companies to meet the needs of a variety of institutions (medical schools, technical institutes, rehabilitation centres and homes for the elderly).

12. Maintenance of the aerial embargo has dealt a serious blow to preventive and curative health services provided under international technical cooperation agreements. The country is endeavouring to develop, strengthen and maintain such agreements with various countries in order to develop the health and social welfare sector and modernize its hospitals with the aim of providing improved medical, therapeutic and prophylactic services for all its citizens.

13. The maintenance of the embargo has also impeded cooperation programmes between the People's Committee for Health and Social Welfare and the bodies under it, on the one hand, and WHO, on the other. Most of the visits which international experts and WHO teams were to make to Libya have been cancelled or postponed, which has adversely affected all the major health care and preventive health programmes and hampered efforts to promote and modernize the health and social welfare sector. The failure or stagnation of international cooperation in this area would prevent Libya from achieving the targets set by WHO and pursuing the WHO strategy of "Health for All by the Year 2000".

14. More than 360 medical specialists and highly qualified instructors from universities and medical centres from around the world have been unable to come to the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya to treat patients with serious conditions, perform delicate surgical procedures in public hospitals, conduct examinations in the country's medical schools at different times of the year, and participate in conferences, symposia and courses organized in the country.

15. The growing shortage of spare parts has resulted in a deterioration in the maintenance of modern medical equipment used in hospitals and medical centres. In addition, there is the lack of technical skills in most hospitals and health establishments in major cities and villages alike.

16. More than 8,500 medical doctors of various nationalities have been unable to come to the country to work in the health and social welfare sector because of the difficulties and hardships presented by the maintenance of the aerial embargo. Some 6,400 medical specialists in various fields have not renewed their contracts, which has adversely affected the quality of health care in the majority of hospitals and other health facilities.

ECONOMIC CONSEQUENCES

I. AGRICULTURE AND ANIMAL HUSBANDRY

Since 15 April 1992, the implementation of the sanctions under Security Council resolutions 748 (1992) and 883 (1993) has inflicted serious damage and caused major financial losses in the agriculture and animal husbandry sector. These have affected all companies and institutions in the sector, as well as related development programmes. Agricultural output and meat production have fallen off markedly, resulting in financial losses estimated at $5,982,249,782...

II. TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

The transport and communications sector has suffered severely since the coercive sanctions were first imposed on Libya on 15 April 1992. Not only has this sector sustained heavy material damage and financial losses, but there have been moral and psychological aspects as well, which have adversely affected the capabilities, aspirations and morale of all transport and communication workers. Financial losses are estimated at $1,157,523,500...

III. INDUSTRY AND MINING

Since the mandatory sanctions under Security Council resolutions 748 (1992) and 883 (1993) were first imposed, the industry and mining sector has continued to suffer considerable losses and other material damages. The total financial loss resulting from these increasingly adverse effects on all aspects of industrial development amounts to approximately $4,150,677,942, which can largely be ascribed to the following: (...)

IV. FINANCE AND TRADE

Like all the other vital sectors, the finance and trade sector has suffered on account of the air embargo imposed on the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya by Security Council resolutions 748 (1992) and 883 (1993). The total financial losses in the sector are currently estimated at $4,257,000,000, primarily owing to the following: (...)

V. ENERGY (PETROLEUM AND ELECTRICITY)

The energy sector (petroleum and electricity) has suffered considerable material losses as a result of the mandatory sanctions applied pursuant to Security Council resolutions 748 (1992) and 883 (1993), and negative repercussions have been felt in most of the vital facilities and economic entities of that sector. The financial losses suffered by the sector are in the order of $3 billion.

Edited by Ingrid Solem (isolem@igc.apc.org).


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


South Africa;
Truth Commission Completes Review of Activities


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - The following statement is from a "bosberaad" of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission which finished meeting yesterday. It was designed primarily for staff but is being released in the same form or the public.

Commissioners, Committee members and the senior management of the Commission yesterday ended a two-day bosberaad during which they undertook a thorough review of its activities, including an analysis of our strengths and weaknesses, and drew up proposals for the way ahead. 

Among areas which were identified for consideration and action were:

-- Re-modelling our hearings schedule to provide for a wider variety of hearings;

-- Enhancing the quality and quantity of statement-taking, on the basis that the making of statements will be the means by which we will reach most victims;

-- Ensuring that findings on human rights abuses begin to be made;

-- Improving the administrative capacity of the Amnesty Committee;

-- Finalising the Reparation and Rehabilitation Committee's proposals for urgent interim relief for those victims of human rights abuses who need immediate assistance;

-- Conveying to the public that it will be Parliament, not the Commission, which decides finally on the nature and extent of reparations and mechanisms of rehabilitation for other victims;

-- Enhancing the Commission's capacity for seeking the truth, specifically in identifying perpetrators of human rights abuses;

-- Concrete strategies to promote reconciliation;

-- Communication and interaction with the public;

-- Improving the information flow in the Commission; and

-- Issues of management and team-building, including factors which affect the Commission's public image.

Proposals to address these and other issues will be finalised by a strategic planning committee and the full Commission, operating in conjunction with management and staff of the Commission.

A key factor in planning the Commission's activities is the financial resources available to it. The Commission, in order to maintain and even step up its activities, is expecting the State to allocate adequate resources to facilitate the achievement of national unity and reconciliation.

However, the Treasury Committee has indicated to us that it believes our budget has to be cut in line with national priorities and other cuts in State spending. This proposal challenges the Commission anew to exercise strict fiscal discipline and to streamline our operations to achieve the strategic objectives identified during the bosberaad at the lowest possible cost.

At the same time, the Commission is determined that its independence from the political process needs to be firmly defended and it will work to ensure that the national objective of promoting unity and reconciliation in South Africa is given proper recognition in financial decision-making. These issues will be taken further by the Commission and discussed fully with staff and management.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


374 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi Humanitarian Situation Report Sept 10 - 17


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2560 words


 

Nairobi - Following is the Burundi Humanitarian Situation Report for the period September 10 to September 17 from the office of the Humanitarian Coordinator of the United Nations Development Program (UNDP).

Bujumbura - Bujumbura remained calm following the assassination of the archbishop and President Buyoya's moves to restore political institutions. However, fighting continued in the hills outside the city and in northern Burundi. Diminished fuel stocks and limited supplies of other essential resources continue to limit humanitarian activities, although specific exemptions granted by the Regional Sanctions Coordination Committee (RSCC) should provide some improvement.

1. General

* Unknown assailants assassinated the Roman Catholic archbishop of Burundi, Joachim Ruhuna, after ambushing his vehicle on September 9 in the parish of Gitongo, 37 km north of Gitega. 

The attack was another significant blow against those arguing for a negotiated settlement to Burundi's on-going civil war. UN and NGO representatives in the country fear that the assassination of the archbishop will further divide the country, isolating moderates arguing for restraint on both sides of the ongoing conflict.

Four of the six people who were travelling with the cleric have been found alive, while the body of a fifth was buried in Gitega on Sept. 11. The archbishop's body, and that of a nun who was travelling with him, have yet to be found.

Neither the military nor Hutu rebels have taken responsibility for the attack, while both sides have blamed the other for the ambush.

The archbishop's diocese of Gitega is the second biggest in the country and has recently been the scene of the some of the heaviest fighting in Burundi. On July 23, the archbishop celebrated a requiem mass close to Bugendana for some 330 Tutsis massacred in the area, criticizing extremists of both sides.

At least 10 Roman Catholic clerics have been assassinated in Burundi since 1993 and the archbishop himself survived an assassination attempt last year.

A public church service will be held for the archbishop in Bujumbura on September 17.

* UN officials have welcomed the decision by the RSCC to exempt certain classes of relief items from the sanctions on Burundi. However, strict sanctions remain on the importation of other essential humanitarian goods. Humanitarian agencies will now be able to import emergency medical and laboratory supplies, and nutritional supplements for infants and hospital patients. The UN will also be to import limited quantities of fuel for distributing these items. However, other essential humanitarian goods will still not be allowed in. The UN continues to seek exemptions for food and other items such as blankets, plastic sheeting, and supplies for water purification and sanitation.

* In a move which Burundian government authorities hope will persuade neighboring countries to lift the economic embargo, President Pierre Buyoya pledged to restore the country's national assembly and once again allow limited activities of political parties. "We have done our duty. We wait for others to do their duty," Buyoya said. "I believe there should be no other pretexts (for sustaining the sanctions)."

While UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros Ghali termed Buyoya's Sept. 12 announcement "extremely positive," political leaders from neighboring countries have made it clear their view that the announcement does not go far enough.

* Former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere, who spear-headed the imposition of sanctions, has said that the sanctions could be eased if there was evidence of serious talks with the rebels. He described the restoration of political institutions as being of lesser importance. Buyoya has offered to hold peace talks, but only if rebel movements first lay down their arms and "renounce their ideology of genocide." Moreover, the constitution remains suspended, no new legislative elections will be held and it is unclear how the national assembly could operate since many of the Frodebu delegates elected three years ago have since fled the country and are now calling on party activists to join the armed rebellion.

In a statement issued from Tanzania, Frodebu leader Jean Minani denounced the Buyoya move as a "totally unacceptable masquerade." But 12 other Frodebu members declared their allegiance to the Buyoya government, setting themselves apart from those who have called for armed insurrection. The mainly Hutu Frodebu party won 65 of the 81 parliamentary seats in the 1993 legislative elections, while the Tutsi dominated Uprona party won the remaining 16.

Some observers, including Uprona head Charles Mukasi think it is unlikely that the contending Frodebu factions could work together effectively in parliament and doubt the viability of a re-instituted national assembly. Mukasi added that the measures taken by Buyoya will be "useless and dangerous" unless the sanctions are lifted and warned that Buyoya risked losing his credibility if they were not. Uprona's withdrawal of support for the Ntibantunganya government was one of the factors which precipitated the July coup.

Former head of state Jean-Babtiste Bagaza, who has influence over sections of the army and Tutsi youth, has also called the plan unworkable. "You can't govern a country in this fashion...Buyoya and his group must go."

However, the CNDD, which might have been expected to be more skeptical, has been more supportive. In a statement issued from Brussels, the organization called the move "a positive step but insufficient."

* Burundian Foreign Minister Luc Rukingama denied accusations by the Zairian government that his country was being used as a base for Rwandan Tutsis currently battling the Zairian army in the hills surrounding Uvira. However, he warned that the fighting could engulf the entire region and called for meetings between the three countries to resolve the conflict. Over the past ten days, the Zairian army has been conducting a sweep against armed Tutsis near Uvira. The Zairian government on September 13 accused the Rwandan government of enrolling some 3,000 Zairian Tutsis and training them to destablize eastern Zaire with Burundi providing rear bases. Although the number of casualties is unknown, several hundred people have fled the region and are now reportedly living as refugees in Cibitoke province.

2. Security

Two days after the ambush of the archbishop, the Burundian military claims to have killed seven Hutu rebels on an attack on a bus. A military spokesman claims the attack was carried out by the same band who ambushed the cleric and that the attack was at the same approximate location.

Hutu rebels killed 15 people Sept. 13 in an attack on a displaced camp in Bubanza province. A military spokesman said that seven civilians, six rebels and a soldier were killed in the raid on Gara camp. In a separate attack, Hutu rebels ambushed two vehicles on the main RN1 highway near Bugarama, 35 kilometers east of Bujumbura, killing one civilian and wounding another. Numerous trucks and minibuses have also reportedly been attacked along the same road.

Security in Bujumbura has returned to normal after rebels lobbed three mortars into the city's suburbs September 3. Three soldiers and over 100 rebels were killed in subsequent heavy fighting that lasted for over a week in the hills surrounding the city, military sources say. Over 1,700 displaced people temporarily moved to the Johnson Center and other sites around Bujumbura to escape the fighting. Many of them have since returned to their homes.

Rebels destroyed two more electrical pylons in Bubanza September 11. Roughly 20 pylons have been destroyed since April, leaving Bujumbura virtually without electricity for the past month.

Anti-personnel mines are increasingly being used in the provinces of Bubanza and Cibitoke. At least eight mine casualties have recently been treated in Bujumbura hospitals.

3. Affected Populations

Following rebel offensives in Kayanza and Ngozi provinces, UNICEF, CRS and DHA conducted a joint mission to the region Sept. 11-12 in order to assess the needs of the affected populations. The mission visited several IDP sites and reported that humanitarian needs were largely being met.

Provincial authorities told the mission that at least 15,000 people had been displaced by the fighting but that they expected many IDPs to return to their homes shortly since security appeared to be improving. Humanitarian agencies in the north provided a quick and coordinated response to the emergency. WFP has provided 15 days of food rations and continues to operate Food for Work programs. The International Federation of the Red Cross and Christian Aid have provided blankets, jerry cans and soap, while MSF-Holland, MSF-Belgium and UNICEF are covering medical needs. UNICEF reports that it has provided 5mt of high energy biscuits to the population. UN agencies and NGOs operating in the area report that humanitarian activities have been limited by a shortage of fuel.

CRS reports that it provided food for approximately 2,360 people in Gitega over the reporting period as well as to approximately 1,000 IDPs and other vulnerable people in Bujumbura Rural. Some of those receiving distributions from CRS in the outskirts of the city were displaced by recent fighting in the area. Oxfam-UK and Christian Aid distributed blankets and other non-food items to individuals in the Kamenge area of the city displaced by recent fighting in the surrounding hills.

5. Coordination of Humanitarian Activities

Given the critical fuel shortages, UN agencies have created a joint logistics service to combine deliveries of existing supplies. WFP and UNHCR will, whenever possible, attempt to deliver humanitarian supplies for other UN agencies and NGOs. WFP will coordinate requests from NGOs to transport food and nutritional supplements, UNICEF will handle NGO requests for the transport of non-food items and WHO will handle NGO requests for medical supplies.

In light of the RSCC's decision to allow UN agencies to import fuel for specified humanitarian activities, the UN system has agreed that WFP will be the sole importer of fuel products. Relying on a single importer, rather than each agency importing its own needs, will simplify reporting and verification requirements. A committee composed of representatives of UN agencies will oversee the distribution of the fuel to ensure that humanitarian agencies use it in strict accordance with the letter and spirit of the exemption. ActionAid will coordinate fuel requests from recognized NGOs and forward those requests to the UN committee.

Work on the Joint Operations Plan for Humanitarian Intervention in Burundi continues. Sectoral drafting responsibilities have been distributed among UN agencies and September 30 has been set as a target date for final completion of the document.

FAO, in conjunction with WFP, hosted a meeting Sept. 16 with UN agencies and NGOs to discuss the effects of the embargo on the agricultural sector. An FAO emergency survey on seeds, fertilizer and insecticide needs is continuing with an FAO assessment mission visiting the provinces of Bururi, Rutana, Makamba, Gitega and Muramvya over the reporting period. FAO, in conjunction with its NGO partners Dorkas Aid and CRS, conducted a mission to Rutana to discuss planned seed multiplication programs with local authorities.

6. Impact of Sanctions on the Delivery of Humanitarian Assistance Sanctions continue to take their toll on the delivery of humanitarian goods. Fuel shortages have been compounded by the lack of electricity in the capital. This has forced all humanitarian agencies to divert a significant portion of their fuel supply to run office generators.

Due to the lack of fuel, for example, UNICEF deliveries of clean water to IDPs were limited to 21m3 of water for 4,500 persons in two camps. Under normal circumstances, deliveries of clean water consist of 100m3 for over 8, 500 IDPs. UNICEF has also been forced to halt field visits planned for the delivery of materials and the monitoring of work being carried out on the rehabilitation of gravity flow water systems.

FAO reports that if seeds and other agricultural inputs required for the upcoming planting season are not allowed into the country, there will be an over 40 percent decrease in the production of basic, non-export food crops.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)
