Africa News


September 23, 1996


United States and Africa;
White House Sends Congress Report On Angola


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Washington DC - Following is a report to Congress on Angola sent by President Clinton to the U.S. Congress, pursuant to U.S. law, on September 19.

TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES:

I hereby report to the Congress on the developments since March 25, 1996, concerning the national emergency with respect to Angola that was declared in Executive Order 12865 of September 26, 1993.

This report is submitted pursuant to section 401(c) of the National Emergencies Act, 50 U.S.C. 1641(c), and section 204(c) of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, 50 U.S.C. 1703(c).

On September 26, 1993, I declared a national emergency with respect to Angola, invoking the authority, inter alia, of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.) and the United Nations Participation Act of 1945 (22 U.S.C. 287c). 

Consistent with United Nations Security Council Resolution 864, dated September 15, 1993, the order prohibited the sale or supply by United States persons or from the United States, or using U.S.-registered vessels or aircraft, of arms and related materiel of all types, including weapons and ammunition, military vehicles, equipment and spare parts, and petroleum and petroleum products to the territory of Angola other than through designated points of entry. The order also prohibited such sale or supply to the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola ("UNITA").

United States persons are prohibited from activities that promote or are calculated to promote such sales or supplies, or from attempted violations, or from evasion or avoidance or transactions that have the purpose of evasion or avoidance, of the stated prohibitions. The order authorized the Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of State, to take such actions, including the promulgation of rules and regulations, as might be necessary to carry out the purposes of the order.

1. On December 10, 1993, the Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) issued the UNITA (Angola) Sanctions Regulations (the " Regulations") (58 Fed. Reg. 64904) to implement the President's declaration of a national emergency and imposition of sanctions against Angola (UNITA). There have been no amendments to the regulations since my report of March 25, 1996.

The regulations prohibit the sale or supply by United States persons or from the United States, or using U.S.-registered vessels or aircraft, of arms and related materiel of all types, including weapons and ammunition, military vehicles, equipment and spare parts, and petroleum and petroleum products to UNITA or to the territory of Angola other than through designated points. United States persons are also prohibited from activities that promote or are calculated to promote such sales or supplies to UNITA or Angola, or from any transaction by any United States persons that evades or avoids, or has the purpose of evading or avoiding, or attempts to violate, any of the prohibitions set forth in the Executive order.

Also prohibited are transactions by United States persons, or involving the use of U.S.-registered vessels or aircraft, relating to transportation to Angola or UNITA of goods the exportation of which is prohibited. The government of Angola has designated the following points of entry as points in Angola to which the articles otherwise prohibited by the Regulations may be shipped: Airports: Luanda and Katumbela, Benguela Province; Ports: Luanda and Lobito, Benguela Province; and Namibe, Namibe Province; and Entry Points: Malongo, Cabinda Province.

Although no specific license is required by the Department of the Treasury for shipments to these designated points of entry (unless the item is destined for UNITA), any such exports remain subject to the licensing requirements of the Departments of State and/or Commerce.

2. The OFAC has worked closely with the U.S. financial community to assure a heightened awareness of the sanctions against UNITA -- through the dissemination of publications, seminars, and notices to electronic bulletin boards. This educational effort has resulted in frequent calls from banks to assure that they are not routing funds in violation of these prohibitions. United States exporters have also been notified of the sanctions through a variety of media, including special fliers and computer bulletin board information initiated by OFAC and posted through the U.S. Department of Commerce and the U.S. Government Printing Office. There have been no license applications under the program.

3. The expenses incurred by the Federal Government in the 6-month period from March 26, 1996, through September 25, 1996, that are directly attributable to the exercise of powers and authorities conferred by the declaration of a national emergency with respect to Angola (UNITA) are reported to be about $227,000, most of which represents wage and salary costs for Federal personnel. Personnel costs were largely centered in the Department of the Treasury (particularly in the Office of Foreign Assets Control, the U.S. Customs Service, the Office of the Under Secretary for Enforcement, and the Office of the General Counsel) and the Department of State (particularly the Office of Southern African Affairs).

I will continue to report periodically to the Congress on significant developments, pursuant to 50 U.S.C. 1703(c).


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


376 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Nigeria;
Muslim Group Calls for Release of Nigerian Leader


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

London - Following is a statement issued by the Human Rights Committee of the Muslim Parliament regarding the detained Nigerian Muslim leader Ibrahim Al-Zakzaky.

On Thursday 12th September 1996, Mu'allim Ibrahim Al-Zakzaky, the 43 year old Muslim leader of the Islamic movement in Nigeria, was arrested and taken from his home in Zaria City. Twenty three other people, including women were also arrested. All but four were released, and the others charged with miscellaneous, fabricated charges. 

The following day, saw a peaceful demonstration in Zaria City against the arrests. Police opened fire on the protesters, many of whom were women and children. 14 died, including Abu Bakr Rabi'u Galadimana a boy of only three years of age. On Wednesday 19th September, 3 people who were among thousands commemorating the deaths of the previous week, were shot dead by police in Kaduna City.

Mu'allim Ibrahim Al-Zakzaky has never called for violence, despite the violence he and his followers have suffered. His movement has always been peaceful in nature. His deputy Hamid Danlani, is the publisher of the Muslim journal Al-Mizan. After his arrest a printing machine, other printing materials and money were all confiscated from his home. Both he and Mu'allim Ibrahim have been charged with publishing without a licence. Given Nigeria's recent record on freedom of expression, there are grave concerns about the safety of Mu'allim Ibrahim and the others being held with him.

We call on the Nigerian junta to free Mu'allim Ibrahim and his colleagues. Please write to the politicians, governments, organisations expressing your concern. Please forward this message to all muslims you know.

For more information, please contact the Human Rights Committee of the Muslim Parliament, 109 Fulham Palace Road, London, W6 8JA. Telephone +44 (0) 181 563 1995, fax +44 (0)181 563 1993, mobile 0860 259 289. E-mail: Demir@ethic.com


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
UN Panel Recommends African Development Priorities


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

United Nations - The Panel of High-Level Personalities on African Development, meeting at United Nations Headquarters on 12 September, has recommended that debt, governance and human resource development should be priority areas for consideration at the current Mid-term Review of the United Nations New Agenda for the Development of Africa in the 1990s. The Panel also highlighted the importance of trade facilitation and resource mobilization, food security and agriculture, as well as greater flexibility and coordination of development support.

The High-Level Panel was established in 1992 by Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to advise and assist him in ensuring the effective implementation of the New Agenda and to foster Africa's development in general. The 12 September meeting was convened and chaired by the Secretary- General. 

Opening the meeting, Mr. Boutros-Ghali restated the United Nations commitment to African development and urged the Panel to consider its advocacy role with regard to enhancing Africa's image in the donor community and ensuring continued support. He asked the Panel to discuss the best ways of mobilizing African leaders to address critical development issues as well as how the resources of non-governmental organizations and the private sector in developed countries could best be harnessed in support of African development.

While stressing the need to reverse the generally negative perception of Africa, the Panel felt that publicizing African success stories might not be enough. Panel members therefore identified several priority areas for consideration by the Mid-term Review.

On debt, the Panel looked forward to a satisfactory outcome of current discussions on debt relief and, most importantly, to quick implementation. It urged that eligibility and other criteria for debt relief should be flexible enough to ensure that significant relief is provided to as many countries as possible.

On governance, Panel members noted the great efforts under way in many countries in the areas of democratization and human rights. However, they urged substantial support to strengthen capacities in the public and private sectors as well as in civil society, for efficient management of development.

Identifying human resource development as essential for Africa's economic recovery, the Panel said such efforts should not be subject to selectivity or conditionality. They should also receive proper attention during implementation of structural adjustment programmes. Without a healthy and well-trained population, Africa would not be able to benefit from globalization. Calling for more attention to be paid to the social sector, Panel members urged African countries to match public spending to their proclaimed commitment to human development, while donor countries were urged to increase their support in that critical area.

Trade was another essential factor in Africa's economic growth development, the Panel stated. To better integrate African countries into the global economy, the international community should support trade facilitation schemes which involved commodity diversification programmes. It should also support efforts to develop supply capability and market access. The Panel urged African countries to mobilize domestic resources and enhance savings for investment and faster economic growth. It also emphasized the importance of an enabling environment for attracting foreign direct investment, which had so far eluded African countries.

In several cases, rigidities in the support provided for African development had contributed to a reversal of progress, the Panel noted. It stressed the need for flexibility in applying pre-established performance benchmarks and welcomed the trend towards improved coordination between the United Nations and the Bretton Woods institutions. That should lead to more effective sectoral programmes which could receive financial support.

The Panel welcomed the United Nations System-wide Special Initiative on Africa and said the Mid-term Review should provide the opportunity to better articulate and also strengthen the links between the New Agenda and the Special Initiative, which was designed to strengthen United Nations support for African development. Through a focused effort, the Initiative could encourage the spread of "best practices" and also improve the efficiency of development implementation.

Emphasizing the importance of food security and agriculture, the Panel fully supported the objectives of the New Agenda and the Special Initiative in that area. The Panel decided to devote its next meeting to food security and agriculture, and also to revisit the issue of governance.

The Panel's current membership includes the following high-level personalities: Sir Ketumile Masire, President of Botswana; Poul Nielson, Denmark's Minister for Development Cooperation; Baroness Lynda Chalker, Minister for Overseas Development of the United Kingdom; Ambassador Andrew Young, former United States Permanent Representative to the United Nations; Philippe Jurgensen, former Director-General of the Caisse francaise de developpement and current Director-General of the Societe francaise de garantie des financements des petites et moyennes entreprises; Mohammed Sadli, Adviser to the President of Indonesia for South-South and North-South Cooperation; R. Barthelt, Director-General for Sub-Saharan Africa in Germany's Ministry for Foreign Affairs; Salim Ahmed Salim, Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity (OAU); Graca Machel, Mozambique's former First Lady and current President of the Foundation for Community Development; Ambassador Yasushi Kurokochi of Japan, who served as Chairman of the Tokyo International Conference on Aid and Development; K.Y. Amoako, Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA); Rubens Ricupero, Secretary-General of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD); and Hazem El-Beblawi, Executive Secretary of the Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia (ESCWA).

Note: Further information may be obtained from the Office of the Special Coordinator for Africa and the Least Developed Countries in the Department for Policy Coordination and Sustainable Development, tel: 963-5006 or 963- 4780.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 23, 1996


Egypt;
U.S. & Egyptian Groups Condemn Egyptian Court Marriage Ruling


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2360 words


 

Washington - An unprecedented coalition of U.S. and international organizations today condemned the recent court-ordered divorce of Cairo University Professor Nasr Hamed Abu Zeid from his wife, Professor Ibtihal Yunis.

The organizations--which include the National Association of Arab Americans, the Arab-American University Graduates, the Muslim Public Affairs Council, the Arab American Institute and the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee--declared that the decision by Egypt's highest court "is in flagrant violation of one of the most cherished of human rights -- the right of a legally married couple to remain married so long as both parties so desire -- as well as the basic right of free expression, including academic freedom."

The coalition calls on President Husni Mubarak to speak out publicly for the rights of Dr. Abu Zeid and Dr.Yunis, and to support the application by Dr. Abu Zeid's lawyers to the Court of Cassation to nullify the ruling which is due to be heard on September 25. The organizations also urge the government of Egypt to initiate legislation that would protect the basic rights of Egyptians from gross violations by courts in cases such as this one. "By upholding the right of a civil court to declare an Egyptian citizen an apostate," the coalition asserts, "the ruling has a severe chilling effect on freedom of expression and emboldens forces of intolerance." 

The text of the statement and the list of signatory organizations is attached.

COALITION OF HUMAN RIGHTS, ARAB-AMERICAN, WOMEN'S RIGHTS, AND ACADEMIC ORGANIZATIONS CONDEMNS EGYPTIAN COURT DECISION DISSOLVING A PROFESSOR'S MARRIAGE BECAUSE OF HIS WRITINGS ON ISLAM

The undersigned organizations wish to condemn, in the strongest terms, the recent ruling by the Court of Cassation, Egypt's highest court, to uphold a lower civil court decision declaring Cairo University Professor Nasr Hamed Abu Zeid an apostate and ordering that he and his wife, Professor Ibtihal Yunis, be legally compelled to separate against their will. This decision is in flagrant violation of one of the most cherished of human rights -- the right of a legally married couple to remain married so long as both parties so desire -- as well as the basic right of free expression, including academic freedom.

The undersigned organizations--comprising human rights, Arab-American, women's rights, academic and other organizations--call on President Husni Mubarak to speak out publicly for the basic rights of Dr. Abu Zeid and Dr. Yunis that have been compromised, and to initiate legislation that would protect these rights from gross violations by courts in the future. By tolerating this silencing and the forcible breakup of a family on the purported basis of Islamic law, the government of Egypt undermines its quest for international as well as local support in its struggle against forces of politico-religious extremism.

On August 5, the Court of Cassation upheld the legality of a Cairo Appeals Court ruling in favor of an Islamist lawyer who had demanded that Abu Zeid's marriage with Dr. Yunis be nullified. The Appeals Court supported the plaintiff's contention that Professor Abu Zeid was an apostate and therefore ineligible, under religious law (shari'a), to be married to a Muslim woman.

The basis for the legal action against Abu Zeid are his scholarly writings and teaching. A professor in the Arabic department of the University of Cairo specializing in Quranic studies, he applied modern tools of linguistics and discourse analysis to the Quran and other early Islamic texts, and particularly to the subsequent interpretations (ijtihad) of these texts in commentaries by Islamic scholars in different periods. In ruling against Dr. Abu Zeid, the Appeals Court, a civil court, concluded that he had "refused to acquiesce to God's legislation, claiming that it is related to a specific historical period, and asking that the mind begin to exchange them with contemporary meanings that are more humane and progressive, better than the literal meanings."

In May 1995, in promoting Dr. Abu Zeid to full professor, the Cairo University Council observed that "If there is something urgent about his style, it stems from the urgency of the crisis which the contemporary Arab- Islamic World is witnessing... Academic research should not be isolated from social problems but should be allowed to participate in current debates and to suggest solutions to current problems by allowing researchers to investigate and interpret as far as possible."

In the first ruling on the case, in January 1994, the Giza Personal Status Court dismissed the suit, declaring that the plaintiff did not have standing. The Cairo Appeals Court reversed this ruling in June 1995, declared Abu Zeid an apostate, and ruled that the couple must separate. It is this ruling that the Court of Cassation has now upheld.

The Egyptian Organization for Human Rights, recalling the 1992 assassination of the secularist intellectual Farag Foda, condemned the Court of Cassation ruling as "a death sentence against Dr. Abu Zeid and his wife." Following the 1995 Appeals Court ruling, the militant Jihad Organization in fact called for the killing of Abu Zeid as an apostate. At that time Abu Zeid accepted an invitation to continue his work in the Netherlands, where he and his wife presently reside.

The Court of Cassation decision also grossly violates the rights of Dr. Yunis, a professor of French literature at Cairo University. With the court- ordered separation, she stands to lose her right to inherit from her husband and to gain custody of any children if they were to have any. She could also face dismissal from her university job: since she is no longer legally married, the reason for her professional leave -- to accompany her husband while abroad -- is removed. The decision also implicitly calls their union adulterous. And it highlights the effectively discriminatory nature of Egypt's code of personal status. If the spouse who was declared apostate were the wife, divorce would not have the same practical consequence of severely compromising the husband's civil and professional standing.

This is the first case in which Egypt's judiciary has ordered the divorce of a couple, on the basis of one's thoughts or writings, where both spouses wish to remain united. This ruling violates several international treaties that Egypt has ratified. These include the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which states in Article 18, "...everyone shall have the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion...no one shall be subject to coercion which should impair his freedom to have or to adopt a religion or belief of his choice." It also violates Article 23, which states, "The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State," and, "The right of men and women of marriageable age to marry and to found a family shall be recognized."

By disregarding Dr. Yunis's desire to uphold her marriage contract and her confidence in the compatibility of her religious beliefs with those of her husband, the court's ruling places Egypt in violation of its obligations as a State Party to the Convention for the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. That Convention requires that women be accorded full equality in rights. Article 15.1 requires parties to accord to women equality with men before the law and Article 15.2 provides: "States Parties shall accord to women, in civil matters, a legal capacity identical to that of men and the same opportunities to exercise that capacity. In particular, they shall give women equal rights to conclude contracts..."

The independent, Cairo-based Center for Human Rights Legal Aid points out that the Court of Cassation has previously declared that principles of international law are considered an integral part of national legislation, and that an Egyptian judge is bound to these principles wherever national legislation does not address the issue in question. Since apostasy is not addressed in national legislation, the principles of international law should have been applied.

In ruling against Abu Zeid, Egypt's highest court affirmed the controversial hisba doctrine, which grants third parties standing in court to initiate cases against defendants whom they accuse of having violated religious law. However, on May 22, 1996 the Egyptian National Assembly, with the support of the Mubarak government, passed a law denying such third parties standing before the court as a matter of public policy. The law explicitly applies to all court cases pending anywhere in Egypt at the time of its adoption. The Court of Cassation nonetheless refused to consider and apply this law to the Abu Zeid case.

The groups signing this statement fear that this decision, if allowed to stand, sets an ominous precedent. By upholding the right of a civil court to declare an Egyptian citizen an apostate, the ruling imperils Egypt's dynamic civil society. Specifically, the ruling has a severe chilling effect on freedom of expression and the lively exchange of ideas, and emboldens forces of intolerance which have no respect for internationally recognized human rights.

While wishing to respect the constitutional separation of the executive and judicial branches of the Egyptian government, the undersigned organizations urge President Mubarak to:

Examine all legal options to prevent the implementation of the court's decision in the Abu Zeid case, including: (a) support for an application made to the competent court for a stay of execution of the court decision dissolving the Abu Zeid marriage; and (b) support for the application made to the Court of Cassation for an extraordinary judgment to nullify the ruling against Abu Zeid on the basis of gross error and bad faith in the application of the law. (Such a case, known as a mokhasama, is heard before seven of the Court of Cassation judges. If they accept the claim on the technical side, it then goes to a court consisting of all members of the Cassation Court. If they accept it, then the case is sent back for a retrial before another circuit of the Court of Cassation.)

Draft new legislation to strengthen guarantees of freedom of expression and academic research, in accordance with Article 49 of the Egyptian Constitution and with Egypt's obligations to respect international human rights covenants, as well as legislation to bring Egypt into full compliance with regard to rights guaranteed by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

Express public support for the right of Professor Abu Zeid to exercise his right to expression free from all forms of harassment, as well as for the right of he and Dr. Yunis to remain married. If need be, provide the couple with adequate security should they request it if and when they return to Egypt.

American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee; American Friends Service Committee; Arab American Institute; Arab American University Graduates; Article 19: International Center Against Censorship; Center for Economic and Social Rights; Center for Women's Global Leadership; Committee on Academic Freedom in the Middle East and North Africa of the Middle East; Studies Association.; Equality Now; Francois-Xavier Bagnoud Center for Health and Human Rights, Harvard School of Public Health; Human Rights Watch; International Women's Human Rights Law Clinic, City University of New; York; International Women Judges Foundation; Khalil Jahshan, Chairperson, Council of Presidents of National; Arab-American Organizations; Jews for Racial and Economic Justice; Lawyers Committee for Human Rights; Muslim Public Affairs Council; National Association for Arab Americans; RAINB: Research, Action & Information Network for the Bodily Integrity of Women; Sisterhood is Global; Women in International Law Interest Group (WILIG); Women Living Under Muslim Laws.

For further information, contact Joe Stork, Human Rights Watch, 1522 K Street, NW Suite 910, Washington, DC 20005, Tel: 202-371-6592, Fax: 202-371- 0124. E-mail: hrwdc@hrw.org.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa Will Not Seek IMF, World Bank Aid


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa has no immediate intention of seeking financial assistance from either the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund, the country's finance minister, Trevor Manuel, has said.

He said that South Africa's success in the international bond market, despite the sharp fall in the rand showed that the country was capable of standing on its own two feet in economic terms. 

"It's not as though we are knocking on the door of the Fund or the Bank with a begging bowl," he told a media conference here Monday ahead of the IMF and World Bank annual meetings which are scheduled to begin in Washington D.C. later this week.

Manuel said South Africa would be attending the constituency meetings of the IMF and the World Bank as part of the Africa Group, and would not be making an independent statement.

The Group, he added, would be presenting joint statements on such issues as relief proposals for heavily indebted countries, and ways of increasing private capital outflow to developing countries.

"South Africa, as part of the African constituency, will participate fully in this process," said Manuel, "and supports a coordinated regional approach."

The country, he added, "believes that more developing countries should be granted debt relief, and that investment initiatives should be mainly targeted at these countries."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


380 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Business;
Zimbabwe Tobacco Season Ends


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - There are signs that sales of Zimbabwe's premier flue- cured tobacco crop are tailing off with little tobacco being delivered to the auction floors as farmers start preparing for the new season.

Zimbabwe Tobacco Association (ZTA) President Robert Webb said up to Monday a total of 192 million kg had been sold, a marginal increase from the 180.5 million kg (2.205 kg = 1 pound) sold up two weeks ago. 

"There are signs that volumes are beginning to tail off and we are now putting our seasonal sales at just on the 200 million kg mark, down from the initial estimate of between 202 and 203 million," Webb said.

Describing the market as bullish, Webb said last week's average price was 29.80 zimdollars (2.98 US dollars) per kg, a shed up from 29.70 zimdollars (2. 97 dollars) attained two weeks ago.

"Prices for quality tobacco in particular still remains strong," he said.

Prices have firmed over the past six months as a result of reports of damage to the crop in the United States and China, the other major tobacco producers in the world.

Both countries have had exceptionally wet years, with the U.S. experiencing freak storms and China suffering from typhoon, exerting pressure on the world stock. Last deliveries are expected Sept. 27, raising fears that the season might end prematurely.

Flue-cured tobacco is this year expected to earn the country 7 billion zimdollars (700 million dollars), making it the single largest foreign currency earner.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Business;
Germans Keen To Invest In Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

HAMBURG, German - Politicians and businessmen from the German port city of Hamburg on Tuesday said businessmen should develop a positive outlook of Africa, saying the continent was no longer the stereotyped land of famine, wars and disasters.

In speeches to mark the opening of the Zimbabwe-Hamburg trade and investment conference, the Germans said there were indications the continent was on the path to economic and political stability and deserved attention from German investors. 

"The world is full of African pessimism, but we know of another Africa of progress," said Nikolaus Schues, president of the Hamburg chamber of commerce.

He said African economies were in many respects better than what was portrayed in the international press.

He cited the World Bank projected average economic growth rate of 4 percent in Africa and of Zimbabwe's recovery from a decline in GDP of 3 percent in 1995 to 7 percent in 1996 as signs of African progress.

The mayor of Hamburg, Henning Voscheran, noted that life expectancy on the continent had improved by 28 percent and that democratic elections were now a common feature. He noted that these were signs of change in Africa.

"Zimbabwe has been an example of the new Africa," he said, adding: " Zimbabwe's future as an emerging economy is very encouraging."

The port city of 11.7 million people currently processed one-quarter of all German trade with Africa and is home to several organizations linked to Africa.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


382 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Funeral Service For Nigerian Players


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - A funeral service was held here Tuesday for 11 Nigerian female police soccer players and three officials, who died in a motor accident Sept. 12 on their way back to Lagos after a league match in Port Harcout, southeastern Nigeria.

The auto crash happened along Benin-Shagamu road, near Lagos. 

In a message to the service held at the police college, Lagos, the inspector-general of the Nigerian police, Ibrahim Coomassie, paid tribute to the "Police Machine Female FC," and pledged that the force would build a new team to continue the job started by the dead players.

Continuing the work began by the team, he said, was the greatest respect and honor which the Nigeria police and the nation could accord them.

Nigeria's youth and sports minister, Jim Nwobodo, reminded mourners that it was not the first time such a tragedy befell a soccer team.

He recalled the Zambian world cup team which perished in 1993 in a plane crash. But the incident did not stop the nation from raising another team which, he said, nearly defeated Nigeria in the final of the 1994 Africa nations cup in Tunisia. Nigeria won that match 2-1.

The bodies of the late players and officials were later taken to their respective home states for burial.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 24, 1996


South Africa;
At Least 18 Die In South African Ethnic Clashes


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - At least 18 people have been killed and 26 injured in ethnic clashes in the Stilfontein area of South Africa's North- West province.

First reports said that at least 10 people died in an attack Sunday in which no fewer than eight explosions ripped through dwellings at a mine contract workers' settlement in the area, and victims fleeing the chaos were caught and either shot or stabbed to death. 

Another 18 people were wounded in the attack, which is understood to have been a direct result of tensions between the Xhosa and Sotho ethnic groups.

Police found and defused four more devices made from commercial explosives of the type used on the mines in the area. Senior police officials voiced fear of further violence in the area in the form of reprisal attacks.

Early Monday police fears became reality when further violence erupted in the Stilfontein area, resulting in eight more people being killed and another eight injured -- some seriously.

Latest reports indicated that, with police maintaining a strong presence with regular patrols moving through the area, there is an uneasy calm. The mine shafts at the nearby Hartebeesfontein and Buffelsfontein gold mines are operating normally and all is quiet at the mine hostels.

A special investigating team has been appointed to consider a range of charges from murder and attempted murder to public violence.

At least 2,000 contract miners and their families are believed to live in the mine settlement complex in the Stilfontein area.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


384 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
France Ratifies Africa Nuclear Free Zone Treaty


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - France has become the first non-African country to ratify the Pelindaba Treaty making Africa a nuclear weapons free zone, the Organization of African Unity (OAU) has said.

Ratifying three protocols, which are annexed to the African Nuclear Weapons Free Zone Treaty, "France has undertaken not to use or threaten to use a nuclear explosive device against any party to the treaty or in any part of the nuclear-weapon free zone," the organization, Africa's foremost political body, said Monday.

France has also agreed "not to test or encourage the research, testing of any nuclear explosive device or the stationing of such devices anywhere within the African Nuclear-Weapon Free Zone." 

The French Ambassador to Ethiopia, Louis Amigues, deposited the instruments of ratification at a ceremony Friday at the headquarters of the continental organization in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa.

France, he said, attached great importance to the objectives of the treaty. "That is why France ratified the treaty so quickly."

However, France remains the only non-African nation to have carried out nuclear weapons tests on the continent. It did so between 1960 and 1966 from its Reggane base in the Sahara desert.

During this period, it carried out four aerial tests and 13 underground explosions at In Ecker. It tested its first atomic bomb February 13, 1960, in Africa.

Until 1996, France was at the center of controversy over its test in the Pacific.

But OAU Assistant Secretary-General Ahmed Haggag said that the Pelindaba treaty was a demonstration of Africa's determination to make the continent free of nuclear weapons.

South Africa, the only African country to have tested nuclear weapons -- during the apartheid era -- has stopped all such activity.

The Pelindaba treaty is for signature and ratification by 53 OAU member states, of which 48 have signed so far. Mauritius, Haggag said, was the only member state that had ratified the treaty.

The treaty's text and the protocols annexed to it were drawn up under the auspices of the OAU in Pelindaba, South Africa, in December 1994. The treaty itself was signed April 11, 1996 in Cairo, Egypt.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


385 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Mozambique;
BP To Prospect For Oil in Mozambique


BYLINE: Paul Fauvet, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The Mozambican government on Monday signed an agreement with British Petroleum (BP), for oil exploration covering an offshore area of about 80,000 square kilometers (30,888 square miles) in the delta of the Zambezi river.

The agreement was signed by the Minister of Mineral Resources and Energy, John Kachamila, the General Manager of the National Hydrocarbons Company (ENH) , Issufo Abdullah, and the BP General Manager for West Africa, David Bamford.

The agreement covers six months of initial surveys. 

A previous prospection in the Zambezi Delta, undertaken by the Norwegian company, GECO, in the 1980s, did not yield good results. However, GECO focused effort on the shallow water zones, while BP is concentrating on areas where the water is up to 2,000 meters deep.

If, as Bamford expects, the initial results are positive, further, and more extensive surveys, relying largely on seismic methods, will be carried out over the next two years.

"If results continue to be positive, we would then shoot 3D seismic data, and maybe sink some wells", he added. According to Kachamila there is now " great interest" internationally in Mozambique's oil and natural gas potential.

In addition to BP, two other foreign companies are negotiating oil prospection contracts.

Abdullah told the Mozambican News Agency (AIM) that a U.S.-based company, ARCO, was interested in natural gas known to exist at Temane, in the southern province of Inhambane, and in prospecting for oil off the coast of the central province of Sofala.

He said a Canadian firm, CANOP, is negotiating onshore oil prospection rights in the Limpopo Basin in the south of the country, where the results of aerial geophysical surveys are said to be highly encouraging.

The negotiations follow deals signed earlier in 1996 with U.K.-based multinational, Lonrho, for oil prospection in the Rovuma Basin in the far north, and with concerns from Canada and the United Arab Emirates for exploiting the gas reserves at Buzi in Sofala.

In November 1995, giant U.S.-based corporation, ENRON, signed an agreement for the exploitation of the largest known natural gas reserves in Mozambique, located at Pande in Inhambane.

According to Kachamila, one South African company is interested in purchasing the gas to feed an iron ore bonification plant. Final results of ongoing feasibility studies on the reserves are expected in December.

Currently, a small amount of the Pande gas is being exploited for electricity generation in the nearby town of Vilanculo. But major exploitation can only start once a gas pipeline to South Africa is built, and that in turn depends on a firm contract with the South African end-user of the gas.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 24, 1996


Zambia and Zaire;
Zambia Accepts Zairean Illegal Immigrants


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Katete - Thirty-seven (37) Zairean illegal immigrants who were stranded in Mozambique a week ago after they resisted to be deported have at last been accepted by Zambia which will now facilitate their eventual repatriation back home.

The Zairean nationals, who included men and women, were stranded at Nsadzu in Mozambique, 57 kilometres South of the Zambian administrative town of Katete.

Immigration spokesperson, Catherine Poso, confirmed the latest development in Lusaka today and added that all 37 persons were handed over to the Zambian government. 

Ms Poso said after the hand over the illegal immigrants were detained at Katete Prison while awaiting the Ministry of Home Affairs to mobilise vehicles which will take them finally to Zaire.

Earlier Zambian Police and Immigration officials had refused to accept the illegal immigrants because it was not quite clear how they entered Mozambique arguing that they did not cross Zambia before entering that country.

Police and Immigration were also initially divided on how to treat the illegal immigrants with some officers arguing that once deported from Mozambique the people could not be regarded as prohibited immigrants in Zambia where they had committed no offence.

But another argument was that though they had been declared illegal immigrants by Mozambique the men and women had failed to produce documents which allowed them to stay legally in Zambia meaning that even in this country too they were not welcome and could not claim to be legitimate visitors.

In view of this it was found necessary to keep them in detention until transport was found to ferry them to Kasumbalesa on the Copperbelt from where they could be handed over Zairean uathorities.

The detainees were arrested in Mozambique's Tete province on September 4 this year for entering the country illegally.

They were brought to Nsadzu on September 19 after the Zambian government finally agreed to take them in for their subsquent repatriation to Zaire through Kasumbalesa in Chililabombwe because they did not pass through its territoy when going to Mozambique.

Some of the detainees claimed that they had refused leave Mozambique for Zaire until security officers fired in the air several times to force them out of Nsadzu when they tried to challenge their deportation to Zaire.

Ms Poso would not say when the final movement might take place for the Zaireans. Source: ZAMTODAY

September 24, 1996


Burundi;
Unicef Supports The Re-Opening Of Schools In Burundi


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Bujumbura - For the re-opening of primary schools on Monday 23 September 1996, UNICEF, in collaboration with the Government of Burundi and the National Radio and Television Service has launched a campaign to raise primary school enrollment rates which have fallen 15% over the last 3 years to only 35% .

Since the beginning of the crisis in October 1993, UNICEF has strongly supported the Government of Burundi's efforts to ensure maximum school enrollment of the country's children. UNICEF played a key role in the re- opening of schools closed following the events of October 1993 and since that time has provided financial and technical support to the Ministry of Education to improve infrastructures, equipment and personnel in the education sector. 

Specifically, UNICEF provided financial support for:

* the production of school textbooks to replaced those destroyed over the past 3 years

* training for over 3,000 underqualified teachers to replace those who left the country, were internally displaced or killed * logistical support to the Ministry through the provision of 3 vehicles, 20 motorbikes, 336 bicycles, 400 radios and 476 library kits

* improving radio distance education programmes

* strengthening administration of the sector

* updating curricula o improving in-class teaching methods

For this year's re-opening of schools, UNICEF has provided large quantities of school materials which will be distributed by the Ministry of Education and by NGOs. To address the needs of the most vulnerable victims of the crisis, UNICEF has provided school materials and health insurance cards to non-accompanied children who wish to attend school. In upholding Article 29 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child , UNICEF, the Government of Burundi and several local and international NGOs have developed the "Let's Build Peace" project which in 1994 and 1995 has reached over 200,000 children in grades 4 and 5, and more than 3,000 teachers, school directors and inspectors. A teachers' manual is currently being prepared to extend peace education to include grades 2 and 3 this year. To provide internally displaced and dispered children access to schools in regions where few exist, UNICEF has undertaken the construction of temporary classrooms. To date, twelve such classrooms have been erected to serve over 1,200 displaced children in Gatumba outside of Bujumbura. Additional temporary classrooms are planned for other sites in and around Bujumbura and for displaced children in Muyinga Province. To meet the psycho-social needs of children traumatized by the crisis, UNICEF has prepared a games and activity book to address the special needs of these children.

UNICEF thanks all donors whose assistance has made possible these efforts to support education in Burundi, including the European Union through ECHO, the Governments of Italy, Norway, Sweden, Canada, the United States, as well as UNICEF National Committees in Belgium, the UK and Australia.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

388 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Business;
Zambian Farmers Union Unhappy With Food Reserve Agency


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia National Union of Farmers is disappointed with the role of the National Food Reserve Agency in the purchase of maize from farmers.

According to ZNFU Executive Director George Gray in an interview yesterday, the agency has not purchased any maize from the farmers since it was set up in April this year. 

"To the best of my knowledge the agency received money this year for the purchase of grain bags but there has been no maize purchased from farmers. We would have expected the agency to participate in the maize market in May, June and July. It would have steadied the market and helped support the maize price," he said.

Gray explained that non-participation of the Food Reserve Agency was especially bad for the small scale farmer who had needed to sell his maize before the end of the marketing season.

"The small scale farmer needs to sell by October in order to get money for inputs for the following season," he said.

He commended the private traders who had gone in to buying maize from farmers as they were able to pay cash to the farmer.

The National Food Reserve Agency, co-ordinated by the Ministry of Agriculture last week announced through its Weekly Market Bulletin that it had decided to purchase maize in 50kg polypropylene bags only, and will not accept the traditional 90kg jute bags used by most farmers.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 24, 1996


Zambia;
Women for Change Appeals To Parties


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Women for Change has appealed to political parties not to impose leaders on the people in rural areas.

Women for Change executive director Emily Sikazwe, in an interview yesterday, said people in rural areas have rejected the idea of having leaders imposed on them by any political party. 

Sikazwe, whose organisation is currently going round the country's rural areas on the the civic awareness campaigns on several contentious issues, said the the Land Act and Citizenship clauses have also been rejected at the grassroot level.

"The people in the rural areas are not happy about the idea of having the national executives of political parties impose parliamentary candidates on them and we would advise that they let the people choose their own leaders, " Sikazwe said. "They have also rejected the Land Act and the citizenship clause in the new constitution."

Sikazwe said that so far, in all the areas of Lusaka, Central and Southern provinces, where her organisation has been, people don't want leaders to be imposed them.

Women for Change is the second Non Governmental Organisation (NGO) conducting awareness campaigns in rural areas on the 1996 Constitution and several other issues on democracy and good governance after Zambia Civic Education Association.

Sikazwe said the idea of the campaigns is to create a critical mass in rural areas so that the people are able to speak out on issues affecting them as the result of government action.

September 24, 1996


Zambia;
Parliament Resumes Sitting


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Parliament resumes sitting today after it adjourned sine die last July.

But opposition Zambia Democratic Congress(ZDC) says unless all the key stake holders agreed "the entire last session would be a fruitless and costly academic exercise at the expense of the taxpayer". 

"It will be meaningless unless the MMD government addresses the question of the electoral process and transitional arrangements should they fail to hold elections by October 31," ZDC deputy general secretary Azwell Banda said in an interview yesterday.

And National Party secretary general, Akashambatwa-Mbikusita-Lewanika, said although it was too late for any legislation that can have an impact on improving the performance record of MMD, the government in the "last lap" should try and pay attention to consensus.

"The only thing one can expect is some consequential law amendment to facilitate the holding of elections," Lewanika said in an interview yesterday.

Among the issues to be tabled before the House is the controversial Electoral Amendment Act of 1996 which spells out the qualifications of a presidential candidate and the autonomy of the Electoral Commission.

But Liberal Progressive Front chairman, Roger Chongwe, appealed to members of parliament not to allow the Bill to pass because it defeats the independence of the Commission.

"It is going to allow President Chiluba to go to a chief or a priest and collect a letter saying he was born in that area and according to this Act this letter cannot be challenged in Court," Chongwe said.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


391 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Zambia;
More Join Nurses In Hospital Strike


BYLINE: Mwila Kunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lusaka - Most departments at the University Teaching Hospital (UTH) were yesterday paralysed as paramedicals, radiographers, physiologists, laboratory technologists and clinic officers joined junior nurses in their strike which has now entered the fourth day.

And UTH junior nurses, who started the strike on Friday last week, yesterday rejected the call by Civil Servants Union of Zambia (CSUZ) secretary general Japhet Moonde to resume work after the hospital's board of management resolved some of the issues which they had raised.

"We have discussed all the issues which you have raised and we have done a lot to resolve them and therefore for the time being return to your work," Moonde pleaded with uncompromising nurses as they kept on interjecting him with slogans; "No money, no work, it's poverty which has made us to go on strike", throughout his address.

Moonde told the nurses, who vowed not to end their strike until the "salary and allowance increment issue" was resolved that his union will not be held responsible if anything happened to them. 

"Let us not spoil our case, we have very good grievances but other issues like salaries and allowances can only be settled through negotiation with the government,"Moonde said. "I have made it clear, we have done a lot but we are not going to be held responsible to what will happen to you if you don't resume your work."

And the Zambia Congress of Trade Union (ZCTU) secretary general Alec Chirwa has appealed to the workers to resume work as the union and management try to resolve the problem.

In a press statement released yesterday, Chirwa said that the resumption of work at UTH would facilitate a speedy solution to the current problems.

Chirwa, however, urged management to take advantage of the good will by the workers to urgently find solutions to the workers grievances in order that normal operations could return to the hospital.

And UTH board of management acting executive director, Dr.Tuckson Lambert, in an attempt to bring sanity to his institution which has been rocked with spates of strike warned nurses to "stay away" from the hospital if they were not ready to work.

"You have heard what the union and management have agreed upon but if you are not going to work then stay at home," a visibly emotional Dr Lambert told nurses who were gathered at UTH main reception. "We don't want to see you gathering at the hospital."

After the address, nurses who were also demanding for an apology from health minister Katele Kalumba for calling them "fools" for the ongoing strike, determined but frustrated walked away from the institution.

And a UTH administrative officer who sought anonymity disclosed the solidarity strike by other junior medical personnel and a snap survey conducted by The Post around 14 00 hours showed that the main pharmacy, radiography and physiotherapy departments were closed.

"You can check for yourself, most of the departments have been temporarily closed because of lack of manpower," the source said.

UTH public relations officer, Don Mwape, who was a "highly wanted man" by the nurses for issuing a statement on Sunday that the strike had been called- off, also confirmed the operational difficulties at the country's biggest hospital.

"We have a few senior medical personnel who are manning the departments but generally the situation is bad," Mwape said in an interview yesterday.

Zambia National Union of Health and Allied Workers (ZNHAW) secretary general, Soda Kabwabwa, whose members include most junior medical personnel said it was unfair for employees to continue their strike when, "dialogue between management and the union was progressively going on".

UTH board of management, the ministry of health represented by health director Dr Ben Chirwa, CSUZ and ZNHAW, who were closed in a crisis meeting for almost four hours, agreed on the issues of zonal monthly bonus, high cost scheme, allocate a doctor to a staff clinic, to stop the transport fee, renovate the nurses' hostels, pay the employees travelling and subsistence allowance on commencement of leave and provide new uniforms by the end of October.

The two parties also undertook to resolve issues of salaries, housing allowance, commuted overtime allowance and commuted night allowance.

The nurses are demanding for a 100 per cent salary increase.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 24, 1996


Zambia;
Electoral Commission Needs Proper Funding


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - The proposed independent Electoral Commission should be adequately funded and no individual should have overriding powers on its operations, a group of prominent Zambians have said.

Speaking during last night's television programme Topic, MMD member and prominent lawyer Mundia Sikatana said that the electoral commission should be free of interference from the executive and that it should only be answerable to the judiciary. 

Sikatana cautioned that unless the Electoral commission Bill is seriously debated and given more muscle in parliament before it becomes an Act, it will fail to live to people's expectations.

And Zambia Independent Monitoring Team president Alfred Zulu said during the same programme that at the moment the President had overriding powers over the commission, an anomaly he said should be stopped.

Zulu said that the commission should determine its operations and must not be influenced by either the executive or the opposition.

Former Law Association of Zambia chairman Sakwiba Sikota deplored the current electoral commission for lacking powers to prevent an election from taking place where irregularities have been observed.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


393 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Zambia;
With Current Government Dialogue Won't Work


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Lusaka - Dialogue on the current political situation will not work as long as the MMD government remained in office, advised Zambia Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) vice-president, Austin Liato on Saturday.

Liato told delegates to a one day National Civic Orga-nisations Convention at Lusaka's Mulungushi Conference Centre on Saturday that no matter how much the political front, especially the constitutional impasse may be debated, it will still not achieve anything.

"All issues on the constitutional impasse have fallen on deaf ears of the MMD government, and no matter how much it may be debated it will still achieve nothing because the government is not interested anymore," Liato said. 

And MMD national secretary, minister without portfolio Michael Sata, speaking on ZNB's Open Forum Sunday night that his government was interested in dialogue but only in so far as it did not touch on the Constitution.

Sata said the Constitution was now the law of the land and was therefore not subject to discussion any more.

But Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) secretary general, Derrick Chitala, told the same forum that even dialogue on other issues has so far been a waste of time.

Although the MMD government had agreed to have an independent Electoral Commission, Chitala said, it was not possible that this would be implemented in the short time left before the elections.

"The government thought it had fooled us but in actual fact we knew what was happening," Chitala said.

And UNIP secretary general, Sebastian Zulu, on the same programme, maintained that UNIP would not accept the election results if issues on the electoral process were not ironed out.

But Liato believes time to reason with this government is long gone and what is remaining now is a way forward - action by civic organisations and opposition parties.

" Let's try to reason with them, and if they don't want to reason with us who are the majority, then we can take action," Liato told the delegates represented by over 26 civic organisations.

Liato accused government of having its own agenda on national issues which it has reduced to party levels.

He challenged civic organisations and opposition political parties to make a stand against government on all contentious issues as government does not want to bargain anymore.

Liato pledged total support from ZCTU to whatever action civic organisation and opposition parties may take against government.

"Total lack of interest to the plight of the worker, which has put ZCTU at the most disadvantaged side has forced us to be very committed to discuss the issues of national interest, especially on the hottest issue of the voter process," Liato said.

And National Party member of parliament Inonge Mbikusita-Lewanika told the convention that no amount of dialogue will move the MMD government to conceding that there is a political crisis.

"We tried dialogue, but it has failed, all we need now is action, because everyone else has identified a problem but the MMD has refused to accept that we have a problem," she said, asking: "What then are we going to discuss?"

Sata admitted on television that his government saw no problems, constitutional or otherwise.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 24, 1996


Business;
Chinese Bank Redeems Zambian Textiles Firm


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - The Development Bank of Zambia and the Export and Import Bank of China yesterday signed an US$18 million loan agreement that will facilitate the rehabilitation of the "cash strapped" Mulungushi Textiles in Kabwe.

Signing the agreement at Lusaka's Pamodzi Hotel yesterday, DBZ managing director Gershom Mumba hailed the move by the EXIM Bank of China in the provision of resources for the rehabilitation exercise. 

"The loan has come at the right time especially for Mulungushi Textiles limited and Kabwe residents in general. As you are aware, a number of industries in Kabwe, some of which were major employers like the mines, have closed down," Mumba noted.

"This loan is going to revitalise Mulungushi Textiles Limited to such an extent that new employment levels are expected to exceed even the highest employment figures ever reached by the company," Mumba said.

And signing on behalf of the Chinese, EXIM Bank vice chairman, Wang Liansheng pledged to continue supporting the industries in the country to help boost the economy.

Wang further defined his bank's role.

"We have four main roles the first being to provide loans to importers and exporters. To offer foreign assistance and also to provide concessionary loans to industries in developing countries," Wang said

The US$18 million cash injection will improve the massive losses in the town's income generation following the closure of the mines.

The company's workforce is expected to rise over five times the current employment level of 200.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


395 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 24, 1996


Sports - General;
Racing: 120 Kilometres On Three Wheels


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - An incredible thing happened during the just-ended Siavonga Fun motor rally. One of the drivers, Sanmukh Patel, broke his right rear wheel but managed to drive the remaining 120 km on three wheels! 

And, as if that were not enough, Sanmukh finished fourth in the rally that claimed seven casualties.

"It was really amazing," remarked rally chairman, Aaron Chungu, in an interview yesterday. "He (Sanmukh) broke his right rear wheel near the Gwabi pontoon but managed to drive the remaining 120km on three wheels."

The trick, according to Chungu, was that when the right rear wheel came off the navigator, Paul Monge, stood on the driver's door to give the car equilibrium.

"When the wheel broke off, they spent a night at Gwabi. However, the following morning the navigator stood on the drivers door and they managed to finish the course," Chungu claimed.

The rally which was won by upstart Vedad Alavian took the drivers from the Lusaka Motor Sport club in the Showgrounds to Leopards, Susumani, Gwabi, Chirundu, Kariba Store, Sand Beach in Siavonga, where the drivers spent a night and back to Lusaka Motor Sports club.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

396 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


East Africa;
Situation Report for September 1996


BYLINE: UN High Commissioner for Refugees (Kigali)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

Nairobi - United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Office of the Special Envoy, Kigali - Situation Report for September 1996, issued 2 October 1996.

Main Developments

Tensions between ethnic groups spread from Uvira to other towns in eastern Zaire, prompting demonstrations and threats against Banyamulenge--persons of Rwandese origin living in the south Kivu area--and aid organizations accused of involvement in reported security incidents along Zaire's border.

In a statement released in Kinshasa on 13 September the government of Zaire stated that 'attackers had logistical support from certain United Nations agencies (and) foreign non-governmental organizations', leading the United Nations in turn to reject the allegations and urge the Government of Zaire 'to take steps to clarify the situation.' Exchange of heavy fire around Bukavu and Cyangugu between 22 and 24 September forced many humanitarian workers on the Zairian side to relocate to Nairobi and Goma, although essential activities and distributions in the camps have not been interrupted to date.

The Regional Sanctions Co-ordinating Committee met twice during the month, most recently in Kigali on the 25th, to discuss the effectiveness and implementation of measures taken against the Burundi government. Taking note of the lifting of the ban on political parties and the restoration of the National Assembly, the Committee nonetheless stressed that 'the most important condition...is the immediate and unconditional negotiations with all groups.' 

Assistant High Commissioner for Refugees Mr. Sergio Vieira de Mello toured the Great Lakes Region between 22 and 28 September meeting with government officials and aid personnel in Bujumbura, Kigali, and Tanzania. The AHC's mission comes a week before UNHCR's one-week Executive Committee session, to be held in Geneva beginning 7 October, where the situation in the Great Lakes is expected to be a main topic of discussion. Later in October the High Commissioner will report on UNHCR's activities to the Third Committee of the General Assembly.

UNHCR announced on 24 September its decision to exclude from refugee status 20 Rwandese indicted by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. Acting in accord with the UN Security Council resolution establishing the ICTR, which requires the cooperation of inter-governmental organizations and states in bringing to justice persons responsible for the genocide in Rwanda, the UNHCR believes that the indictments by the tribunal constitute sufficient grounds for exclusion within the meaning of the Statute of UNHCR, the 1951 Convention and the 1969 OAU Convention.

In a note sent to all Permanent Missions accredited to the UN, UNHCR urged 'States faced with requests for asylum from Rwandans indicted by the Tribunal to take similar measures.' Any individual indicted by the ICTR from now on will automatically be excluded from refugee status.

Zaire

The International Federation of the Red Cross suspended its operations in Goma for a week after a bus carrying volunteers to Kibumba camp struck a mine on 7 September, killing two and injuring over thirty. The incident occurred within a few kilometers of the Goma airport on the main road serving the northern camps, in a section which was being resurfaced at the time--the job of repaving the northern axis is expected to last for another 10 months. Taken after consultation with other agencies, the suspension did not affect food distribution or basic health care in the camps where the IFRC assures for these services.

500 refugees were to be moved on 1 October to the new site of Kahanda, which presently holds 6,000 persons transferred from other camps in a consolidation operation in Uvira. The effort will alleviate crowding and improve on the water and sanitation facilities ofsome of the older camps. Refugees continue to arrive from northwest Burundi at the rate of approximately 20 a day.

Tanzania

The rate of arrival of Burundese refugees in Kigoma area camps increased over September, from 1,728 during the first half of the month to 2,739 in the last two weeks. Mtendeli's population is now over 6,100 while a second site in Kasulu District, Nyarugusu, will be prepared in order to receive refugees by 1 December at the latest. The total for Kigoma camps stood at 43,241on 30 September.

Good yields from two boreholes sunk in Kitali camp should permit the transfer of 20,000 refugees from Keza to begin before the end of October. Water is also at issue for camps in the Greater Benaco area, where the debit from two streams in the Lukole Valley is being brought by pipeline to the IFRC treatment plant at K9 and may be used to supplement the supply in Benaco and Lumasi.

The Regional and District Commissioners for Kagera were to meet with the Prefect of Kibungo on 2 October in Rwanda to discuss repatriation. After a visit to Mwisa, the Principle Secretary for the Ministry of Home Affairs stated that the site designed for persons separated from other camps should be ready to open during the month of October. Burundi 456 refugees have crossed into Bubanza Province, north of Bujumbura, from Zaire over the past weeks and have been grouped at Gihanga, where IFRC and MSF began preparing a site negotiated with authorities on 27 September. Another 244 refugees are present in Burundi's Cibitoke Province and may be shifted to the camp at Gihanga. The arrivals are predominantly persons who left Rwanda during the 1960's and consider themselves Rwandese.

The reintegration of Burundese still living in the former refugee camps in northern Burundi continues, with 91 moving from Magara on 27 September to communes in Ngozi Province, leaving 383 there, 600 in Ntamba and 1,000--down from over 5,100 when the camp was opened--in Rukuramigabo.

Rwanda

392 Burundese refugees from Kibangira camp in Cyangugu Prefecture were forced by authorities to return to Mugina Commune in Cibitoke Province on 30 September. UNHCR is in contact with the GoR over the action, which came after a small group from the camp returned to Cibitoke Province on a visit organized by the Governor of that province and officials from Rwanda.

Monitoring in Butare of the almost 80,000 who returned from Burundi during July and August shows that on average approximately seven per cent of returnees' houses are occupied while the rate of land use by others is around 10 per cent. The Human Rights Field Operation for Rwanda reports that 322 returnees were arrested between the 1st and the 20th of September, some of whom were subsequently released. 342 returnees were detained in August.

Repatriation Statistics

1,008 refugees repatriated to Rwanda under UNHCR auspices during September. By country of departure (unless indicated otherwise

figures denote new caseload refugees):

Burundi (includes 39 old caseload)...............141

Zaire (includes 59 old caseload).................747

Tanzania (includes 28 old caseload)..............120

1,390 persons were registered as they crossed spontaneously into Rwanda over the period:

Uganda (includes 5 new caseload)................765

Zaire (includes 50 new caseload)................572

Burundi (includes 2 new caseload)................24

Tanzania (includes 2 new caseload)...............29

In addition, 568 Rwandese were refouled from neighboring countries during the month: 10 from Tanzania, 23 from Uganda and 535 from Zaire, chiefly Banyamulenge from Uvira. (UNHCR Kigali)

Produced by UNHCR Public Information, Kigali, Tel: 250 85093 Fax: 250 85104, B.P. 867, Attn. Paul Stromberg

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

Africa News


September 25, 1996


South Africa;
Call For Ministry Of Crime In South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South African business has called for the formation of a special ministry of crime so that a concerted effort can be made to ensure law enforcement in the country.

Writing in the quarterly political review of the South African Chamber of Business (SACOB), political analyst Professor Lawrence Schlemmer says crime in South Africa has reached proportions which elevate it to the status of a major threat to investment. 

Business confidence, he adds, is being undermined by the rate of murder and violent crime, which is higher in South and Southern Africa than anywhere else in the world.

"Some lawbreaking activity is so widespread as to overwhelm the capacity of the law," he says.

Schlemmer says that while unemployment is a significant contributing factor to crime, it cannot explain the estimated 700,000 cases of rape and sexual violence a year.

"We have to start somewhere," he adds, "and one has to ask whether the time has not come for a single ministry of crime? Should the cities not establish fully-fledged local police forces?."

The SACOB review comes hard on the heels of increasing pressure from the country's opposition parties in parliament for President Nelson Mandela to establish a single ministry responsible for ending escalating crime in South Africa.

They have called for either a single ministry, or for the three ministries concerned--safety and security, justice and correctional services--to combine forces and work together to combat the crime wave.

South Africa, they say, needs better-paid police officers with better training and equipment, as well as for detectives and prosecutors to cooperate in working against crime.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


398 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


Science;
Sleeping Sickness Threatens 50 Million Africans


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - At least 50 million people in Africa face the risk of contracting sleeping sickness, scientifically known as trypanosomiasis, it was revealed here Monday.

The revelation was made by the permanent secretary in the Kenyan ministry of research, Wamatu Njoroge, during the opening of a five-day international trypanosomiasis meeting.

The meeting, organized by the Food and Agricultural Organization in conjunction with the International Atomic Energy Organization, has attracted vector disease experts from all over the world. They will deliberate on methods of controlling the disease. 

Njoroge said the 50 million figure could be an under-estimation since surveillance in endemic areas was difficult, hampering data collection on the disease, caused by tsetse flies.

The problem is compounded by shortage of skilled personnel, financial constraints and presence of other communicable diseases given priority in existing programs, he said in a message to the meeting.

He observed that more than 10 million square kilometers (about 3.9 million square miles) of the African continent was tsetse-fly infested, adding that if cleared of the menace, this land surface could support an additional 120 million head of cattle and generate about one billion U.S. dollars annually.

He said that about 60 percent of Kenya's rangelands (about 25 percent of the total land mass) could not support livestock because of tsetse flies.

According to Njoroge, trypanosomiasis was responsible for the under- exploitation of resources in the rangelands and concentration of livestock in limited grazing areas.

Most tsetse-fly infested areas, he said, experience low rainfall and are not conducive to livestock keeping without massive reclamation.

The permanent secretary suggested that tsetse fly control programmes should take into account land use and water management practices which enhance environmental balance.

Research by the Kenya Trypanosomiasis Research Institute, department of veterinary services, Kenya wildlife service and the International Center for Insect Physiology and Ecology had brought the tsetse fly problem in Lambwe valley to manageable levels, said Njoroge.

He said though the tsetse fly related human disease was currently under control, the same could not be said of animal trypanosomiasis.

With the problem of drug-resistance increasing at an alarming rate, the most promising approach to control the tsetse-fly menace was by attacking the fly itself, the permanent secretary said.

According to him, the integrated use of traps, insecticide impregnated targets, cattle dips and sterile insect technique (SIT) are expected to eradicate the fly.

Njoroge said SIT, potentially an effective method of control, was effective in low density areas and possibilities of integrating it with other control techniques to mop up small residual tsetse fly populations should be explored.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
