Africa News


September 25, 1996


South Africa;
Neighbors Concern Over South Africa's Trade Deal With Europe


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Countries of southern Africa fear that a proposed trade agreement between South Africa and the European Union will hurt their commerce with the rest of sub-Sahara Africa.

Namibia has warned that the effects of any such agreement would need to be assessed carefully. 

The Namibian Economic Policy Research Unit (NEPRU) points out that the Southern African Customs Union--which includes South Africa, Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia and Swaziland--allows for free trade between its members, with one-third of all revenue to its common revenue pool going to its members.

The proposed South African-EU agreement, NEPRU adds, could result in a large influx of highly competitive European products, causing South Africa to import even less from its neighbors in future. This could cost the union's common revenue pool up to 500 million U.S. dollars a year.

Zimbabwe has also expressed concern over possible repercussions of the proposed deal.

"South Africa is being unfair to the sub-region," says the Zimbabwe National Chamber of Commerce. "It would be prudent for South Africa to restructure multilateral trade imbalance in the region before the EU can grant it concessions for a free trade area."

Even without the threat of the new trade agreement, the regional trade balance in southern Africa is heavily in favor of South Africa.

Latest statistics show that South Africa exports products worth 1.7 billion dollars a year to six other southern African countries. It imports goods worth 356 million dollars annually from these countries.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 25, 1996


Zambia;
Nurses Strike Cripples Lusaka Teaching Hospital


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Military doctors and paramedics were Wednesday deployed at the University Teaching Hospital (UTH) in Lusaka, crippled by a strike embarked upon by nurses and other unionised staff.

The nurses began a sit-in last week, demanding a pay rise of 100 percent, among others grievances. Other unionized hospital workers, including mortuary attendants, joined the strike on Tuesday.

The UTH public relations officer, Don Mwape, told PANA in Lusaka on Wednesday that medical personnel from the army, airforce, the Red Cross and staff from the health ministry had been called to assist the hospital.

Paramilitary police Wednesday dispersed the striking workers from the hospital premises. Mwape said the management of the hospital would invite part-time and volunteer nurses to beef up available staff.

"We are now insisting that patients go to clinics to alleviate the problems here at the hospital, and in view of the on-going illegal work stoppage by some nurses, we urgently require part-time and volunteer nurses" Mwape said.

The General Secretary of the Civil Servants Union of Zambia, Japhet Moonde, said that his union had appealed to the striking workers to resume work since negotiations were going on.

Moonde, who visited the hospital Wednesday, said the union was arranging a meeting with the striking workers to plead with them to return to work. The workers rejected similar pleas this week.

Africa News


September 25, 1996


Rwanda;
UNHCR Denies Refugees Status To Accused Mass Killers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said Tuesday it was excluding from refugee status 20 people indicted by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda for their part in that country's genocide in 1994.

"The indictments by the tribunal constitute sufficient grounds for exclusion from refugee status in accordance with its own mandate and the OAU (Organization of African Unity) convention," the U.N. refugee agency said.

In a statement from its Geneva headquarters Wednesday, the agency said governments should also deny asylum to those indictees seeking protection. 

The U.N. Security Council resolution, which established the tribunal, requires the cooperation of inter-governmental, non-governmental organizations and states to arrest persons responsible for the mass killings and flagrant violations of international humanitarian law in Rwanda.

The 20 Rwandans are believed to be among those behind the execution and planning of the genocide in which at least 500,000 Rwandans, mostly Tutsi and moderate Hutu, were killed.

Some of these Rwandans are in the custody of the tribunal. They include three who were arraigned June in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha. The others are known to be in Europe and elsewhere in Africa.

The indicted Rwandans are Ignace Bagilishema, Charles Sikubwabo, Aloys Ndimbati, Vincent Rutaganira, Mika Muhimana, Ryandikayo, Obed Ruzindana, Clement Kayishema, Jean-Paul Akayesu, Anderson Georges Rutaganda Nderubumwe, Alfred Musema, Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, Gerard Ntakirutimana, Andre Ntagerura, Ladislas Ntaganzwa, Anatole Nsengiyumva, Elie Ndayambaje, Ferdinand Nahimana, Theeoneste Bagosora and Eliezer Niyitegeka.

The 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, to which 131 states are party, sets out the criteria for recognition of refugees and standards for their treatment. The Convention also excludes any person considered to have committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity. A similar exclusion provision is found in the 1969 refugee convention of the OAU.

The exclusions were the first announced by the agency on the basis of the tribunal's indictments since at least two million Rwandan refugees flooded into Zaire, Tanzania and Burundi following three months of civil war and genocide in Rwanda in 1994.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


402 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


Nigeria;
Lagos Cab Driver In A Show Of Honesty


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - A Lagos cab driver, in a rare show of honesty, has returned 14,460 U.S. dollars forgotten in his car by a visiting Ivorian businessman.

Businessman Mamadou Coulibaly, on arrival at the Murtala Mohammed International Airport on an Air Gabon Flight from Congo last Sunday night, hired one of the airport cabs into Lagos.

But he forgot the cash and the documents in the car when he disembarked. 

A delighted Coulibaly, a regular visitor to Nigeria, told reporters in Lagos on Tuesday, after receiving the cash and documents, that the gesture had changed his impression about Nigeria and its people.

"I am very happy. I had been given a bad impression about Nigeria, but today I am very impressed with what they (the drivers) have done and I now believe that there are great and honest Nigerians," he was quoted as saying.

The money and documents were returned to him by John Ogbonna, chairman of the airport car hire service association.

Ogbonna, who did not identify the particular driver that returned the money, said his association worked as a responsible team. He used the occasion to debunk what he called propaganda against Nigerians.

Coulibaly's case adds to a growing series of show of public spirit by Nigerians in recent times.

Early this year, a Lagosian, not only rescued a Zairean lady accident victim, but also mortgaged his house to pay for the cost of surgery the lady underwent.

Recently, two members of Nigeria Airways cabin crew were honored for returning 6,000 U.S. dollars forgotten by a passenger on a London-Douala (Cameroon) flight on August 23.

The crew members, Bulus Jonathan and Patience Oghoghome were honored by Owena Bank, based in Lagos.

The bank also honored two employees of Eko Hotels in Lagos for turning in foreign currencies forgotten at different occasions by guests in Lagos.

Sunday Solarin returned 5,000 dollars, while Temitope Kazeem turned in 8, 705 dollars and 5,500 pounds sterling.

Also last year, a Nigerian police corporal returned one million naira, about (12,500 dollars) he found at an accident scene in Lagos.

The gesture earned him promotion as well as cash and car gifts.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


403 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


Rwanda;
Human Rights Watch Chronicles Abuses of Rwanda's Women


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

New York - During the genocide of 1994, Hutu militia groups and the Rwandan military regularly used rape and other sexual violence as weapons in their genocidal campaign against the Tutsi community. In Shattered Lives: Sexual Violence During the Rwandan Genocide and its Aftermath, released today, Human Rights Watch and the Federation Internationale des Ligues des Droits de l'Homme (FIDH) provide detailed and disturbing testimonies from women who survived horrific attacks on their families and themselves, only to face a future complicated by laws and practices that discriminate against them and social services that cannot begin to meet their needs.

Human Rights Watch and FIDH call on the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR), convening on September 26 in Arusha, to investigate and prosecute rape and other gender-related crimes. In addition, we urge the Rwandan government to ensure that women are guaranteed equal protection under domestic law and alert the international humanitarian community to the necessity for their humanitarian programs to address women's needs, especially in the areas of health care, trauma counseling, housing, credit, and education. "The genocide in Rwanda left a population that is 70% female, and the stories told by survivors defy comprehension. What is clear is that Rwanda will only rebuild itself through these women, and the international community must do everything possible to help them deal effectively with the past in order to move productively into the future," said Dorothy Q. Thomas, director of the Human Rights Watch Women's Rights Project. 

Although the exact number of rapes that occurred in Rwanda may never be known, testimonies in the 104-page report confirm that rape was extremely widespread and that women were individually raped, gang-raped, raped with objects such as sharpened sticks or gun barrels, held in sexual slavery or sexually mutilated. These crimes were frequently part of a pattern in which women were raped after they had witnessed the torture and killings of their relatives and the destruction and looting of their homes. Women from both the Tutsi and Hutu ethnic groups were raped, although most rape and other forms of violence were targeted against Tutsi women.

Until very recently, the ICTR largely neglected its responsibility to investigate and prosecute rape. It has to date issued no indictments for rape and other forms of sexual violence. Initial investigations were hampered by serious methodological flaws, including investigative procedures which were not conducive to eliciting rape testimonies from Rwandan women. In July 1996, the International Tribunal took the welcome step of forming a sexual assault committee to coordinate the examination of gender-based violence and has begun to investigate such abuse. However, unless the ICTR takes further steps to incorporate attention to sexual violence into its overall work, rape and other gender-based crimes could go unpunished.

Human Rights Watch and FIDH call on the ICTR to

-- fully investigate and prosecute, where appropriate, rape, sexual slavery and sexual mutilation as crimes against humanity, genocide crimes, or war crimes;

-- ensure that the issue of violence against women is treated with the same gravity as other crimes in its jurisdiction;

-- amend its investigative procedures and methodology, which have largely failed to elicit rape testimonies, to ensure that investigations of rape and other forms of sexual violence are conducted by teams that include women investigators and interpreters skilled in interviewing women survivors of gender-based violence;

-- and strengthen and expand its Witness Protection Unit to ensure that victims and witnesses are protected against potential reprisals and given the appropriate support services.

Gender-based crimes are even more likely to go unpunished given that the Rwandan judicial system is still not functioning. In August 1996, the Rwandan legislature passed a law which authorizes prosecution of crimes committed during the genocide, including rape. However, the likelihood of any rape prosecutions, even with a functioning judiciary, is remote given the lack of investigation into cases of rape and sexual violence and given the discriminatory attitudes towards gender-based crimes on the part of local police inspectors collecting evidence.

Human Rights Watch and FIDH call on the Rwandan government to

-- fully investigate and prosecute the sexual violence that took place during the genocide;

-- and ensure that all police inspectors receive mandatory training on the issue of rape and other sexual abuse, including their status as crimes punishable by law.

As Rwandan women work to rebuild their lives in the wake of the genocide, they must struggle to make ends meet, to reclaim their property, to rebuild their destroyed homes and to raise surviving children, both their own and orphans. These problems are compounded by their second class status under Rwandan law. Many widows have been unable to return to their property because of discriminatory practices in customary law which often deny them the right to inherit. The government has initiated a legal commission to address these issues and to introduce legislation to allow women to inherit equally with men, but the reforms are expected to take a long time.

Human Rights Watch and FIDH call on the Rwandan government to ensure that legal reforms eliminating discrimination are adopted expeditiously and to upholds its obligations under International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights an the Convention on the Elimination All Forms of Discrimination Against Women to ensure that Rwandan women are guaranteed equal protection of the law.

The situation of women in Rwanda cries out for a stepped up humanitarian response from both the international community and the Rwandan government. Since July 1994, international donors have expended approximately $2.5 billion on the Rwandan refugee camps in Zaire and Tanzania, while devoting only $572 million to Rwanda itself. Of that, a negligible amount is targeted for gender-related issues, despite the fact that the overwhelming majority of the country is female. Only a few aid programs address the specific needs of Rwanda's women and the United Nations Field Operation in Rwanda, which has a mandate to protect and promote human rights, is not addressing the current discrimination against women. The Rwandan government, while concerned about these women's pressing needs, has yet to develop a coordinated strategy to respond to these issues.

Human Rights Watch and FIDH call on the international community and the Rwandan government to

-- ensure that aid programs do not neglect women's needs, especially in the areas of criminal justice, health care, housing, credit, education, vocational training, and trauma counseling. To the degree possible, programs for rape survivors should be integrated into broader programs to ensure that rape survivors are not further stigmatized;

-- provide support for training judicial and law enforcement personnel particularly investigators of genocide crimes on gender-based crimes against women. Programs should also be devised to enhance the recruitment of women investigators;

-- ensure adequate financial and logistical support for the ICTR and the UN Human Rights Field Operation;

-- and increase the cooperation and coordination among different government ministries with the aim of improving the social, medical and legal responses to women's needs in the aftermath of the genocide. An inter- ministerial task force should be created to deal with the violence inflicted on women during the genocide and related current problems facing women.

This report is based on an investigative mission to Rwanda by Human Rights Watch and FIDH in March and April 1996. Researchers conducted interviews with victims of rape and sexual violence and current abuses in six of Rwanda's eleven prefectures. Human Rights Watch/FIDH also met with a wide array of non- governmental human rights and women's rights organizations, social workers, journalists, doctors, nurses, government officials and representatives of the International Tribunal and humanitarian organizations.

For more information or a copy of the report, contact Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017-6104.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


404 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


East Africa;
Weekly Roundup of Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2694 words


 

Nairobi - This is number 27 (16 - 22 September) in a series of weekly reports from IRIN on general developments in the Great Lakes region. Sources for the information below include UN agencies, NGOs, other international organisations and media reports. IRIN issues these reports for the benefit of the humanitarian community, but accepts no responsibility as to the accuracy of the original sources.

* UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali is sending Ibrahima Fall, UN Assistant Secretary-General, to Kinshasa for discussions with the Zairean authorities to clarify misunderstandings on the role and operations of the UNHCR, it was announced on Thursday. The mission was prompted by accusations from the Government of Zaire that the UNHCR had provided logistic support to armed groups infiltrating Zaire from Rwanda and Burundi. Two UN staff were beaten by Zairean Army soldiers. The Secretary-General had earlier in the week expressed concern at the Zairian allegations. The mission, due to leave as soon as possible, will include representatives of both UNHCR and the International Organisation of Migration (IOM).

The activities of IOM in Zaire have been suspended. Zaire government spokesman Oscar Lugendo reportedly said on 22 September, 'The IOM, which has gone beyond the framework envisaged in the cooperation accords it signed with Zaire, has been banned until further notice from operating on our territory.' Zaire will 'systematically identify all humanitarian NGOs and evaluate all their activities', he added. 

In a continuing escalation of insecurity in South Kivu, Zaire, heavy arms fire across the border of Rwanda and Zaire was reported overnight on Sunday at Bukavu. Mortar-fire, rockets and automatic fire could be heard but no casualty toll has been reported nor any official explanation given.

* Amnesty International has accused the Zairean security forces and government officials of committing atrocities against members of the Banyamulenge community in South Kivu. In a statement issued on Saturday, Amnesty said that though they understood the Zairean authorities' right to take action against armed opponents, 'there is no justification for this calculated abuse of human rights - including unlawful killings, disappearances, severe beatings and deportation or 'refoulement' to another country.' Some 217 people of Banyamulenge origin were expelled from Uvira to Rwanda by the Zairean authorities during last week, according to UN sources, and several hundred people have fled Zaire to take refuge in western provinces of Burundi.

Amnesty singled out Kyembwa wa Lumona, the District Commissioner of Uvira, for criticism, citing reports that he had authorized the enrolment of youths into the armed forces to fight the Tutsis and said that houses vacated by Tutsi would be given over to army officers. On Wednesday Amnesty welcomed the release from detention of four "prisoners of conscience", all from CADDHOM (Collectif d'action pour le developpment des droits de l'homme), who had been the subject of an Amnesty urgent appeal.

About two hundred Zairians are reported on 16 September to have fled their homes and sought refuge in Ntoroko in Uganda's Bundibugyo district. The new influx is reported, ironically, at a time when 2,000 other Zairian refugees were leaving camps in western Uganda to return home. The returnees are from some 6,000 Zairians who crossed into Uganda early in the year. According to Uganda's New Vision newspaper, the new refugee arrivals were fleeing fighting between Zaire government troops and armed rebels inside Zaire.

* Pierre Buyoya, Burundi's leader who came to power in a military coup d'etat in July, said on Sunday that continued sanctions on Burundi were destroying the peace process and could plunge the country into further violence. Buyoya called on the regional leaders to lift the sanctions imposed by regional leaders following the coup. In an interview with the East African newspaper published on 23 September, Buyoya said that he may cut short his planned three years of military rule if the internal situation in Burundi is brought under control. He also said that he was ready to start negotiations with armed factions, one of the conditions under which sanctions will be lifted.

The next meeting of the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee (RSCC), is scheduled to take place in Kigali on Wednesday 25 September. The meeting will assess the impact of sanctions and requests for exemptions. Since the loosening of sanctions decided by the RSCC at Arusha on 6 September for humanitarian agencies, WFP has organized flights to and from Nairobi on behalf of the UN system and NGOs and arrangements are in hand to import fuel overland for the humanitarian community during the coming week.

* The leader of Burundi's National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), Leonard Nyangoma, said on Friday that he had taken over the leadership of the main Hutu political party, Frodebu. Five members of the Hutu-dominated Frodebu, including Nyangoma, said that they made up a majority of surviving members of the party's management committee and had appointed the rebel leader as party president. In Dar es Salaam, Frodebu president, Jean Minani insisted that he remained the party's leader and that there was no formal coalition between Frodebu and the CNDD. The CNDD said on Wednesday they were prepared to open talks with Burundi's new regime under certain conditions, but repeated their support for sanctions imposed by the regional states. Nyangoma said his party was willing to negotiate but only with those who had not taken part in the planning and execution of the 1993 attempted coup d'etat during which the country's first Hutu president, Melchior Ndadaye, was murdered.

* Thousands of Catholics paid their last respects on Tuesday to Burundi's archbishop Joachim Ruhuna who was murdered in an ambush north of Gitega last week. The body of the archbishop was seen by witnesses burning in his vehicle after the ambush but subsequently disappeared. Soldiers found the bodies of the archbishop and a nun eight days after they had been killed in a shallow grave some three kiometers away from the scene of the attack. The archbishop was buried on 19 September. Four people survived the attack. The rebels and the Army blame each other for the murders. Pope John Paul's special envoy at Tuesday's memorial service in Gitega appealed for an end to the slaughter. The US Catholic Bishops' Conference and the OAU condemned the killing.

* The Burundian military reported that three people were killed and others wounded when rebels opened fire on their minibus near Rumonge, less than 50 miles from the capital, Bujumbura. Small ambushes such as this are apparently becoming more frequent.

* US congressman, Harry Johnstone suggested on Tuesday that the international community should work together to close down the camps for Rwandan refugees in Eastern Zaire and Tanzania. Following talks in Rwanda with government officials and in Kenya with refugee leaders, Johnstone said that an option would be to stop feeding the refugees. He suggested that an UN security force may be required to escort the refugees across the border and guarentee security to returning refugees. The food situation in refugee camps in Goma, meanwhile, has been critical following the ban imposed by a major donor on deliveries of its food aid donations pending the production of viable refugee figures.

WFP expects an improvement in the food supply situation as trucks arrive from Uganda. A planned three-day census of Rwandan refugees in Goma had to be suspended earlier in the month, following a boycott by the refugees. UNHCR, WFP and the Government of Zaire have met in Goma to discuss a new date for the verification exercise.

* The Tanzanian Foreign Minister said on Friday that he feared Rwandan refugees in Tanzania would turn part of the country into a barren desert. The Foreign Minister on a visit to Algiers told news media that the 900,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees in Tanzania were competing with local people for scant resources and threatening the area with an environmental disaster. In addition, he said that the local people wanted the refugees to go home because of rape, attacks and burglaries.

* US Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, will visit the region beginning 8 October, for a series of meetings with regional leaders. Presidents Daniel arap Moi of Kenya and Yoweri Museveni of Uganda have been invited to Arusha to meet with Mr. Christopher during his visit to Tanzania. In Arusha, the Secretary of State will meet with President Benjamin Mkapa and former president Julius Nyerere. Discussions will centre on bilateral relations as well as on the Rwanda and Burundi situations. In an earlier stop in Addis Ababa, he will meet with Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi and OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim. Mr. Christopher will also visit Mali, Angola and South Africa.

* A Rwandan national has been arrested in Nairobi charged with genocide and crimes against humanity - the first arrest in Kenya in connection with the 1994 massacres in Rwanda. Obed Ruzindana, a former trader, is on the list of eight suspects who were indicted by the UN International Tribunal in December. One of those indicted with Ruzindana, former Kibuye police chief, Clement Kayishema is being detained at the Tribunal headquarters in Arusha. Kenya's President Daniel arap Moi had initally refused to cooperate with the Tribunal but subsequently changed his position. So far some 20 genocide suspects have been arrested. The first trial - that of former mayor Jean-Paul Akayesu - was scheduled to begin on 26 September, but is likely to be delayed. Earlier this week Akayesu's defence counsel and other lawyers for some of the accused lashed out at the Tribunal saying that it did not respect the rights of lawyers. Belgian lawyer, John Scheers said that he had not been given all the files relating to his case. His colleague Luc de Temmerman who is due to defend Georges Rutaganda, will also be in Tanzania this week but will ask for a postponement. Temmerman said that his client is seriously ill and in need of medical attention. Both Akayesu and Rutaganda pleaded not guilty at their preliminary hearings in May. A third lawyer, Andre Ferran, of France who is due in November to defend the former prefet of Kibuye, Clement Kayishema, was also strongly critical of the Tribunal.

* More than 100 investment projects worth US$ 950.85 million will be promoted at Tanzania's first international investment forum in November. Projects include agro-industry, tourism, mining, infrastructure, chemicals, paper, textiles, and pharmaceuticals. The forum will take place 5-8 November in Dar es Salaam. Since the introduction of trade liberalisation in 1985, the Tanzanian government has initiated economic reforms that have included cutting controls on foreign currency trading, allowing market-driven interest rates and creating the independent Tanzania Revenue Authority. The UN is providing US$ 750,000 in organisational and logistical support for the forum.

News that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is likely to restore Tanzania's credit facilities suspended since 1992 has raised confidence in the prospects for economic revival. Leading businessmen in Dar es Salaam, however, have warned that Tanzania still has far to go to emerge from the list of the world's poorest countries. IMF's representative in Tanzania said that final talks were underway for an Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility worth about US$ 234 million to be approved by October. The approval of the ESAF would lead to a resumption of donor aid now suspended.

* Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni on a four day visit to Tanzania has urged East African countries to remove remaining trade barriers in order to promote cooperation in the region. Rwanda's Vice President, Paul Kagame, on Friday called for greater involvement by South Africa in trying to solve the crisis in the Great Lakes region. Kagame said that he was satisfied that the government of South Africa understood what was happening in the region. Kagame, who is also Rwanda's Minister of Defence, made his remarks during a four-day visit to South Africa aimed at persuading Pretoria to exercise its position as a regional power. Last month South Africa announced its support for a peace initative launched by leaders in the Great Lakes region aimed at normalising the situation in Burundi. It appointed a special envoy to help peace efforts in the region.

* Uganda accused Sudan of dropping around ten bombs from MiG aircraft near Moyo, 16 km inside Uganda's northwestern border on 22nd September, and pledged to retaliate. The news comes despite a recent agreement on 9 September between Uganda and Sudan brokered by Iranian President Akbar Hasemi Rafsanjani.

The Lord's Resistence Army (LRA) rebels have killed an average of 25 people daily for the last two weeks in Gulu district, Ugandan security officials said at the weekend. The attacks have been concentrated mainly in Aswa and Omoro counties. The Ugandan Army is reported to be seeking permission to evacuate villagers to safer areas.

The Ugandan government said on Friday that it was ready to meet with rebels of the West Nile Bank Front operating in the western region of the country from bases in Zaire and southern Sudan. Uganda's deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Tourism made his remarks duing a parliamentary committee hearing on the war in northern Uganda.

* The plight of refugees is being discussed this week at the 4th Pan African Conference of the Red Cross and Red Crescent which opened in Kampala on Sunday. More than 300 delegates from 53 soceties in Africa will review how best to assist refugees in the wake of increasing conflict in the continent.

Africa News


September 25, 1996


Business;
Farmers in Zambia Cry Out For Guidelines


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia National Farmers Union has urged the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries to immediatetly publicise the 1996/97 fertiliser policy.

Farmers union president, Mr. Ajai Vashee said in a statement released in Lusaka today that the ministry should announce whether they will import fertiliser for this season and how much would be imported. 

He charged that if the policy on fertiliser is not well publicised, the private sector fertiliser supply initiatives will not take off which would lead to a shortage of the commodity in the coming season.

Mr. Vashee further disclosed that farmers and fertiliser distributers are anxious to know whether government would import fertiliser supplies from outside Africa and when the commodity is expected to arrive in the country.

He said if government intends to make stocks of basal dressing available to farmers on time, it should place it's orders now.

ZAMNET-ZANA

Africa News


September 25, 1996


Sports - General;
Karate: Zambians Pick Squad For World Championship


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Karate Federation (ZKF) has picked a 13-player provisional squad to represent the country at the 13th World Karate Championship in Sun City, South Africa this November.

In an interview in Lusaka recently, ZKF president, Raymond Phiri, said the squad will be trimmed to a smaller number before departure. 

"The world championship is the highest in the world and we feel this is our chance as a country to achieve honours. We are certain that at least something can come out of the trip to South Africa," said Phiri.

The players in the team include, James Mambwe, Tom Banda, Amos Simbeye, Lemmy Nyambi, Boyson Lungu, Justine Chemba, Patrick Mutale, Allan Mumba, Moodle Chola, Sam Sikatali, Reuben Tifuka, Arthur Simunza and Sebastain Simba.

"All the karatekas we have picked are of high class, and whoever shall be picked in the final team will surely be among the best. But we have not yet decided on how many people to pick for the championship," said Phiri.

407 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


Business;
Livestock Industry In Zambia Heading For Disaster


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela and Sycorax Ndhlovu, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Lusaka - Livestock industry in Zambia is heading for a total collapse if the current problems affecting the industry are not addressed.

This was revealed during the launching of the Livestock Production Society of Zambia which took place at Mulungushi International Conference Centre in Lusaka recently.

University of Zambia Animal Science Department lecturer, Judy Lungu, said the livestock industry has been neglected for a long time. This is because agriculture in Zambia is associated only with crops, she said. She continued that only seven per cent of agriculture budgetary allocation goes to livestock production. 

Speaking at the same function, deputy agricultural minister Matthias Mpande agreed with Lungu, adding that the following are some of the major constraints the livestock industry is facing;

* lack of adequate credit facilities to livestock farmers;

* unimproved livestock extension services;

* poor extension-farmer, research-extension, research-farmer linkages;

* inadequate staffing;

* poor human resource development;

* weak livestock delivery system; and

* poor land tenure system which was a disservice to livestock farmers.

Mpande said his ministry had identified these constraints and is tackling them. He said the Agricultural Sector Investment Programme (ASIP) has animal production and health sub-programme to address such problems affecting the livestock industry.

But Zambia Institute of Animal Health (ZIAH), lecturer who is a stockfeed production consultant in Mazabuka said in addressing any problem, there is need to formulate an appropriate policy.

He said policy is a major tool of change. Livestock industry is dying because of policies which allow importation of livestock products without considering the effects of such imports on local industry.

He said there should be import quotas, and the larger part of livestock products should come from local livestock industry.

However, an agriculture extension officer speaking in Monze last Friday, Cosmas Malawo, said though there were a number of high quality imported livestock products on the market, they did not benefit the local small scale farmer who is increasingly unable to purchase them because of the costs involved.

"Cattle have died in Southern Province not only because of the corridor disease but because the owners literally can not afford to look after their cattle. If there was more local production of livestock products in Zambia, peasant farmers might even be able to form groups and donate towards the purchase of drugs," he said.

Once the Province with the highest numbers of livestock, the population of cattle and sheep in Southern Province has decimated to drastically low levels prompting a K200 million drugs donation from IFAD to try and arrest the trend.

"We might have adopted a market economy, but the government should realise that some sectors may be wiped out if they are not assisted," Malawo said.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


Business;
Forest Won't Be Sold


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - The Chichele plantation currently being managed by the Zambia Forestry and Forest Industry Company (ZAFFICO) will not be privatised together with the sawmill, Parliament heard yesterday.

Environment minister, William Harrington, made this clarification after Kafue MMD member of parliament, Yusuf Badat, asked him who will take over the management of the plantation after the ZAFFICO sawmill is privatised as scheduled in tranche six. 

"Although the ZAFFICO sawmill is earmarked for privatisation in tranche six, we have to de-link the two," Harrington said, explaining: "The plantation covers an area of 55,000 hectares. No responsible government would put such a vast land under private hands."

Harrington stressed that only the sawmill will be privatised while government "will hold ownership of the plantation on behalf of the people".

"We are examining various ways of managing the forest, including the transformation of the forestry department into a commercial enterprise," Harrington said. "A study is underway to transform the forest department into what will be known as the Zambia Forest Authority."

This response, however, drew a point of order from UNIP's Feira member of parliament, retired Major General Tom Fara, who pointed out that Harrington had made no mention of the Mwekera Forestry Training School and the fish farm which is located within the plantation.

"Is the minister aware that the Southern African Development Conference (SADC) is eyeing the school to turn it into a SADC Forestry Training School?" General Fara asked.

Harrington replied that he was "very aware".

"This is what the study is meant to address," Harrington said.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


409 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


Business;
Zambian Farmers Have To Pay Debts


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The government has no intentions of putting in place measures to prevent lending institutions from harassing small scale farmers for the loans they received during the 1993 to 1995 agricultural seasons.

Replying to a question raised by Mwinilunga West MMD member of parliament, Peter Mpashi, who wanted to know whether his ministry would protect small scale farmers whose properties are being seized by lending institutions for failing to re-pay the loans, agriculture deputy minister Mathias Mpande said the government has no intentions of putting in place a debt relief incentive programme for small scale farmers who got loans between 1993 and 1995. 

"Loans are contractual obligations and have to be honoured," Mpande said, but hinted that government had worked out a debt relief incentive programme for thirty-one districts which were adversely affected by drought over the said period.

The latter, however, prompted Chisamba MMD member of parliament, Reuben Musakabantu, to ask Mpande whether the list of names for the farmers who have been given this relief is available for scrutiny.

"Yes, the names are available," Mpande assured.

The lending institutions involved include the Credit Union Savings Association (CUSA), Lima Bank and the Zambia Co-operative Federation (ZCF).

Meanwhile agricultural deputy minister Dickson Matutu disclosed in Parliament yesterday that government is working out a new Agricultural Credit Act to protect lending institutions from willful defaulters.

Matutu was responding to a question by Masaiti MMD member of parliament, Jazzman Chikwaka, who wanted to know what assistance government was rendering to small scale farmers involved in cotton production.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


410 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


Zambia;
President: Convince Zambians To Alter Constitution


BYLINE: Kindness Paradza and Masautso Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba says his predecessor Kenneth Kaunda should convince all Zambians to alter the Constitution that bars him from contesting next month's presidential elections.

But President Chiluba, in a telephone call to Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, claimed former president Kaunda did not respect him and his idea of dialogue is a meeting in a big hall and in the presence of journalists.

The telephone call was made on September 10 after talks with the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) and the conversation was narrated to UNIP president Kaunda and Liberal Progressive Front chairman, Rodger Chongwe, by President Mugabe at a meeting in Harare on September 11.

And last week President Chiluba told The Financial Gazette, Zimbabwe's leading financial independent paper, during the World Solar Summit in Harare that it was Zambian laws, not him, that disqualified former president Kaunda and other non-indigenous Zambians from running for public office. 

"We do not bar individuals from contesting ... those who are eligible will contest," President Chiluba said in an interview. "We don't know whether Kaunda can come up with his own supernatural constitution that supersedes the one we have."

President Chiluba added: "We believe that constitutions are matters for individual nations. If they decide on a constitution it is their right to do so."

But Chongwe, in an interview yesterday, said President Chiluba's call to President Mugabe on September 10 was announcing his agreement with the ZDC which he said he would shortly make public.

Chongwe, who met Mugabe on September 11 in Harare with his security minister Dr Sidney Sekeremayi and UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda who also confirmed the conversation, said President Chiluba told President Mugabe that ZDC had raised eight points and they had agreed on four.

"He claimed that the most difficult person in Zambia was Kaunda who had even broken off talks," Chongwe said, adding: "About those points not agreed, Chiluba did not tell Mugabe that these related to the Constitution and the voters register. So Mugabe appreciated that we were able to tell him the truth about Chiluba's bilateral meetings."

Chongwe added that their meeting with Mugabe exposed Chiluba's lies about Kaunda, especially in regard to the interparty meetings where Chiluba claims the former president did not want one-to-one meetings because he wants to play to the gallery of reporters.

And the Financial Gazette writes that the amended Constitution, which many people believe was targeted at UNIP president Kaunda whose parents came from Malawi although it is not clear where they originated from, drafted largely by the MMD and enacted into law last May, bars non-indigenous Zambians from contesting presidential elections.

President Chiluba recently invited the UNIP president to discuss, among other issues, the controversial constitution. But the talks failed to produce conclusive results.

Meanwhile over the last three months several donor countries and organisations have been threatening to cut the much needed economic aid to the impoverished country, saying the constitutional amendments put in place by President Chiluba were undemocratic and dictatorial.

But President Chiluba appears undaunted by donor threats.

"I don't think people make constitutions to make money," President Chiluba said. "So I believe that the people of Zambia, although they are not economically fit, must determine their own destiny."

In addition to world condemnation, the 12-nation Southern African Development Community (SADC) has expressed concern at constitutional changes adopted by President Chiluba's government.

President Chiluba has, however, constantly snubbed his SADC colleagues claiming the problem was a national issue.

President Chiluba said Zambians had, as early as 1972, demanded constitutional changes when Kaunda was in power.

"It was one party dictatorial government but since 1972 people wanted to have an indigenous Zambian for their leader," he said.

Last year, when he received a draft of the amendments to the constitution, President Chiluba claimed that "constitutions everywhere in the world are discriminatory in one way or the other".

"Zambians should not be too expectant of the document because there is no constitution that does not discriminate," President Chiluba warned. " I have never heard of a constitution that takes care of the interests of all citizens, hence, we cannot think of a completely non-discriminatory document here."

And President Chiluba was yesterday advised by Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) president, Alfred Zulu, to take note of the 13 recommendations made by the Commonwealth Human rights Initiative (CHRI) in order to save Zambia's young democracy.

"President Chiluba cannot continue ignoring the overwhelming view taken by international organisations, NGOs (non-governmental organisations) and friendly governments that remedial summer saults must be made instead of sending envoys on fruitless diplomatic consultative missions...," Zulu said in a press statement released in Lusaka yesterday.

The CHRI team visited Zambia on a fact finding mission between August 27 and September 5, this year and warned against any delays in helping Zambia in her situation because "the shortage of time is a critical factor".

Amongst the recommendations are that the government should open itself up for dialogue, consider a constituent assembly for broadened constitutional debate and desists from forcing an election on Zambians without ironing out the pressing problems.

But MMD national secretary, minister without portfolio Michael Sata, recently said although government was ready to dialogue with all the parties such talks will not include the Constitution as it was now law and not open for any further debate.

Sata also maintained that his government saw no problems in Zambia - constitutional or otherwise.

Zulu said the government has not made adequate attempts to amicably move the obstacles and resolve the internal conflicts which have been heightened by the failed one to one inter-party talks.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

411 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 25, 1996


East Africa;
Regional Sanctions Group Reaffirms Burundi Embargo


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Kigali - Recommendations by the 2nd meeting of the regional sanctions co- ordinating committee, 25 September 1996.

1. At the kind invitation of the Government of the Republic of Rwanda, the Regional Sanctions Co-ordinating Committee held its 2nd meeting in Kigali, Rwanda on 25 September, 1996 under its Chairman H.E. Major-General M.S.H. SARAKIKYA, High Commissioner of Tanzania to Kenya. Representatives from Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and the OAU Secretariat attended the meeting. Zaire and the OAU current Chairman were not represented. 

2. The Committee reviewed the recent developments in Burundi, the implementation of Sanctions and noted that the Sanctions have so far been effective.

3. The Committee considered the requests for exemptions made by various U.N. Agencies and the Diplomatic corps based in Bujumbura and recommended that the exemptions given so far including those related to fertilizer and vegetable seeds are sufficient.

4. The Committee took note of the positive steps taken by the BUYOYA regime towards meeting the conditions set out by the Arusha II Summit, namely the lifting of the ban on political parties and the restoration of the National Assembly. However, the Committee stressed that the most important condition yet to be fully met is the immediate and unconditional negotiations with all groups.

5. In view of the steps taken so far by the BUYOYA regime, the Committee recommended that Major BUYOYA be invited to be available during the forthcoming Summit. In addition, other leaders of parties to the conflict as may be recommended by the Facilitator also be invited to be available during the Summit meeting.

6. The Committee underscored the fact that the sanctions were not imposed for the benefit of, or to the detriment of any group or political faction. To that end, it reiterated the Political objective of the sanctions, namely to pressure the BUYOYA regime to undertake measures aimed at restoring Burundi to legality and constitutional order; finding a negotiated settlement to the conflict and to bring about lasting peace to Burundi.

7. The Committee reiterated the need for coordination, harmonization and information-sharing among all the participating countries in order to maintain cohesion and unity of purpose in all matters pertaining to the Sanctions.

8. The Committee recommended that a Ministerial meeting be held on 10 October 1996 in order to review the situation in Burundi and prepare for the proposed Third Regional Summit.

9. The Committee agreed to hold its 3rd Session in Arusha, Tanzania on 8 October 1996.

10. The Committee expressed its appreciation to the Government of the Republic of Rwanda for hosting the meeting and for the warm reception and hospitality accorded to all the delegations.

(Transcribed from a faxed original by UN DHA IRIN, Nairobi. Distributed via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. Africa News


September 25, 1996


East Africa;
Weekly Roundup of Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2294 words


 

Nairobi - This is number 26 (9 - 15 September 1996) in a series of weekly reports from the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network (IRIN) on general developments in the Great Lakes region. Sources for the information below include UN agencies, NGOs, other international organisations and media reports. IRIN issues these reports for the benefit of the humanitarian community, but accepts no responsibility as to the accuracy of the original sources.

* Major Pierre Buyoya, leader of Burundi's governing regime, agreed to unban political parties and reinstitute the suspended National Assembly according to a Radio Burundi broadcast on Thursday. The statement, read by Pierre-Claver Ndayicariye, the Minister of Communications, said the decision was made by the Council of Ministers in a meeting on Thursday afternoon. The meeting decided that "the national assembly is restored within the legal framework of the transitional institutional system" and that "political parties and associations of a political nature are authorised to resume their activities within the context of the law." 

The move was welcomed by Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the UN Secretary-General, as "extremely positive", while Marc Faguy, the UN Special Representative of the Secretary-General in Burundi described it as "a step in the right direction and an excellent response". However, the major Hutu political and military movements were less enthusiastic. FRODEBU described the decision as a "totally unacceptable masquerade" and said Major Buyoya was "making fun of the Burundi people and the international community". The CNDD described the move as "a positive step but insufficient", a statement that surprised some observers by the moderation of its tone.

The decision was condemned by a FRODEBU MP, Joseph Ntakarutimana, speaking on behalf of other exiled politicians. "Parliament cannot function while most of the MPs of the majority party, FRODEBU, have been forced to go into exile and others assassinated by the army or Tutsi militias while their killers enjoy total impunity," he said.

An increasing number of FRODEBU MPs in exile are switching their allegiance to the CNDD. A group of 16 FRODEBU deputies living as exiles in Uvira, Zaire, announced their 'unconditional support' for the CNDD and its armed campaign in Burundi in a statement released on Tuesday in Nairobi. On Tuesday 2 September, 22 FRODEBU parliamentarians in Tanzania had announced their support for the CNDD, joining three FRODEBU parliamentarians in Kenya.

Regional Governments who imposed the sanctions on Burundi have yet to respond to the decision. The move meets two of the three conditions for the suspension of sanctions laid down by the Arusha II summit on 31 July, but not the condition that the regime undertake 'immediate and unconditional talks with all groups within and outside the country', a clear reference to Hutu rebel groups who have been fighting the army within the country and from bases in Zaire.

* The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Burundi, Joachim Ruhuna, was still missing at the end of last week and believed to have been murdered after the discovery of his burnt car last Tuesday. His vehicle was found in a valley near Bugendana town in Gitega province, with traces of blood and burnt clothing beside it. A nun travelling with him was missing, but the body of another woman was found. The Burundian army confirmed on Thursday church reports that four other people travelling with the archbishop had survived the attack, the archbishop's driver, a woman accountant and two schoolgirls. The army had previously stated that only the driver had survived.

The army reported a deacon as saying that he had discovered the burning car on Monday shortly after the attack, with the bodies of the archbishop and a nun burning inside. The deacon had reportedly pulled the bodies out of the car and gone to seek help, but found the archbishop's body missing by the time he returned.

The army blames Hutu rebels for the archbishop's death. However, the CNDD's spokesman, Jerome Ndiho, on Wednesday denied that Hutu rebels carried out the killing and claimed the army were responsible. Monsignor Ruhuna, a Tutsi, was regarded as a force for moderation in Burundi and had been an outspoken critic of violence by all parties to the conflict. His killing has been condemned by political leaders around the world and the Pope, who expressed his "deep pain" at the murder.

* UN officials have welcomed the decision by the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee to exempt certain classes of relief items from the sanctions on Burundi. The decision on Friday 6 September followed concerns from humanitarian agencies that the sweeping sanctions would bring the whole emergency relief effort in Burundi to a halt. The full Sanctions Committee statement, which includes details of which relief items have been exempted, is available from IRIN.

* Human Rights Watch (HRW) and the Federation Internationale des Ligues des Droits de L'Homme (FIDH) called on Monday for the creation of an ad hoc international tribunal to prosecute those charged with 'massive human rights violations in Burundi'. The human rights organizations condemned as 'shocking' the conclusion of the UN Commission of Inquiry for Burundi report that '(t)o make the suppression of impunity a precondition for the solution of the crisis is completely unrealistic'. They also argued that this conclusion contradicts Security Council Resolution 1012 of August 1995 which established the Commission to 'recommend legal, political and adminstrative measures to bring to justice those responsible for the acts'. HRW/FIDH said that '(t)o turn away from such clear evidence of guilt would... invite continuing violence not only in Burundi, but also elsewhere in the world.'

* Reports from Uvira in South Kivu, Zaire, indicate growing tension and conflict between local authorities, local people, Zairean soldiers and Banyamulenge, Zairean Tutsis of Rwandan expression. On Monday local people declared Uvira town a "dead city", demonstrating against Banyamulenge and attacking their property. This prompted large numbers of Tutsis to seek refuge at UNHCR in Uvira. Some 220 people have since been arrested and taken to Luberizi military camp, while at least three Tutsis and four Zairean soldiers have been killed in the past week. Some 50 people were expelled to Rwanda by the Zairean authorities on Saturday, most of whom were Banyamulenge. An estimated 30 Zairean Tutsis and three Zairean soldiers are reported to have died in fighting in the area during the week beginning Monday 2 September.

The Zairean army is conducting a military operation in the hills around Uvira town, and more troops have been despatched from Goma, Bukavu, Shaba and Kinshasa. Zairean army chief of staff Major General Eluki Monga is reported to have arrived in Uvira to supervise the operation, which the authorities claim is designed to counter Tutsis seeking to "destabilize eastern Zaire". They also claim that the Rwandese Patriotic Army has been training the Banyamulenge and that Burundi has been providing them with rear bases. The Governor has declared the area between Uvira and Fizi closed to foreign aid organizations.

Both Rwanda and Burundi have categorically rejected these charges, while local Tutsis have claimed that Rwanda's Former Government Army and the Interahamwe are targetting the Tutsis alongside the local authorities and army. They say that, as in the case of Masisi, regional political tensions are being used as a pretext for targetting Tutsis simply in order to take their property and cattle. The Tutsis from Masisi were forced to flee from Zaire to Rwanda earlier this year when they were targetted by the local authorities and the army. There is substantial evidence that Hutu extremists from the refugee camps played a leading role in this process.

* Zaire's military pledged its support on Monday to the institutions governing the country's democratic transition, following rumours of a military coup in the absence of President Mobutu. The President is out of the country, recovering from a prostate operation in Switzerland. A military statement broadcast on state radio said that the military high command rejoiced at the success of the operation and affirmed its support for the electoral calender leading to elections next year.

* Uganda and Sudan announced on Tuesday their decision to normalise diplomatic relations and not to support rebel forces operating from the territories of each other's country. The decision, brokered by Iranian President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, commits both parties to a series of measures including: to stop immediately official propaganda campaigns against the other party; to prevent any elements hostile to the other party from using its territory against the other; to end direct or indirect assistance to hostile elements, and to move all refugees and all elements hostile to the other party from the border to an area not less than 100 km inside the border.

Uganda severed diplomatic ties with Sudan in April 1995, accusing the Khartoum Government of supporting Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels in the north of the country. Sudan, for its part, accused Uganda of supporting the Sudan People's Liberation Army in its war to end domination of the south by the north. The LRA said on Wednesday that the decision would not affect its armed campaign in northern Uganda.

* Pierre Celestin Rwigema, Prime Minister of Rwanda, announced on Tuesday the resignation of Justice Minister Martha Mukamurenzi, following the disclosure that she had misappropriated public funds. According to Information Minister, Jean-Pierre Bizimana, Ms Mukamurenzi misappropriated 27 million Rwandan francs ($90,000), most of which she spent on "her personal needs". The former Justice Minister will not be prosecuted as she has received a presidential pardon. "She was taking money, and then putting it back. She has replaced almost everything she stole. She has asked for forgiveness, so we are not going to prosecute her," Bizimana said.

* The International Tribunal for Rwanda will start the trial of three suspects being held in Tanzania on 26 September. The three are accused of genocide and crimes against humanity during the genocide which claimed an estimated 800,000 lives between April and June 1994. Proceedings against Jean Paul Akayesu, who is accused of killing 2,000 Tutsis in Taba, will open the hearings in Arusha.

* The arms embargo against the Rwandese Government was totally lifted on 1 September, such that the Government is no longer required to report on arms that it is importing. The announcement was made last week by the Chairman of the UN Security Council Committee established by resolution 918 (1994) to monitor the arms embargo. The full arms embargo will still apply in relation to non-governmental forces in Rwanda and 'to persons in the States neighbouring Rwanda if such sale or supply is for the purpose of the use of such arms or material within Rwanda.'

* The Tanzanian and Iranian Governments have agreed to strengthen trade and technical ties between their countries, after a large delegation headed by Iranian President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani visited Tanzania last week. The two countries agreed to cooperate further in trade, agriculture, education, health and communications during talks held on Monday. The visit by the Iranian delegation was part of an African tour which also included visits to Kenya and Uganda.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not be taken always to reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. Africa News


September 26, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1467 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Members of the delegation of the House of Peoples' Representatives currently on a visit to Germany met and held talks with the Ethiopian community in that country, German Radio reported.

The delegation visiting Germany upon the invitation of the Federal council of Germany gave briefings to Ethiopians on the prevailing political, economic and social situations in Ethiopia.

During talks at the Ethiopian Embassy, the delegation presided over by Ato Eshetu Kebede, Chairman of the Economic Affairs Standing Committee, discussed with community members political and economic questions in Ethiopia, the radio said.

The radio quoted Ethiopian Ambassador to Germany, Dr. Behanne Tensay, as saying Ethiop-German bilateral cooperations have further been consolidated and added the government of Germany is extending broader support in the political, educational, tourism and economic development sectors. 

Authority says tank truck deployment becomes more effective

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Road Transport Authority announced here yesterday that the lifting of the tariff control and its determination by the market has enabled tank truck owners to distribute fuel to areas which had previously been beyond their reach. This, it said, is indicative of the fact that tank truck deployment has been more effective than it was before the deregulation.

Ato Kasahun Haile-Mariam, acting head of trucks and truck drivers department in the authority, said 223 tank trucks have transported fuel from the Port of Assab to different regions across the country.

With the tariff control system there was hardly any truck intending to go to Gondar as the result of which there was serious shortage of fuel there, the official said, adding now 28 trucks with trailers have travelled to the area since the decision that the tariff should be negotiated between the truck owners and distributors.

Wollo, part of the Amhara Regional State also gets ten trucks of fuel daily through the Ethiopian Petroleum Corporation, he said.

According to the official, no disagreements have surfaced so far between truck owners and distributors on the issue of transportation cost.

The price of fuel in Ethiopia is the lowest as compared to that of many countries in the world, it was reported.

ALFP issues four-point resolution

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Afar Liberation Front Party (ALFP), announced that it has passed a four-point resolution following a meeting it held in Addis Ababa.

In a statement it issued here yesterday at the end of an eight-day meeting, the front said the resolution mainly focused on further promoting the over- all development activities in the region.

The statement said that the Front has taken measures that would help ensure the existence of the party by rooting out the differences among its executive committee members.

It said the party will call a general meeting in the very near future to help further strengthen itself at kebele and central levels.

The party will contribute its share and actively work towards the rapid development of the Afar Region thereby helping extricate the public from economic backwardness.

The party will make maximum effort to put into practice the rural centered five-year development programme , the statement said.

Lack of service jeopardises medical service in the country: Physician

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The ministry of Health sad Tuesday lack of service and timely maintenance work on life-saving medical equipment has paralysed the over-all medical service in the country.

Health service department head, Dr. Mathewos Wkbulcho said several X-ray, laboratory and other relevant medical apparatus have gone idle for years due to lack of timely maintenance.

He said the Ministry needs skilled manpower in the field so as to provide adequate service to the people.

He told a six-week training organized for scientific and medical equipment technicians that health institutions could provide dependable health service to the community only when the idle laboratory and X-ray machines are repaired and made ready for use.

Dr. Mathows said the National Scientific Equipment Centre, the organizer of the training, should work hand inglove with the Ministry in a bid to mitigate existing shortage throughout the country of medical equipment technicians.

It was noted that the aim of the training was to strengthen regional and institutional capability on the repair and servicing of medical equipment.

Some 20 individuals with diplomas in electronics are attending the training programme,. it was reported.

Sugar Factory nets 25 million birr

NAZARETH (ENA) - The Wonji-shoa Sugar Factory has obtained a 25 million birr net profit during the previous fiscal year, the acting general manager of the factory said.

Ato Solomon Baraki said despite plans to produce 748,000 quintals of sugar, it has produced 725,000 due to muddy roads which hindered the activity of the factory.

He, however, said that the quantity produced last Ethiopian year is more than that of the preceding due to increased productivity on the plantations.

Ato Solomon added that the factory has plans to obtain 30 million birr in profit by producing 782,000 quintals this year.

Preparations have been finalized to distribute the production of the Matahra and Wonji sugar factories in 18 major towns throughout the country, he noted.

Enterprise to harvest 90,000 quintals of seeds

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - About 90,000 quintals of seed is expected to be harvested from 4,770 hectares of land of the bale Agricultural Development Enterprise, the general a manager predicted.

Ato Abebe Gobeze said about 35-40 quintals of seed can be harvested from a hectare to be distributed among farmers in Bale Zone to help increase agricultural production.

The general manager said over 63,000 quintals of select seeds were produced during the past production year from the farmlands of the enterprise.

Embezzled money retrieved

DEBRE MARKOS (ENA) - Nearly 878,000 of the total 5.2 million birr which reported was embezzled from many farmers' service cooperatives in East Gojjam Zone of the Amhara Regional State has now gone to safe while charges were levelled against the remaining embezzlers, a monitoring office of the cooperatives announced.

Ato Zemenay Menelik, head of the office, said task forces set up at zonal and woreda levels have helped the return of the money taken from 157 cooperatives.

He said his office has used 586 people while more charges are to be levelled against 1,794 others.

He added the office has plans to strengthen 44 cooperatives and reestablish two others this year, adding of the total 183 cooperatives in the zone, some have weakened and others dissolved.
