Africa News


September 26, 1996


Science;
Killer Beans Scare In Nigeria


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - It is unusual for a top Nigerian government official to take a meal by the roadside.

However, Col. Muhammed Marwa, the Military Administrator of Lagos state, did just that on Monday. He wanted to prove a point.

Marwa led a team of officials to stage a public show of eating bean cakes popularly called 'Akara' in Nigeria, to allay growing fears that consumption of the protein-rich food could lead to death. 

The story of the so-called 'killer-beans', which started as a rumour, later spread like wild fire across Nigeria's western states of Oyo, Ogun, Osun and then Lagos.

At the root of the problem was a press report that armed robbers raided a warehouse in the area and stole a lorry-load of sacks of beans, which had been treated with insecticides for planting.

The beans later found their way in local markets, and sold cheaper than normal.

The country's vibrant press gave vent to the rumour with numerous catchy headlines.

Until now, the average Nigerian regarded beans as a choice menu, sought after because of its nutrient-rich properties.

As a leading Nigerian staple, beans can be prepared as a sauce, taken either as a single dish or together with other food items such as plantain, rice, pap (maize cream) or garri (cassava flour soaked in water).

Better still, it can be processed and eaten as 'Moi Moi' or fried into cakes.

Such was the culinary variety associated with beans in Africa's most populous nation of some 100 million people, before the controversy.

Some of the stories that fueled the panic were that several members of different families in western Nigeria either fell ill or died after eating bean meals.

The reports had included graphic descriptions of mostly nameless victims and testimonies from generally anonymous witnesses, including medical practitioners.

One of the harrowing reports said that a woman beans seller in the city of Abeokuta (some 62.5 miles north of Lagos), died after eating some of the grains she prepared, in a bid to convince those who cared to know that her food was safe.

The woman was reportedly confronted by an angry mob after several members of a family allegedly died after eating the meal she sold them.

The rumours took a frightening dimension after several deaths were also reported in Agege, a suburb of Lagos, the country's commercial nerve centre, with some six million people.

The intensity of the rumour was such that not even the assurance by the national agency for food and drug administration could stem the public panic. "At present, no human being has been produced who took beans and died," the agency's director-general, Gabriel Osuide, was quoted as saying.

He, like other health officials, dismissed the rumour as baseless.

But the public continued to shun beans, causing sellers losses of some 400 million naira (about 50,000 U.S. dollars) in unsold stock of the staple.

It was at the heat of this controversy that Marwa and his officials took to the Lagos street and made a stop at the stall of an Akara seller.

Press photographers had a field day as the military officer and members of his entourage munched away, joined by an army of young men and women who ate up the cakes.

While the public awaits reports of a medical investigation of the beans saga, Marwa has identified the cause of the reported deaths as cholera, traced to a burst water pipe in Agege. The pipe had now been rectified, he said.

Even so, observers say it will take a while before the staple grain returns to its prominent slot on the Nigerian household menu, especially in the western part of the country.

An editorial by Lagos-based privately-owned 'Thisday' newspaper captured the national mood when it said: "It is particularly worrisome that anxious Nigerians have been left in the dark for so long, (thereby) fueling the current panic."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


415 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 26, 1996


Zimbabwe;
British Land Experts In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A Team of five British land experts are in Zimbabwe to identify ways in which the U.K. government can support the country's land re- distribution programme.

The team, that arrived in the country on Monday, will finish its work on Oct. 4, after which it will prepare a report.

A spokesman of the team, Martin Lowcock, told a press conference on Thursday that their terms of reference, as agreed between the British and Zimbabwean governments, were to assess the possibility of future British aid for land resettlement. 

The team has already spent most of its time visiting model resettlement schemes in Manicaland, Mashonaland West and Mashonaland east provinces of the southern African country.

It has also been looking at the farming systems and facilities that exist such as schools and clinics.

Lowcock said they had also had meetings with central and local government officials, teachers, health workers and communities.

"We have been impressed by the clear message we have received, especially from the settlers that their livelihoods now are considerably better than in their previous homes in the communal areas," he said.

"This reinforces other evidence, including major evaluation conducted by the British Overseas Development in 1988, that the resettlement programme of the 1980s was a considerable achievement."

More detailed discussions with government and other interested parties were still to take place.

"But on the basis of our work so far, we are confident that it should be possible to design a further programme aimed at reducing poverty in rural Zimbabwe through land reform which will justify funding by the British government and other interested donors," said Lowcock.

He said the mission envisaged a programme including land acquisition, which the British government could help fund on the basis of the willing seller, willing buyer principle.

"The principal objective of the programme would be the reduction of rural poverty. The scale and pace of the implementation would need to reflect the implementation capacity and other constraints faced by the relevant government and other institutions in Zimbabwe," he said.

Lowcock said the programme would need to have an acceptable economic rate of return, be cost effective and sustainable.

Zimbabwe requires more than five million hectares of land to settle millions of its landless people. The resettlement programme has been moving slowly since Zimbabwe attained independence in 1980 due to lack of funds, resources and manpower.

The British government and other donors stopped funding the programme when the government abandoned the willing seller, willing buyer scheme and enacted the land acquisition act of 1992 to designate and compulsorily acquire farms.

Only about 60,000 families have been resettled since independence after an initial target of 162,000.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


416 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 26, 1996


Liberia;
U.N. Food Agency Reaches Starving Liberians


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - After months of trying, the World Food Programme of the United Nations said Wednesday it had managed to reach previously inaccessible parts of Liberia's Cape Mount County where possibly thousands of hungry people are struggling to survive in the jungle.

"We saw many empty villages," said the agency's country director for Liberia, Arnt Breivik.

"The people we saw said that most of the population was hiding in the bush. They said they had no food, no medicine, nothing at all there." he said. 

Breivik's team saw about 1,200 people along the main road running through the county.

"The people we saw were in a bad state," he said.

A local nongovernmental organisation in the town of Single, a village of about 8,000 people, reported 403 deaths related to malnutrition since April.

World Food Programme officials estimate that 50,000 people lived in the area previously. Officials said thousands more will come out of hiding once word spreads that relief food had arrived.

The agency traveled to Cape Mount with a United Nations Inter-Agency team. They and personnel from nongovernmental organisations entered Cape Mount after months of negociations with rebel factions.

The agency's last made food deliveries to the area in December 1995. Since then, The county has been vitually cut off from international relief. Only 60 tons of food were airlifted to the country in March.

The U.N. inter-agency team traveled to within 10 miles of the Liberia- Sierra Leone border. Fighters from the ULIMO-J faction told the team to stop because of factional fighting along the road. The Liberian health minister also traveled with the convoy.

In a statement to PANA in Dakar, the World Food Programme said that clearance would be sought to bring food convoys into the area for direct distribution to the population on Friday. It said it would distribute food directly from food trucks along the main road in the country. The agency said it would, initially, give two-week food rations to the civilian population before assessing longer-term needs.

The agency is the largest international food aid organization in the world. In 1995, it fed at least 50 million people, including half of the world's refugees and internally displaced people.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


417 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 26, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia Closes Treason Case


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - State prosecutors Thursday closed the Zambian treason case involving six opposition political leaders after hearing testimony from the last state witness.

The Director of Public Prosecution, Gregory Phiri, told high court judge Peter Chitengi that the state was closing the case. Defence counsels have decided not to call any witnesses. 

Six members of the opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP), of former Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda, have been on trial since Aug. 15, on treason and murder charges.

The six, who have been in detention since June 2, have been linked to the clandestine Black Mamba group that has claimed responsibility for recent bomb blasts in the country.

Four of the accused have been further charged with the murder of a police bomb disposal expert, Ordon Banda. He died June 6 while trying to defuse the bomb allegedly planted by the four.

Police acting superintendent, Robinson Choka, who arrested the accused, denied in court Thursday that his superior, Crispas Siame, had ordered him to arrest the accused.

Siame, who was the head of the investigating team, told the court Wednesday that he had instructed Choka to arrest the accused.

However, under cross-examination Thursday by defence lawyer Edgar Lungu, Choka said Siame was lying.

Choka insisted that he had made his mind to arrest the accused after sufficient investigations.

The defence claimed that a senior police officer, who was heading the treason investigating team, was transfered to administration after he advised the police inspector general, in June, that there was insufficient evidence against the accused.

Choka said that he knew that the officer was transfered during the investigations, but said that he did not know why. He failed to tell the court whether or not it was normal to transfer an investigating boss when inquiries were still going on.

Forty-three state witnesses have testified during the 16 days that the high court sat to hear evidence. Among the key witnesses who gave the evidence were police inspector general Francis Ndhlovu and Zambia's mines minister, Keli Walubita.

State and defence lawyers were to make final submissions later Thursday.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


418 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 26, 1996


Ghana;
Ghana Stock Market Continues To Decline


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - Shares on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) extended previous session's steep decline Wednesday as the market's blue chips suffered another set-back on their share prices.

The GSE All-Share Index closed mid-week trading 2.77 points lower at 381.54 from Monday's opening figures of 384.31 points, as decliners outnumbered advancers by a margin of four to three.

Total volume of shares tumbled from the previous closing of 434,900 shares to close at a paltry 15,370 shares. 

Share offers, like in previous weeks, were higher than demand at 1,653,500 to 149,250 shares.

However, bids for AGC, FML and MGL, outnumbered offers giving dealers the impression that there might be an upward price change on their share prices.

Total market capitalisation made the third dip in a week, ending at 3,206, 96 billion cedis down from Monday's 3,256.84 billion cedis (One U.S. dollar = 1,696.5 cedis).

On the broader market, AGC, MOGL, PZ, and UNIL lost heavily. AGC lost 500 cedis to close at 29,000 cedis. This has been due to the unstable price movements on the London Exchange in recent times.

In London, gold was quoted at 383.25 dollars per ounce barely lower than its 383.30 dollars rate on Tuesday.

MOGL and PZ depreciated by 500 cedis and 10 cedis to end trading at 6,500 cedis and 370 cedis, respectively.

UNIL also lost seven cedis at 790 cedis, selling only 1,000 shares out of 21,900 offered.

The advancers were SSB which gained three cedis to end at 1,033 cedis and PTC which went up four cedis to close at 124 cedis.

The other market gainer was FML which appreciated by a cedi to close trading at 391 cedis.

Following were the last prices of listed equities at the close of business on Wednesday: ABL, 510 cedis; AGC, 29,000 cedis; CFAO, 22 cedis; EIC,430 cedis; FM, 391 cedis; GCB, 750 cedis; GGL, 243 cedis; HFC, 130 cedis; KBL, 650 cedis; MGL, 130 cedis; MLC, 49 cedis, MOGL, 6,500 cedis; PAF, 154 cedis; PTC, 124 cedis; PZ, 370 cedis; SCB, 5,500 cedis; SPPC, 111 cedis; SSB, 1,033 cedis; UNIL, 790 cedis and UTC - E 60 cedis.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


419 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 26, 1996


Gambia;
Gambians Vote For New President


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

BANJUL, Gambia - Gambians began voting Thursday, in crucial presidential polls to end just over two years of military rule.

The Provisional Independent Electoral Commission said some 444,182 registered voters were expected to cast ballots in 582 polling stations across this nation of some 956,600 people. 

They are to choose a president among candidates Sidia Jatta, Ossainou Darboe, Hamat Bah and military ruler Yahya Jammeh.

The winner will be decided by a simple majority.

Jammeh, who was recently promoted from army captain to colonel, has ruled this tiny West African nation since toppling President Dawda Jawara on July 22, 1994.

Jatta is the presidential candidate for the Peoples Democratic Organisation for Independence and Socialism (PDOIS). Jammeh heads the recently formed Alliance for Patriotic Reorientation and Construction (APRC). Darboe is the leader of the United Democratic Party (UDP) and Bah heads the National Reconciliation Party (NRP).

The presidential frontrunners are widely believed to be Jammeh and Darboe. Jammeh's government has implemented a number of high profile development projects since the 1994 coup.

Darboe, a lawyer, has defended ranking officials of Jawara's ousted government whom the military regime has charged with corruption. Many former politicians from other parties, including Jawara's banned Peoples Progressive Party, have rallied behind Darboe.

The campaign, which began September 9, has been marred by one incident of violence. This was when allegedly anti-Jammeh voters stoned his motorcade Sunday. Three people died and scores were injured.

However, in a radio address Wednesday, Jammeh appealed to Gambians to vote peacefully.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


420 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 26, 1996


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The government has declared the burial site for the national soccer team which perished off the coast of Gabon in an air disaster to be a national monument.

All the eleven choice players, the reserves, officials from the Football Association of Zambia, Zambia Air Force crew members and the lone journalist from the Zambia News Agency are now buried at a site near the Independence Stadium in Lusaka. 

The designation is according to a statutory instrument number 138 of 1996 under the National Heritage Conservation Commission Act which is contained in the latest Government Gazette and was signed by Tourism Minister, Gabriel Maka.

The site is to be known as the Football Heroes Burial Site to commemorate the gallant Zambia national football team and officials who died in a plane crash off the cost of Libreville on April 28, 1993.

Under the national heritage conservation commission act, Mr Maka has provisionally declared Lusaka thermal power station a national monument for six months.

The thermal power station is located along the Great East Road and consists of three boilers, three steam turbines with connected reduction gears and auxiliary equipment, buildings and other structures.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

September 26, 1996


Zambia;
Marathon Treason Trial Nears End As State Rests Case


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - The State this morning closed the treason case, involving six UNIP leaders among whom is Vice-President Inyambo Yeta, with the last witness testifying on how he decided to effect arrests of the accused persons after consulting other officers and not his superiors.

Police Superintendent - Criminal Investigations Department - Rabison Chooka, 40, of Mess 3, Mazabuka Police Camp, told High Court Judge Peter Chitengi that he made up his mind to arrest the accused after counsultation with Mr. Crispus Siame, the late Ordon Banda and other officers. 

Defence lawyer, Edgar Lunga, however, doubted Mr Chooka's claim since Mr. Siame told the court yestarday that it was him actually who instructed Mr. Chooka to arrest the accused. Mr. Chooka's earlier statement also agrees with this position.

Defence Counsel, Professor Patrick Mvunga, also quizzed him on how he decided to arrest Rabison Chongo when the statement by Winfred Mwale only mentioned him as being among the many churchmen and students who met at Dr. Kaunda's home in Kalundu.

"Is meeting at Kalundu treason?" asked Prof Mvunga.

"That is the way I took it when I read the report." Mr. Chooka replied.

Mr Sebastian Zulu, another defence counsel, also put it to him that a Mr. Singini, former Senior Assistant Commissioner for Crime, was transfered to a lower rank because he reported to the Inspector-General of Police, Francis Njovu, that the accused had not committed any crime going by the statements.

Mr Chooka replied that he was hearing it for the first time.

The case was adjourned to this afternoon for submissions after the prosecution announced that no more witness would be called, a move that cheered the defence.

Africa News


September 26, 1996


Zambia;
European Union Gives Zambia Helping Hand


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - The European Commission has donated 14 Land-Rovers to the National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) to revamp the development of sustainable wildlife management in Zambia.

Speaking at the official launching of the European development fund financed project on the development of sustainable wildlife management project in Chilanga today, head of EC delegation, Charles Brook said the project would create an opportunity to plan the future of the wildlife department's depleted resources.

He said the European Union and its member states were pleased to assist Zambia in one of its largest assets and greatest responsibilities - the wildlife resources, which he said was under the threat of depletion. 

The project launching and donation follows the signing of the financial agreement for an K8 billion programme between Zambia and the European Union three months ago.

"One of Zambia's largest assets and greatest responsibilities is the country's wildlife resources. We all know the depth of concerns which have frequently been expressed over the depletion of these resources", Mr Brook said and attributed this to factors like poaching and population growth.

"Partly it is poaching, partly population and agricultural encroachment and partly over-exploitation both by hunters and tourism activities. The result will eventually be a virtually lifeless desert of little or no beneffit to the remaining human population or the country as a whole", he said.

Officiating at the launching of the project and receiving the vehicles, Tourism Minister, Gabriel Maka said the donation will enhance the effective work programme for the department of NPWS.

"The donation of the 14 vehicles will go a long way in enhancing the work programme for the department of national parks and wildlife services", Mr Maka said.

He said the project the EU has embarked on was the biggest investment it has made in Zambia in the wildlife resources development and expressed confidence of continued co-operation, saying "I am confident that this is only the beginning of our co-operation".

The Minister said five vehicles would be used by management biologists in their research, two for anti-poaching in Kafue and Luame national parks, two by planning co-ordinators, another two by the planning unit, one each by NPWS director, the team leader of the project and the financial adviser.

He advised all users of the vehicles to properly maintain and use them for the purpose for which they were intended.

"A donation of this nature can only be appreciated if we satisfy the donors that the vehicles are used for the purpose for which they were intended. I am sure the donors too expect that the vehicles should run the full span of their expected life", Mr Maka said.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

September 26, 1996


Zambia;
Use Of Armed Police At Hospital Condemned


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The Resident Doctors Association (RDA) has condemned the move to deploy armed police at the University Teaching Hospital (UTH).

RDA also expressed displeasure at the failure of negotiations between the concerned parties. 

"This is creating undue animosity and is also a major source of apprehension and insecurity for staff and patients," RDA chairman, Dr Kachinga Sichizya, said yesterday. "Threats and counter threats will not solve the problem."

The move has also incensed nurses who were barred from entering the institution yesterday.

"We shall not allow anyone of us to be intimidated," a group of nurses found at the UTH entrance shouted.

Meanwhile, Zambia Nurses Association president, Olive Ng'andu, yesterday blamed the UTH board of management and the government for the on-going strike.

Ng'andu, however, denied earlier reports that she had condemned the strike action by her members.

"Nurses are committed to their professional ethics of caring for the sick but for them to react to such an extent it means they have been pushed far for too long," Ng'andu said. "But management and the government are too blame for waiting until the situation got out of hand."

General workers who joined the strike on Tuesday resumed work yesterday as a UTH "crisis committee" headed by acting executive director Dr Tuckson Lambert, met and shortlisted 17 names for questioning and by mid-day had already called six people.

And UTH public relations officer Don Mwape admitted the situation was still bad but disclosed that the hospital is recruiting part-time nurses.

"We are advertising for part-time nurses and volunteers," Mwape said. "We are also receiving a lot of help from Maina Soko Military Hospital and from the Red Cross."

Africa News


September 26, 1996


Zambia;
Student Group Demands Elections Date


BYLINE: Samson Mujuda and Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Lusaka - October 31 will mark the end of the MMD govern-ment's mandate and elections have to be held on or before that date, demanded the University of Zambia Students' Union (UNZASU) in a statement released in Lusaka yesterday.

UNZASU also demanded the immediate announcement of the date for the presidential and general elections.

"It's unfair for others to campaign in disguise while other stakeholders are wallowing in the dark," read in part a statement signed by UNZASU president Brian Yuyi and publicity secretary Shalala Oliver Sepiso. " Let's have a fair and even road to elections so as to uphold our democratic principles, ideals and morals." 

UNZASU charged that "it is utterly irresponsible and unfair to misinterpret the laws of Zambia in as far as the term of office of this government is concerned".

"The situation is very clear that 31st October will mark five years and elections have to be held on or before that date," the UNZSU statement further read. "Let's not hide under misinterpreted clauses that give unfair advantage to those already in power."

UNZASU also condemned the government's insistence that National Registration Cards (NRCs) will not be used for elections when that decision is supposed to be made by an independent Electoral Commission to be set up before this year's polls, as promised by President Chiluba.

"That is the preserve of the electoral commission and such sentiments should not be made by interested parties," UNZASU carped, demanding: "Once the new independent Electoral Commission is put in place, it should be left to work autonomously."

And UNZASU warned that it will use its power and influence to ensure that free and fair elections are held.

But Zambia Democratic Congress(ZDC) general secretary, Derrick Chitala, in an interview yesterday charged that the Electoral Amendment Bill of 1996 the government wants to introduce in Parliament is another law intended at making the electoral body partisan and was not consistent with what was agreed upon in the recent interparty talks with the ruling MMD.

"During the September 7 meeting we agreed that the commission was going to have seven members. We agreed that three members were going to be nominated by political parties, two nominated by NGOs and the other two from the judiciary," Chitala said. "But Article four of their Bill says 'the commission shall consist of the following members: a chairperson and not more than four other members, one of whom shall represent the ruling party and another the opposition parties'."

Chitala added: "The article also says the members shall be appointed by the President which makes the whole thing no better than the current situation."

Chitala also criticised the Bill for allowing current Electoral Commission members to continue for the next three months.

"The whole thing is just the same, all those people who are serving on the current electoral commission will still be there even at the election time," Chitala said. "According to article 17 of the Bill 'subsequent to other provisions of this Act, a person who immediately before the appointed date, held office as a member of the former commission, shall hold office as a member of the commission for a period'."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

September 26, 1996


Zambia;
Opposition Parties May Boycott Polls


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - UNIP will only participate in the elections when the contentious clauses are removed from the 1996 Constitution and the decision is made to use the 1991 Constitution, resolved the party's 31st national council held in Kabwe this week.

And Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) president Dean Mung'omba has also warned that his party will never go into an election knowing very well the electoral system is in a mess - it won't enter the "arena" if the Nikuv mess is not rectified.

UNIP publicity secretary, Bweendo Mulengela, at a press briefing in Lusaka yesterday said his party, which has stood against all forms of discrimination and has resolutely supported wars of liberation against racism and apartheid, cannot accept it in Zambia under the diabolical 1996 Constitution. 

The UNIP national council also resolved to support party president Kenneth Kaunda's candidature in the forthcoming presidential elections.

The 1996 Constitution is believed to disqualify Kaunda from standing.

"The position is to resolve the current political impasse and not have an intransigent position," Mulengela said, warning: " President Chiluba and his party will be responsible for the direction the nation takes thereafter."

Mung'omba told the Evelyn Hone College Press Club on

Tuesday night that though his party is fully prepared for the forthcoming presidential and parliamentary elections, they cannot pretend all is well with the Nikuv register when it's in a mess.

"It's football, if you are not comfortable with the referee to go on the pitch," Mung'omba said. "But we shall do our best to prepare for this election."

Mung'omba, however, feared the election may not legitimate if the MMD government decided to go ahead with it without making sure all stakeholders are happy with the system before polling day.

"An election can only be legitimate if all the stakeholders are happy, and the process is also legitimate, no one can ligitimatise an election, it has to be all the interested parties," Mung'omba said.

He said if the electoral process is legitimate, ZDC will accept defeat.

"Every competitor must accept the result, be it a win or loss it is a game," Mung'omba assured.

And UNIP secretary general Sebastian Zulu on Sunday's ZNBC television's Open Forum programme warned that his party will not accept the election results if issues on the electoral process were not ironed out.

Mulengela also disclosed that Kaunda will be holding a press conference today at which he will make major party pronouncements.

Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Players Envied In China


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - Former "Great" Zamsure players, Kabamba Kala-nde and Vesper Janza, who are currently plying their trade in the port city of Qingdao in China with premier division side Sea Bull FC, are said to be curving out an enviable niche for themselves and clubs there are now cla-mouring to sign on Zambian players.

According to the press attache at the Chinese Embassy in Lusaka, Yang Xiaokun, the duo who have featured in more than ten league games so far, have captured the imagination of the normally conservative Chinese soccer fans and helped push Sea Bull to the summit of the Chinese premier league. 

"They (the duo) are the key players for Sea Bull football club," an excited Yang said in an exclusive interview yesterday. "Kalande combines well with Janza and they are definitely the star players of the club."

Yang also hinted that the duo's contracts, which are scheduled to expire at the end of October, could just be extended.

Kabamba, normally plays as a libero and was regularly a member of the national team winning some caps at last year's All Africa Games in September with the national under-23 side, while Janza is terror on the wings though he is yet to win a call-up to the national team.

"They have proved that Zambian players are very good. There is a possibility that their contracts might be re-newed," Yanga said, adding: "As a matter of fact, alot of Chinese clubs want to recruit Zambian players."

Yang also reveleaved that the "dynamic duo" have been given an interpreter each "to help them in their day-to-day life".

"However, they have no difficulties on the pitch as you know football is a universal language," he said.

September 26, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Members of the delegation of the House of Peoples' Representatives currently on a visit to Germany met and held talks with the Ethiopian community in that country, German Radio reported.

The delegation visiting Germany upon the invitation of the Federal council of Germany gave briefings to Ethiopians on the prevailing political, economic and social situations in Ethiopia.

During talks at the Ethiopian Embassy, the delegation presided over by Ato Eshetu Kebede, Chairman of the Economic Affairs Standing Committee, discussed with community members political and economic questions in Ethiopia, the radio said.

The radio quoted Ethiopian Ambassador to Germany, Dr. Behanne Tensay, as saying Ethiop-German bilateral cooperations have further been consolidated and added the government of Germany is extending broader support in the political, educational, tourism and economic development sectors. 

=================

Authority says tank truck deployment becomes more effective

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Road Transport Authority announced here yesterday that the lifting of the tariff control and its determination by the market has enabled tank truck owners to distribute fuel to areas which had previously been beyond their reach. This, it said, is indicative of the fact that tank truck deployment has been more effective than it was before the deregulation.

Ato Kasahun Haile-Mariam, acting head of trucks and truck drivers department in the authority, said 223 tank trucks have transported fuel from the Port of Assab to different regions across the country.

With the tariff control system there was hardly any truck intending to go to Gondar as the result of which there was serious shortage of fuel there, the official said, adding now 28 trucks with trailers have travelled to the area since the decision that the tariff should be negotiated between the truck owners and distributors.

Wollo, part of the Amhara Regional State also gets ten trucks of fuel daily through the Ethiopian Petroleum Corporation, he said.

According to the official, no disagreements have surfaced so far between truck owners and distributors on the issue of transportation cost.

The price of fuel in Ethiopia is the lowest as compared to that of many countries in the world, it was reported.

=================

ALFP issues four-point resolution

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Afar Liberation Front Party (ALFP), announced that it has passed a four-point resolution following a meeting it held in Addis Ababa.

In a statement it issued here yesterday at the end of an eight-day meeting, the front said the resolution mainly focused on further promoting the over- all development activities in the region.

The statement said that the Front has taken measures that would help ensure the existence of the party by rooting out the differences among its executive committee members.

It said the party will call a general meeting in the very near future to help further strengthen itself at kebele and central levels.

The party will contribute its share and actively work towards the rapid development of the Afar Region thereby helping extricate the public from economic backwardness.

The party will make maximum effort to put into practice the rural centered five-year development programme , the statement said.

=================

Lack of service jeopardises medical service in the country: Physician

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The ministry of Health sad Tuesday lack of service and timely maintenance work on life-saving medical equipment has paralysed the over-all medical service in the country.

Health service department head, Dr. Mathewos Wkbulcho said several X-ray, laboratory and other relevant medical apparatus have gone idle for years due to lack of timely maintenance.

He said the Ministry needs skilled manpower in the field so as to provide adequate service to the people.

He told a six-week training organized for scientific and medical equipment technicians that health institutions could provide dependable health service to the community only when the idle laboratory and X-ray machines are repaired and made ready for use.

Dr. Mathows said the National Scientific Equipment Centre, the organizer of the training, should work hand inglove with the Ministry in a bid to mitigate existing shortage throughout the country of medical equipment technicians.

It was noted that the aim of the training was to strengthen regional and institutional capability on the repair and servicing of medical equipment.

Some 20 individuals with diplomas in electronics are attending the training programme,. it was reported.

==================

Wonji nets 25 million birr

NAZARETH (ENA) - The Wonji-shoa Sugar Factory has obtained a 25 million birr net profit during the previous fiscal year, the acting general manager of the factory said.

Ato Solomon Baraki said despite plans to produce 748,000 quintals of sugar, it has produced 725,000 due to muddy roads which hindered the activity of the factory.

He, however, said that the quantity produced last Ethiopian year is more than that of the preceding due to increased productivity on the plantations.

Ato Solomon added that the factory has plans to obtain 30 million birr in profit by producing 782,000 quintals this year.

Preparations have been finalized to distribute the production of the Matahra and Wonji sugar factories in 18 major towns throughout the country, he noted.

=================

Enterprise to harvest 90,000 quintals of seeds

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - About 90,000 quintals of seed is expected to be harvested from 4,770 hectares of land of the bale Agricultural Development Enterprise, the general a manager predicted.

Ato Abebe Gobeze said about 35-40 quintals of seed can be harvested from a hectare to be distributed among farmers in Bale Zone to help increase agricultural production.

The general manager said over 63,000 quintals of select seeds were produced during the past production year from the farmlands of the enterprise.

=================

Embezzled money retrieved

DEBRE MARKOS (ENA) - Nearly 878,000 of the total 5.2 million birr which reported was embezzled from many farmers' service cooperatives in East Gojjam Zone of the Amhara Regional State has now gone to safe while charges were levelled against the remaining embezzlers, a monitoring office of the cooperatives announced.

Ato Zemenay Menelik, head of the office, said task forces set up at zonal and woreda levels have helped the return of the money taken from 157 cooperatives.

He said his office has used 586 people while more charges are to be levelled against 1,794 others.

He added the office has plans to strengthen 44 cooperatives and reestablish two others this year, adding of the total 183 cooperatives in the zone, some have weakened and others dissolved.

Africa News


September 27, 1996


United States and Africa;
United States Adamant Boutros-Ghali Must Go


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The United States of America is sticking to its

position of ousting the current United Nations Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, despite him receiving favorable support from some members of the U.N Security Council.

Speaking to reporters soon after he had a lengthy closed meeting with President Robert Mugabe on Friday, the U.S. Assistant Secretary for African Affairs, George Moose, said the Bill Clinton administration was not going to change its decision to replace Boutros-Ghali.

"The U.N. will have to play a more critical role worldwide and this is going to be more than now, and to do that, it needs a leadership that is not only able to run the organization but to deal with critical issues such as civil strife...

"...it was on that basis that we took that decision (not to endorse his candidature to run for the second term of office)," Moose said. He did not disclose who the U.S. had in mind to replace Boutros-Ghali. 

Washington D.C. is accusing Boutros-Ghali of failing to run the world body effectively and failing to deal with critical issues such as civil strife but observers have taken it to be a racial issue.

Moose said his visit to Zimbabwe was part of an ongoing process between the U.S. and African governments to help African organizations such as the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and the Southern African Development Community (SADC) maintain peace and stability and to develop the capacity to deal with problems that affect the continent.

"We want to help them develop a capacity to prevent crisis such as the Burundi one and to ensure that they have the ability to deal with the crisis through good response," he said.

Moose said his talks with President Mugabe had also centered on regional peace and development.

He said the two did not reach any agreement on what type of assistance the U.S. would provide to Zimbabwe to maintain peace and stability.

The meeting was attended by U.S. army and navy officials, Ambassador Johnie Carson, Vice-President Simon Muzenda, Defence minister Moven Mahachi, among other military officials.

Zambia;
Zambian Nurses Continue Strike Over Pay Rise


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Authorities at Lusaka's main University Teaching Hospital (UTH) on Friday, placed advertisements in local newspapers for part-time nurses to fill the vacuum left by some 800 nurses who have been on strike since last week, over a pay rise. 

The UTH public relations officer, Don Mwape, told PANA on Friday that part- time workers were being sought to alleviate the workload for senior staff and other volunteers currently manning the various medical services.

Some military medical personnel, the Red Cross and other volunteers were earlier this week mobilized to join senior personnel at the hospital.

The nurses are demanding a general pay rise, better housing, shift and uniform allowances.

Africa News


September 27, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa To Sell Arms To Rwanda


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa has decided to go ahead with arms sales to the central African state of Rwanda, following last week's visit to the country by Rwandan Vice-President Paul Kagame.

During the visit, Kagame, who is also the defence minister, met with Deputy President Thabo Mbeki and Foreign Minister Nzo to discuss the troubled situation in his country and neighbouring Burundi. 

The National Conventional Arms Control Committee--which includes several South African cabinet ministers, and was specially formed to handle such matters--met in Pretoria Thursday and decided to give the green light for the sale of what it described as defensive arms to the government of Rwanda.

Committee chairman Kader Asmal emphasized that Rwanda's neighbouring states had been consulted on the matter. They had supported the proposal in the belief that it would assist the Rwandan Government to address the security threat it was facing.

There had also been consultations with the United Nations. Asmal said the decision by his committee was in line with the United Nations decision to lift the arms embargo against the Rwandan government from the beginning of September--but not the one against non-government forces.

The embargo was introduced in 1994, when a three-month civil war resulted in the massacre of more than half-a-million people.

Latest reports indicate that tension has been rising between Rwanda and Zaire, because of the presence of Rwandan Hutus in Zairean refugee camps, and armed bands of Tutsis from Rwanda operating in Zaire. The two groups have been clashing for several weeks in the mountainous northern part of Zaire, near the border with Burundi.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 27, 1996


Sudan;
12 People Killed In Ethnic Fighting In Western Sudan


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Ethnic clashes in western Sudan's Darfur region has left 12 persons dead and many families homeless, an privately-owned Sudanese daily reported Friday.

Al-Wan, a newspaper sympathetic with the government, said a group of the Arab Rizigat ethnic nomads attacked the Zagawah, in retaliation for a previous raid on a Rizigat village. An unspecified number of people were killed.

The recent clashes took place at Um-Kadada, an area in north Darfur. The newspaper reported that the attackers used guns against the Zagawah. It did not say when the battle occurred.

Police units were deployed in the area and the situation the has now been brought under control.

The Darfur region has been the scene of various ethnic clashes which intensified after the 1985 drought that hit most of the sub-Sahara Africa.

As most tribes in the region are nomads, fighting around grazing and water areas have become common.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


432 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwean Traditional Healers Fight HIV/AIDS


BYLINE: Chemist Mafuba, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Traditional healers in Zimbabwe are going all out in the fight against the deadly AIDS.

More than 200 traditional medicines have been collected for testing by the Zimbabwe regional drug control laboratory, and 95 percent of them have shown to be useful medicines, says Professor Gordon Chavunduka, president of the Zimbabwe National Traditional Healers Association.

In his annual report, Chavunduka says that a total of 80 HIV-positive patients between 18 and 45 years took traditional medicines administered by four association members over a period of 10 months. The 50,000-member association has 317 branches in 83 districts. 

According to Chavunduka, these tests showed that some traditional remedies can, in fact, remove or reverse AIDS symptoms.

A large number of medicines were collected, extracted and analyzed with the assistance of a research institute in the United States, and 10 percent of them showed some protection against the effects of the HIV/AIDS virus on human blood cells.

American scientists recommended that some of these traditional remedies be developed further as potential drugs for the treatment of AIDS.

Pure compounds from some of the plants which had shown to have active principles against AIDS were identified and isolated.

This prompted the association to apply for patent protection in Zimbabwe and also a number of countries since the association now has potential drugs for the treatment of AIDS.

It is carrying out small pilot studies using these compounds, and patients who are taking them are showing great improvement in the quality of their health.

Health and child welfare minister Timothy Stamps has praised the work which the association has been doing to fight AIDS.

Many of the traditional healers are often the first to be consulted when people have health and other social problems.

It is, therefore, important that they receive adequate information about HIV/AIDS so that they may advise their patients correctly, says Stamps.

Being influential members in their societies, he adds, traditional healers must therefore use their influence and prestige to change people's sexual behavior.

One area they could help, he says, is by re-examining such customs as polygamy and widow inheritance because of the dangers of AIDS.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


433 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Gambia;
Jammeh Leading In Presidential Polls


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

BANJUL, Gambia - The incumbent Gambian president, Yahya Jammeh, is leading in the country's presidential elections held on Thursday, according to provisional results released by the Electoral Commission on Friday.

The commission said Jammeh polled 126,073 votes from 34 of the 45 constituencies, compared to his closest rival, Ossainou Darboe, who obtained 89,833 votes. 

But a panel of poll watchers featured on Gambia radio have expressed surprise at Jammeh's performance, especially in Banjul, where he took 61.84 percent of the vote as against Darboe's 33.95 percent.

The panelists did not rule out the possibility of Jammeh, who seized power in a military coup July 22, 1994, winning the highly populated Serekunda east and west, which together with Bakau, have 83,839 registered voters.

The panelists views were influenced by Jammeh's unexpected performance in Bakau, where he received 41.92 percent of the votes in an area where people usually vote against incumbents. Darboe won 54.35 percent of the votes here.

Jammeh's highest score was in Brikama, his stronghold, where he got 66.33 percent of the votes, compared with 27.72 percent for Darboe. Two other candidates who ran for president won very few votes.

Full results are expected later Friday, when the candidate who secures a simple majority of all votes cast will be declared the winner.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


434 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Sports - General;
Rugby: Winning Show From Losing Teams


BYLINE: Jon Swift, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Johannesburg - It is perhaps one of the supreme ironies that so often mark man's sporting endeavours, that the nub of last weekend's rugby came from the performances of two sides on the wrong end of the final scoreboard.

For, while Natal held out Transvaal 37-36 to stay top of Section A and Northern Transvaal duly ran out 27-16 winners over Western Province, there was much to be acclaimed and admired in the performances of both losing sides.

Both marked a turning point in application and attitude from teams who have had a tough year of it thus far, sharing disappointing campaigns in the Super 12, battling through almost unprecedented injury lists and struggling to get into gear in the Currie Cup.

For Pienaar's Transvaal, the resurgence could not have come at a more critical time with the selection panel's eyes on the coming tours to Argentina and France as the province which provides the nucleus of the Springbok side came good in all but the eventual result. 

It was a stirring fight-back in the second half that was as much a part of the greatness that the game can produce as Andre Joubert's superb hat-trick of tries for Natal.

Pienaar led, as he always does, with his body on the line and, aided by a truly monster game from the giant Kobus Wiese, the Transvaal pack finally produced the fire they are capable of.

Fritz van Heerden's Province side too were far from disgraced against a Northerns side which has re-established the winning pattern of simplicity before spread that the late Buurman van Zyl turned into such an artform.

It is true that while there will always have to be winners, the true mark of the health of rugby in this country is the gap between the eventual scorelines. In these two instances at least, this was true.

And while there must be cause for some relief at the South African Rugby Football Union's offices over these two results, there must equally be some concern over the monster 113-11 win Free State recorded over a hapless South Western Districts.

In the former encounters, there lay all that is good in the Currie Cup system - hard, committed play, skill, flair and adventure - in the latter all that is inherently unbalanced in the present set-up.

When the fact that Free State missed the Super 12 is taken into account, the new-look boys from Bloem have managed to do in their own backyard what has evaded Transvaal and Western Province on a more global platform.

But there will have to be a hard look at the ethos professionalism has introduced to the remnants of a system that must, by its very nature, leave sides like South Western Districts as whipping boys.

To produce a combination capable of consistently taking on the bigger unions, there has to be a better and more equitable spread of resources. It is impossible for the men from Oudtshoorn to be expected to match the megabucks at Ellis Park.

One would suspect that, in the age of the electronic spectator, the idea that the late Doc Craven fought so hard for - that of getting the big name sides and players to the lesser-known venues - no longer really holds water.

It is all very well holding the local side dear to one's heart, but laying out good money to watch yet another weekend whipping, when the beer at home is cold, the couch comfortable and the confrontation on offer more appealing, has proved to be another.

It would be a sad day if these representative sides were to disappear altogether. They have every much a right to pride and tradition - and it might be added playing Free State -as any other.

Perhaps Sarfu should examine more closely the system which has kept American football competitive in a professional era; one where the teams are traded and sold as franchises rather than regional fixtures.

The Americans rely on a draft system to smooth out imbalances. This allows for the team which finishes last to have first choice of the new players coming through or even to barter that choice for another.

In this way, the lesser sides are able to build whatever strengths they own by filling in the gaps in their make-ups with real talent. The players are able to command big money on their way into the game and free to move on when the initial contract has been fulfilled.

In a South African rugby-playing context, the major centres - with major budgets - are already able to do this, slotting in players almost at will, given the incentives they can offer.

A draft system would, however, enable more and more young players to find their way into the Currie Cup competition. Those who make it able to move to the bigger, better- paying unions, those who don't, welcome to finish their careers in the lesser sides.

And it will certainly go some way towards producing the kind of performances from losing sides evident last weekend.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 27, 1996


Arts;
South Africa: Soccer's 'Big Guns' Shooting From The Lip


BYLINE: Andrew Muchineripi, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Johannesburg - It had to happen at some point. With so many commissions doing the rounds in the new South Africa at the moment, it was only a matter of time before the soccer world had its own.

The Pickard Commission into irregularities in soccer administration has been around for the past few months, but things are only starting to hot up now, as the main players start to flex their muscles. Judging by the way matters are developing at the moment it is clear that the gloves are off as South Africa's soccer administrators battle for supremecy, and already mud is starting to fly. 

The findings of the commission, which was instituted by Minister of Sport and Recreation Steve Tshwete, are to be presented to President Nelson Mandela, and it is sure to change the face of soccer in this country.

On the one side there is the South African Football Association (Safa) led by its executive president Solomon "Stix" Morewa, and supported by his childhood friend, Kaizer Chiefs boss Kaizer Motaung. A man never keen to shy away from publicity, Morewa has been out of the public eye for longer than he would like - since the country won the Nations Cup in February.

On the other side of the "struggle" is the National Soccer League (NSL) from whom Morewa is receiving opposition in a more collective form, with Jomo Sono, managing director of Jomo Cosmos, and Irvin Khoza, head of Orlando Pirates, at the helm. They are backed by, among others, Veli Mahlangu, Raymond Hack and Sundowns "Iron Lady" Nastasia Tschiclas.

The amazing twist in the story is that the two organisations share offices at the FNB Stadium, home of South African soccer, and the officials at loggerheads basically have to pass each other on a daily basis.

In soccer circles over the years it has been common knowledge that a "cold war" exists between certain officials, but it has always been a matter to which everybody, including the media, has been quite conveniently turning a blind eye.

In fact, it has become part of the game in a country where more is seen and heard of the exploits of the officials running the game than the people who actually make the sport, the players.

But at the current centre of the storm is Safa's marketing wing, Awesome Sport International (ASI), to which Morewa's organisation has been accused of selling its biggest asset - football.

ASI's managing director Brian Mahon has yet to appear before the commission and has for some reason not been forthcoming despite numerous appeals by commission chairman Judge Benjamin "Bobby" Pickard.

So far, evidence has mainly been heard on the misuse of the Safa trust fund, which was supposed to benefit players but has, as Pickard put it, "been benefiting the employees of Safa and their families".

Among those who received money from the trust fund are Kaizer Chiefs football club, which received R10 000, Morewa himself, who was awarded a R3 000 bursary to, as Safa's vice-president Molefi Olifant put it, "do a diploma" .

A journalist also received R1 500 from the fund, something which interested Pickard who said that the reason he was so keen to learn more about this particular matter was that he had heard allegations of journalists "being bought" to ensure favourable publicity for certain soccer officials.

The hearings resumed again on Thursday after a break of a week.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


436 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Stars Can Sparkle Again In Cup Semifinal


BYLINE: Andrew Muchineripi, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Johannesburg - With no Premier League fixtures scheduled for this weekend, all attention will be focused on the Coca-Cola Cup, formerly known as the JPS Cup, which reaches the semi-final stage.

Out of the four sides that have reached this stage of the competition, two - QwaQwa Stars (1994) and Bush Bucks (1993) - have already won the trophy, and both have home ground advantage against their opponents this weekend.

Stars host Sundowns on Saturday and Bucks, conquerors of Orlando Pirates in the previous round, host Supersport United, who did the job against Kaizer Chiefs in the previous round to earn their place in the last four. Supersport are attempting to win their first trophy since being taken over by pay channel M-Net's sports wing, Supersport. 

It has been a bit of an up-and-down season for Mike Mokoena's men from Qwa Qwa, who slumped badly after a good start to the 1996 campaign - they reached the final of the BP Top 8 competition, which they lost to Orlando Pirates. Since then, their form took a major and inexplicable slump, which fortunately seems to be over now.

They should start Saturday's game against the Brazilians as favourites. Stars have beaten Sundowns twice so far this season, 4-0 in the BP Top 8 semifinal, and then 2-1 in the Coke Challenge.

But both those victories were in the pre-Reinhard Fabisch days, and the German coach seems to have instilled a new sense of motivation and confidence in the players who have been shoved around quite a bit this season. In the previous round they needed a penalty shoot-out to oust Jomo Cosmos

Sundowns are also the only "big name" club still left in this competition which has a history of tilting the balance toward the smaller guns.

Stars advanced to the semi-finals without scoring a goal in the previous round, they left that to their opponents, Wits, who scored three times, but still lost the game.

They beat them 2-1, with the Students scoring all the goals on the night, defenders Gordon Ewen and Kevin Rafferty suffering the embarrassment of putting the ball into their own net.

Stars coach Peter Nyama will obviously miss the skills of Zairean forward Emeka Mamale, who has embarked on a new career in the Far East, this after going Awol a few months ago.

But Stars, holding the player's clearance, appealed to Fifa and the Korean club where Mamale was on trial was forced to pay Stars a substantial amount - said to be more than a R1-million - for the player.

They have in the past had the ability to aquire players that the bigger clubs seem to miss, a perfect example being another Zairean Bunene Ngaduane who led Stars to the 1994 Coke Cup title. Realising the ability of Stars managing director Mokoena to unearth these gems, other clubs did the next best thing, they waited at the airport and poached the players en route to the Free State! So these days, Bra Mike waits for his players at the airport.

Supersport United face the daunting task of travelling to Umtata to face a resurgent Bush Bucks side on their cabbage patch pitch at the Independence Stadium in front of around 30 000 partisian home fans.

There is little doubt that Supersport MD Terry Paine is not relishing the trip, despite the fact that the last time these two sides met it was Supersport that ran out 4-0 winners at the Odi Stadium. The Pretoria-based side has improved leaps and bounds under their new owners, and has exceeded even their expectations.

Over the next few years United will undoubtedly become a force in African soccer judging by the way the club is run and the professional way players are treated.

Bucks beat Orlando Pirates on penalties in the previous round and were quite outstanding in doing so, despite the fact that it was a tired Pirates that opposed them on the day.

Although they start the game as favourites, the last time they played a semi-final game at that venue, in the BP Top 8 Cup, they were beaten by Pirates.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 27, 1996


Sports - General;
Cricket: Skipper's Hand Needed At Helm In South Africa


BYLINE: Jon Swift, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Johannesburg - It is a tough enough task which faces the national cricket team this summer, and the news that skipper Hansie Cronje starts the international season less than fully fit makes that task even tougher.

Thankfully, Cronje's injury is nothing more serious than a strained ligament in his left hand, but it does raise the thought that the South African cricket side has relied as heavily on Cronje's presence as on his cerebral yet joyous brand of captaincy.

It is hard to believe that Cronje has only just turned 27, so great has his on-and-off- field maturity showed itself to be.

It has been noted more than once over the past few seasons of this country's journey back from the Outer Hebrides of the days of isolation that the national side has always leaned firmly on guts and determination. And while there can be no question that the South Africans will always be a difficult team to beat, it is as a team that they have played the game rather than as an assembly of individual stars. 

One would tend to question parts of that assumption. We have, in many areas of the game, individuals to match if not better the names the rest of the world can offer. But in one area the argument remains a very valid one.

They have, in analysis, continued to provide the unassailable truth that cricket, imbued though it may be with a vast array of skill essential to playing the game at top level, remains a team effort.

In this respect, we have been extremely lucky in being able to call on the experience of first Clive Rice, then Kepler Wessels and now Cronje.

Rice, one still feels, got a raw deal after leading the team out of isolation. But it was Wessels, regardless of what his critics continue to say, who single-mindedly drove the side to new heights.

Yes, he had a dour and unspectacular captaincy style. But you cannot deny his fighting abilities. Or, for that matter, the spirit and self-belief he hammered into a group of players, many of whom had never been further north than Centurion Park or further east than St George's Park.

Along with him went Cronje, captain of Free State at 21 and learning from Wessels every step of the way. He embraced all that was good in his mentor ... and then grafted on to that a youthful exuberance and sheer inner feeling for the game that marked him as something special when the mantle of leadership passed to him.

What all that leads up to is the fact that, while we have a wealth of young talent just bursting to come through, there is no one at present ready to take over the reins from Cronje at the helm.

Craig Matthews is the vice-captain and a vastly experienced skipper at provincial level, and only the foolish would begin to believe that he has no capabilities as a skipper. But there is the nagging thought that, as one of the veterans of the team, the opportunity leading to the happy circumstance which elevated Cronje to the hot-seat so young is not evident in this case.

Doubtless Matthews will be the man to lead the South Africans in the "one or two games" Ali Bacher is confident is all Cronje will have to sit out on the tour to Kenya which starts with the hosts playing would champions Sri Lanka in Nairobi this Saturday.

This means that Matthews will lead the side onto the field against Pakistan on Sunday and probably once again against Sri Lanka next Tuesday, without any shadow of doubt, the two toughest games in the quadrangular tournament.

Should Cronje's problems persist, there is also the looming spectre of a gruelling tour to the Indian sub-continent which follows just a week after the end of the Kenyan safari on October 7.

This starts with an unenviable round of six one-day internationals in a triangular series involving India and Australia, with the possibility of a seventh should the side make the final on November 6. And then straight into a three-test series against the Indians, with matches at Ahemadebad(check??), Calcutta and Kanpur to think about with only a week's break before the Indians arrive in this country for a mirror image series.

There is, given a glance at this arduous schedule, some room for fervent prayer that Cronje's injury is as slight as the authorities say it is. We need him as a player... and even more so as a captain.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 27, 1996


Arts;
Book Review: Story Of A Priest's Partisan Life


BYLINE: Anthony Egan, SJ, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Johannesburg - MICHAEL LAPSLEY - PRIEST AND PARTISAN: A SOUTH AFRICAN JOURNEY by Michael Worsnip (Ocean Press, R69,99)

Conventional boundaries between the genres of political and religious biography take something of a tumble in this generally excellent new book by theologian and church historian Michael Worsnip. His subject is Father Michael Lapsley, priest of the Society of the Sacred Mission, an Anglican religious order. Lapsley is also a member of the African National Congress (ANC) and one of a few survivors of a death-squad assassination attempt.

A New Zealander by birth, Lapsley came to South Africa as a young monk in the early 1970s,was soon elected national chaplain to Anglican university students, was exposed to the harsh apartheid realities of the times and, although still a committed pacifist (as a schoolboy even refusing to do cadets!), was deported from South Africa after the 1976 students' uprising. 

Moving to Lesotho, he worked among university students in Roma (including young South African exiles) and with Anglican ordinands. He also joined the ANC, having come to the conclusion that pacifism in South Africa did not work. His work as spokesperson for the ANC became a source of tension for his church and religious order, and he was eventually moved from Lesotho.

After much discussion, often heated, he was allowed to move to the recently independent Zimbabwe, where he tried to combine pastoral ministry, graduate studies and ANC work. Controversy followed him - a dispute with the then bishop (Peter Hatendi) and his sharply critical account of Anglican " neutrality" under the Ian Smith regime made him unpopular in some circles.

He worked for the ANC mission and the Lutheran World Federation in Zimbabwe until 1990 when, on April 28, a bomb concealed in a magazine sent to him by an alleged comrade blew off both his hands and blinded him in the right eye. He recovered, returning to South Africa to work in Cape Town with the blessing of Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who in early 1990 had strongly supported the Anglican synod's decision not to allow priests to be members of political parties. Lapsley currently works as the chaplain to the trauma centre at Cowley House in Cape Town.

Within the framework of such a life, Lapsley's biographer weaves a fascinating and moving account of what it meant to be a Christian priest within a liberation movement. Since Worsnip himself was for a while an exile in Lesotho, where he secretly joined the ANC and was later also ordained an Anglican priest, and is a good friend of Lapsley, one might describe the author's approach to his subject in the anthropological terminology of a " participant observer". This common ground both gives the book its depth and perhaps explains some of its weaknesses.

Worsnip has a clear, and partisan, view of church politics. He has no doubts as to the inevitable and even natural links between religion and politics. He and his subject share the same broad theological and political positions: both are adherents of the theology of liberation, which asserts that Christians should take the side of the poor and oppressed and work for a just, more equal distribution of power and wealth in human society.

Similarly, they see the local church as a basic unit of the religious community, whose interests should take precedence over the hierarchical structures of the church if a conflict of interests arises.

This reviewer would share this opinion,but the problem is that Worsnip perhaps takes it for granted that his readers both understand these presuppositions and/or endorse them. From his tone, it is clear Worsnip is also trying to advocate such a position in the course of his biographical narrative. It is a pity that he doesn't state his case more overtly. This is but one broad example of an instance where advocacy (and I do believe that Worsnip is advocating a theological- political position throughout) is weakly handled. Other issues that deserved attention include the Christian "just war" tradition and the question of a priest's partisan political alignment.

Alternatively, Worsnip's position vis-a-vis Lapsley also gives us helpful insights into Lapsley's personality and ultimately his faith. Worsnip manages to represent the realities and difficulties of being a monk today in a way a secular biographer might find difficult.

The nature of religious life, with its paradoxical - and to some people slightly weird - vows of poverty,chastity and obedience, is presented realistically. A vowed monk or nun is not (or at least shouldn't be) a kind of "otherworldly superbeing" or even the comic parody of popular media, but a real person, with weaknesses and fears and strengths like the rest of humanity. This certainly is the picture one gets of Michael Lapsley.

Religious readers may also pick up from this book the elements of a spirituality, a way of living out a faith commitment. It is one which articulates a "service of faith and promotion of justice" (to borrow the terms of a 1975 document of the Roman Catholic Jesuit order) and, highly relevant to South Africa today, one that focuses on notions of repentance, truth and reconciliation. Amid much pie-in-the-sky dross that often gets presented as spirituality, this will be truly refreshing.

Much more could be said about Michael Lapsley -Priest and Partisan. More needed to be said about Lapsley - perhaps an autobiography is still in order. Despite its weaknesses, Worsnip has written a really engaging, readable and at times deeply provocative book that deserves a wide readership beyond the " politico" and "religious" circles.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


439 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Arts;
Television: Where The Heart Isn't


BYLINE: Bafana Khumalo, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Johannesburg - I did a double take when I watched the first episode of Homeland, the SABC3 drama series: there on screen, prime time SABC, was a relatively graphic depiction of a drunken white man raping a black woman. Here seemed to be a groundbreaking series that was going to force us, as a nation, to confront our past in all its ugliness.

This view still remains, but I am no longer sure how the makers have stayed true to exposing us as we truly are. By the end of that episode I was of the opinion that maybe this is all just about the rehabilitation of our image. This rehabilitation seems to say that most white people in this country never complied with the apartheid machinery, that we were all merely victims of an outside system. 

I feel awkward about the three main characters - the people whose experiences one identifies with throughout the series. These three are a government of national unity: one white English-speaking lad who ends up within the the murderous bosom of the SADF, one Afrikaans lad who discovers the power of the pen in the just war of human rights, and, the final member of our nightmare trio, one black lad whose lot leads him to the training camps from whence he will try to right all the wrongs of our society.

In essence there is nothing wrong with this depiction, as each member neatly represents a sector of our society. It's just that it's precisely the neatness of it all that makes it awkward for me. It's the kind of neatness that makes the character who ends up in the SADF appear to be an essentially nice guy who somehow got caught up in the madness. He is the one that defends the black protagonist from the abuses of other whites.

The Afrikaans activist is perhaps the most profound of the lot - maybe the makers felt that in real life the Afrikaner is the one most in need of rehabilitation. From his mouth pearls of wisdom flow: "If you treat somebody differently because of the colour of the skin, God will punish your soul." This is directed at a racist uncle who is treating the black friend with contempt. And when he is sent to bed without supper, he replies: "Even if I never have another meal in my life, at least my soul won't go hungry." Too neat. Too clean. Too profound. Coming from the mouth of this babe, the words are way too wise. Even the black character is just too perfect. He discovers The Communist Manifesto at the age of 10 and devours it voraciously. It must take some ability to be able to decipher, at that age, what surely ranks as some of the most turgid writing in history - especially in your second language.

Maybe I'm being petty, but I found the cliched character a bit too much to stomach. He finally decides that he is going to leave the country - at age 10 - and here the makers of the series could not resist sprinkling it with a dash of Hollywood as the three children meet for the last time and say their goodbyes.

The surprising thing - perhaps it is showing the ironic contradictions of life, but I doubt it - is that the child who ends up being a state terrorist is the one who is most distraught at the departure of his black friend.

We watch as the camera pulls back to reveal a look of frustration on his face, his voice echoing through the woods as he screams his friend's name. A significant part of me is hoping that 10 episodes on I am not going to be confronted by the character explaining that he got involved in cross border raids because the childhood trauma of losing his friend left him permanently damaged. While the script does work at times, what I find most problematic is that it seems embarrassed to show us who and what we really are. Instead of saying that it represents a particular, subjective perspective - a liberal view in the nicest sense of the word - it bills itself as the whole truth, the only truth and nothing but the truth.

But the thing is that there are as many different truths out there as there are people.

Homeland is on SABC3 on Wednesdays at 8.30pm


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
