Africa News


September 27, 1996


Ethiopia;
Health is Cornerstone of Social Development (Editorial)


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele, Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Addis Ababa - The World Health Organization (WHO) considers health as both a goal and a means of achieving social development. Health is inseparable from economic and social production and family cohesiveness. Equity in access to health services, therefore, is an essential component of strategies for social development. 

The health situation in general, the health and nutrition of women and children in particular has deteriorated in Ethiopia markedly during the last decade. Between 1970 and 1981, crude death rates and infant mortality rates were on the decline and there was an increase in life expectancy. However after 1984, the infant mortality rate and under-five mortality rate have steadily increased, while life expectancy at birth has decreased.

Unofficial figures quoted indicate that the current infant mortality rate of 101/1000, under-five mortality rate of 152/1000 and maternal mortality rate of 700/100,000 live births, all indicate the poor health status of children, and women in Ethiopia. In some ways this is not surprising in a country where 84 per cent of woman receive no antenatal care and only less than 10 per cent of children have access to health and medical care. Even where there is access to health and medical care, patients, mothers and children are treated with negligence and carelessness. In a recent bureaucratic bungle, a pregnant women was transferred from one hospital to another. The second hospital did not know why she was moved and in a tragic conclusion, both mother and child died.

Presently, the available health services capacity of about 45 per cent coverage of the population consists of 89 hospitals with 12,000 beds (i.e. one bed for more than 4,000 people), 160 health centers, 2, 292 health stations and over 11, 000 community health posts. The annual per capita recurrent health budget is about 10 birr and nearly 70 per cent of this spent on salaries, leaving very little to cover operational costs and drugs. Low health care coverage, inefficiency of the available health facilities and under utilization of these services have all undermined the opportunity to curb health problems.

Ethiopia is one of the least developed countries. The health dimensions of todays complex social problems call for a multifaceted response that is not restricted to medical solutions. Strategies that address health problems will also need to be related to the other major social problems of the decade.

Health status gaps between regions mirror the unequal development of health infrastructure that varies both by population group and by community within our country. Ethiopia needs to define health policies that take into consideration the complex interaction of factors at play evolving political and economic environment. The health and well-being of people, particularly the poor and the marginalized should be the main target of such policies aiming , in the long term , at self-reliance and sustainable development.

Issue cover date: September 20


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


471 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Ethiopia;
Rights Group Says Rent Increase Illegal


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Addis Ababa - In a special report issued by the Ethiopian Human Rights Council (EHRCO) dated September 17, the Administration in Addis Ababa, or Region 14, came under fire for allegedly using powers it does not possess. The dispute began when the region sharply raised the rent of Kebele houses in which businesses are run as well as shops and market plots controlled by the region itself. The report stated "Ato Tefera Waluwa, Chairman of the Addis Ababa Regional Council, told government journalists during a press conference that the rent of a house which used to be 25 birr a month has now been raised to 5000 birr and that houses which were rented from the Kebeles and then sublet to others have been taken away from the original tenants together with the businesses and let to the sub-lessee under a new contract signed with the Kebeles. 

However, the report said, "the law by which Region 14 was established has been annulled by the Federal Constitution and hence Addis Ababa is no more a separate administrative region... Therefore, the Council of Region 14 has no legal basis and as such has no legal power to take any measure in the name of the city of Addis Ababa." EHRCO went on to say that according to Article 20(5) of Proclamation No. 47/75, "the power to administer and collect the fees of nationalized houses whose monthly rents fell below 100 birr was given to the Kebeles and the rest to the Agency for Rental House Administration."

The new directive of Addis Ababa Administration, is contrary to international and national human rights laws, in particular "the right to work". The report said the rise in rent does not take into account the financial capacity of the petty traders. It cited one case where "Ato Toye Dibaga makes his living by selling spices in Woreda 5, Kebele 17, House no. 57. He used to pay 6 birr a month for the rent of the house during the regime of Emperor Haile Sellassie. The rent was reduced to 3 birr by the Proclamation No. 47/75, but now he is asked to pay 171.45 birr a month. Since he can't afford to pay this, he says he will either go begging or migrate elsewhere."

Issue cover date: September 20


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


472 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Ethiopia;
National Bank of Ethiopia Slashes Interest Rates


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2227 words


 

Addis Ababa - Effective as of September 16, 1996, the National Bank of Ethiopia (the country's central bank) has cut the deposit interest rate from a prescribed minimum of 10 percent to 7 percent and the lending interest rate from a maximum of 15 percent to 10.5 percent.

Two arithmetical features of the action taken by the National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) are immediately noticeable: the magnitude of the interest rate reduction (30 percent) is substantial; the spread between the maximum lending rate and the minimum deposit rate has been narrowed down from the previous 5 percent to 3.5 percent or by 30 percent.

Why have the interest rates been reduced? One important reason is the officially reported low rate of inflation at present. The general retail price index in July 1996 (the latest available at the time of writing) for Addis Ababa reported by the Central Statistical Authority stood at 960.7 as against 1015.6 in July 1995, showing a decline of 5.7 percent. Comparing the average general indices for the January-July periods of 1995 and 1996, the rate of inflation registered a drop of 3.9 percent. So, the official inflation statistics indicate that the rate of inflation is negative or that prices are actually falling. This may sound incredible to the average person in Addis Ababa who, apart form the long-standing, rising house rents on the free market, is currently experiencing a substantial rise in sugar and restaurant food prices. But that is what the official figures are showing and we don't have any alternative set of figures to resort to at the moment. 

Very simply, the connection between the rate of interest and the rate of inflation is as follows: A person who lends another person his money should be able to earn something more than the rate of inflation on his loan: otherwise, upon repayment his money would be worth less than what it was at the time he lent it out. Assume the loan amount is 1000 birr and the annual rate of inflation is 20 percent. If the annual rate of interest on the loan is only 15 percent, that is 5 percent less than the rate of inflation, the creditor's loan money plus interest would be 1150 birr if repaid a year later, but when discounted by the 20 percent rate of inflation, it would amount to only 920 birr, i.e. 80 birr less than the original 1000 birr loan extended, which obviously would be a loss to the lender. Hence, the lender must get something appreciably more than the rate of inflation in order to be induced to lend his money.

That essentially is presumed to be one of the justifications behind the NBE's move to reduce the deposit and lending rates. The rate of inflation in 1995 as compared to 1994 was 10 percent. So in 1995 (as of November 1995) the minimum deposit rate was raised to 11 percent and the maximum lending rate was set at 16 percent, indicating an interest rate / inflation rate differential of only 1 percent on the deposit side and a much higher differential of 6 percent on the bank lending side. Now, the official statistics show that prices have fallen so far by around 4 percent, which would mean that even at the substantially reduced bank deposit and lending rates differentials are a huge 11 percent and 14.5 percent, respectively. Hence, the upswing in the differentials has been massive because of the downswing in the rate of inflation.

Ideally, the rate of interest as the cost of money should be determined, much like any other price, by the forces of demand and supply, but this is not entirely the case even in developed countries. The rate of interest is now being used as a major policy instrument in West Germany, the U.K. and the United States and several other economically advanced countries. One of the basic reasons why it would not be prudent to leave the determination of the rate of interest entirely to market forces is that in the context of reasonable free and fair competition, banks would be inclined to keep on cutting their lending rates and their margins in the hope of attracting more borrowers and in the belief that what they lose on lower lending rates, they could make up for on business turnover, but although this may be a sound business strategy at the micro level, its macro consequence could well be disastrous, with the possibility of disruptive hyperinflation resulting from economic overheating.

On the other hand, the rate of interest should not be allowed to be too remotely divorced from he scarcity price of money (capital) signaled by market forces. In Ethiopia, the major loan capital market is provided by the banking system and here the rates of interest are administratively set by the monetary authorities. The closest loan capital markets come to being governed by the forces of demand and supply in Ethiopia is on the treasury bills auction market. The rate of interest on the treasury bills market is essentially determined by auction and currently the annualized rate is below 5 percent. On the informal credit market, the annual rate of interest could be as high as 200 percent on a compound basis. Here lack of information on alternative sources, partly resulting from its informal nature; the atmosphere of illegality associated with informal money-lending and the presumed high risk element involved in it are some of the major factors contributing to the usurious rates of interest charged. By contrast, no interest is levied on credits provided through the savings pools of the traditional savings associations of "Ekubs". As a recapitulation, let us enumerate the lending rates charged on the various major non-traditional and traditional credit markets in Ethiopia as follows:

Credit market Lending interest rate

( in percent )

Commercial banks 10.5

treasury bills auction market 4.1

Savings and credit cooperatives 10.5

Credit unions 10.5

informal money-lending 200 (approximate)

Ekubs nil

The maximum lending rate charged by Commercial banks, savings and credit cooperatives and credit unions are more or less administratively fixed. Theoretically, they could charge anything less than this maximum rate (latest) , but in actual practice there has been no significant trend in that direction for fear of negatively affecting interest margins, which are partly determined by the minimum deposit rates administratively fixed. The 200 percent lending rate on the informal credit market could hardly be viewed as having been market-determined because of the rather "unmarked" mode of its operations, not least its illicit characteristics. Of all the credit markets, perhaps the rate on treasury bills auction market is the one that comes closest to being genuinely market-determined. However, the even here participation is limited to big institutional investors with idle money such as the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia, the Social Security Authority, the Ethiopian Electric light and Power Authority and the Ethiopian Insurance Company. Restricted though the treasury bills market may be the procedure by which the rate of interest is determined is fairly market oriented.

Looking at the Ethiopian financial macro-economy, there appears to be a major contradiction at least on the basis of official statistics: on the one hand, there is reported to be a colossal amount of excess liquidity in the banking system and elsewhere (for example, in institutions bidding on the treasury bills auction). For instance, the excess reserves of the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia, the largest retail bank in the country, was reported to be over 750 million birr as of April 1996. On the other hand, Ethiopia's saving rate officially estimated at about 5 percent is one of the lowest in the world and hardly bears comparison with the average of over 35 percent for East Asian counties. On the evidence of the reported excess liquidity (or savings), the bank deposit rate should in fact be lower than the minimum rate of 7 percent to which the NBE has just reduced it; as a matter of fact, it should perhaps be well below 4 percent, which is the rate at which, say, the Commercial bank of Ethiopia is lending its excess reserves to the government; on the evidence of the low domestic saving ratio, the bank deposit rate should perhaps be where it was before the latest interest rate reduction, i.e. around 10 percent or more. This is quite a dilemma for the monetary authorities in Ethiopia.

Excess liquidity is one sign that investment activity is low overall. Low overall investment activity is in turn an indication that the investment climate is not favorable. So, something should be done about that. In the meantime, however, the rate of interest should reflect the demand/supply situation on the financial market. Right now even the 7 percent rate of interest on bank deposits appears to be on the high side, considering the reported amount of excess liquidity. On the other hand, in view of the very sluggish nature of investment at present, there is every reason to reduce lending interest rates even further in order to stimulate investment activity, at least from the financial point of view.

On the question of what the margin between the deposit and lending rates of interest should be, percentage profit margins and total business turnover in other business activities should be examined for comparison with the situation in the banking business. For example, the precious 5% margin between deposit and lending interest rates represented a gross percentage interest profit margin of about 50 percent, taking into account only interest- bearing deposits. Taking into consideration demand deposits which bear no interest, the margin would be much higher, perhaps as high as 200 percent. Assuming that the weighted deposit rate is now about 3.5 percent (i.e. taking into account the zero rate of interest rate on demand deposits), the absolute interest rate margin between this weighted rate and the maximum lending rate of 10.5 percent prescribed by the NBE would be 7 percent and the relative interest profit margin would be 200 percent, which means the reduction in the absolute interest margin from 5 percent to 3.5 percent may not adversely affect the profitability of banks on their interest account in relative terms. In fact, substantial absolute gains may be made if the reduced lending rate spurs lending activity. If, however, such expansion of turnover fails to materialize, the reduced absolute interest rate margin would negatively affect bank profitability in absolute terms.

To summarize, the major effects of NBE's action to reduce interest rates would be the following:

* bank depositors would be hurt by the loss of interest income, but the reduction in the deposit rate would not significantly discourage savers from depositing money in the banking system as the 7% deposit rate is considered to be still high enough in the current financial circumstances;

* bank lending may be stimulated as a result of the reduction in the lending rate, especially in the now depressed housing construction sector;

* the profitability of the banking sector in relative terms is not likely to be adversely affected in any significant way; in fact, gains could be made from higher turnover on lending activities; however, lack of such business turnover may negatively affect bank profitability in absolute terms;

* inflationary tendencies may re-emerge with higher lending activity, especially if existing investment bottlenecks such as land and infrastructure unavailability are removed.

Issue cover date: September 20


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


473 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Malawi;
Kangaroo Court For Former Top Official?


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Blantyre - Malawi's Inspector General of Police, Patrick Chikapa, must be regretting convening a press conference on September 2 to clarify the arrest a day earlier of MCP treasurer general John Tembo, his son John Jr, and former official hostess for ex-president Hastings Banda, Cecilia Kadzamira.

Although the intention of the press conference was good, the mistake Chikapa will probably live to regret, and which surprised members of the press, was when they found that two of the people the police had announced two days earlier had been arrested in connection with the January Kalaria Wholesale broad daylight armed robbery, were also there, both seemingly composed and relaxed. These were Chimwemwe Mputahelo, a former editor of the defunct Malawian newspaper, an abhorred critic of State President Bakili Muluzi, and Adamson Chunga, John Tembo's former driver.

Chikapa's brief introductory remarks, detailing the press conference and the presence of the two accused persons, only set the tempo for scepticism and doubt among the pressmen and triggered a set of probing questions most of which seemingly proved too hot for the police to handle. 

One journalist said he felt the press conference was a kangaroo court of some type aimed at condemning the Tembos, who were not there and able to defend themselves from being unfairly accused by Chunga and Mputahelo. Chikapa did not agree with the journalist's question, but it was clear he had been taken by surprise. He argued there was no need to produce the masterminds behind the conspiracy to murder and attempted murder charges. " When the investigations are over all the accused will be tried in a court of law," he argued.

Chikapa gave a vague excuse: "These people are still helping us with investigations," without telling the press whether the two would be tried for being hired as marksmen in the conspiracy. Again when the suggestion was made to him that the manner in which the events have unfolded since the initial announcement on 31 August could not be coincidence, the police boss was again at a loss to give a convincing explanation.

When another reporter wanted to know why the government always rushes to arrest MCP cadres while it hesitates or drags its feet when there is need to arrest UDF leaders involved in matters of contempt of court, financial scandals, corruption or evading customs, Chikapa pleaded that such issues should not be mixed with the purpose of the press conference.

When MBC aired the press conference, attended by Chief Information Officer, Grey Mang'anda, Principal Secretary for Information and Broadcasting Ziddy Medi and MBC Acting Director General Sam Gunde, later in the evening, all those issues on which the police and the two marksmen had failed to answer convincingly had been removed.

Meanwhile, Cecilia Kadzamira on September 3 expressed concern over her incarceration by the UDF government, but vowed never to leave the former head of state. She had been granted bail after a 24-hour stint in prison.

"Maybe the government wants me to join politics," said Kadzamira, when she addressed over 200 supporters at Banda's official residence at Mudi House. " What I see is that they want to arrest the Ngwazi. They are not content with what they did to us during the Mwanza case," she said. She vowed "never to leave the Ngwazi" in spite of the harassment by the UDF government. "We have always kept peace and calm and abided by the four corner-stones yet UDF thinks we are stupid. But they should not forget that a shy and stupid snake bites from the tail," she said.

Talking of her stint in prison, a seemingly tired but smiling Kadzamira said she was well received and treated by female inmates at Chichiri prison who, she said, also sent a message of solidarity to the opposition MCP. Cecilia Kadzamira was granted bail on September 3 less than 48 hours after her arrest on charges of conspiring to murder three UDF cabinet ministers.

Bail was granted by Judge Duncan Tambala who said people should not use detention to punish suspects before trial.

LATE NEWS --- JOHN TEMBO AND SON RELEASED: MCP strongman John Tembo and his son by the same names, John charged with conspiracy to murder and attempted murder were given bail on September 4. The two were arrested on September 1 following confessions by three accused persons in a shooting incident that took place in Lilongwe in January 1996 incriminating them. The Tembos must report to police once every two months. The bail carries a bond of K20,000, non-cash and another surety of K20,000.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

474 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Malawi;
Malawi News Roundup


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2000 words


 

Blantyre - PATEL RESIGNS FROM UDF: A founding executive member of the UDF, and former cabinet minister, Rolf Patel, announced his resignation from the party on September 2.

Patel, proprietor of Uniprint, which has been sued by President Bakili Muluzi for printing a newspaper with a libellous article, has not yet joined another party. He is an MP in Thyolo, southern Malawi. He may remain an MP as long as he does not join another political party.

He fell out of favour with Muluzi and his cabinet, along with a group of ten other members of parliament, for openly criticising Muluzi on a number of issues. Patel, who was then minister of energy and mining, was changed to the less prestigious portfolio of relief and rehabilitation. In a reshuffle two months later, Muluzi dropped him completely from the cabinet. 

Patel says there is rampant corruption in the Muluzi government with some cabinet ministers , who previously could not afford the busfare from town to their homes , now owning mansions and fleets of vehicles. "How could anyone accumulate such wealth within the two years they have been cabinet ministers?' queried Patel.

Patel is the second MP to resign from the party, Fred Nseula from Mwanza being the first.

POLICE ARREST KADZAMIRA AND TEMBO: Police have announced the arrest of opposition MCP Treasurer General John Tembo, his son, John Tembo Jr and former president Kamuzu Banda's confidante, Cecilia Kadzamira, for their alleged role in a conspiracy to murder, and for attempted murder.

Police announced on 2 September that the three, and a former police officer, Thunga, were arrested following the confessions of three other people already in police custody in connection with the robbery in January this year of a wholesale shop in Lilongwe. The three are former editor of The Malawian newspaper, Chimwemwe Mputahero, Adamson Chunga and William Phakamisa, arrested 31 August. They were using John Tembo Jr's vehicle.Tembo Jr told the police, his car had been borrowed by Chunga, one of his employees, because he wanted to go a funeral in Lilongwe.

Police did not disclose details of the confessions.

MALAWI BEMOANS TRADE PROTOCOL: For some time, the Malawi government has held the strong opinion that it would benefit if it forged special trade agreements with its neighbours.

Such a view culminated in Malawi signing one such trade agreement with Zimbabwe in October 1995. The agreement provides duty free access of imports and exports of finished products between the two countries. But now, barely ten months after Malawi signed the agreement, the business community is crying foul and would like to have the agreement cancelled.

The government has come under fire from the business community through its spokesman, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI), for rushing into the trade protocol without consulting the private sector. MCCI Executive Director says since signing the Malawi/Zimbabwe trade agreement, Malawi's exports to Zimbabwe have plummeted. Zimbabwe's exports to Malawi have, however, increased.

To make matters worse, Zimbabweans have taken advantage of Malawi's poor industrial base by fully utilising the trade agreement to penetrate the Malawian market with their cheaper goods, allowed duty free access under the agreement.

At a meeting by the chamber on August 29, the business community urged the government to waive duty on importation of a number of raw materials in order to reduce production costs by manufacturers which would then make the products more competitive, locally and internationally. The community feels that unless the government provides incentives to the industrial sector, Malawi will continue to suffer trade imbalance from Zimbabwe which is benefiting from the trade protocol because of its strong industrial base.

The private sector argues that because of the agreement, Zimbabwean products have become much cheaper than local ones. One businessman said it would even be profitable for Malawians to manufacture in Zimbabwe and export to Malawi. "Traders are even importing chickens and eggs at much cheaper prices than locally produced ones," lamented a poultry feed milling company. Zimbabwe, unlike Malawi, does not charge duty on importation of stock feed.

Controller of Customs and Excise, Ernest Mtingwi, rules out the possibility of removing duty on import of raw materials saying this would cripple government revenue collection. More than 50% of Malawi's budget is funded by revenue from customs and excise.

VEEP THREATENS PRINCIPAL SECRETARIES, DISTRICT COMMISSIONERS: Vice President Justin Malewezi has threatened to fire principal secretaries and district commissioners who do not support the United Democratic Front (UDF) government. He was speaking last week, at the installation of Bibi Abiti Chapola as Chief in Salima, central Malawi, about 70 kilometres east of the capital Lilongwe.

He said the UDF had discovered that there were some district commissioners and principal secretaries in the government supporting the opposition parties, MCP and AFORD. He threatened that any civil servant who does not support the government will have their services terminated or be retired.

AK 47, PISTOLS IN CAR CRASH, DIPLOMAT'S DAUGHTER AMONG THREE DEAD: A diplomat's daughter was among three dead in a car crash, and an AK 47 assault rifle, two pistols and several fake vehicle number plates were retrieved from the vehicle giving rise to suspicion that the victims were car thieves. Ntcheu Chief Superintendent of Police, Patrick Phiri said the accident happened last week, in Ntcheu, central Malawi, about 200 kms from Blantyre.

Trancy Malemena, daughter of an administrator at the Zambian High Commission in Lilongwe, was the only female in the hired car, which was being driven by a Malawian, Joseph Sayani. The other passenger, Manete was a Zairean refugee based at Dzaleka camp in central Malawi. The vehicle, which overturned four times when the driver failed to negotiate a corner, had different number plates at the front and rear.

There is rampant car theft in Malawi, with most of vehicles stolen ending up in Zaire, where there is said to be a ready market.

INDIAN HEMP TRAFFICKER INTERCEPTED: Following a tip, police in Nkhota-kota, central Malawi, on August 23 intercepted a minibus carrying 15 and a half bags of Indian hemp (locally known as chamba), each weighing 90 kgs. All but one person in the minibus fled with police apprehending the one man who did not run.

President Muluzi set up a fund a few months ago to reward people tipping the police in chamba dealing. Nkhota-kota, along Lake Malawi, is reputed to be the biggest supplier of chamba in Malawi.

President Bakili Muluzi, who attended a SADC summit on August 24 in Lesotho at which several protocols were signed, including one on drug trafficking, afterwards warned that the law on chamba dealing would become tougher.

POLICE TEAR-GAS MARCHERS: Riot police in Blantyre on September 3 used tear- gas to disperse more than 300 demonstrators carrying anti-MCP placards, marching from Blantyre city centre to the High Court about five kilometres away.

The marchers said they were going to the High Court to petition the Chief Justice and demand that Judge Mackson Mkandawire should not preside over the case involving John Tembo, his son, John Jr, Cecilia Kadzamira and a former police man, Thunga. One of their placards read 'MCP party of murderers' another, 'Tembo stop killing us.'

Mkandawire acquitted Banda, Tembo and three others in a case in which they were charged with conspiracy to murder and attempted murder. The UDF supporters fear that Mkandawire would free John Tembo and company ust as he had done in the previous case.

MBC STAFFERS: There is a ray of hope that dismissed Malawi Broadcasting Corporation reporter, Hastings Maloya, could be reinstated, while his colleague, Francis Chikunkhuzeni, might have his suspension lifted following revelations confirming that an opposition rally, whose story the reporter filed took place.

Maloya was dismissed allegedly for filing a story on an MCP rally held in the volatile Ndirande township, where a by-election is due on November 19. Officials at MBC said the meeting was never held and said Maloya was dismissed solely for that reason.

But unofficial reports say a team was set up to investigate the issue and establish whether the said meeting really took place or not and has since confirmed the opposition rally actually took place.

GOVERNMENT TO PROBE LUNGUZI'S DEATH: President Bakili Muluzi announced at a rally in Lilongwe on September 2 his government would probe the death of former inspector general of police McWilliam Lunguzi who died in a car accident in June this year. He said it was difficult to believe how out of four passengers only one person sitting at the back of the car could die. Lunguzi died when the vehicle he was travelling in together with MCP Vice President Gwanda Chakuamba hit a stationary tractor trailer in Dowa, central Malawi.

But police inspector general Patrick Chikapa contradicted Muluzi at a press conference on Monday when he said as far as the police investigations were concerned, Lunguzi died in car accident, and the issue was closed.

Meanwhile the Lunguzi family on September 5 said they were gravely concerned with Muluzi's announcement that the government would institute a probe into the death of their father.In a press release, Lunguzi's eledest daughter, Lucy Mauluka said it was sad that the UDF were now posing as if they sympathised with the the family when neither the party nor the government sent a message of condolence to the deceased's family. She said in addition, she had evidence that some central executive members of the UDF were even celebrating over their father's death. "Which was why he was not buried with full police honours as should have been the case," said Mauluka. She said it was therefore hypocritical for the UDF government to pose as if they cared about his death.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

475 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


Malawi;
Malawi's Freedom Of Press Honeymoon Over


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Blantyre - The honeymoon that Malawi's media has been enjoying with freedom of the press since the advent of political pluralism seems to be over.

The country's media landscape during the past two months has begun to change. The clear writing on the wall is that those ruling Malawi now will stop at nothing when it comes to suing a publication at the slightest hint of what they consider libel or defamation.

Ironically, this ship is being steered by no other than the man who has all along been touted by the local press as taking a leading role in defending and upholding freedom of the press in Malawi - President Bakili Muluzi. 

In an unprecedented move which looks like the beginning of a breakdown in press freedom, Muluzi has slapped a weekly newspaper, the Tribute, with a libel suit for publishing an article alleging that he grabbed land worth K500, 000 ($44,440) from a late friend. He has put in motion separate lawsuits - for the editor of the paper, its publisher and the printer of the newspaper . His lawyers, Legalwise, have not, however, indicated how much they are demanding from each of those served with lawsuits.

Muluzi has also won a court injunction restraining the printers of the tabloid, Uniprint, from printing any newspaper until the issue is finalised in court.

First Lady, Anne, has also obtained a court injunction barring another weekly tabloid, the Statesman, from carrying a column carrying her name (Anne) which used to ridicule her and the president. Perhaps the mother of all lawsuits is one from a wealthy Blantyre businessman and politician in the ruling party United Democratic Party, James Makhumula. The former minister has sued another weekly newspaper, the Chronicle, for K20 million (US 1.44 million dollars) , for publishing an article alleging that he grabbed land from a poor man in Zomba, 70 kilometres east of Blantyre. The case is being handled by lawyer and fellow deputy, Arthur Makhalira.

While some analysts say Muluzi's sudden about face is a gimmick, primarily targeted at punishing another fellow UDF central executive politician and member of parliament, Rolf Patel, who owns Uniprint, others say Malawian journalists should expect the terrain to become tougher, sooner than later. Patel is one of ten or more UDF deputies dubbed 'rebels' for not toeing the party line and for openly criticising Muluzi's policies.

Last year in September, Muluzi refused to turn into law a bill on publications that required all publications, including newspapers, to publish the name of the printer, publisher, editor and reporter. The fine for failing to fulfil this requirement was K20,000 ($1,440). In refusing to assent to the bill, Muluzi said that if turned into law it would be a big dampener to the newly-found and much avowed freedom of press the country was enjoying after 30 years of single-party dictatorship.

But, just about a year later, Muluzi says journalists must be responsible in their reporting. He said that they should not create lies or distort facts at the expense of other peoples' reputations. If they step on other people's toes they must face the law just like everybody else. "They are not above the law," he said.

Unfortunately, the publications bill resurfaced in parliament during its recent sitting and it was passed. It is now back on Muluzi's desk to either make it into law or overturn it for the second time. And it is unsure just what Muluzi will do now. " We have been asking ourselves what exactly is the use of the this bill? To whose benefit?" asks Frank Kamwendo, Chairman of the Lilongwe Press Club. Kamwendo wonders how the bill could advance press freedom when it requires those newspapers which do not abide by it to pay a large fine.

As if this was not enough to induce professional fear among journalists, the national radio, Malawi Broadcasting Corporation, only two weeks ago fired a reporter and suspended an editor allegedly for filing a story about an opposition party meeting which, it was said, did not take place. MBC, long criticised for its biased coverage of events and reportage in favour of the ruling UDF, is strongly controlled by government.

Unfortunately, media groupings such as the Media Council of Malawi and the Journalists Association of Malawi have remained mute on the issue. Mollande Nkhata, chairman of the council, apparently trying to keep his head - he leads the news and current affairs section - says his council has not come up with a statement on the undemocratic decision by his employers because the council was still in its formative stage!!

Apart from the opposition and the print media, it is only the Media Institute for Southern Africa (MISA), Malawi chapter, that has come up with a bold statement condemning the action and its aim of inducing fear among the electronic journalists and other media workers.

The national radio has also received instructions, apparently from the Information and Broadcasting ministry, not to air anything in its news broadcasts about meetings addressed by a Blantyre member of parliament, Nicholas Kachingwe, who belongs to the same UDF 'rebel group'.

The court may not necessarily award Makhumula K1.4 million for defamation, but the strong message to Malawian journalists is that the days when they could lay their hands on any bits and pieces of information and send it further with impunity are gone.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 27, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria--Caught in State of "Permanent Transition"


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

New York - Despite its stated commitment to return Nigeria to civilian rule by October 1, 1998, the Nigerian government continues to violate the rights of Nigerian citizens to freely engage in political activity. Nigerian military rulers first announced a program to return the country to democratic government over ten years ago, and in "Permanent Transition," released today, Human Rights Watch/Africa assesses the transition program and the steps that have been taken toward its implementation to date, including an examination of the seriously flawed local government elections of March 1996.

The 52-page report identifies the impediments to free political activity that destroy the transition program's credibility, including the detention and imprisonment of opposition politicians, human rights and pro-democracy activists, trade unionists and journalists, as well as restrictions on freedom of expression, assembly, association and movement. 

Human Rights Watch charges that recent reforms announced by the government including the restoration of a right to appeal in some cases where it had been denied, the repeal of a decree preventing the courts from granting writs of habeas corpus in favor of detainees held without charge, and the creation of a human rights commission are purely cosmetic, and do not begin to address the need for fundamental reform and renewal. As a result, Human Rights Watch calls for the imposition of additional international sanctions including freezing the foreign assets of members of the Nigerian military government to ensure that Nigeria is returned to civilian rule by a freely elected government as soon as possible.

Repression continues in Ogoniland, birthplace of executed minority rights activist Ken Saro-Wiwa. Nineteen Ogonis still await trial before the same Civil Disturbances Special Tribunal that convicted Saro-Wiwa and eight others and sentenced them to death in October 1995 executions later described by British Prime Minister John Major as "judicial murder." Other suspected sympathizers of Saro-Wiwa's organization, the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP), were detained after demonstrations on January 4, 1996, celebrated as "Ogoni Day" since January 1993. Still more Ogonis were detained before or during the April visit of a fact-finding team sent by the U.N. Secretary General to Nigeria, despite assurances by the Nigerian government that nobody would be penalized for attempting to speak to the team. While the Nigerian government has put in place token efforts at " reconciliation" in Ogoniland, it has not made any move to pay compensation to the families of the executed activists, as recommended by the U.N. fact- finding team.

International attention has shifted from Nigeria during 1996, after an outcry following the November 1995 executions of the Ogoni Nine. Although sanctions imposed following the executions remain in force, as well as those put in place in 1993, no further measures have been imposed, despite the lack of genuine progress in returning the country to an elected government. The Commonwealth, which suspended Nigeria from membership in November 1995, has halted the implementation of additional sanctions recommended in April 1996 by the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group (CMAG), pending further discussions with the Nigerian government. The Organization of African Unity has failed to take any measures against Nigeria, and the African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights, which held an extraordinary session on Nigeria in December 1995, has yet to follow this up with further action or recommendations.

Human Rights Watch calls for international pressure to be maintained and intensified to ensure that the Nigerian government takes meaningful steps to improve the human rights situation. Detainees must be released and free expression and assembly restored in order to ensure a genuine transition to civilian rule. In particular, Human Rights Watch urges the imposition of a total arms embargo on Nigeria, and the freezing of assets held in other countries by members of the Nigerian armed forces or senior members of the government, and their families. Human Rights Watch calls specially on CMAG, which is meeting over the weekend of September 28 and 29, to urge the Commonwealth member states to implement the sanctions recommended by CMAG in April, and also to adopt an asset freeze and arms embargo.

For additional information, Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017-6104. Tel: 212/972-8400. Fax: 212/972-0905 E-mail: hrwnyc@hrw.org.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


477 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 27, 1996


United States and Africa;
Burundi: Do the Right Thing (Commentary)


BYLINE: Salih Booker, Council on Foreign Relations (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Washington - Since seizing power in Burundi two months ago, Major Pierre Buyoya -- mistakenly described as a moderate by U.S. and other western policymakers and media professionals -- has presided over the killing of more than 6,000 civilians. This represents a five-fold increase in the rate of slaughter in that divided country since the July 25th coup.

While Burundi edges closer to the precipice of the genocidal abyss that claimed nearly one million people in neighboring Rwanda in 1994, the U.S. and its western allies have hesitated over how to respond. Meanwhile Burundi's African neighbors and the Organization of African Unity (OAU) have swiftly imposed full economic sanctions on the junta in Bujumbura. 

The reaction of the U.S. and its allies to the new emergency in Burundi will make clear how important the prevention of genocide is to these countries. Given the failure to prevent or stop the genocide in Rwanda, their response in Burundi will also confirm or dispel the belief that western governments operate with a double standard when African civilians are the ones dying by the tens of thousands in conflict situations.

At its core, Burundi's problem is apartheid. Any lasting solution to the conflict must offer a plan to end Tutsi hegemony, or minority rule, while offering guarantees for every citizen's human rights. This is clear to those on the ground and ultimately the future security of the Tutsi minority depends upon the creation of a truly democratic state.

Finding such a durable solution will require the full support of the international community, especially the western powers. Policymakers who assume that Burundi should be left to itself and its neighbors to sort out are captives of a false, dangerous and racist belief that African conflicts are somehow different from those in other parts of the world and therefore do not warrant the same degree of international cooperation to resolve.

The imposition of sanctions against Burundi signals an important turning point. The six states that adopted these measures -- Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Zaire and Ethiopia -- want to force Burundi's new military leaders to restore the national assembly and lift the ban on political parties. The larger aim is to create conditions for talks among all the key participants in the conflict and to establish a cease-fire between government and rebel forces.

The sanctions are beginning to take effect. The economy is in a rapid decline and soon the military junta will be unable to pay its civil servants and its rapidly expanding army. If the military dictatorship doesn't move quickly to restore constitutional rule and establish a cease-fire and a mechanism for all-party talks, additional sanctions will be required. Already an arms embargo should be adopted and applied against both sides of the conflict.

If these pressures succeed in producing negotiations, the talks must then focus on ending minority rule.

The habit among many State Department officials and their European counterparts, of defining the problem in Burundi in terms of "moderates" vs. " extremists" on both sides of the Hutu majority - Tutsi minority divide, is misleading and counterproductive. The bottom line struggle in Burundi is to end the exclusion of 85% of the population from decisionmaking and access to resources, and create a system of democratic majority rule.

The Tutsi minority has legitimate fears of retaliation and genocide at the hands of the long repressed Hutu majority in much the same manner that South Africa's white minority feared black majority rule. But until this minority, which includes both the military and the business elite, is forced to accept a democratic system of governance its continued repressive and deadly rule will sow even more seeds of the tragic future it fears.

If agreement is reached to negotiate a way out of this national nightmare in Burundi, a peacekeeping force will be required to keep the warring parties apart and eventually to oversee a disarmament, demobilization and retraining process aimed at establishing a thoroughly reformed national force.

But if economic sanctions do not produce the desired talks and cease-fire, then a different type of international intervention force under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter will be required to intervene and create the conditions necessary for peace talks.

Other military options such as an international observer brigade or an all- African intervention force are both poor alternatives. The first would be little more than a toothless observer while the second idea should only be considered as a last resort. A truly international peacekeeping or peacemaking force should not be an all-African volunteer force, but rather a blued-helmeted U.N. force like those to which African nations have contributed soldiers -- and lives -- for numerous conflict resolution efforts around the world in places such as Bosnia, Cambodia, and Lebanon.

The prevention of genocide in Burundi requires and deserves external intervention. Sadly, out of some 80 countries asked by the United Nations to lend support for a possible peacekeeping mission in Burundi, only three African states have offered to send troops. Without a change of policy on the part of the U.S. and its western allies, the double standard will be confirmed and an all African force will become the only option available.

U.S. policy to support economic sanctions and facilitate peace talks doesn't go far enough. While the U.S. must continue to refuse any formal recognition the military regime, it must also prepare to commit financial resources, logistical support and -- yes -- ground troops to an international peacekeeping or peacemaking intervention in Burundi.

The so-called "Somalia syndrome" -- which suggests that Americans won't support sending soldiers on peace missions in Africa -- applies more to policymakers than to the public. The prevention of genocide anywhere is in the national and international interest. The public has the heart to understand this and the stomach to accept the risks involved. This is something that both the President and Mr. Dole should have the courage to acknowledge even in an election year.

(Salih Booker is the Fellow for Africa Studies at the Council on Foreign Relations. The Council on Foreign Relations takes no institutional position on policy issues. This article is the sole responsibility of the author.)


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


478 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 30, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria Welcomes Commonwealth Decision To Send Mission


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1344 words


 

NEW YORK - Nigeria's foreign minister, Tom Ikimi has welcomed the decision by the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group (CMAG) to proceed with its fact- finding mission to Nigeria, saying it would help build on the dialogue started in London in June.

Ikimi said in an interview in New York that the decision, reached Sunday after two days of CMAG talks was in consonance with the Nigerian position on its disagreement with the Commonwealth.

"Our position has always remained the same: we believe that the difficulties that we have with the Commonwealth can only be resolved through negotiations and discussions and dialogue.

"We welcome their decision to come to Nigeria to attend a meeting between the Commonwealth and Nigeria and we look forward to the meeting," Ikimi said. The Nigerian minister is in New York to attend the current 51st regular session of the United Nations General Assembly. 

However, he cautioned that in proceeding with the meeting, the eight-nation CMAG should understand the "areas of concern to Nigeria" at this time.

"They also need to recognize the fact that since Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth in a manner which was indeed very unprecedented. Nigeria has not been standing still. A lot of changes have taken place in Nigeria during the past year," he added.

The foreign minister also stressed the need for CMAG to take into consideration the role that the U.N. had played so that "nothing should be done to set back the progress already made by the U.N. or the progress already made by Nigeria."

This was a reference to the U.N. fact-finding mission to Nigeria early in the early, which gave qualified support to the military government's transition to democracy programme.

Ikimi reiterated Nigeria's commitment to the Commonwealth, saying that the country cherished its long membership in the organisation, and would not do anything to upset the opportunity it had always had to contribute to world peace and understanding.

The CMAG, which has the mandate of ensuring adherence to the Harare Declaration on democracy and human rights, among others, decided Sunday after its fifth meeting in New York, to drop the threat of sanctions against Nigeria.

CMAG is made up of Britain, Canada, Ghana, Jamaica, South Africa, Malaysia, New Zealand and Zimbabwe.

Putting sanctions on hold and opting for dialogue, the group decided that it will proceed with its fact-finding mission to Nigeria.

"The group was fully conscious of the need to continue the dialogue began in June 1996," according to a communique issued by the CMAG.

The group said that the trip, expected to take place "at the earliest possible date" and for which no conditions were set, would enable it to complete its current assessment and make recommendations on future measures relating to the situation in Nigeria.

During the talks, held at the Malaysian mission to the U.N., CMAG deliberated on the report of the Commonwealth Secretariat team that visited Nigeria early September, and was briefed by a U.N. assistant secretary- general, Lansana Kouyate, on the U.N.'s fact-finding mission to Nigeria.

The CMAG Chairman, Stan Mudenge of Zimbabwe, said the New York meeting dwelt more on the need to continue dialogue than on sanctions.

"When we go to Nigeria, we are continuing with the dialogue (that) we started with the Nigeria authorities (in June in London)," Mudenge, Zimbabwe's foreign minister, told reporters.

Asked what guarantees CMAG had that it would have a free access to all those it would wish to see during the trip, he said: "we are expecting to be given access to enable us to make the right assessment and recommendations. We have made it clear to the Nigerian authorities what it will take us to be able to make an informed assessment."

He added that he expected that the group would visit Nigeria before the end of the year.

He disclosed that the sanctions, which include a ban on sporting links and arms sale and downgrading of cultural links and diplomatic missions, would not be implemented until CMAG had made its assessment and recommendations to the Commonwealth heads of government meeting.

CMAG sources said the meeting was held under a "largely cordial atmosphere," making it easy to reach a consensus in spite of the hard line taken in the past by some members.

Mudenge defended the organisation's decision to pursue further dialogue with Nigeria instead of sanctions, saying this did not amount to a loss of credibility on its part.

He said no other organisation was more credible than the Commonwealth in dealing with Nigeria.

Lloyd Axworthy, the foreign minister of Canada, whose country has unilaterally imposed sanctions on Nigeria, supported the assertion, saying: " we are working consensus here and what is really important is to have opportunity to have the kind of access to Nigeria to find what's going on and to make an assessment." On the fact that CMAG was no longer giving any condition for the mission, the British minister for overseas development, Lynda Chalker, said: "you wait for guarantees in this life (and) you never get anything achieved. You have to venture forth. We are venturing forth."

Relations between Nigeria and the Commonwealth, which groups Britain and its former colonies, have soured since 1995 when it was suspended from the group following the execution for murder of Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other activists.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


479 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 30, 1996


Gambia;
Soldiers Celebrate Jammeh's Victory


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

BANJUL, Gambia - Soldiers drove Sunday through the streets of Banjul, capital of this tiny West African state, to celebrate the victory of the retired colonel Yahya Jammeh in Thursday's presidential elections.

The uniformed soldiers waved green tree branches, the symbol of the former military ruler's Alliance for Patriotic Re-orientation and Construction (APRC) , which scooped 55.76% of the votes.

Hoteliers in the Gambian capital expressed optimism of a good winter tourism season because of the new democratic era that has been established after the elections. 

One hotel manager expressed concern, however, over a report by a foreign radio station Saturday to the effect that the polls were rigged.

"The radio report was fictitious because all the four contesting parties had agents in all the polling stations, and where the ballots were counted," said the manager on condition that his name be kept secret.

He conceded, however, that the continued hiding of Ousainou Darboe, Jammeh's most serious challenger in last Thursday's polls, in the Senegalese embassy could cause apprehension among potential tourists that "something was wrong here."

Daraboe, who went into hiding Thursday night, has not conceded defeat. His party, the United Democratic Party (UDP) received 35.84 percent of the 394, 537 votes cast.

One of the contestants, Hamat Bah of the National Reconstruction Party (NRP) , who received 5.52 percent of the votes, conceded defeat at a news conference Saturday.

His agent told PANA Sunday morning that his organisation had no quarrel with the election results.

Analyst told PANA that those who are surprised by Jammeh's victory ignore the fact that he singly occupied the political scene for two years.

"Only those who don't go to the rural areas are unaware of what this young man has been doing, especially in the construction of schools, " said an expatriate, Clive Barlow, who has lived in the Gambia since 1985.

"Who will not vote for someone who reduces the distance his child has to walk to school", said a veteran Radio Gambia broadcaster.

"I started this work in 1962. But it's only under Jammeh that our radio can cover the whole country because he allocated the funds. In addition, we now have television," he added.

Some analysts said Jammeh could have scored even higher had he not banned three other political parties, including the People's Progressive Party (PPP) of former President Dawda Jawara.

"Jammeh would have scored even higher votes because the other political parties would have inevitably engaged in bickering. It was not easy for him this time because the three banned parties simply threw their weight behind Darboe, " said one political analyst.

He said Jammeh should use his newly acquired legitimacy to tackle "the extremely low standard of living of the majority."

He said Jammeh has done well in providing basic infrastructures, schools, television, roads, extension of the airport and the "July 22 arc".

"But the living conditions of many Gambians are so bad that priority needs to be directed there," he said

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 30, 1996


Mozambique;
Killer of Swedish Premier May Be Living in Mozambique


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The man who murdered Swedish Prime Minister Olof Palme in February 1986 may be living in the central Mozambican city of Beira, according to the Swedish newspaper 'Aftonbladet'.

In its weekend edition, 'Aftonbladet' said that the South African agent suspected of assassinating Palme, Antony White, is based in Beira, and working at a sawmill that serves as a cover for various criminal activities, including drug running. 

The paper says that White was working for the notorious South African spy Craig Williamson. He was named last week as heading the secret police 'Operation Longreach' which targeted Palme for assassination.

Williamson is currently in Angola working in the diamond trade. He told 'Aftonbladet' that White had gone to Beira, but was unsure whether he was still there.

Williamson's role in planning the Palme murder was indicated last week by Col. Eugene de Kock, former head of the apartheid police's Vlakplaas death squad. Citing Swedish police sources, 'Aftonbladet' confirmed that Williamson had been in Sweden at the time of the assassination.

De Kock claimed that the apartheid regime had spent at least 70,000 rands (about 23,000 U.S. dollars at the exchange rate of the time) in arranging Palme's murder.

De Kock's predecessor at Vlakplaas, Dirk Coetzee, the man who blew the whistle on apartheid death squads, and defected to the African National Congress, named White as the assassin on Saturday.

He believed, however, that White had taken refuge on a Greek island or in Cyprus, rather than in Mozambique.

White was once a member of the Selous Scouts, one of the most feared and hated units in the Rhodesian army that waged war against the people of Zimbabwe and the neighboring states in the 1970s.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 30, 1996


Sports - General;
Quaye, Jones, Retain West African Boxing Titles


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana's Kofi Quaye retained his West African light- heavyweight crown when he technically knocked out Bamidele Disu of Nigeria in the third of their scheduled 12-round title bout at the Kaneshie sports complex on Saturday night.

The Nigerian, who went down once in each round, failed to withstand Quaye's heavy punches and his corner threw in the towel to save him after the third round knockdown in one minute 15 seconds. 

Disu, who had earlier described Quaye as a sluggish boxer and had predicted a resounding victory, was forced to eat back his words right from the opening bell.

The Nigerian was the first to attack but Quaye parried away his punches.

Quaye, relying on tips from Azumah Nelson, WBC super- featherweight champion, landed a powerful right on the chin of the Nigerian which sent him on to the ropes.

Disu, thereafter, started to retreat but Quaye chased him round the ring and got another right punch through, which sent the Nigerian to the canvas for the mandatory count.

The Nigerian could not offer any resistance as he kissed the canvas for the second time in round two.

Quaye dominated the exchanges and after Disu's third knockdown, his cornermen threw in the towel to save their ward from further punishment.

Stoner Jones also retained his national and West Africa super-bantamweight crown on points over T.T. Quaynor in their 12-rounds title bout.

All the three judges scored for the champion. E.J.D. Osabutey scored the fight 118-114, J.B. Owusu-Ansah 117-115 and Abbey Adama 117-114.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


482 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 30, 1996


Sports - General;
Senegal Prepares To Host WBC Title Fight


BYLINE: Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - Sports officials here say preparations are in top gear for the Nov. 12 World Boxing Council (WBC) title fight between home boy, Jean- Baptiste Mendy and Steve Johnston of the United States.

Mendy, 33, decided to defend the WBC light-weight title he won in April 1996, in Dakar as a tribute to his home fans and supporters, the president of the Senegalese Boxing Federation, Mamadou Ndoye, told PANA.

The France-based boxer will trade punches over 13 rounds with Johnston, an African-America based in California, at the Demba Diop stadium in the Senegalese capital, Ndoye said in an interview. 

An estimated 45,000 spectators are expected to watch the fight, the third major world boxing bout to take place in Africa, added Jacques Diouf, vice- president of the local boxing and one of the promoters of the fight. Contracts for the bout which was previously scheduled to take place on Nov. 7, was signed at the beginning of September. Diouf said an investment of some 225 million f CFA (about 450,000 U.S. dollars) would go into event. Both boxers will share 400,000 dollars of prize money.

Mendy, a naturalized French citizen, defended the European light-weight category title nine times. He has 47 fights, winning 30 by knock-out and losing only five.

Johnston, 23, has won all 38 fights of his career, 20 of them through knock- out.

Organizers regard the fight as a mega event, comparable only to the Ali- Foreman heavyweight fight Tagged "the Rumble In the Jungle' in Kinshasa, Zaire in 1974. Another world boxing tournament took place later between Cote d'Ivoire's Elisa Obeth and American Sea Robinson in Abidjan.

Among dignitaries expected at the Dakar fight to be hosted under the high patronage of President Abdou Diouf, is WBC President, Jose Suleiman of Mexico and the President of the African Boxing Federation, Taib Houichi of Tunisia.

Mendy is offering 1,000 seats free of charge to folk from his native Casamance region of southern Senegal, to enable them watch the match, Diouf said.

He said apart from the economic "boom" and the exposure the event would give the country of seven million people, It would also provide an opportunity to relaunch Senegalese boxing mooted in 1993, when the ashes of its best known boxer, Louis Mbareck Fall, alias "battling Siki" was returned from the United States.

Fall was shot dead in New York December 1925, after he won a middle-weight title fight against an American challenger.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


483 of 490 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 30, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigerians Mark 36 Years Of Nationhood


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerians mark the 36th anniversary of their country's independence Tuesday, still grappling with the problem of how to evolve an enduring democracy after more than 25 years of military rule.

Africa's most populous nation of some 100 million people has had a checkered political history since gaining independence from Britain on Oct. 1, 1960.

According to political analysts in Lagos, one of the greatest problems has been the incessant military interventions in politics, characterized by coups and counter-coups. Civilians have governed the country for only 11 years. 

But neither the military regimes nor the civilian administrations have been spared by critics on allegations of corruption, mismanagement and ethnicity, considered the bane of governance in the country.

Speaking at an church service Sunday, as part of the anniversary events, an official of the Christian Association of Nigeria, said "many Nigerians wonder whether our independence has been a blessing or a curse."

Methodist Bishop Sunday Makinde noted that in the 36 years of independence " some of our fine, knowledgeable, astute and brilliant politicians have been killed, detained and humiliated out of office for political and economic recklessness."

Makinde's recipe is that Nigerian politicians should "dialogue with the military in the process to disengage them from politics if they don't want (Gen. Sani) Abacha's transition programme to be Babangidaised."

The clergy was referring to the eight-year transition to democracy programme of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, which ended in political chaos, forcing him to step aside on Aug. 26, 1993.

After postponing his hand-over several times, Babangida annulled Nigeria's June 12, 1993 presidential election, in a move that threw the country into one of its worst political crisis after the 30-month civil war that ended in January 1970.

Abacha, a key member of the Babangida regime, inherited the political turmoil that trailed the annulment, when he took over power on 17 Nov. 1993, from a lame-duck interim civilian administration installed by Babangida.

Through tough decisions, the bespectacled infantry general has managed to calm the restive political temperature in the multi-ethnic and culturally plural west African country.

On the contentious issues of human right and democracy, Abacha virtually took on the international community and the uncoordinated pockets of pro- democracy and opposition groups at home.

But with time, his no-nonsense approach has started to win him grudging support from even his most vociferous critics.

The April dethronement of Ibrahim Dasuki, the powerful 18th Sultan of Sokoto and the supreme head of Moslems in Nigeria, is often cited as one of such tough actions by the Abacha regime.

Dasuki, who was replaced by Muhammadu Maccido, was accused of financial impropriety and being disrespectful to the military government.

On the economic scene, Abacha has impressed many, especially with his failed banks and economic frauds decree, which has resulted in the imprisonment of a dozen bank chief executives convicted of corruption.

There are indications similar measures could be extended to poorly-managed government parastatals as part of the sanitation of governance.

According to economists, the regime has also achieved some success in budget discipline, resulting in relative stability of the exchange rate and reduction in the rate of inflation as part investor confidence-building measure.

The government recently launched another economic blueprint "vision 2010," designed to ensure "prosperity, political stability and socially harmonious society" within 14 years.

Regarding the political arena, after initial opposition from pro-democracy groups at home and abroad, the international community seems to be reading good meaning in the administration's three-year transition to democracy programme, planned to end on Oct. 1, 1998.

Although the British-led Commonwealth, which suspended Nigeria from its fold over the 1995 execution for murder of nine minority rights activists, including author Ken Saro-Wiwa, is still raising an issue over human rights situation in the country, the United Nations has given a qualified support to the transition programme.

In a report after its fact-finding mission visited Nigeria March 29 to April 12, the world body opposed imposition of sanctions on the country, and said that nothing should be done to upset the momentum of the transition programme.

The U.N. also called for political and judicial reforms, especially to improve Nigeria's human rights situation.

In his speech to mark the independence anniversary, Nigerians expect Abacha to address the issue of detainees such as Lagos lawyer Gani Fawehinmi, oil union official Frank Korori and civil liberties organisation representative Chima Ubani.

There is also the issue of politician Moshood Abiola, who claimed victory in the June 1993 presidential election annulled by Babangida. Abiola is facing trial for treason after he declared himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

On the transition programme, expectations are high that the anniversary speech could announce creation of at least six new states in Nigeria in addition to the existing 30.

Political parties that will vie for power in the upcoming republic are also expected to be known.

Informed sources indicate that at least four of the 14 political associations that applied for registration could make the pack.

Still on the bright side, one area in which Nigerians can beat their chest for glorious achievements since independence is sports, especially soccer.

Abacha's anniversary speech is expected to contain one or two lines of commendation for Nigeria's gold-winning under-23 soccer squad at the recent Centennial Olympics in Atlanta, United States.

By and large, analysts say, Abacha owes Nigerians a duty to engineer a successful transition that would guarantee peace and stability in the country.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 30, 1996


Zambia;
Ex-President Kaunda Jilted By Voters


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Kasama - Former President Kenneth Kaunda was on Sunday denied access to the tomb of the late Catholic Archbishop Elias Mutale at St. John's cathederal in Kasama.

Dr Kaunda, who is in the Northern Province to drum up support for himself and his one time ruling party, had wanted to use his time there to win sympathies from significant catholic believers.

As part of his campaign then the former President asked one time UNIP leader and long standing catholic Rankin Sikasula to accompany him to the cathedral for the main mass. 

Whilst there he decided to effect a 'coup de theatre' by requesting that he be allowed to visit the tomb of the late Archbishop Mutale.

But rector in charge of the cathedral, Father Chomba, deferred an answer suggesting that the request be put to the congregation instead.

When Father Chomba delivered it to the congregation it was unanimously rejected as being out of order.

The rejection was easy to understand because at the time that Archbishop Mutale died in a mysterious road accident in 1991 a finger had been pointed at the Kaunda regime which was believed at the time to have master minded the death of this catholic cleric who had been determinedly opposed to the one party rule of Kaunda.

The visit to the late Bishop's tomb, therefore, would have helped to raise his standing particularly in the eyes of young voters who at the time of the incident might not have understood what it was all about.

Meanwhile barely four days after declaring their intention to boycott the coming presidential and parliamentary elections UNIP president, Dr Kaunda has announced a u-turn from the position adopted at the 31st National Council meeting held in the midlands town of Kabwe.

Speaking to Zambia Information Service in Kasama on Saturday Dr kaunda said the party would not boycott the polls after all but that the party will continue to fight the 1996 constitution which bars him and his vice, Chief Inyambo Yeta, from contesting the coming polls.

He hinted, however, that the boycott may only be resorted to if government turned out to be unyielding on the question of the constitution, Nikuv compiled voters rolls and other issues which have remained unresolved betwee opposition parties and government.

Meanwhile a UNIP official maintained today that the party has many leaders who can take over the mantle from Dr Kaunda should he be barred from lodging his candidature for presidential elections.

UNIP secretary for Information and Publicity Bweendo Mulengela said in an interview: "UNIP has a surplus of leaders but we would prefer to dialogue and remove contentious clauses in the constitution which is discriminatory," he said.

He disclosed that the just ended national council in Kabwe, resolved to boycott the elections not because UNIP had no quality leaders but because they feel their elected leader was being victimised deliberately.

He boasted that his party has produced many leaders who were in both the ruling MMD and the opposition and was capable of finding a leader when Dr Kaunda's term ends but would remain united and royal to party guidelines.

"We cannot desert Dr Kaunda now because in UNIP we are united unlike other parties which run-away from their leaders when faced with problems," he said.

Mulengela would not say, however, why it had taken Dr Kaunda close to five years before he could renounce his Malawian citizenship.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Zambia;
Opposition Won't Boycott Polls


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)

Lusaka - UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda yesterday said his party will not boycott this year's elections. Former president Kaunda yesterday told the Zambia Information Service in Kasama where he is meeting chiefs in the area that UNIP will not boycott the elections but that his party is expecting government not to use the 1996

constitution or will make amendments to it.

At a press briefing on Wednesday UNIP publicity secretary Bwendo Mulengela said the party will only participate in the elections when contentious clauses are removed from the 1996

constitution and the decision is made to use the 1991 constitution.
